HEADLINE: No Handouts Without a Handover

BYLINE: By Mitch McConnell and Patrick Leahy; Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky, is chairman of the Senate appropriations subcommittee on foreign operations, and Patrick Leahy is the ranking Democrat.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
As global leaders move toward welcoming Serbia into the community of Western nations, the White House is considering the issue of aid to Belgrade's fledgling democratic government. The urgent question, as Congress heads toward adjournment, is whether to tie such aid to the prosecution of Serbia's war criminals.
Both the European Union and the United States have moved swiftly to reward the Serbian people for their ouster of Slobodan Milosevic by taking steps to recognize President Vojislav Kostunica and resume normal diplomatic relations with Belgrade. Steps have also been taken to lift the embargoes on oil and civilian flights and to meet urgent humanitarian needs in Yugoslavia. 
 The Serbian people -- exhausted by war, corruption, inflation and unemployment -- deserve such political and economic rewards. But further support, directly or through the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, should hinge on Belgrade's willingness to surrender war criminals harbored in Serbia to the International Tribunal at The Hague. Those indicted -- including Slobodan Milosevic, Ratko Mladic, Radovan Karadzic and Milan Milutinovic -- must be held accountable for the atrocities that scar lives and landscapes from Srebenica to Suva Reka.
The European Union and the Clinton administration are equivocating on whether further aid should be linked to Belgrade's surrendering these men to the tribunal. They are wrong to do so. The failure to hand over these suspected war criminals will decapitate the tribunal's efforts and set back the cause of international humanitarian law. The extradition of Mr. Milosevic and his cronies is also crucial to building trust in Serbia's neighboring governments.
Indeed, such trust is fundamental to stability in the region -- and the only sure basis for an exit strategy for American troops. Kosovars, Montenegrins, Albanians and Macedonians have ample reason to be concerned about the durability of any agreements with Belgrade as long as Mr. Milosevic lurks in the shadows.
Serbia must soon come to terms with these neighbors: Belgrade must end its support of those who have undermined the full integration of Bosnia Herzegovina. Mr. Kostunica's government must also assure regional leaders, especially in Kosovo, that it will respect the aspirations and political rights of minorities.
If Mr. Kostunica and his coalition partners advance on such a course and comply with the war crimes tribunal, the United States and Europe should be generous with aid to help rebuild Serbia's tattered economy. Serbia's membership in international and regional organizations should also be on the agenda.
History will be unkind and unforgiving in judging us if we fail to support the work of the war crimes tribunal at this critical time. The European Union, the Clinton administration and Congress should set a course that brings a democratic Serbia into Europe while affirming a collective commitment to international law and justice.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY;
I.B.M. Invests to Profit From Latest Chips

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
Last week, I.B.M. announced a plan to pour $2.5 billion into constructing a new microchip factory in East Fishkill, N.Y., the biggest investment in I.B.M.'s history. It then underscored its intent to be a superpower in semiconductors well into the 21st century by committing an additional $2.5 billion to modernize chip plants in Burlington, Vt., and overseas.
Despite the huge sums, I.B.M.'s risks seem remarkably modest. 
 The East Fishkill factory is not scheduled to be ready before 2003, putting I.B.M. up to a year behind rivals like Intel and NEC in the industry's transition to making chips on 12-inch silicon wafers instead of today's 8-inch wafers. The bigger format should bolster profitability by yielding hundreds more chips per wafer. But I.B.M. says it is content to lag behind a bit -- so that others bear the brunt of any kinks in new machinery being designed for handling the bigger sizes.
As for the rest of the modernizing, it is a drive to capitalize on a recent burst of I.B.M. design and manufacturing innovations before competitors catch up.
The innovations might seem obscure to those outside semiconductor circles -- techniques for replacing aluminum connectors with more efficient copper wire, novel insulating designs that allow processors to run faster while consuming less power and so forth. But the new wrinkles are cropping up in electronic devices from the largest mainframes to the slenderest cellular phones as well as communications routers, switches and countless other components that drive the growth of the Internet.
Louis V. Gerstner Jr., chairman and chief executive of I.B.M., said last week that demand for the kinds of chips I.B.M. makes for itself and other electronics companies was "white hot." With most of that demand stemming from the growth of the Internet and telecommunications, no end is in sight.
"We've strapped ourselves to a rocket," said John Kelly III, the senior vice president for the I.B.M. microelectronics unit. "The $5 billion is just to keep fueling it."
Chip making is a small piece of I.B.M.'s balance sheet. The company does not break out results for its microelectronics group, but analysts estimate it will contribute about $4.2 billion, or just under 5 percent, of I.B.M.'s projected revenues of around $90 billion this year. Thomas Kraemer, a Merrill Lynch analyst, estimates the unit is growing at a 30 percent clip and that profits are climbing almost as fast.
No wonder longtime I.B.M. watchers like Sam O. Albert, an information technology consultant in Scarsdale, N.Y., said the $5 billion plan "wasn't a tough call."
But the decision does reflect a tough call Mr. Gerstner made seven years ago, shortly after he arrived at I.B.M. to confront the task of turning around what was then a loss-ridden company. After studying the work in I.B.M.'s laboratories and the cost structure of its manufacturing, Mr. Gerstner decreed that I.B.M. would no longer make electronic components like disk drives and microchips solely for its own use.
That order freed executives in the components groups to produce as much as they could sell, even if some of those customers were outsiders who could use I.B.M. innovations to compete with other parts of I.B.M. To reinforce the mandate, Mr. Kelly moved researchers from the company's Yorktown Heights, N.Y., lab, as well as application developers from its chip plants, into a development center in East Fishkill with the assignment of rapidly pushing the most promising technology into production.
Since then, more than $1 billion has been invested in the development center, which currently employs 1,400 workers in East Fishkill and 300 more technicians at other I.B.M. sites; some 200 technical experts dispatched from various customers and partners are also working at the center.
The new strategy goaded the rest of I.B.M. to race ahead with products incorporating those components before I.B.M.'s competitors did.
"Putting it in the marketplace put pressure on the rest of the company to adapt new technology rapidly," said Stephen C. Dube, an analyst who follows I.B.M. for Wasserstein Perella Securities.
For much of the last decade, the strategy's perils were more prominent than its payoffs. I.B.M.'s microelectronics group invested heavily in joint ventures to design new memory chips and expand its dynamic random access -- or D-RAM -- memory chip production, then paid dearly for it when the market for such commodity chips crashed in 1996. Unwinding that mistake has taken years. The last step was I.B.M.'s pending sale of its share of a memory chip plant in Manassas, Va., to Toshiba, its partner.
Nor has Mr. Gerstner's open-door strategy always helped I.B.M.'s product groups. The EMC Corporation, for instance, is using I.B.M.-made disk drives to battle I.B.M. for the data storage market. And I.B.M.'s agreement to sell Dell Computer $16 billion of components over seven years is strengthening one of the toughest competitors of I.B.M.'s struggling PC group.
Mr. Kelly said, "1999 was a key year. That's when outside customers stopped asking me whether I.B.M. would get preferential treatment."
I.B.M. says that its hardware units are generally making better use of its chip innovations than any rivals are. The latest example, scheduled to be announced today, is a new line of large I.B.M. servers with a base price of $420,000 that run the Unix operating system.
I.B.M. said the new computers used copper circuitry and chips with an innovative I.B.M. insulation design that allows transistors to work more quickly. It said its tests showed that the new server, using just 24 processors, performed transactions 40 percent faster than the more expensive "flagship" computer with 64 processors from Sun Microsystems, the Unix market leader.
Such developments signal how the microelectronics unit hopes it can help I.B.M. far beyond the sales and profit it generates directly. But the unit's success is measured by more specific benchmarks, like whether the development center churns out enough leading-edge technology that the royalties, licensing and outside joint development contributions more than cover the center's costs.
"The second guy pays the first guy," said Bijan Divari, vice president for technology and emerging products at the microelectronics unit. "If you're not first, the whole thing unravels."
Lately, I.B.M. has been first or nearly so with an impressive number of microchip developments. The hit parade began in 1997 with I.B.M.'s announcement that it devised an economical method of laying copper circuits on microchips, a much more efficient conductor than aluminum. So far, I.B.M. is the only microchip maker mass-producing such chips, though Motorola and some others are striving to catch up.
In 1998, in a similar breakthrough, I.B.M. said it had overcome the longstanding challenge of efficiently laying a very thin layer of silicon under the transistors on chips and insulating them from the thick substrate below. The technology, known as S.O.I. for silicon on insulator, bolsters chip performance up to 35 percent by allowing chips to handle power much more efficiently.
I.B.M. also figured out how to use a soft insulating polymer from Dow Chemical to cram copper circuits more closely together, allowing chip designers to increase processor speed and reliability. Another series of innovations gave I.B.M. the technology lead in handling silicon germanium, a material especially suited for making the kind of compact, high-performance chips for handling radio signals used in cell phones and other wireless communications devices.
But I.B.M.'s real advantage, according to analysts like Trevor Yancey at IC Insights in Scottsdale, Ariz., is coming from aggressively integrating so many of the new technologies. If things pan out as I.B.M. plans, that process will reach a new pinnacle at the new factory in East Fishkill.

Chart: "Minute Differences"
I.B.M. will manufacture computer chips in its new factory planned for East Fishkill, N.Y., which will incorporate numerous advances in chip design within the same chip. Here are the main components of a microprocessor and two major developments that the plant's chips will feature.
 
Diagram shows computer chip magnified 30,000 times and sliced into a cross section.
 
1. COPPER WIRING -- Provides a better electrical conductor than the aluminum now widely used. I.B.M. developed a practical method for making chips with copper.
 
2. SILICON OXIDE INSULATOR -- Makes it possible for chips to operate faster while using less power by keeping electrical current from leaking downward.
 
SILICON WAFER -- The substrate, or structure, that the chip is built on.
 
SILICON -- A thin layer of silicon in which the current flows when allowed to by the transistor.
 
TRANSISTORS -- Essentially on-off switches for the current, millions of which are on a typical chip.
(Source: I.B.M.)

HEADLINE: MEDIA;
Soldier of Fortune Toughs Out Changing Times

BYLINE: By JIM MOSCOU 

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Oct. 15

 BODY:
Robert K. Brown, a retired Army colonel, snatches a ringing phone while sitting amid strewn manuscripts, laundry, defused ordnance, plaques, pictures and a mock human brain in a clear bucket of bubbling water.
"Maximus!" he snaps. 
 He is fielding a barrage of telephone assaults in his Boulder, Colo., office on a busy Saturday morning. The founder, editor and publisher of Soldier of Fortune magazine is not a patient man.
Slam. The receiver goes down and Maximus -- Mr. Brown's self-assigned nickname, a reference to the Russell Crowe character in "Gladiator" who cheats death only to rise again and fight the Roman establishment -- spits a round of tobacco juice into an aging coffee mug.
He is brash, cantankerous, egotistical, intelligent and always in your face. He never sees gray on an issue.
This week, Mr. Brown celebrated his magazine's 25th anniversary at its annual Las Vegas convention. That makes him a survivor. But the convention drew only 250 people, half the number it did in the early 1980's. It was further confirmation that though the world's first and only supermarket tabloid for mercenaries, mercenary-wannabes and anyone fascinated by combat and conflict remains one of the most identifiable military brands around, it no longer carries the impact it once did.
Time and the world have caught up to the 67-year-old Mr. Brown. At the heart of his success was the magazine's unusual, but popular, editorial mission: Soldier of Fortune's foreign correspondents often do not simply report from trouble spots, they join the fight. And the magazine has consistently been one of the greatest media advocates for disgruntled Vietnam veterans. It was anger over their treatment that led Mr. Brown to start the magazine in 1975 after returning from two tours of duty.
But times have changed. "Now, the cold war is over," he said. "You don't have the interest in those countries. And, the Vietnam veteran is older, more mellow. He's gotten a certain amount of acceptance and the recognition that he didn't have 25 years ago."
The changes have left the magazine searching for its editorial place in face of a new world order and declining profits. While a steady base of 20,000 subscribers "keeps the engines running," Mr. Brown said (the magazine's circulation is not independently audited), he acknowledges, and others at Soldier of Fortune confirm, his newsstand sales have plummeted the last 10 years to around 40,000 in a good month, far from its high of 150,000 during the cold war.
"Soldier of Fortune has become an oxymoron," said Samir Husni, a professor of media studies at the University of Mississippi, who follows the magazine industry. "There was once a fortune to be made in being a soldier. There is no place where those folks can go and fight the good fight and make some money."
Dan Goure, deputy director of the International Security Program at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, a public policy research institution, said modern trends were not in the magazine's favor. A politically muddled world, job-producing economies, a fading romance with Rambo and a generation of young adults who were never drafted and never trained in war have inevitably whittled away Soldier of Fortune's market.
"Today, America's image of war is an F-16 at 20,000 feet dropping a precision bomb," Mr. Goure said. "High-tech conflicts and Soldier of Fortune are just incompatible."
But people who follow the magazine say Soldier of Fortune is likely to survive. Mr. Brown has already shifted its tone in light of bottom-line realities. Traditionally, the magazine practiced a particularly bloody form of "participatory journalism." When he had the cash, Mr. Brown dispatched not just a reporter but small mercenary "teams" to deliver supplies, train, write and fight. In 1981, Mr. Brown and the magazine spent $350,000 in a failed search for prisoners of war in Vietnam. In 1992, he sent fighters and writers to support Croatian forces.
But those efforts came when "we had the luxury of money," Mr. Brown said. With revenue shrinking -- Soldier of Fortune grossed about $2 million last year, down from $7 million in the early 1980's, he said -- the magazine's teams are grounded. Its emphasis has often shifted to domestic, less expensive, somewhat wonkier topics, like opposition to gun control; columns like the "Slick Willie Watch"; open-seas piracy; and warnings of Vietnam-like quagmires ("Colombia Burning: The Dark Future of Narco-Wars").
"Instead of shooting from the hip, they are shooting from the brain," Mr. Husni said.
Mr. Brown has also hedged his financial woes by licensing Soldier of Fortune's identity -- first to Hollywood in 1995 for a one-hour television action drama and earlier this year to Activision, which developed a Soldier of Fortune computer game. The series was canceled, but the game has grossed more than $5 million, according to PC Data, a market research firm.
Still, the magazine will have trouble shaking its reputation. "If you want to go find the mercenary to kill someone for you, you pick up a copy of Soldier of Fortune," Mr. Husni said. And that might be unfair: the magazine changed its policy regarding mercenary ads 15 years ago.
In 1993, the magazine and the Omega Group, its corporate entity, were held negligently liable after an assassin hired through a classified ad in Soldier of Fortune murdered a Georgia man in 1985. Mr. Brown lost a $4.3 million judgment. He settled the case for $200,000, and Soldier of Fortune has not run a similar classified ad since the murder.
Through it all, Mr. Brown says, he has been waiting patiently for the next big war or conflict to lift sales. In the meantime, back in his office, Mr. Brown's thoughts are on Sierra Leone and a September feature story in which his reporter (a South African mercenary) mans a machine gun on a Russian Mi-24 attack helicopter for the government. Sierra Leone is battling a notoriously brutal rebel group, the Revolutionary United Front, which killed one of the magazine's reporters in 1995. Like an old coach reminiscing of his playing days, he ponders his comeback.
"I still may go to Sierra Leone," he said.
To help fight or do a story?
"Both," he said. "I'm not going to bring a team. I'm just thinking of doing my memoirs and I can see that as an opener: The last hurrah! I'm too old to bust through the bush with a 60-pound pack, but I sure as hell can operate a machine gun out of an Mi-24. And nothing would give me more pleasure than some pay back for my guy."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Chevron to Acquire Texaco In a $36 Billion Stock Deal
Chevron, the nation's third-largest oil company, has agreed to buy Texaco for $36 billion in stock, creating the world's fourth-largest oil concern. The company's boards approved the deal, which is expected to be announced today.
The acquisition is likely to come under intense scrutiny by regulators, who could force the combined company to divest itself of certain assets, especially in states like California where the company would dominate the retail gas station business. Page A1. 

Judge Allows EBay Suit to Continue
A California judge has allowed six people to proceed with a lawsuit that strikes at the core of how eBay runs its business. The lawsuit, filed by people who say they bought autographed sports memorabilia later found to be fake, contends that eBay has a responsibility to ensure the authenticity of the sports memorabilia sold on its site. EBay counters that it merely operates a venue for sales and cannot be held liable for fraudulent goods. C6.
 
New Mission for Soldier of Fortune
The end of the cold war has left Soldier of Fortune magazine searching for its editorial place in the face of a new world order and declining profits. A steady base of 20,000 subscribers "keeps the engines running," says Robert K. Brown, its editor, but newsstand sales have plummeted over the last 10 years to about 40,000 in a good month, far from its high of 150,000 during the cold war. C16.
 
Exchange-Traded Security Planned
Epoch Partners, an investment bank in San Francisco, wants to create exchange-traded baskets of stocks for sale to customers of Charles Schwab and the Ameritrade online brokerage firm. The baskets would be called New Era Trust Securities, or Nets. C8.
 
Bringing E-Commerce Into the Fold
For large companies made up of disparate business units, the most difficult task often is creating a structure that can weave e-commerce through the various divisions smoothly. Two of the more popular approaches are either to appoint an e-business czar with the authority and budget to foist change on the entire organization or to create a team of e-business evangelists who can spread the Internet religion one corporate division at a time. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. C14.
 
Apple Faces Future With Part of Past
At the heart of the new Apple Macintosh OS X operating system, expected to reach the market early next year, is Steven Jobs's 11-year-old Nextstep operating system. The fact that Mac users will be asked to move into the future by stepping into the past underscores the largest difficulty for Mr. Jobs since he returned to run Apple in 1997. A crucial question for Apple is whether it can successfully move its millions of customers from their current software systems to its yet-to-be-finished operating system. New Economy. C5.
 
Checking That Bow Tie for a Camera
The Plus Guard, a hand-held gadget the size of a makeup compact, lets users scan their surroundings for hidden audio bugs or wireless cameras that may be capturing sounds or pictures. When such a surveillance device is in the area, a red light goes on and an alarm on the device sounds. In the two months since the device has been distributed in the United States, 100 of the gadgets have been sold. But so far, there have been no reports of customers' uncovering hidden cameras or bugs. C5.
 
I.B.M. Invests to Profit From Chips
Underscoring its intent to be a superpower in semiconductors well into the 21st century, I.B.M. is spending $2.5 billion on a new microchip factory in East Fishkill, N.Y., and another $2.5 billion to modernize chip plants in Burlington, Vt., and overseas. C5.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
A Writer Wildly Tearing Up His Life to Feed His Art

BYLINE: By JAMES SHAPIRO; James Shapiro is a professor of English at Columbia University.

 BODY:

BELLOW
A Biography
By James Atlas
Illustrated. 686 pages. Random House. $35.
"I write from about 8 o'clock in the morning until 1," Saul Bellow once told an interviewer. "Then I go out and make my mistakes." As James Atlas makes clear in this exhaustively researched biography, Mr. Bellow's literary output and his mistakes have been equally prodigious. 
 He has produced one of the most remarkable bodies of work by an American novelist: most notably "Dangling Man" (1944), "The Adventures of Augie March" (1953), "Seize the Day" (1956), "Henderson the Rain King" (1959), "Herzog" (1964) and "Humboldt's Gift" (1975). He has also racked up most major literary awards, including a Pulitzer Prize, three National Book Awards and in 1976 the Nobel Prize in Literature.
Viewed in retrospect Mr. Bellow's long reign near the top of the American literary scene seems inevitable, almost preordained. Yet Mr. Atlas shows that it was anything but. He offers us glimpses of Mr. Bellow, unemployed and unpublished, writing at his mother-in-law's house while his young wife went off to work. At 25 he had yet to sell a story.
Fifteen years later, though a National Book Award winner, Mr. Bellow was disappointed that his fourth novel, the much admired "Seize the Day," had barely sold 5,000 copies, and was still accepting money from a father who was contemptuous of his literary aspirations. Mr. Bellow himself, Mr. Atlas shows, was never in doubt about his talent.
Because each of his novels reaches deeply into his past, offering "a bulletin on his own condition" invariably distorted by nostalgia and spite, Mr. Bellow has long had misgivings about anyone's relying on his fiction to get an accurate fix on his life. "Biography," he warned, "is a specter viewed by a specter."
"Bellow" isn't an authorized biography, but, as Mr. Atlas tells us, Mr. Bellow didn't refuse him, as he has refused others, permission to quote freely from letters, manuscripts and unpublished work. Mr. Bellow, who turned 85 last summer, was eventually won over by Mr. Atlas's dogged persistence. When Mr. Atlas asked Mr. Bellow's son Dan, "Why did he let me do it?," Dan explained, "He realized that you weren't going to go away."
For Mr. Atlas the central dynamic in Mr. Bellow's career has been his tendency "to tear up his life to feed his art": it "was as if he needed some obstacle, some impediment, to define himself against." Mr. Atlas's primary interest, then, is less Mr. Bellow's ideas or philosophy (which leave him cold) than the stormy marriages and literary friendships that became fodder for his fiction. Much of this hefty biography is taken up with the fallout of Mr. Bellow's failed marriages. (He is now with a fifth wife, 44 years his junior, with whom he had a daughter last year.)
Like the women in Mr. Bellow's novels, Mr. Atlas argues, the "women in his life remained for him secondary figures who served his own fantasies of them as providers, entrappers, sexual predators." For Mr. Atlas, Mr. Bellow's philandering and sexism were "still well within the normal range of male chauvinism for his day"; he is more persuasive in tracing Mr. Bellow's trouble with women back to the central trauma of his life: the death of his mother when he was a teenager, a loss Mr. Bellow never properly mourned. The men in his life haven't fared much better: Mr. Bellow regularly missed the funerals of close friends, reviled his enemies and never forgave a negative reviewer. "Bellow wasn't a nurturing person," Mr. Atlas suggests, because "he wanted the nurturing."
Weaving together the artistic triumphs and personal crises, Mr. Atlas captures the enormous excitement that greeted each of Mr. Bellow's groundbreaking novels of the 1950's and early 60's. He also shows how challenges to the establishment in the 1960's and early 70's upended Mr. Bellow's familiar role as outsider and victim. Where Mr. Bellow, the youngest son of poor Jewish immigrants, had long struggled to gain a foothold within "the WASP literary establishment," he now found himself defending the high culture that had finally embraced him and was now under siege.
As Mr. Bellow grew older, Mr. Atlas writes, "the bones of a deeply conservative, xenophobic vision of life emerged more clearly." The low point was Mr. Bellow's unfortunate remark: "Who is the Tolstoy of the Zulus? The Proust of the Papuans? I'd be glad to read him."
Because Mr. Atlas's approach depends on discovering chunks of Mr. Bellow's life in his art, he tends to underestimate the extent to which Mr. Bellow has utterly transformed events from his life in his fiction, even when surface similarities teasingly remain. Mr. Bellow himself has chastised Mr. Atlas for "confusing fact with fiction."
In practice this means that Mr. Atlas can confidently declare that a character's first sight of his wife in "Herzog" "faithfully reproduces" Mr. Bellow's own experience, and he can insist, over Mr. Bellow's objections, that "Humboldt's Gift" is really a portrait of Delmore Schwartz (the subject of Mr. Atlas's previous biography) and then accuse Mr. Bellow of failing to get Schwartz right.
At the heart of this book is an unanswered question: Do the many unsettling facts Mr. Atlas unearths about Mr. Bellow's personal life devalue the novels, which he sees as emerging directly from Mr. Bellow's experiences? Or, alternatively, does Mr. Bellow's art somehow transcend the life, in which case why bother writing (or reading) literary biography? It is hard to understand why Mr. Atlas would spend more than a decade amassing the facts of Mr. Bellow's life and then sidestep the question of how they affect how he -- and by extension we -- now judge the novels and Mr. Bellow's place in the pantheon of American writers. It is the only serious flaw in a biography unlikely to be surpassed for some time.
The most melancholy page in "Bellow" appears in the acknowledgments, where Mr. Atlas lists those who have helped him who have since died, including Ralph Ellison, Leon Edel, Irving Howe, Saul Steinberg and Diana and Lionel Trilling. The list underscores the extent to which Mr. Atlas's "Bellow" is not only a compelling story of a great and flawed writer, one who continues to demand our attention, but also a portrait of an extraordinary (and now rapidly receding) epoch in the history of American letters.

HEADLINE: Stunts and Thrills at Daybreak;
Competitive Hysteria Drives the Morning News Programs

BYLINE: By JIM RUTENBERG 

 BODY:
Dakota, a dog, was mad as hell and wasn't going to take it anymore.
It was hard enough to tolerate all the morning news-show producers crowding into his Silicon Valley town house at 2:30 a.m., maneuvering to get the first interview with his owner. Dakota was big news: just a few days earlier, he had been saved from a dangerously cold airplane cargo hold. 
 But the 10-year-old Basenji really lost it when CBS producers became angry at being bumped to last in the interview line and descended on Mike Bell, the dog's owner, during a live CNN appearance, taking off his microphone and cutting the interview short.
"The dog starts growling," Mr. Bell said. "He freaks out the guy who does the sound, who falls back into my refrigerator and my dog attacks him and tries to bite him. I just couldn't believe how cutthroat the morning news was."
But, he recalled: "The calmest people there were with NBC. They were just sitting back and enjoying it."
The story sums up the state of the morning news shows. Despite massive assaults by CBS and ABC the last two years, NBC's "Today" still stands confidently at the top of the heap. In the meantime, rest assured, America: while you sleep, network producers are conniving hard to serve up your first jolt of information and perky chat each morning.
In fact, the competition behind the scenes is the fiercest in morning-show history, longtime producers say. Accusations and counteraccusations are flying -- about stolen guests, outright sabotage and petty thievery. In essence, it's similar to the great old newspaper movies like "The Front Page."
"There's an air of hysteria," said Steve Friedman, executive producer of the CBS "Early Show," who previously ran "Today." "I've never seen this before, and I've been doing this a long time."
This is a profit-driven hysteria. The morning is the only time when the audience for network news is actually growing. The three morning programs pulled in nearly $400 million in revenue just through July -- nearly $100 million more than the three major evening network newscasts, according to estimates by Nielsen Monitor-Plus. What's more, though there is a difference of less than $20 million in revenue between NBC's first place "Nightly News" and CBS's third-place "Evening News," there was a difference of nearly $150 million in revenue between the first-place "Today" and the third-place "Early Show." And, by the end of July, "Today" had taken in nearly $80 million more than its closest competitor, "Good Morning America," according to Nielsen.
The main reason given for the growth in audience is the strong economy. More people are up and about before 9 a.m. because more people are working. Whatever the reason, with so much at stake, the networks are plowing more resources than ever into the shows. In fact, NBC extended the length of its show this month from two hours to three, taking on ABC's vaunted "Live with Regis."
The entrance of CBS's "Early Show" -- a year ago Nov. 1 -- and changes to ABC's "Good Morning America" clearly raised the intensity of the fighting. "Early Show's" Bryant Gumbel, Jane Clayson and their $30 million new glass studio off Central Park added a whole new team of competitors. Things had already begun heating up the previous January, when ABC brought in Diane Sawyer and Charles Gibson to be co-hosts of a sagging "Good Morning America."
But neither show has cut much into Katie Couric and Matt Lauer's very significant lead on "Today." Though "Early Show" has gained on "Good Morning America" among young women, it is doing only as well as the third-place show it replaced, "CBS This Morning," in the overall ratings. And though Ms. Sawyer and Mr. Gibson have raised the profile and ratings of "Good Morning America," its audience still falls as much as two million viewers below that of "Today," which stands at six million. Last week, the audience of "Today" was the equivalent of those of its competitors combined.
Even his competitors give Jeff Zucker, the executive producer of "Today," credit for keeping the NBC show fresh. But, to some degree, the continued success is based on simple inertia: groggy morning viewers are a notoriously intransigent lot. It is difficult to lure them from a program they have come to watch as they throw on their clothes, brush their teeth and prepare children for school.
And there is only so much the programs can do to lure viewers from the enemy. The morning format is believed to be rigid by necessity, leaving little room for ingenuity. The prevailing wisdom is that in the first half hour of the shows, which begin at 7 a.m., most viewers are heading to work and want hard news and traffic and weather information. As time ticks by, the stay-at-home crowd becomes dominant and so the shows gradually switch to softer segments about health, cooking, dieting and preening.
But just because segments are softer, does not mean the competition is any less fierce.
The programs, for example, duel over bookings for their Friday outdoor concert series. On a Friday morning in June, Dionne Warwick was singing to an audience of hundreds in Manhattan's Bryant Park for "Good Morning America." A few blocks away, at Rockefeller Center, Sting sang to an audience of thousands for "Today."
In the middle of a song, Ms. Warwick was drowned out by a "Today" show helicopter, which hovered low overhead panning the crowd and Ms. Couric said, "We're looking at Bryant Park, where I understand some kind of concert is going on."
Mr. Zucker said he had sent the helicopter in the spirit of fun.
But Shelley Ross, the "Good Morning America" executive producer, called the stunt "shameful." She also accused "Today" of sending interns to the Bryant Park concert to persuade people to leave and see Sting, an accusation Mr. Zucker denies.
Another way to draw viewers, of course, is the old-fashioned way: landing exclusives, at which "Today" has a distinct advantage. Because of its large audience, "Today" is often the first stop on the media publicity train for celebrities and news makers. When it comes to morning bookings, "You start with 'Today,' period," said one prominent entertainment publicist.
Mr. Zucker said that sentiment allowed him to avoid much of the sniping in which his competitors must engage.
"By and large, we've tried to stay out of that fray," he said.
His competitors beg to differ.
Ms. Ross has charged Mr. Zucker with spitefully holding guests who are making the rounds of all the shows for too long, throwing off her schedule. A "Today" representative said the program would never intentionally hold a guest to hurt a competitor.
Ms. Ross, however, is in no way considered an angel. In fact, her competitors say she is a key ingredient in the morning war flambe.
Ms. Ross came to "Good Morning America" with a reputation as a tough and aggressive producer. She cut her teeth as a young woman at The Miami Herald and The National Enquirer, where she was a reporter and editor. Later, she led ABC's news magazine coverage of the O. J. Simpson case.
In February, "Today" accused Ms. Ross of throwing off its schedule by keeping Darva Conger, the bride in the Fox show, "Who Wants to Marry a Multimillionaire?" in its studio too long for her to make an appearance on NBC.
"Good Morning America" further rankled "Today" last month when it publicly ribbed it for showing taped programs during its first week in Sydney, Australia, where it was based for the Olympics. Australia is 15 hours ahead of New York and the "Today" producers wanted to show Mr. Lauer and Ms. Couric in daylight.
During live reports from Sydney, "Good Morning America" flashed messages on the screen like "Really Live" and "Hey, it's really dark now!"
Citing that example, Mr. Friedman, a morning producer for 21 years, said he blamed "Good Morning America" in general, and Ms. Ross in particular, for causing an unprecedented level of distrust between the programs.
"It's a mean-spirited show," he said, echoing words Ms. Ross has used to describe "Today." "They are worse than I've ever seen. When these people tell you something, you check your wallet."
Mr. Friedman is no wallflower (he sometimes carries a Louisville slugger to meetings). But he pointed to the case last month of a Pittsburgh skydiving student who was caught on a plane's landing gear during a jump. He dangled for more than 40 minutes before the plane was safely landed.
"Early Show" producers jumped on the story and paid for the pilot, the student and the man who owned the skydiving school to fly to New York. They were put up in the Plaza Hotel the day before their appearance.
ABC producers found out they were staying at the Plaza and asked them to come to tape an interview for their morning show.
"I said it didn't feel right to me morally for me to do that," said Don Bick, who owns the skydiving school.
Mr. Bick said he relented after "Good Morning America" agreed to pay for another night in the city, and promised, in writing, not to show its taped interview until after the live interview with the "Early Show" was complete.
In the written promise, "Good Morning America" said it would tape the interview "with the full intention" of showing it after the live one was shown on CBS. The guests were driven to the "Good Morning America" studios and interviewed around midnight.
The next morning, Mr. Friedman said, he nearly exploded when he noticed on a control room monitor that "Good Morning America" had begun showing its taped segment about the skydiver as his program's live interview was still taking place.
Mr. Bick said, "I felt like somebody's whore at that point."
Ms. Ross said the men had participated in her program happily. And she said: "We really did honor the spirit of the commitment that we made to them. We had an agreement that CBS would go first and they went first."
She also said the taped interview was not seen until 45 seconds into her skydiving segment, leaving only about 40 seconds of actual interview overlap.
Ms. Ross denied she is mean-spirited.
"There is nothing mean-spirited; This is about journalism," she said. "I think that we operate within the time-honored journalism traditions of competition."
She added, "I think competition is healthy."

HEADLINE: In a Democratic Europe, Belarus Stays Authoritarian

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Oct. 15

 BODY:
If Europe's only remaining strongman of any note was shaken by the specter of Slobodan Milosevic's sudden fall from power in Yugoslavia, he showed no signs of it at the polls in his own country today.
Aleksandr Lukashenko, the autocratic president of Belarus, all but mocked his critics as he cast his vote this morning in a parliamentary election that the United States and other Western nations have called meaningless and that he insisted mirrors the will of his subjects. 
 "Now let us see the reaction by Western observers, and what kind of motivation they will have not to recognize the outcome of the election," he said on state television. "Over 70 percent of voters will turn up at polling places, and this will be our victory."
And in fact, there was no doubt that Mr. Lukashenko's backers would sweep the contest for 110 seats in the Belarussian Parliament, even though preliminary results were not expected before Monday.
Belarus's small democratic opposition, some of whose members sat in the Parliament before Mr. Lukashenko packed it in a 1996 constitutional referendum that outsiders say was rigged, has boycotted the election as a sham.
Even if opponents had not staged a boycott, it is doubtful whether they would have mustered much at the polls. Despite a stagnant economy and a growing reputation as Eastern Europe's backwater, Belarus has remained mostly loyal to Mr. Lukashenko and his charismatic, vaguely Soviet style of rule.
Opinion surveys indicated that only about 1 in 10 voters favored any sort of boycott of the elections.
In the opposition daily Narodnaya Volya, Anatoly Lebedko, a leading opposition figure, sarcastically challenged voters to shed apathy. "If you feel no need for change -- if you want Belarus to remain an enclave of lawlessness and poverty at the center of a fast-developing Europe -- then you are free to give your vote to those in power," wrote Mr. Lebedko, who heads the United Civic Party.
Opponents staged rallies this weekend in a score of cities, but an anti-Lukashenko protest in downtown Minsk on Saturday drew only about 3,000 marchers, far below the turnout organizers had hoped for. Mr. Lukashenko called the protesters "a bunch of windbags" and said that "the people will not let them get anywhere near power."
He said earlier this week that his government had taken all steps necessary to make the elections conform to the highest European standards of fairness. But the Minsk government has a history of suppressing dissent, including beatings of dissidents. In the last year, two prominent democratic activists have disappeared.
Among more recent measures, the police are enforcing an administrative rule that prohibits protesters from advocating an election boycott. Anti-Lukashenko activists said this week that more than 100 persons had been detained for violating it.
On Thursday, the Minsk correspondent for the English-language newspaper Moscow News was beaten in the stairwell of his apartment house, suffering a concussion. Newspaper officials said they believe that his critical reporting on Mr. Lukashenko was a factor in the attack.
The European Union sent a small delegation to observe the voting, but stressed beforehand that the presence of the group should not be interpreted as blessing the results.

HEADLINE: Behind the Scenes, a Budget Expert Distills Details

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15

 BODY:
In the wee hours every weeknight, Alan Cohen sits hunched over his computer in his cluttered third-floor Treasury Department office, tapping out what many in his trade consider to be the daily bible of the budget wars in Washington.
Mr. Cohen is a revered if slightly eccentric budget analyst extraordinaire who works for Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers. 
 Overnight, he puts out a snappy summary of the day's budget highlights that is a must-read for senior Treasury officials before their 8:30 a.m. senior staff meeting at the White House.
With administration and Congressional negotiators hoping to put the finishing touches on budget and tax deals later this week, this is Mr. Cohen's season to shine. As a consummate senior aide toiling in the trenches -- and every Cabinet secretary has at least one -- Mr. Cohen arms his bosses with the facts, figures and inside information they need to wage the bureaucratic battles of the day.
"He's one of the real insightful guys behind the scenes," Mr. Summers said. "And because he is insightful, he's influential."
Mr. Cohen's summary, usually two to four pages long and prosaically titled "Today's Update," typically contains a pithy status of spending bills, remarks from top officials and Mr. Cohen's succinct analysis of arcane budget issues and processes that he has mastered over two decades in government.
He has been writing them since early last year.
Mr. Cohen said he collected items for his summary throughout the day, poring over several publications and the Internet, and then filling in gaps with phone calls to budget sources around town. "It's a combination of policy, process and the political world," he said.
Treasury officials say they rely on Mr. Cohen to interpret everything from the latest Congressional Budget Office surplus estimates to a new proposal for Social Security to political infighting among key members of the Senate and House Appropriations committees.
Mr. Cohen sends his summary by electronic mail to about 30 top Treasury officials (except Mr. Summers, who has his report faxed to his home), but bootleg printouts enjoy a surprising circulation inside the department.
There's nothing confidential in his memos (Mr. Cohen sends his most sensitive remarks in a separate eyes-only memo to Mr. Summers or Deputy Secretary Stuart E. Eizenstat). Nonetheless, Mr. Cohen expressed disappointment that an outsider had learned of their existence, and agreed to let a reporter view a few recent copies only on the condition that their contents would not be published.
For this reason it's no wonder that Mr. Cohen is virtually anonymous outside the budget cognoscenti in the administration and on Capitol Hill.
"Alan is a budget genius," said Robert E. Rubin, the former treasury secretary, who recalled at least one time when Mr. Cohen bailed him out of a tricky budget problem hours before he had to testify before Congress.
Rubbing shoulders with cabinet secretaries aside, Mr. Cohen, a heavyset, bespectacled, 50-year-old bachelor, is hardly your typical civil servant.
His marathon work hours are legendary. "Because I'm often up late, I'm often the receiver of a midnight call from Alan Cohen, who's realized a major flaw in a Republican budget document or a major procedural move that we'd missed at an earlier meeting," said Gene Sperling, the White House's economic policy director.
Legendary, too, is Mr. Cohen's office, which colleagues say is stacked with mountains of papers, books and other detritus of a self-proclaimed "budget wonk" who hates to throw anything away. (Mr. Cohen refused to show a visitor his office, just down the hall from Mr. Summers's suite, saying he was "too embarrassed. It's a total mess.")
Born and raised in Manhattan, Mr. Cohen earned a bachelor's degree in physics from Grinnell College in Iowa, followed soon after by a master's degree in public policy from the University of Michigan and a doctorate in economics from the University of Wisconsin.
He spent four years at the Health and Human Services Department working on anti-poverty programs before moving in 1983 to Capitol Hill, where he was a staffer for nine years on the Senate Budget and Finance committees.
When President Clinton tapped Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, the Finance Committee chairman, to be treasury secretary in 1993, Mr. Bentsen brought Mr. Cohen with him.
Now serving his third secretary, Mr. Cohen said his insider's job has given him the perfect perch from which to negotiate official Washington: "One thing I've learned here is that it's hard to be successful in the policy world unless you understand and work in the political dimension."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE WISCONSIN ELECTORATE;
An Enclave of Undecideds Stays a Campaign Battleground in a Swing State

SERIES: BATTLEGROUNDS/Wisconsin

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: APPLETON, Wis., Oct. 14

 BODY:
The leaves have turned cranberry red and mustard yellow in the Fox River Valley, and people are obsessing as usual about the Packers, the community-owned football team up in Green Bay.
But something new has been added to the usual seasonal mix: Appleton, a pleasant city of 85,000 at the northern end of Lake Winnebago, finds itself squarely in the cross-hairs of the 2000 presidential campaign. This is the swing region in one of the handful of swing states in the neck-and-neck battle between Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush of Texas. 
 The region in eastern Wisconsin is rich in undecided voters. The candidates know it. They apparently think that women hold the key to the valley vote and that women care most about education. Mr. Bush came to Appleton on Oct. 5 for an event at McKinley Elementary, a public school with a charter school on the second floor; he favors charter schools, which are independently run institutions paid for with public funds. Tipper Gore, the vice president's wife, is due here on Monday for a visit to an all-public school.
And when the candidates and their surrogates are off campaigning somewhere else, there are endless commercials on Green Bay television stations to ensure that Appleton does not forget the campaign and its role. Mr. Gore alone ran 2,322 spots in this region between June 1 and September 30, and one of Mr. Bush's education commercials appears several dozen times every week.
"It goes on and on," said Donald Koteki, who runs the survey center at St. Norbert College in Green Bay. "It's nonstop. We had a furious campaign about whether to renovate Lambeau Field, where the Packers play, and just as that was ending, the presidential stuff started. People here are numb."
Numb they may be, but they, like other people in Wisconsin, are expected to vote heavily next month. New registrations are up, and crowds -- like the throng of 6,000 to 8,000 that turned out for Mr. Gore in Milwaukee on Thursday -- are full of enthusiasm.
The state still seems there for the taking. Jeff Mayers, a veteran political reporter in Madison, Wisconsin's capital, said the last month had "seen a lot of action but not much change." The most recent statewide public poll, showing Mr. Gore up by five percentage points, was completed for The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel on Sept. 20 -- more than three weeks ago, and well before the two presidential debates and the recent intensification of violence in the Middle East.
"We haven't gone up, they haven't gone up, we haven't gone down, they haven't gone down," said Teresa Vilmain, Mr. Gore's manager in the state. "It's a struggle to the death here."
Republican strategists say they sense movement in their direction, and private polls taken by Democrats here before Wednesday night's debate showed Mr. Bush taking the lead in the Fox River Valley and cutting into Mr. Gore's lead in Milwaukee. Two additional factors cheer the Republicans: they have more money for the stretch drive, and Mr. Bush seems to many in Wisconsin to have bested Mr. Gore in the second debate.
Appleton's and the Fox River Valley's pivotal role stems from some rough-and-ready electoral arithmetic. Democrats usually win Milwaukee, Republicans, the Milwaukee suburbs; Democrats usually win Madison, Republicans, the rural parts of the state. That leaves this region with a balancing role -- although such calculations are imprecise, omitting other cities like Racine and Kenosha.
Though tucked away in a relatively remote corner of the United States, Appleton has had its share of famous citizens. There was Joseph R. McCarthy, the Red-hunting senator whose bust stands in the Outagamie County Courthouse; there was Harry Houdini, the illusionist, who grew up here; and there were two presidents of little Lawrence College (now Lawrence University) who moved on to major national educational roles -- Henry M. Wriston, who became president of Brown University, and Nathan M. Pusey, who became president of Harvard.
But by and large, Green Bay and the valley are blue-collar places, good customers for the overalls made just south of here in Oshkosh. Big paper mills (like the ones in Appleton and Neenah owned by the Kimberly-Clark Corporation, which makes Kleenex and Scott tissues) remain important employers, as do food packers.
This district is "the district of the pro-life, pro-family, Catholic deer hunter," said Mark Green, a Republican who represents it in Congress.
"If you don't hunt, you don't fish and you don't milk cows in northern Wisconsin, what are you doing here?" asked Susan Squires, a political reporter for The Post-Crescent in Appleton.
Ms. Squires offered to bet that Mr. Bush would carry this area. Why was she so sure?
"George Bush is the kind of guy you want to sit down and have a few beers with, and talk for an hour or so," she said. "Gore isn't, not even the new, remodeled Gore. He's too much of an egghead for these people up here."
This region and Wisconsin as a whole do seem to have a certain affinity for low-key, not particularly electric politicians. Gov. Tommy G. Thompson, a Republican, and Senator Russell D. Feingold, a Democrat, both have reputations as unpretentious men of the people. Senator Herb Kohl, a multimillionaire and a Democrat, puts on fewer airs than many of his colleagues on Capitol Hill.
Mr. Green argued that Mr. Bush, a governor preaching compassionate conservatism, would benefit from Mr. Thompson's innovative style of politics, which voters have grown accustomed to in electing him to four four-year terms. It is not that Mr. Thompson can deliver the state, Mr. Green said, but that he has made it receptive to Mr. Bush's ideas.
By no means everyone buys his or Ms. Squires's analysis of this area.
"This state votes on issues, not personality," said Bill Dixon, a Madison Democrat who runs a weekly political panel on a statewide public-broadcasting television program. "It's a political junkie's show. But people come up to me in the True Value hardware, or on the sidewalk downtown, and tell me what they think. Issues count in Wisconsin. They count in the Fox River Valley."
The valley has prospered during the Clinton-Gore years, others note, and there seems to be no particular reason for people here to want to change administrations. Taken together, the three area counties -- Brown (Green Bay), Outagamie (Appleton) and Winnebago (Oshkosh, Neenah and Menasha) -- voted for Mr. Bush's father in 1988, but supported Bill Clinton in 1992 and 1996.
In fact, a woman asked Mr. Bush at McKinley school why an undecided voter should opt to switch parties in the White House, given current prosperity.
"I'm groping for the right answer, as you can tell," he replied, stumbling over his words and syntax for four minutes or more until he finally managed to say, "The economy's done more for this administration than the administration has done for the economy."
Ken Harwood, the mayor of Neenah, listened to Mr. Bush struggling and said: "He has to be prepared to answer that question over and over again. He needs to say, I understand business and industry, and I can create a balance that will sustain this economy."
Mr. Gore never forgets to talk up the administration's economic achievements. But in his speech to the labor-dominated crowd in Milwaukee on Thursday, he pledged to create "a better, fairer, stronger economy" if elected.
"Too many have been left behind," the vice president declared.
So far, however, no issue has taken a dominant role, and a number of imponderables remain. One of the most important is Ralph Nader, the nominee of the Green Party, whose Wisconsin headquarters are prominently located on State Street, the funky pedestrian mall in Madison that links the State Capitol and the University of Wisconsin. Most politicians here thought that Mr. Nader would begin to lose strength as the campaign progressed, but he has held steady at 4 percent to 5 percent, which could cost Mr. Gore the state if it holds up at the polls.
And what of the situation in the Middle East? Will it help Mr. Gore, who has more experience in international affairs, or Mr. Bush, whose party is trusted by more people, generally speaking, on foreign policy issues?
Few here will risk a guess, and the candidates are taking nothing for granted. Mr. Bush will return to the state next week, on the day after the final debate, probably to visit La Crosse, on the Mississippi River, and Eau Claire in western Wisconsin. Mr. Gore is expected again, too, well before the end of the campaign. It's quite a lot of fuss over 11 electoral votes.
 
About This Series
 
A series of articles last month examined four swing states -- Pennsylvania, Ohio, Wisconsin and Michigan -- that are likely to be critical in the presidential race. This is the second of four articles revisiting the race in those states.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: POLITICAL MEMO;
Exuding Confidence, Avoiding Complacency

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 15

 BODY:
Only an hour or so after Gov. George W. Bush's well-reviewed performance in Wednesday night's presidential debate, one of his top aides called to tell him that he "just became the president of the United States."
The next morning, as his campaign plane flew low over Washington, the pilot publicly announced, "If you look over to your left, Governor, there's your new home." 
 And throughout that day, at rallies in Langhorne, Pa., and Grand Rapids, Mich., politicians essentially jumped to the same celebratory conclusion, with Gov. Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania proclaiming, "I know a blowout when I saw one, and I saw one last night during the debates."
Small wonder that by late Friday afternoon, as Mr. Bush's week on the campaign trail ended, he jittered across the tarmac in Pontiac, Mich., like a human pinball machine, juiced by electricity, lit from within, beaming and bopping.
With little more than three weeks until Election Day, Mr. Bush and his aides are exuding a mood as helium-buoyant as at any other point in the 16 months of his campaign.
They feel that he aced last week's debate and turned the tide of polls decidedly in his favor, and they seem to be operating in a zone of comfort and joy, or at least are successfully projecting that image.
And there is some wisdom and potential benefit in that: many political scientists say that late-deciding voters often break in favor of the candidate who is perceived to be on the surest path to victory. But there is danger, too, in all of the Austin ebullience, because the Bush campaign has fallen prey to overconfidence in the past.
In the days immediately before the Republican primary in New Hampshire, Mr. Bush went sledding, bowling and snowmobile riding, obviously unprepared for the landslide victory Senator John McCain of Arizona ended up posting. Just weeks later, the Bush campaign was surprised again when Mr. McCain beat the Texas governor in the Michigan primary.
One senior Republican official who advises the Bush campaign said he did not believe that Mr. Bush and his aides, for all their brio, were letting themselves be lulled into a false sense of security this time around.
"I don't think they're anywhere near overconfident," he said. "I think they're confident, but they're also being careful."
Indeed, the Bush campaign is in some ways beginning to pull out all the stops. This week, it is sending Mr. Bush's mother, Barbara Bush, out to campaign in the crucial swing states of Michigan and Pennsylvania, and next week, it is putting 28 fellow Republican governors in four airplanes to spend several days crisscrossing the country for Mr. Bush.
But the adviser acknowledged that Mr. Bush has a tendency toward excessive optimism, citing as an example his selection in July of Dick Cheney, the former defense secretary and a longtime Bush family friend, as a running mate.
Many Republican officials still see that choice as an indication that Mr. Bush felt so serene atop the polls that he put emotional preference before political strategy. Mr. Cheney, after all, is from Wyoming, a solidly Republican state with only three electoral votes, and his conservative voting record in Congress would seem to have little appeal to moderate swing voters.
But several political analysts said that what Mr. Bush and his campaign may be doing now, with their constant trumpeting of recent polls that show Mr. Bush edging ahead of Mr. Gore, is trying to weave an aura of imminent triumph. It could make a difference.
"There's a mild bandwagon effect for the leader," said Michael Lewis-Beck, a professor of political science at the University of Iowa, referring to what often happens in the electorate in a campaign's waning days. "Success breeds more success, and people like to back winners."
Mr. Lewis-Beck said he thought Mr. Gore would prevail, based on a predictive formula that weighs factors like the health of the economy and the approval ratings for the incumbent administration.
But he noted that the candidate who voters believe will win is often the one who does, so campaigns have a powerful interest late in the game in portraying themselves as being ahead.
Still, Mr. Bush and his allies might be accused of pushing it a bit far.
On Saturday, the Bush campaign produced a news release with the headline that Mr. Bush was "leading Al Gore among the next generation of women voters," and Mindy Tucker, a spokeswoman for Mr. Bush, drew reporters' attention to this development in a conference call today.
The surveys Ms. Tucker was referring to were either commissioned by or conducted among the Girl Scouts, and the respondents were 11 to 17 years old.
Chris Lehane, a spokesman for the Gore campaign, said the Bush campaign was "gloating," while Mr. Gore and his aides have "always had a gloat-free zone."
"I think it shows a degree of hubris," Mr. Lehane said, "and my guess is voters are not going to react to it very well."
But even as Mr. Bush's supporters flash broad smiles, their language suggests an awareness that the Republican presidential nominee still has to work to convince hesitant, ambivalent voters that he is adequately prepared to run the affairs of the country.
The word Mr. Ridge used on Thursday afternoon to sum up Mr. Bush's debate performance was "presidential," and he made a point of saying it twice.
Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, insisted on NBC's "Meet the Press" this morning that Mr. Bush was "ready" for the presidency, which happened to be the same locution Gov. John Engler of Michigan repeated several times at a Bush rally on Thursday night.
That same evening, aboard his campaign plane, Mr. Bush had an exchange with the press corps that revealed a keen awareness of the disparaging questions about the depth of his knowledge and a keen interest in putting that chatter to rest.
A reporter jokingly asked Mr. Bush if she could leave the plane through the less crowded front door, which Mr. Bush uses, instead of the back door, noting that the rear exit was "separate" but not "equal."
"Plessy v. Ferguson!" Mr. Bush exclaimed, showing off his familiarity with the 1896 Supreme Court decision that instituted a separate-but-equal doctrine to permit racial segregation in public facilities. His grin was gargantuan.
