LENGTH: 3707 words

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: RUNNING TEXAS;
A Master of Bipartisanship With No Taste for Details

SERIES: GOVERNOR BUSH'S JOURNEY/Running Texas

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex.

 BODY:
Gov. George W. Bush has written that "by far the most profound" decision he or any governor can make is whether to proceed with an execution.
"I get the facts, weigh them thoughtfully and carefully, and decide," Mr. Bush wrote in his autobiography. What he did not say is that he normally does this in 15 minutes. 
 A review of Mr. Bush's daily schedules, correspondence and other documents, obtained after requests made under public-information laws in Texas, underscores that he has devoted himself remarkably little to policy details -- including whether to go ahead with executions -- and instead spent most of his time wooing legislators, the public and the news media.
Yet this may have made him more effective as governor, not less. Even many Democrats in Texas praise Mr. Bush, saying he has appointed unusually well-qualified people, avoided disabling scandals or controversies and succeeded in getting a popular agenda passed into law.
It is impossible to know clearly what a Bush presidency would be like from his years as governor, in part because Mr. Bush has held office for just five years and has never been tested by a recession or other crisis. But his experience here in Austin can help form some tentative ideas about how he might operate as president.
The 900-page stack of Mr. Bush's schedules and correspondence obtained from the governor's office portrays a governor who works short hours and spends little time studying specific issues or working on executive matters. The schedules show that Mr. Bush typically had his first office meeting about 9 a.m., took two hours of "private time" at lunch for a run, and then wrapped up his last meeting by about 5 p.m.
A large portion of the officially scheduled meetings were "photo opportunities," interviews with reporters, or meetings with school groups or other ceremonial occasions. Relatively little of the day was devoted to hard-core examination of the issues.
Aides acknowledge Mr. Bush's impatience with long meetings and briefing papers. But they praise this as a Reagan-style assertion of a chief executive's responsibility to dictate broad principles and then delegate minor matters.
The detachment from policy details may arise in part because Texas law gives a governor very limited powers -- he cannot commute a death sentence, for example, but only delay its implementation for 30 days. And it may partly arise because Mr. Bush shows great trust in those to whom he delegates authority, such as the people he appoints to the board of pardons and paroles. He almost always follows the board's recommendations.
A spokeswoman for Mr. Bush, Linda Edwards, said he might spend more than 15 minutes reviewing a death penalty case -- the meeting might go longer than scheduled, or he might make a follow-up call later -- and that the time schedule reflected Mr. Bush's confidence in his legal advisers. Ms. Edwards said the advisers might have spent hours reviewing a death penalty case before discussing it with the governor.
The schedules examined were for 1997, because that was a year in which the Texas Legislature met (there is no legislative session in even years) and thus gave Mr. Bush the chance to be more involved in policy, and he had not yet begun traveling widely in pursuit of the presidency. These days, Mr. Bush is rarely in the governor's office.
The schedules do not, of course, tell the full story. Long chunks of time were left blank, and just because nothing was scheduled does not mean that Mr. Bush was playing solitaire on his computer (although he sometimes did). Aides say that during periods when his schedule was blank, Mr. Bush made phone calls, read and answered correspondence, talked to staff members, met visitors and dropped in on legislators.
These visits with legislators -- which Mr. Bush made much more frequently than past governors had -- have generated enormous good will for him and helped increase his effectiveness in getting legislation passed.
 
An Unusual Partnership
It was a quiet morning in October 1994, three weeks before Election Day, as a car pulled up at 3001 Gilbert Street in a residential area of Austin. The unlikeliest of visitors got out, stepped quickly up the walk and rang the bell of the ranch-style home.
It was George W. Bush, then the Republican candidate for governor, and he was making a secret visit to a legendary Democratic kingmaker, Bob Bullock. They had never met, and even their aides did not know of that first meeting.
It would have been natural for them to sit down together after the election, but it was extraordinary for Mr. Bush to reach out in this way in the middle of a campaign that many thought he would lose. Yet Mr. Bullock, a craggy, explosive man, a Rodin statue come to life, invited Mr. Bush into the kitchen and sat down at the table.
Jan Bullock, Mr. Bullock's widow (he died last year), recalled that Mr. Bush first walked to the counter and, without invitation, poured himself a mug of coffee. Then he sat down at the small table and made a plea for a truce instead of a political war.
"He just explained that if he was elected he had no intention of playing the political game," she recalled. "He said, 'I'm here to tell you that I want to work with you.' "
"Of course, my husband was wary and skeptical, but he liked him," Mrs. Bullock said, adding that the two men talked for three or four hours about their ideas for state government.
That meeting, recounted by Mr. Bush's aides as well as by Mrs. Bullock, helped lay the groundwork for one of Mr. Bush's proudest achievements as governor -- the spirit of bipartisan cooperation that hugely multiplied his effectiveness. Many politicians and consultants say that so far, at least, Mr. Bush has not left any fundamentally new imprint or legacy in Texas, but that he did succeed in uniting Republicans and Democrats behind an agenda that took Texas several steps toward bolstering schools and creating a more pro-business environment.
One of Mr. Bush's campaign themes has been his boast, which many Texas Democrats say is justified, that as governor he worked particularly closely with Democrats. Thus a central question about Mr. Bush is simply how transferable his style would be to Washington.
Many here in Austin say the bipartisanship was possible largely because of a special circumstance: Democrats in Texas are like Republicans anywhere else. Democrats from rural Texas, in particular, tend to be fiscally conservative, supportive of the death penalty, very tough on crime and suspicious of environmental regulation.
As a result, the two parties were divided by rivalry and distrust in Texas, but not by their positions on the issues, as is true in most of the nation. Mrs. Bullock, for example, says there were no ideological differences between her husband and Mr. Bush.
"Texas politics has been based more on friendship than party lines," she mused as she sat in her living room here. "Texas must be extremely unique in that respect."
Yet while there are doubts about whether Mr. Bush could achieve a similarly harmonious relationship in Washington, this bipartisanship remains a real and unexpected achievement in Texas. No one would have anticipated his partnership with Mr. Bullock, and the two men's cooperation became a reason Mr. Bush could get things done and a source of his tremendous popularity.
His critics accuse him of being a terrible governor on the issues -- keeping poor children off the health insurance rolls, backing polluters as they destroy the air and water, doing little to improve the quasi-third world conditions in the communities known as "colonias" close to the Mexican border. But few critics try to argue that Mr. Bush has been ineffective or unpopular.
"On his own terms, taking his goals to measure him against, he's been a successful governor," said Bruce Buchanan, a political scientist and presidential scholar at the University of Texas at Austin.
Professor Buchanan said Mr. Bush would be remembered as an incrementalist who had achieved modest progress on his own limited agenda -- more progress than his Democratic predecessor, Ann Richards -- but that he would leave a much smaller imprint on Texas than such predecessors as John B. Connally, who helped build the state's university system, or Mark White, who worked with Ross Perot to begin an overhaul of the state's education system.
 
Holding His Temper
Back when Mr. Bush began his campaign for governor, just about everybody thought he was crazy. Ms. Richards was a national figure and media star with high popularity ratings. Even Mr. Bush's own mother, Barbara, urged him not to run against her.
Yet Mr. Bush was determined, and he ran a shrewd race while keeping his hot temper in check. Ms. Richards tried to aggravate Mr. Bush into self-destruction by needling him and belittling him as a dull-witted daddy's boy who had never accomplished anything on his own.
If Mr. Bush had detonated in front of a television camera, such an explosion would have been particularly costly because it might have been seen as confirmation of what many Texans suspected: that he was running against Ms. Richards partly for personal reasons, to seek revenge. Ms. Richards had made a famous speech to the Democratic National Convention in 1988, ridiculing Mr. Bush's father as "born with a silver foot in his mouth."
Yet Mr. Bush, whose temperament in the past had resembled a string of firecrackers popping, simply grinned amicably when Ms. Richards goaded him over the course of the campaign as a "shrub" and a "jerk."
His cousin Elsie Walker said she watched Mr. Bush and Ms. Richards debate on television, periodically cowering behind a bathroom door as she waited for Mr. Bush to blow up. But he had matured, and he came across as the cooler candidate.
"As I watched, she was needling him and he wasn't needling back," Ms. Walker recalled. "So I sent a telegram to Barbara, something like 'What's he on, animal tranquilizers?' And then I realized he'd really developed a lot of discipline."
One of Mr. Bush's insights was that while Texans liked Ms. Richards, they did not much agree with her and regarded her as too liberal. And so he ran an exceptionally focused, tight campaign that hammered home his themes day after day: better schools, a tougher juvenile justice system, tighter restrictions on welfare and new limits on tort lawsuits.
Mr. Bush's greatest asset in life, with the possible exception of his name and connections, has been a winning personality, and he used it to great effect in the campaign. On the opening day of dove season, Sept. 1, Mr. Bush went out -- with 30-odd reporters in tow -- to shoot a dove. A bird flew up, he blasted away with his shotgun, he held up the bird proudly for the news photographers. Then the reporters pointed out that he had shot not a dove, but a protected songbird known as the killdeer.
Mr. Bush promptly confessed, paid a $130 fine and began a news conference that afternoon by saying: "Thank goodness it wasn't deer season. I might have shot a cow."
The humor and discipline of the campaign worked: Mr. Bush defeated Ms. Richards with a healthy 54 percent of the vote.
 
A Lesson From Billy Graham
During the campaign, Mr. Bush had told a reporter of his belief that the path to heaven comes from acceptance of Jesus as one's personal savior. Mr. Bush later recalled: "It was, of course, picked up and politicized -- you know, 'Bush to Jews: Go to Hell.' It was very ugly. It hurt my feelings."
So one of the first things he did after becoming governor, he recalled, was to meet a group of Jewish leaders in Houston and give a speech that he remembers this way: "I know, really, why you all are here. You're here to know whether this governor condemns you to hell. I can tell."
"It hurt me," Mr. Bush recalled saying. "It hurt to think that you think I've condemned you to hell, because I would never do that. That's not my role in life."
Mr. Bush later explained that the Rev. Billy Graham had helped him reach this position. As he recalled in a 1998 interview, the issue arose when he was visiting his parents in the White House and the discussion turned to religion: he argued that only Christians had a place in heaven, while his mother disagreed.
"I said, 'Mom, look, all I can tell you is what the New Testament says,' " Mr. Bush recounted. "And she said, 'Well, surely God will accept others.' And I said, 'Mom, here's what the New Testament says.' And she said, 'O.K.,' and she picks up the phone and calls Billy Graham. She says to the White House operator, 'Get me Billy Graham.'
"I said, 'Mother, what are you doing?' " Mr. Bush said. "Seriously. And about two minutes later, the phone rings, and it's Billy Graham, and Mother and I are on the phone with Billy. And Mother explains the circumstances, and Billy says: 'From a personal perspective, I agree with what George is saying; the New Testament has been my guide. But I want to caution you both. Don't play God. Who are you two to be God?' "
The issue reflects Mr. Bush's penchant for holding to views whose implications some might find offensive, while doing all he can to avoid giving any offense. The logical conclusion of Mr. Bush's theology may be that non-Christians cannot enter heaven, but he consciously steps aside before reaching that conclusion and insists that it is not his role to be gatekeeper.
A similar pattern arises on gay issues. While campaigning in 1994, Mr. Bush opposed an effort to repeal an anti-sodomy law making homosexual acts a crime in Texas. The effort to repeal the bill failed very narrowly, and it remains on the books, apparently with Mr. Bush's support.
The sodomy law is rarely enforced. But in 1998 police officers entered a home in Houston after getting a report of an armed intruder, and arrested a gay couple they said were having sex. The couple appealed, and in June an appeals court agreed that the law violated the Texas Equal Rights Amendment. The state has appealed.
Yet Mr. Bush has avoided trumpeting his views about homosexuality.
Glen Maxey, a gay Democrat in the Texas House of Representatives, recalled an occasion when Governor Bush was visiting the House floor to support a bill that would have banned adoption by gay couples. "We had a short talk on the House floor," Mr. Maxey said. "He said, 'Glen, I value you as a friend, and what I say about gay people doesn't apply to you personally.' And I said: 'Governor, when you say you're against gay adoption, you're talking about me. And I take that very personally.' "
"George Bush was totally comfortable with me," Mr. Maxey added. "But it's all those other gay people out there. I think that mentality runs through him, whether it's race or sexual orientation. Up front, he's a great guy. But when you move to policy things, it's a great danger."
 
Friendly Headlocks
Elliott Naishtat, a Democratic member of the state House of Representatives, was walking down the steps of the Texas Capitol one day. Suddenly, a man seized him from behind and put him in a headlock.
Mr. Naishtat looked through the tangle of arms and identified the mugger.
"It's Bush, and he's very friendly," recalled Mr. Naishtat, a liberal who is the chairman of the House committee that was then considering welfare legislation. Some Capitol police officers were nearby, and Mr. Naishtat jokingly called out to them for help, but they did not interfere. So the governor walked Mr. Naishtat down the steps, keeping him bent over and in the headlock.
"And he said, 'Elliott, I hear we're hung up on welfare,' " Mr. Naishtat recalled. " 'You know how important this is, I hope we can work it out.' "
This aggressive bonhomie is very much Mr. Bush's style, and it has been very effective in Texas. Mr. Naishtat, for example, admits that it was "seductive" to be mugged by the governor, although he quickly adds that this aggressive approach did not work: he did not allow the welfare bills out of committee.
Still, what is striking in talking to Texas politicians, even Democrats, is how much they like Mr. Bush. He invites them to the governor's mansion, he drops by their offices, he praises them in the press, he puts them in friendly headlocks.
"His strength is not policy, not details," said Paul Sadler, a Democrat who is chairman of the House education committee. "His strength is that you like him and you want him to succeed."
Mr. Sadler worked very closely with Mr. Bush on changes in the education system, and when the new school law was signed in June 1995, Mr. Bush scheduled the ceremony in Mr. Sadler's hometown, Henderson, and then praised him for his work. It would be difficult to imagine such an event at the federal level, with a president traveling to the hometown of the other party's congressman to thank him for his work on a bill.
One result of this gesture is that Mr. Sadler describes himself as a friend of Mr. Bush and is not taking sides in the presidential race. That is remarkably common: many Texas Democrats are steering clear of Vice President Al Gore and remaining on the sidelines.
Yet the Texas Democrats are sometimes also a bit irritated that all the credit for bipartisanship goes to Mr. Bush. They emphasize that Mr. Bush's success was in large part a consequence of his extraordinary partnership with Mr. Bullock, who was the lieutenant governor and arguably held more power under the Texas system than Mr. Bush. The two men developed almost a father-son relationship, with Mr. Bullock doing much of Mr. Bush's heavy legislative lifting. And while it was Mr. Bush who reached out, Mr. Bullock responded with equal enthusiasm.
Likewise, Democrats say Mr. Bush's agenda was partly drawn from measures that were already bubbling up in the Legislature, which would have been passed even under a different governor.
"Was he significant?" Mr. Sadler said, referring to Mr. Bush's role on the education bill. "Absolutely. But were the ideas his? No, that's not the way it happened. There were a whole bunch of people, Democrats and Republicans alike, working to get it done, and he was a part of that team. He was no more significant than any member of my committee or of the Senate committee."
 
'He's Looking for Perfection'
A Texas governor's main powers lie in making appointments and using the bully pulpit. On both counts, Mr. Bush gets high marks from many Democrats as well as Republicans.
State records show that Mr. Bush has appointed many fewer members of minority groups than Ms. Richards -- 80 percent of his appointees have been white, compared with 66 percent of Ms. Richards's and 55 percent of the Texas population as a whole. In addition, 63 percent of Mr. Bush's appointees have been men.
While Mr. Bush's appointments have been less diverse over all, his choices have mostly been well-respected moderates rather than hard-line ideologues (although a couple of appointees have aroused criticism because of their remarks about blacks and Hispanics). And Mr. Bush's judicial appointees say they were never asked about their positions on issues like abortion.
"It's the toughest appointment process I've ever seen," said George Christian, a former aide to President Lyndon B. Johnson and now a Texas political consultant. "He's looking for perfection. I handled appointments for two governors, and the way we did it was we checked with local campaign people and state Democratic Party folks. It was a much more political process."
In contrast to this traditionally political approach, Mr. Bush appointed an old friend from the business world, Clay Johnson, to head the appointment process. Many of his appointees are financial contributors or cronies, but many others are simply experts in their field who are not politically active, or even Democrats.
"I have clients who want appointments," said Bill Miller, a prominent lobbyist in Austin who works with Democrats and Republicans. "And one of the gripes I hear from them is 'What the hell, these guys are trying to get somebody right for the job.' "
Mr. Bush's one effort to leave a major legacy in Texas showed just the kind of vision that critics often said his father lacked in the White House. It was a far-reaching tax proposal that would have addressed weaknesses in public finance in Texas by reducing property taxes, raising the sales tax and levying a new tax on partnerships of professionals like doctors, lawyers and accountants.
It was a bold move that reflected a measure of political courage: Mr. Bush, not surprisingly, was promptly denounced for trying to raise new taxes. The proposal failed ignominiously, for while there was widespread agreement that Texas' emphasis on property taxes was outdated, reflecting an era when most wealth came from the land, Mr. Bush could not build a consensus on how to replace the lost revenue.
Mr. Bush never mentions the proposal these days, perhaps because it failed, or perhaps because it could remind voters that he had once favored raising the sales tax. He said afterward that the failure demonstrated how hard it was to achieve dramatic change without a crisis to force it.
Since then, he has concentrated on less sweeping proposals but has not seemed chastened by the failure. On the contrary, he comes across as exuberant simply at waking up each morning as governor, and at times he seems surprised that his wandering course through life has led him to the governor's mansion and, perhaps, on a path to the White House.
An old friend and high school roommate, John Kidde, recalled visiting Mr. Bush for a 50th-birthday celebration in July 1996.
"All of a sudden he comes over, and he's dripping wet," Mr. Kidde recalled. "I thought he'd been dunked in a pool, but it turned out that he'd just come back from jogging. So he comes over and gives us hugs.
"And then he stands up and throws up his hands at the governor's mansion behind him, as if to say: 'What's this? How could this have happened to us?' "
 
Governor Bush's Journey
 
This is the 16th article of a series about the lives of the presidential candidates. Future installments will look at Al Gore and religion and George W. Bush's decision to seek the presidency.

HEADLINE: Lease Deal Helps Pave Way for Fourth New Tower in Times Sq.

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Arthur Andersen, the world's largest accounting firm, has signed a lease with Boston Properties that would enable the developer to build the last of four office towers at the core of an 18-year-old plan to transform Times Square from a dowdy and foreboding crossroads into a vibrant, neon-drenched entertainment and commercial district.
The 47-story, $600 million skyscraper would sit on an island at the south end of Times Square, bounded by Seventh Avenue and Broadway, between 42nd and 41st Streets. Designed by David M. Childs of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, the tower would offer a distinctively different face to Broadway, Seventh Avenue and 42nd Street. 
The site is now occupied by the Times Square Brewery and a nearly vacant office building, both of which would be demolished.
Executives on both sides of the deal said that the lease, signed late Friday night, commits Arthur Andersen to taking more than 500,000 square feet in the 1.2 million-square-foot tower. The deal is dependent on Boston Properties' obtaining full control of the site from Prudential Insurance Company and on Arthur Andersen's completing its negotiations for about $10 million in tax breaks from city officials.
Some officials have questioned the wisdom of providing subsidies to the company to go into what has become one of the most desirable locations in the city.
But Charles A. Gargano, chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, said: "You couldn't get a better example of a public-private partnership than what's happened in Times Square. That's the role government should play, and it works."
The office of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani did not return telephone calls seeking comment.
The accountants from Arthur Andersen would be the latest in a wave of corporate employees to move to an area that less than a decade ago was populated mainly by pimps, prostitutes, drug dealers and wary tourists.
The old denizens of Times Square have been replaced by investment bankers from Morgan Stanley, entertainment executives from Viacom and Bertelsmann AG, boisterous teenagers who flock to the MTV music studios and millions of visitors to Broadway theaters, the new movie palaces and other entertainment sites.
Later this month, Madame Tussaud's plans to open its wax and audioanimatronic museum on 42nd Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues.
"It's both the end and the beginning," said Rebecca Robertson, the former president of the state's 42nd Street Development Project, who oversaw the development for a decade ending in 1997. "Forty-second Street and Times Square has become E-squared. It's amazing how in tune it is with this new world. It's business, it's entertainment and it's quintessentially New York."
Executives from Arthur Andersen and Boston Properties said neither side expected problems in moving forward with the deal. And with the vacancy rate in Midtown office buildings at a barely perceptible 3 percent, real estate brokers say they do not expect Boston Properties to have any trouble filling the rest of the building.
Both sides expect construction to begin early next year.
"It came together very quickly," one person involved in the negotiations said. "It's the last piece of the puzzle in Times Square."
Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the chairman of Boston Properties and the publisher of The Daily News, has told friends he hoped that Times Square Tower, the name he has given the skyscraper, would become an international icon. It would loom over One Times Square, home of the New Year's Eve ball drop, and dominate the southern view of the "crossroads of the world," the subject of millions of tourist photographs every year.
According to one real estate broker who has been briefed on the project, Boston Properties plans to hold space at the top of the skyscraper off the market for a while and then rent its panoramic view for a premium, more than $100 a square foot annually. Brokers said that Arthur Andersen would be paying about $70 a square foot.
Taxpayers have also had a stake in the revival of Times Square since state and city officials have provided hundreds of millions of dollars in tax breaks and other incentives to developers and tenants. The incentives continued even after corporations began migrating to the area in the late 1990's.
Boston Properties has already received an incentive package valued at $236 million over 20 years for the site where Arthur Andersen plans to move. In asking for additional tax breaks, Andersen has threatened to move some workers to Roseland, N.J., where it has offices.
Boston Properties' project would cap a redevelopment plan that began in 1982, when city and state officials announced that they would offer developers huge tax breaks and the opportunity to build four office towers in the once vibrant neighborhood, which had fallen on hard times. In return, the developers were to restore a half-dozen live theaters on 42nd Street and improve the huge Times Square subway station.
The developer George Klein and later, Prudential Insurance, were chosen, but progress was slow as the state's effort to gain control of 13 acres along 42nd Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues ran into 47 separate lawsuits and a devastating recession in the early 1990's.
Because the city was littered with vacant office towers in 1991, Prudential, which had put up more than $400 million to acquire the land, did not want to go forward. That provided the state with an opportunity to redesign the project. Instead of wiping out the bustling, brightly lighted past of Times Square and replacing it with something akin to a suburban office park, a new plan called for restoring the district's "razzmatazz," with large illuminated billboards, entertainment venues and office towers that reflected the street life of the area. Prudential ultimately decided to sell the development rights for the four office sites.
It was a huge gamble, Ms. Robertson said, and no one knew if it would work. Suddenly, the redevelopment project took off in 1995, as the the city's economy was starting to boom. First, the Walt Disney Company renovated the dilapidated New Amsterdam Theater on 42nd Street.
In 1996, the developer Douglas Durst signed a deal to build the first of the four towers, a 48-story, 1.6-million-square-foot skyscraper that is now home to Conde Nast Publications and the law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom. The next year, Reuters and the Rudin real estate family began work on the Reuters Building, a 32-story, 855,000-square-foot tower that is nearing completion on the west side of Seventh Avenue between 42nd and 43rd Streets.
Boston Properties started demolition last year for what is known as Five Times Square Tower, a 37-story, 1.1-million-square-foot headquarters for Ernst & Young, the accounting firm, at the southwest corner of 42nd Street and Seventh Avenue, next door to the New Amsterdam Theater. And now Arthur Andersen, plans to move onto the street that hustlers once called the Deuce.
Along with the office towers, multiplex theaters, game rooms, a Hilton hotel, the B. B. King nightclub, the MTV music studios and the largest video screen in the world have gone up along 42nd Street and elsewhere in Times Square.
"It was a wonderful coincidence of planning and market," Ms. Robertson said.

HEADLINE: Mrs. Clinton Visits Harlem as Lazio Courts Upstate Vote

BYLINE: By ERIC LIPTON and JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
Hillary Rodham Clinton urged Bronx and Harlem churchgoers yesterday to pray for peace in the Middle East, while her opponent, Rick A. Lazio, stumped for votes in western New York, visiting tailgaters assembled for a Buffalo Bills game and Italian-Americans gathered in Geneva for a lasagna dinner in his honor.
The contrasting schedules illustrated once again the two campaigns' strategies. Mrs. Clinton has spent four of the last five Sundays at predominantly black churches, working to generate a large turnout among black voters. Mr. Lazio, meanwhile, invested his seventh day in upstate and western New York, seeking to shore up his support in the state's more conservative, and predominantly white, corners. 
 Mrs. Clinton, in discussing Middle East affairs yesterday, was careful not to interject herself too much into her husband's dealings. Yes, she said, she had spoken with President Clinton yesterday morning, wishing him well before he left for a summit meeting with Middle East leaders.
But no, she said, she did not offer him any particular advice. Instead, she asked the congregations she visited yesterday to pray for him.
"It is a time of peril and danger," Mrs. Clinton said to the congregation at the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem, where she was joined by prominent black leaders, including Representative Charles B. Rangel and the state comptroller, H. Carl McCall.
In her church visits, Mrs. Clinton has offered a relatively consistent message. Despite the economic growth in recent years, too many people do not have health insurance, too many schools are overcrowded or poorly equipped and too many of the elderly and their families cannot afford medication or specialized care, Mrs. Clinton repeatedly says.
By using techniques common to ministers -- carefully modifying her cadence, raising and lowering her voice, repeating certain refrains that seem almost designed to evoke cries of "amen" from the congregations -- she generally succeeds in workingthe crowds into a fervor.
"No matter what, keep going," Mrs. Clinton said yesterday, recalling the advice she said the freed slave Harriet Tubman offered as she helped other slaves escape to the North. "If you hear gunshots, keep going. If you hear footsteps and shouts behind you, keep going. If you hear the barking of the dogs that are trying to hunt you down, keep going."
Her 13 minutes of remarks at Goodwill Baptist Church in the Bronx elicited applause 17 times. At Abyssinian, applause came 15 times, along with two standing ovations. And at Emmanuel Baptist Church in the Bronx, the congregation sang a hymn with the words "Victory is mine, victory is mine. Yes, I told Lazio, get thee behind," substituting Mr. Lazio's name where the traditional lyric calls for a reference to Satan. Mrs. Clinton, at least for this song, did not appear to sing along.
Mr. Lazio encountered his own share of enthusiastic crowds at stops his campaign bus made in Buffalo, Geneva, Auburn, Skaneateles and Tully yesterday, a journey in which he was joined by his wife, Patricia, and their two daughters.
At the "Lasagna with Lazio" dinner in Geneva, held by the Sons of Italy Post 2397, Mr. Lazio spoke of his grandmother, an immigrant from Italy, and the values she instilled in the family. Then he turned to his campaign.
"Nobody from Washington, D.C., or Little Rock or Hollywood is going to tell us New Yorkers who's going to represent us in the United States Senate," he said, echoing the theme of two new television advertisements his campaign is running, emphasizing Mrs. Clinton's newcomer status.
In an interview yesterday morning on Fox News, Mr. Lazio asserted that during his upstate campaign stops "75 percent of the people were Democrats," a claim that Mrs. Clinton's aides challenged, noting that a large portion of upstate residents are Republicans.
Mr. Lazio visited the Ukrainian National Club in Auburn and a bowling alley in Skaneateles, and spent about two hours in the parking lot of Ralph Wilson Stadium greeting people on their way to the Buffalo Bills game.
The reaction to Mr. Lazio was characterized as much by apparent disdain for Mrs. Clinton as by genuine support for Mr. Lazio.
"You've got to stop her," several Bills fans yelled to Mr. Lazio. He responded generally by smiling and asking for the support of voters.
In a question-and-answer session with reporters, Mr. Lazio defended the tone of his campaign literature, which describes Mrs. Clinton as "extreme" and "radical."
"I stand by that language," Mr. Lazio said. "Anytime somebody puts forth proposals that would spend $2.5 trillion over 10 years," a figure that a spokeswoman for Mrs. Clinton's campaign called inaccurate, "that's not exactly a fiscal conservative."

HEADLINE: Metro Briefing

BYLINE: Compiled by Anthony Ramirez

 BODY:

NEW YORK
 
BUFFALO: RURAL ECONOMY STRENGTHENING
Economists at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York report that rural areas of the state grew in population from 1990 to 1999 compared with urban areas, which shrank or remained the same, and that nonfarm employment from 1975 to 1999 rose 41 percent, compared with 32 percent in urban areas. Economists in the Buffalo office said businesses may be moving to rural areas in search of less expensive labor, land and housing. (NYT) 

MANHATTAN: STRICTER FUEL STANDARDS URGED
Senator Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat, yesterday announced a plan to encourage nationwide energy conservation, including reclassifying what he called gas-guzzling sport utility vehicles as cars instead of trucks. He noted that sales of the vehicles had more than tripled to 3.1 million in 1999 from 976,000 in 1989 and that their fuel efficiency had dropped to 19.6 miles per gallon from 20.9 during the same period. Reclassifying them as cars would force them to adhere to a standard of 27.5 miles per gallon. He also proposed $1 billion in tax credits to encourage the development of energy sources other than petroleum. (NYT)
 
MANHATTAN: THE CASE OF THE SUSPICIOUS SUITCASE
The hustle and bustle of the 26th Street flea market was interrupted yesterday morning by the sort of find no one wants -- a suitcase left unattended long enough for the Police Department's bomb squad to be called. The black case, which turned out to be empty save for three AA batteries, had been left on the sidewalk in front of one of the market's busiest sites, on the Avenue of the Americas between 25th and 26th Streets. According to the police, an anonymous man called to report a "suspicious suitcase, standing upright and unattended" at 10:23 a.m. The police evacuated the 26th Street site and cordoned off the Avenue of the Americas between 23rd and 27th Streets for about an hour. Joyce Wadler (NYT)
 
HAUPPAUGE: SUPPORT FOR IMMIGRANT LABORERS
Just before dusk yesterday, a crowd waving a multinational sea of flags gathered outside a Suffolk County office building here to urge county leaders and other officials to address the problems faced by day laborers, most of whom are immigrants from Mexico and Central America. About 3,000 people attended the rally, the police said. Organized by the Suffolk County Human Rights Commission and Paul J. Tonna, the presiding officer of the Suffolk Legislature, the candlelight rally came a month after an attack on two day laborers in Farmingville, and the day after a town hall meeting in Centereach, where 200 Suffolk residents demanded tougher enforcement of immigration laws. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)
 
ALBANY: FEWER HUNTING LICENSES ISSUED
Sales of hunting licenses in New York have dropped every year since 1991 before rebounding slightly last year. A common lament from hunters is that young people are more interested in video games than the outdoors. Charles Mowatt, who encourages deer hunting in his woods in Cattaraugus County, said hunters are getting old and "they're like me -- they don't shoot so straight." It is too early to draw a link between fewer hunters and the thriving deer population, estimated at one million in New York, said William Porter, a wildlife biologist at the State College of Environmental Science and Forestry in Syracuse. But he warned that there might be trouble if hunting continues to decline. (AP)
 
CONNECTICUT
 
HARTFORD: PHARMACIST SHORTAGE
A shortage of pharmacists in Connecticut has forced many drugstores to close during regular business hours because Connecticut laws require drugstores to close when there is no pharmacist working. The University of Connecticut, home of the state's only pharmacy program, usually graduates more than 90 new pharmacists annually. But it has extended its pharmacy training to six years from five, so no pharmacy students graduated from its program this year. (AP)
 
BLOOMFIELD: LATINO EPISCOPAL BISHOP INSTALLED
The Episcopal Diocese of Connecticut has consecrated its first Latino bishop. The ceremony in Bloomfield on Saturday for the bishop, Wilfrido Ramos-Orench, was delivered in English, Spanish and French Creole. Bishop Ramos, 60, has served in a regional ministry in Hartford as well as in the Spanish-speaking congregation in New Britain. (AP)
 
BRISTOL: EMISSIONS CLEANUP
Taxpayers in 14 central Connecticut towns will have to share the more than $3 million cost of altering a Bristol incinerator to make it less polluting. Leaders of the towns whose trash flows into the Odgen Martin incinerator are negotiating a contractual change that will pass the cleanup cost plus $55,000 annually on to taxpayers. The 13-year-old plant needs updated scrubbers and equipment that strips poisonous mercury from its emissions. (AP)
 
NEW JERSEY
 
PISCATAWAY: NADER SPEECH DISRUPTED
Reports of a suspicious package at Rutgers University's Busch Campus Center yesterday disrupted the campaign speech of Ralph Nader, the Green Party presidential candidate, officials said. Sgt. Ron Brown of the state police said the agency's bomb squad was called to the campus center around 3:30 p.m. Sergeant Brown had little additional information about the package, and the university police declined to release information about the incident. (AP)
 
TRENTON: SLAVERY REPARATIONS FRAUD
Almost 600 people in New Jersey have been bilked by con artists who tell black residents they can receive money for a phony "slave reparations" tax credit. Although the Internal Revenue Service has issued warnings nationwide, regional officials worry that many New Jersey residents are still unaware of the fraud. The number of claims sent from state residents to the I.R.S. dropped from 512 in July to 30 in August. But the filings increased to 51 in September, despite a summer campaign to warn people. The hoax usually involves con artists posing as tax preparers who tell blacks they can receive credit for slavery reparations in exchange for a fee of $30 to $50. (AP)

HEADLINE: An Oil Merger That Assumes That Bigger Is Not Just Better, It's Necessary

BYLINE: By NEELA BANERJEE 

 BODY:
With violence raging in the Middle East and lofty oil prices drawing harsh criticism of petroleum companies, it might seem an inopportune time for Chevron and Texaco to announce a merger that opens them to the scrutiny of the federal government and the jittery stock market.
But the timing has less to do with the high price of oil over the last several months and more to do with the trend toward larger oil concerns that has radically reshaped the industry in the last two years. In fact, the two companies tried to merge more than a year ago but were unable to work out the terms. 
 As for the tensions in the oil-rich Middle East, Chevron and Texaco do not have a presence in the region, and so are unaffected by the turmoil there. In fact, some of the largest new oil fields in the world have been discovered far from the Middle East, mainly in the deep waters off Brazil and West Africa and in the Caspian Sea.
The wide geographical range of the projects and their location below the sea reflect how high the stakes have become in the oil industry. Older fields like those in the United States are drying up, and the number of wells that are easy to drill and operate is winnowing.
To feed the world's powerful demand for oil, companies in search of the "elephant fields" that contain hundreds of millions of barrels of oil must now take on new political and technical perils, from the spasmodic civil war in Angola to the depths of the Caspian. Those conditions, in turn, require oil companies to have far greater revenues than were necessary only a few years ago.
"What all the oil companies have found out is that as you go deeper and deeper into the offshore projects, that you are a pioneer and, therefore, mistakes will be made," said Mehdi Varzi, director of research at Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, an investment bank. "To exploit those reserves, you need the acreage and you need the money."
While Chevron and Texaco already have projects in the waters off West Africa and Brazil, their merger is largely motivated by the need to either pool their assets and expertise or risk being pushed aside by the biggest players in the industry: Exxon Mobil, Royal Dutch/Shell and BP Amoco.
"On a combined basis, especially in exploration and production, we'll really be in a league with those other companies," said a senior executive involved in the talks.
Certainly, when the price of oil hovers above $30 a barrel as it has for much of this year, companies have greater resources for a merger and can use their income to go after sprawling projects. But much of the money companies expect to see from a merger will be in the savings they extract from cutting jobs, jettisoning less-profitable units and streamlining some operations, a process that oil experts say has been going on industrywide, in one form or another, since 1980. In creating a new, unified company, Chevron and Texaco expect to save $1.2 billion annually and to eliminate at least 4,000 jobs, senior executives said.
"The hidden value in mergers is that you cut people and inventory," said Larry Goldstein, president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation. "Companies have realized that they may not have control over the price of crude oil, but they do have control over costs."
Those cuts, in turn, have profoundly changed the main business of oil companies. The market giants now focus much more heavily on exploration and production rather than refining and selling gasoline, which they do primarily through joint ventures. Even now, for example, Texaco-brand gasoline is sold at filling stations in the United States through a joint venture with the Shell Oil Company called Equilon.
High gasoline prices this summer may have unleashed accusations of profiteering against gas stations and refiners. But oil companies make most of their money at the well-head, where it might cost about $3 to $4 to pump out a barrel of oil that, on the world market, may sell for $35.
"One of the dynamics happening in the oil industry is that the old vertically integrated structure is breaking down," said Dave Wilson, a recently retired partner in energy strategic consulting at PricewaterhouseCoopers. "There's not so much balance between production and refining any more. The merged companies sold off much of their refining and marketing to joint ventures, because refining and marketing usually perform so poorly."
Senior executives involved in the negotiations said that Chevron and Texaco had traditionally placed great emphasis on exploration of new fields, but the merger would make it more economical for them to continue such projects. Most of the $1.2 billion savings from the deal, for example, are expected to come from streamlining projects each company has in the Gulf of Mexico, Nigeria, Angola, Britain and Kazakhstan.
As with any merger, Chevron and Texaco will be playing up the hand-in-glove way they will fit together as they go about creating a new company. Indeed, the two have worked together for about 65 years through Caltex, a joint venture that sells petroleum products in Asia.
For all their similarities in strategy, their corporate cultures are said to be quite different. Chevron is considered by some to be buttoned-up and staid, while Texaco is thought of as more free-wheeling.
But it may be Chevron's culture that prevails. The new corporate headquarters will be in San Francisco, where Chevron is now based, and the combined company's chairman and chief executive will be David J. O'Reilly, now Chevron's chief. Texaco's chief executive, Peter I. Bijur, will become a vice chairman, with few operational duties.
"I don't expect there to be much of a corporate clash," one analyst said. "I think Chevron will be the surviving company and Peter Bijur and the others will be happy to take their money and sit on the board."

A news analysis article yesterday about Chevron's acquisition of Texaco misstated the companies' relationship to the Middle East. Both companies indeed have operations there.
Articles on Oct. 14 and 16 and a front-page chart on Oct. 16 about the acquisition of Texaco Inc. by the Chevron Corporation misstated the total 1999 revenue for the companies. Including their Caltex joint venture, which sells petroleum products in Asia, the combined revenue for the companies was $85 billion, not $66.5 billion.

HEADLINE: SCIENTIST AT WORK: Joan Roughgarden;
A Theorist With Personal Experience Of the Divide Between the Sexes

BYLINE: By CAROL KAESUK YOON 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
Speaking to a standing room only crowd at the annual meeting of the Ecological Society of America in Snowbird, Utah, Dr. Joan Roughgarden, one of the world's most influential theoretical ecologists, is methodically taking apart the way that biologists think about sex.
Providing details that make some titter and shift nervously in their seats, she is re-thinking orgasms and the architecture of female genitals, making arguments for the existence of more than two genders and presenting evidence for widespread homosexual copulation in the wild. 
 "What's coming out now is to the rest of the species what the Kinsey Report was to humans," she says later, discussing recent research.
Described as a visionary and iconoclast who consistently ignores disciplinary and conceptual boundaries, Dr. Roughgarden always draws a good crowd. But on this August day the room is packed, in part because this is not just more talk about science, but the outgrowth of a personal experience that two years ago riveted this entire community of scientists.
That was when Dr. Roughgarden crossed the most rigidly enforced boundary of all, the divide between the sexes. Born Jonathan Roughgarden, she became Joan in the spring of 1998 -- a profound transformation that has led her not only onto new paths in science but into San Francisco politics as well.
"People are wrapping their minds around this," said Dr. Roughgarden of re-meeting colleagues. "They don't quite know what to say."
Whatever they may have been thinking about Dr. Roughgarden herself, the ecologists at the meeting seemed to welcome the new work, though it remains to be seen whether her radically different views of sex and mating will take hold, or be dismissed.
"This is the usual sort of mold-breaking creativity that she brings to a problem, not just this problem," said Dr. Steve Pacala, an ecologist at Princeton. "Just because she broke her own mold it's particularly applicable here, but the kind of thing she always does with a problem is think about it afresh."
For those who knew Dr. Jonathan Roughgarden well, and the many more who knew him only through his prolific production of scientific papers and books, it came as a much-discussed surprise when this Stanford professor, then 52, announced on his Web site that he was a transsexual, posting pictures of himself as Joan.
"It became clear to me that I wasn't ever going to figure out how to do the guy thing," Dr. Roughgarden said. She believes that gender is a matter of cognition, an instinctive ability and desire to learn a certain way of being, she said. "Imagine as a woman if you'd set out to be a man, to learn how to live as a man. Could you do it? I couldn't. It's like asking a fish to fly."
She said the light dawned on her one day as she sat in a department faculty meeting. "There were all these guys around this table, staking out their territories and going at one another," she said. "After a while I said, you know, this is not a battle you want to win. You don't want to be like them."
But as Jonathan, Dr. Roughgarden, who in her own mind has always identified herself as female, was universally regarded as the quintessential macho academic: aggressive, abrasive and competitive.
"Aggressiveness is the easiest male trait to emulate," she explained in a recent interview at her apartment in San Francisco, where she has taken the unusual step for a high-powered academic of running for a public office. "It's easy to duplicate."
Such behavior, along with the talent to back it up, can play well in the male-dominated world of theoretical ecology, in which scientists study ecology using mathematical models, and in which Jonathan Roughgarden was at the top of his game.
"I don't think there are a lot of people who have been so influential or sweeping in their approach," said Dr. Ted Case, a theoretical ecologist at University of California at San Diego.
The transformation to Joan, Dr. Case said, appears not to have diminished Dr. Roughgarden's status in the field. Her gift, he said, is "to look at the natural world and convert it to math." He added, "I've looked forward to a new paper by Joan or Jon the way the world looks forward to the next Harry Potter book."
Known for her itinerant interests, Dr. Roughgarden has boiled down into mathematical expression complex ecological phenomena, including what drives some species to produce many offspring and others to produce just a few, and how predators decide which prey to chase and which to let scramble away.
And, unlike most theoreticians, Dr. Roughgarden has gotten her hands dirty doing field studies, looking, for example, at competition between lizards on the Caribbean islands. Even now, in addition to her work on sex and gender, she continues work on very different projects, including developing a theory on the relationship between economics and ecology.
In many ways, Dr. Roughgarden's transition to life as a woman mirrors that of other transsexuals. Tall, slender and somewhat androgynous looking, she has spent two years preoccupied with her physical appearance as she made the transition from one gender to another. Over the same period, she also settled into a softer, more traditionally feminine demeanor.
Moderating a discussion at the meetings in Snowbird, she operated as colleagues said Jonathan never would have: seeking out consensus, affirming others' opinions, welcoming dialogue.
Other scientists universally describe Joan as friendlier, more nurturing and significantly happier-seeming than Jon.
"I've seen Joan smile more in two years than I saw Jon smile in the last 20," said Dr. Paul Ehrlich, an ecologist and longtime colleague of Dr. Roughgarden's at Stanford.
Dr. Roughgarden insists she is in many ways entirely unchanged. She acknowledges, however, that life as a woman is quite different.
"At first I was amused," Dr. Roughgarden said, describing how she is now much more frequently interrupted, ignored and condescended to by men, particularly those who did not know her as Jonathan. "I thought, if women are discriminated against, then I'm darn well going to be discriminated against the same way. Well, the thrill of that's worn off, I can tell you."
Dr. Roughgarden's transformation is leading toward what she hopes will be a change in how biologists think about gender, courtship and reproduction.
In the world view of nearly all biologists, there are males and there are females and they mate only with one another. Dr. Roughgarden likewise had not questioned these most basic of premises. But that began to change when, seeking to understand what science could tell her about herself as a transsexual, she began reviewing the literature. She presents her results in "Evolution's Rainbow," a book to be published by Princeton University Press.
What she found, she said, was that biologists have been unsuccessfully trying to cram the immense variation in nature -- the rainbows, as she calls them, both in gender and mating -- into overly simple, outdated categories.
"There are two sexes," she said, meaning females that produce large reproductive cells like eggs and males that produce small ones, like sperm. "But how you package those sexes is all over the waterfront."
Hermaphrodites, for example, which can produce both eggs and sperm, do not fit the standard male or female definitions, yet they are widespread in nature. In some species, male-female lines are blurred where sexual identities are flexible.
In fish known as wrasses, for example, some large females change into males later in life and have harems of females, while small males remain male for life, mating with females under the large males' control. Some females remain female for life.
Curiously, Dr. Roughgarden noted, biologists consider females that turn into large males to be the standard males while the life-long males are considered "sneakers" and are described as having an alternative mating strategy.
In Dr. Roughgarden's framework, rather than designate any type as the normal or alternative, scientists would recognize the fundamental difference between these three differently sexed, shaped, sized and behaving fish and designate them as different genders.
Dr. Roughgarden said scientists had also been shockingly blind to same-sex mating.
"There are 303 published examples of species with same-sex courtship," she said of behaviors typically discounted as anomalies. "We know examples are suppressed. No one wants to say the organism they work on is gay."
Rather than view mating through the conventional lens of sexual selection, in which competing males vie for choosy females and in which same-sex courtship becomes invisible, she suggests biologists think instead in terms of the evolution of courtship and mating in general -- between males, between females as well as between females and males. In fact, Dr. Roughgarden argues that same-sex copulation is so widespread that scientists must test the idea that, rather than being a mistake, homosexual behaviors may have some advantages in an evolutionary sense.
Just as she hopes the work of gay and transsexual scientists will improve the scientific understanding of sex and mating, Dr. Roughgarden said she believed a wide diversity of perspectives would lead to better governance. For that reason, she is running for the half-time, city council-like position of district supervisor for District 6, which includes some of the poorest parts of San Francisco.
"I got tired of people saying we need to convince the politicians," she said, referring to the common lament of scientists who feel their perspective is lost or misunderstood by politicians and the public. "Instead of trying to convince them, let's just do it."
Walking through the district with Dr. Roughgarden, one sees the beginnings of what is promised to be a upscale new development, called Mission Bay, which includes a new University of California campus. It sits alongside neighborhoods where homeless people sleep in doorways and others pick through the trash.
"Some ecological thinking could really help," said Dr. Roughgarden, who has promised to use her expertise in the analyses of complex systems to rethink the growth of District 6. She has already crunched the numbers.
"The displacement of people will be enormous," she said."And they're not going to go quietly."
To create more of a sense of community between the new campus and the rest of the district, Dr. Roughgarden is proposing that two large piers extending into the bay near the university be developed as Diversity Plaza, home to a statue celebrating diversity. "I imagine it as the West Coast's equivalent to the Statue of Liberty," she said.
Hank Wilson, a longtime community activist and a friendly competitor running for the same office, said Dr. Roughgarden, a political novice, and Diversity Plaza had captured people's imagination. "Joan is on people's radar screen," he said.
Always mathematically minded, Dr. Roughgarden notes that with 17 candidates vying for the position and no incumbent, everyone theoretically has a chance. Still, considered a dark horse, she remains philosophical about where she has come from and where she is going.
"One thing I've learned is that almost all professional women have had a very nonlinear path to get where they are," said Dr. Roughgarden, who said she intended to pursue her science whatever the outcome on Nov. 7. "It's taken me a while to get here, but we've all got a story."

HEADLINE: As Greenland's Seal Population Surges Its Fishermen Look to Revive the Hunt

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: KAPISILLIT, Greenland

 BODY:
Over a bowl of caribou stew in his wooden house overlooking a fjord here, Kaaleeraq Ringsted, an Inuit hunter and fisherman, remarked on a new arrival in his timeless world of glaciers and icebergs: seals, seals and more seals.
"When I was young, you would rarely see seals here," the wiry 48-year-old recalled through a Greenlandic-speaking interpreter. "Now, when spring comes, the big seals come in and eat all the fish. Because of the number of seals in the fjord now, I have to go farther and farther out to fish." 
 In decades past, his father would hunt seals, earning a tidy profit catering to tastes for fashionable fur coats in Europe and the United States.
But anti-fur campaigners, particularly opponents of the annual Canadian baby seal hunt, have virtually destroyed the sealskin fur market, so today Mr. Ringsted hunts harp seals only for meat for his family; usually, he throws the pelts away.
But as fisheries suffer and Greenlanders seek a way to stay on the land, people here argue that prices would rise if the United States would lift a ban imposed almost 30 years ago on imports of seal products.
With an estimated 5.5 million harp seals swimming off the western shores of Greenland -- about 100 for each Greenlander -- no government argues that harp seals are endangered or even threatened. And by the time seals make the 1,200-mile swim from Atlantic Canada to Greenland, they are considered adult seals.
"Greenlanders do not kill baby seals," Jonathan Motzfeldt, the island's premier, said, speaking slowly for effect. "Because we do not have baby seals."
But imports of seal products into the United States are banned by the Marine Mammal Protection Act of 1972, a law that was drawn up partly out of revulsion over the clubbing of seal pups in Canada. (That hunt itself is on the decline. Last spring, about 80,000 pups were killed, 40 percent of the levels of the late 1990's, according to the Canadian government.)
In 1998, Greenlanders hunting off their western coast in what they call "the ranch of the sea," killed 82,500 harp seals, about 1.5 percent of the estimated population.
Biologists and government officials here say the seal population is expanding so rapidly that many more could be hunted without threatening the species.
"We have two legs for our economy to stand on: seals and fish," said Mikaela Engel, a foreign affairs spokesman for Greenland's home rule government. But with the decline of seal hunting, he said, "there are a gazillion seals swimming around, and they are eating our fish."
There is widespread agreement with this view. "The seals are very numerous," said Klaus Nygaard, director of the Greenland Institute of Natural Resources. "They are actually creating problems with the fishing industry."
In Newfoundland, many fishermen blame seals, at least in part, for the collapse of the Grand Banks cod fishery. A Canadian government study in 1994 calculated that each year 4.5 million harp seals eat 140,000 tons of cod, or 2 billion fish.
In Nunavut, Canada's new Arctic territory, Inuit living across the Davis Strait from Greenland also complain about seals. "There are too many harp seals," said Peter Kilabuk, a former national park ranger who is now the territory's minister for sustainable development. "The fishermen are concerned about them eating up the char," a popular food fish.
But not everyone agrees.
"Fewer seals means more fish -- that is the simple-minded view," said Dr. David Lavigne of Guelph, Ontario, a marine biologist who advises the International Fund for Animal Welfare, an animal protection group. "We have a population that swims across international borders and is hunted by two countries with no joint agreement for a sustainable hunt."
Dr. Lavigne, a lifelong seal specialist, estimates that as many as half a million seals are killed each year between Canada and Greenland, including seals caught in fishing nets, seals shot but not reported by Inuit and hunted seals that escape and drown. If the United States ever lifted the ban on seal products, he warned, numbers would spiral upward.
Though market prices for seal pelts remain low, partly because of the American ban, there are signs of change.
The royal family of Denmark, the colonial power here, has helped touch off a minor sealskin revival by wearing stylishly cut seal fur coats in Copenhagen.
With Europeans allowed to buy seal products, shops in Greenland's larger towns and airport merchants display racks of sealskin fur coats, jackets, scarves, hats, gloves and boots.
"Some Americans are morally upset that we sell them here," said Bodil Nielsen, a Danish saleswoman at a fur shop at Kangerlussuaq, Greenland's international air hub. "Other Americans say it is a shame they can't buy."
For a people who have survived for generations on the forbidding fringes of this landmass covered with ice and snow, the lectures from environmental groups about seal hunting are often taken as intrusive -- yet another example of meddling from a long line of outsiders.
This colonialist history, they say, began with 18th century Danish missionaries and merchants, continued with European and North American whalers who almost wiped out seal and whale populations and appeared most recently in the form of American military officers dotting this island with cold war bases.
The talk is particularly galling given that, according to the Greenland National Museum, Greenlanders have hunted seals as their primary food supply for roughly 4,400 years, and hunting seals is deeply imbedded in their culture.
In Nuuk, the capital, the premier's waiting room is decorated with four harpoons on a wall.
In an interview in his office, Premier Motzfeldt noted that he had been seal hunting several days earlier. "I got three seals -- enough for me and my three friends to have enough meat for 14 days," he said through a Danish interpreter.
Mr. Motzfeldt, who has been premier for most of the years since Greenland won home rule from Denmark in 1979, said that selling furs was one of a few economic activities that would anchor people like Mr. Ringsted to small villages like Kapisillit as Greenland's urbanization rate has soared, from 25 percent in 1950 to 81 percent today.
"Twenty years ago, a lot of people in small settlements made a good living, partly by hunting seals, partly by fishing," said Jorge Waever Johansen, minister of social welfare and employment. "Now one of those legs has collapsed."
The collapse in economic value of hunting has debilitated native societies across the Arctic, according to Aqqaluk Lynge, president of the Inuit Circumpolar Conference, an international group that represents 150,000 Inuit in Greenland, Canada, Alaska and Russia.
Noting high native suicide rates in Greenland and northern Canada, Mr. Lynge said: "If a man doesn't hunt, he isn't man enough to be husband to anyone. It has a devastating impact."
In recent years, some American critics of the seal hunt have suggested that Greenlanders try cattle ranching instead. But, Greenland's climate and geography do not allow much animal husbandry beyond a few sheep farms near the island's southern tip.
"I suppose we could play the indigenous card," Ms. Engel, the diplomat, mused sardonically. "People will want to watch us row up and strangle animals with our bare hands. Then, they will pay us with mirrors and shiny beads."
Mr. Lynge, who once had his sealskin vest confiscated by American customs agents as he entered the United States to attend an Inuit congress in Alaska, put it another way. "Save the seals, O.K.," he said. "But how about saving the Eskimos?"

LENGTH: 1152 words

HEADLINE: The Mixed Prospects of Indonesia

BYLINE: By WAYNE ARNOLD 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 15

 BODY:
The Indonesian government, which presides over the weakest of Southeast Asia's economies, is rebuffing criticism from international donors even as it approaches them for $4.8 billion in assistance.
The Consultative Group on Indonesia, an umbrella organization headed by the World Bank and including roughly 30 foreign governments, will meet Indonesian officials in Tokyo this week to decide how much the group will lend to Indonesia and under what conditions. 
 The meeting, which begins on Tuesday, comes against the backdrop of further decline in Indonesian political stability. President Abdurrahman Wahid, hobbled by two strokes and blindness in one eye, has largely failed to contain ethnic violence in far-flung areas or to prevent attacks on aid workers in West Timor. A series of bombings, most notably a blast last month under the Jakarta Stock Exchange, has unnerved investors further and left many wondering if the government is able to salvage what has become the worst-performing economy in the region.
At the same time, questions from the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank about a government plan to take over the country's largest corporate debtor have provoked angry remarks from Indonesian officials, who accuse the international lenders of favoritism and interference. Jakarta officials have also rebuffed some United Nations demands on West Timor despite warnings from Britain and the United States that lending could be held up over this matter.
The nation's chief economics minister, Rizal Ramli, was in Tokyo last week to seek assurances from Japan, Indonesia's biggest lender, that it would not let political issues stand in the way of aid. Japanese finance ministry officials reportedly favor keeping noneconomic issues out of the discussions.
The consultative group's pledges are an important gauge of international support for economic recovery, and any sign that support is wavering could batter Indonesia's already fragile financial markets.
Nonetheless, some economists and analysts say that the group has lost much of its leverage over Indonesian policy because members have too much riding on economic recovery to deny the country further funds.
"Indonesia at the end of the day has a very big strategic importance in the region," said Vincent Low, first vice president for fixed-income research and strategy at Merrill Lynch in Singapore. "From a geopolitical point of view, it's too big to fail."
Moreover, Indonesia's government owes the rest of the world more than $60 billion, so much of the donor group's pledges go toward servicing existing debt. Indonesian annual foreign debt payments are the equivalent of about two-thirds of the group's pledge, said David G. Fernandez, a J. P. Morgan economist.
Indonesia is counting on the international loans to offset roughly 40 percent of its expected budget deficit next year. High prices for Indonesian oil, however, may reduce the country's need for some of the aid. The proposed budget prices crude oil at $22 a barrel, while oil is now trading around $35 a barrel. Conservative estimates of that sort enabled Indonesia to finance its budget deficit this year without drawing on the credit line from the consultative group's lenders.
And despite continued separatist violence, religious strife and political instability, Indonesia's economic recovery still appears to be on track. Many economists predict growth of at least 4 percent in 2001, with the World Bank noting that wages, adjusted for inflation, are rising, and demand for cars, electricity and building materials like cement are increasing, as well.
That is good news to Indonesian creditors, especially Japan. Lenders there account for more than 30 percent of the Indonesian government's foreign debt, according to the World Bank, and Japan is offering to contribute more than $1.5 billion of the group's total pledge this week.
Indonesia's bargaining position in Tokyo may, therefore, seem strong, but economists warn that its financial situation is still precarious. "Financial markets remain unconvinced by developments in the real economy," said the World Bank's regional vice president, Jemaluddin Kassum, who will preside at the meeting in Tokyo. Indonesia's currency, the rupiah, has fallen about 20 percent since the start of the year and stock prices, down 40 percent in local-currency terms, are at their lowest level in a year and a half.
Unlike in the United States, though, falling markets here have little impact on consumer confidence; most Indonesians do not own stocks. But such developments make it harder for Indonesia to hold up its end of financing the budget deficit.
The country's bank restructuring agency, which controls assets equivalent to more than half the economy, is also responsible for plugging roughly half the budget deficit by selling some of those assets. The agency recently postponed plans to sell one of its most highly prized assets, Bank Central Asia, citing poor market conditions.
The delay upset the I.M.F., which had set the bank's sale this year as one of the terms for its own, separate $5 billion assistance program. The I.M.F. and foreign investors say the orderly sale of the agency's repossessed assets is important in reviving investor interest in Indonesia. But concerns that foreigners would be able to purchase national assets at fire-sale prices arouse nationalist furor here.
The latest source of disillusionment among investors was a deal late last month by the bank restructuring agency to take over a textile and engineering company, Texmaco, to recover $2.7 billion in debts the company owes it. Because the deal eventually puts the company's politically connected management back in charge, critics are calling it a bailout.
The Texmaco controversy opened a rift between the government and the World Bank and I.M.F., after the leak of a letter to Mr. Ramli from the two organizations urging Indonesia to obtain a second opinion. Mr. Ramli, who before his appointment as economics minister this year was a prominent critic of the I.M.F., accused it and the World Bank of discriminating against President Wahid's government.
Many Indonesian politicians suspect that other conglomerates were given unduly favorable treatment under the administration of Mr. Wahid's predecessor, B. J. Habibie, when the bank restructuring agency had a much closer relationship with the I.M.F. and Western financial advisers.
Despite the rancor, the World Bank has taken pains to emphasize Indonesia's progress and explain the country's turmoil as an inevitable side effect of its newly minted democracy. Analysts here say that with so much at stake, little rebuke in practical terms is to be expected from the donors' meeting in Tokyo.
"Nobody's going to sink Indonesia's first democratic government in 50 years," a Western banking official said. "Not in its first year."

HEADLINE: OBSERVATORY

BYLINE: By HENRY FOUNTAIN 

 BODY:

Earthquake Threat
 Residents of the Central Mississippi Valley are on something of a roller coaster ride -- a slow roller coaster ride -- when it comes to the threat of large earthquakes.
The New Madrid fault zone, a 100-mile stretch along the Mississippi River from Missouri to Arkansas, has been the site of several large earthquakes over the past 1,500 years, including three powerful ones in 1811-1812 when, fortunately, there were comparatively few people around. The question has been whether the area, which now includes St. Louis and Memphis, can expect another strong earthquake anytime soon. 
 The issue appeared to have been resolved last year, when a study by a Northwestern University geologist showed almost no ground movement in the fault zone, suggesting that it would take at least 1,000 years, and possibly much longer, for enough strain to build up for a devastating earthquake to occur.
But a new study in the journal Science by researchers at the California Institute of Technology and Stanford suggests that a quake could occur much sooner. The surface may not be moving much, these researchers say, but stress is building up below.
The researchers say that the earlier study applied the ground-movement data to a fault model similar to that found at the edges of tectonic plates, while the New Madrid zone is in the middle of one. The scientists developed a new model for such a region, called an intraplate zone, suggesting that strain builds up in a weak area below the surface and eventually shifts to the surface, where it causes a rupture in the fault.
The scientists put the time between such ruptures at 250 to 4,000 years, meaning a strong quake could occur as early as the middle of this century.

Land of Sprawl
Earthquakes are more certain in California, and the joke has been that someday half the state will slide into the ocean. But California is already losing land in a different way.
A new report by the state's Department of Conservation says about 70,000 acres of open space was lost to urban and suburban sprawl over a two-year period ending in 1998 -- a 25 percent increase over the previous two years. The state's booming economy and population growth are to blame, officials said.
Southern California, the region that put sprawl on the map, lost the most open space, nearly half the state total, followed by the San Joaquin Valley and the San Francisco Bay area.
Of the acreage lost (an area about five times the size of Manhattan), about 60 percent was farmland. Since California now supplies more than 50 percent of the country's fruits and vegetables, loss of farmland is cause for some concern nationally. The report did, however, show an increase in the amount of irrigated farmland in some areas. But this was mostly in form of vineyards.

Salt of Antarctica
There is still plenty of open space in Antarctica, including the Dry Valleys, landforms curiously devoid of the ice and snow that smothers the rest of continent.
In addition to being dry, the valleys, which are near McMurdo Sound, are very salty. Researchers have long debated where the salts, including sulfates, came from. Some believe it was sea salt blown from the oceans; others hold it was the legacy of an ancient sea that covered the region.
A report in Nature offers convincing evidence that the salt does originate in the oceans around Antarctica, but not largely from sea salt. Instead, by examining the composition of oxygen isotopes in the sulfates, researchers from the University of California at San Diego discovered that they come from sulfur-belching marine algae. The sulfur gas is oxidized in the atmosphere and deposited as sulfates in the valleys.
Since the Dry Valleys are about the closest thing to Mars on Earth, the researchers say their findings could have implications for the search for signs of life on Mars, to see how similar phenomena may have occurred there.
