HEADLINE: WORLD BUSINESS: When Greenland Exports, It's Ice;
Bottled Water and Cube Sales to Seekers of Boutique Purity

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: NUUK, Greenland

 BODY:
For Greenland's 55,000 people, the defining fact of life has always been the ice sheet, a mammoth expanse nearly three times the size of Texas that blankets 85 percent of their island. Now, entrepreneurs on this Arctic frontier think they have figured out how to capitalize on the icecap.
Three companies are drawing up business plans to export to Europe and the United States the No. 1 resource of Greenland: pure water. Building on one company's pioneering sales in Europe of Greenland ice, they hope romantics will want to sip drinks mixed with water or chilled with ice cubes that first fell as snow when Cleopatra made eyes at Marc Antony. Health buffs, they hope, will want to drink crystalline water that has been locked in the icecap for thousands of years, long before humans started pumping pollutants into the atmosphere. 
 Here in Greenland's capital, a Scandinavian-style town of 14,000, people have watched enviously as Canada, 350 miles away, supplanted France in 1998 to become the leading exporter of bottled water to the United States. With world bottled-water consumption increasing by 10 percent annually in recent years, Greenlanders say they believe that there is plenty of room for their premium-price offerings.
"The purity of our water is perfect," Vagn Andersen, a 30-year veteran of Greenland's business scene, said over breakfast here recently. "Now we have a real possibility to help the country."
Mr. Andersen is the managing director of one of the new enterprises, Greenland Water Production, which has an ambitious goal of bottling near here as much as 500 million liters of water a year, or 132 million gallons, the equivalent of Canada's water exports to the United States last year.
On Aug. 24, a new Canadian-Greenlandic joint venture, Aquapolaris, announced that it had been granted a license to export glacial meltwater by tanker from a waterfall a few miles east of here.
A third company, Greenland Ice Cap Production, started exporting ice to Europe in 1997. "Put the bright, sparkling ice diamonds in your glass, and hear the soft whispering sound of the past," says an advertisement in Britain for "Greenland icecap rocks."
It continues, "You will be fascinated by the sound of past millenniums, and your thoughts will flow lightly." The company expects to complete negotiations with an American investor by the end of October to start exporting glacial meltwater.
Greenland's home-rule Parliament is expected early in November to approve a framework for long-term licenses of water exports. Treating water like oil, Greenland legislators may impose royalties on bulk water exports or may favor operations that create jobs by bottling water locally.
In Canada, most provinces have banned bulk water sales, largely from fear of causing environmental damage for relatively little economic gain. Maurice J. Murphy, chief operating officer of Aquapolaris, works out of an office in Newfoundland, where such a ban was imposed last year.
Under the Aquapolaris plan, tankers that can hold as much as 150,000 tons would steam up Nuuk's fjord and take water by pipe from the waterfall. The venture, Mr. Murphy said, would invest up to $2 million for mooring facilities and "will create a fair bit of employment."
In contrast, Mr. Andersen, whose company is backed by a Copenhagen entrepreneur and a former Danish interior minister, proposes that Greenland Water Production be granted a 25-year monopoly for the export of drinking water from Greenland, with share ownership widely held by Greenlanders.
"We are definitely working against bulk water exports," he said of his company's lobbying efforts. "There is no money in that for Greenland. This is Greenland water. It should be bottled here, and sold as made in Greenland."
Mr. Andersen's project would draw water from a lake seven miles southeast of here that is fed by three glaciers. Using a maximum of 5 percent of the lake's intake, Greenland Water Production would send water by pipe to a bottling plant in Nuuk.
High shipping costs routinely present obstacles for business projects in Greenland, 2,000 miles west of Denmark, the island's colonial and economic power.
But Mr. Andersen said that a new technology would allow one-liter plastic bottles to be shipped collapsed into the size of salt shakers. Filled bottles would go to Denmark weekly in a Royal Arctic Line freighter that brings food and supplies to Nuuk and that generally leaves here nearly empty, often taking on seawater as ballast. Bottles of Greenland water could be delivered to supermarkets in Northern Europe for about 25 cents a liter, he calculated, about 95 cents a gallon. Delivery to North America is also possible, he said.
Greenland Ice Cap Production, a privately held company run by a prominent local businessman, Kaj Egede, is planning both bottled and bulk water exports. The company has been mining two-ton blocks of ice from a glacier near Narsaq, about 15 miles southeast of Nuuk, and plans to start selling the water obtained as a byproduct of its icecap rock operations.
Some people may have environmental concerns about using the water from ancient ice. But the entrepreneurs note that there is plenty to go around. For starters, the ice sheet is thick, two miles deep in some places and shrinking by 11 cubic miles a year -- not much considering its magnitude, with an estimated weight of 2.5 quadrillion tons.
By such measures, the amount of water the three companies expect to take is minuscule. Greenland Ice Cap Production mines about 2,000 tons of ice a year near Narsaq.
Aquapolaris, the joint venture that wants to export the waterfall's water, is partly owned by Allan Idd Jensen, a Nuuk shipping company executive, and the Iceberg Corporation of America, which is based in Newfoundland. The Canadian company has been taking ice from icebergs floating south from Greenland, and hopes to triple its water production next year to 10,000 tons.
"There are approximately 2,000 icebergs that come past Newfoundland each year," said Mr. Murphy, who is also the Iceberg corporation's vice president for engineering. A single iceberg, he said, is sufficient for the Canadian operation for several years.
According to Mr. Murphy, once icebergs are in international waters, they are fair game. His company and its affiliates have used the ice for more than three years to produce bottled water, or as an ingredient for alcohol. Its beer and vodka are sold in North America under the Borealis Iceberg label. Aquapolaris plans to sell bulk water from the waterfall in new markets yet to be determined.
In Scandinavia and Britain, bags of Greenland icecap rocks are marketed as luxury products, according to Philip Hughes, proprietor of the Ice Box Ltd., a major London supplier.
The cachet? "It is the aesthetics," he said. "Sometimes, restaurant-produced ice is murky. This is clearer. You get this sparkling effect as it releases oxygen."
But now, only seven months after Greenland Ice introduced its products in Britain, London shops are cutting retail prices in half, to the equivalent of about $1.25 a pound -- still a premium price.
Mr. Hughes is undeterred. "We remember when Perrier came to the U.K., and no one in England would drink mineral water," he said. "Now, the industry is moving billions of liters a year."

HEADLINE: Production In September Rose, but Pace Was Slower

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17

 BODY:
Industrial production slowed in September from a month earlier, closing out the weakest quarterly performance for manufacturers since early last year, Federal Reserve statistics showed today.
Output rose 0.2 percent last month, mainly reflecting increased production of cars and replacement tires for the Explorer sport utility vehicles, made by the Ford Motor Company. That followed a 0.4 percent rise in August. Production in the third quarter rose at a 2.8 percent annual rate, the slowest three-month pace since a 2 percent rise in the first quarter of 1999, when Asian economies were starting to emerge from recession. 
 Higher interest rates, weaker global demand and a resulting buildup of inventories have contributed to a slower pace of growth in manufacturing, which accounts for about one-fifth of the nation's economic output.
"Manufacturing is providing far less support for the economy than earlier in the year," in part reflecting more restrained consumer spending, said Kevin Flanagan, an economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter in New York.
The report backs up an industry survey released on Oct. 2 that showed manufacturing contracted in September for the second consecutive month. That drop reflected the biggest drop in new orders in almost two years, according to the National Association of Purchasing Management.
Analysts expect the manufacturing slowdown to persist in the months ahead because larger inventories and a drop in consumer spending mean fewer goods will need to be produced. Business inventories rose 2 percent in the three months ended in August, according to the Commerce Department. Consumer spending slowed in the second quarter to a 3.1 percent annual rate after rising 7.6 percent in the first three months of the year.
The Fed's production report also pointed to restrained inflation. "There's little inflationary threat from manufacturing," said Christopher Low, an economist at First Tennessee Capital Markets in New York.

HEADLINE: Judge Rules That Tax Shelter Worth $6 Billion Is a Sham

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
A federal judge in Delaware, in a decision made public yesterday, held that one company's corporate tax shelter was a sham and noted that 85 other large corporations used the same deduction to avoid paying $6 billion in corporate income taxes.
Judge Murray Schwartz of United States District Court in Wilmington, Del., ruled that Camelot Music could not deduct interest on loans it took out against life insurance on its 1,430 employees in 1990 through 1993. 
 The decision could affect many of the other 85 companies, which the judge did not identify by name, because his ruling applies to every company organized in Delaware, whose corporate-governance laws have made it a leading center for the nominal headquarters of large companies.
American Electric Power, an electric utility in Columbus, Ohio, has a case involving almost identical issues scheduled to go to trial in two weeks. Pat D. Hemlepp, a spokesman for the company, said that $240 million in taxes were at issue.
The case in which the ruling was issued Monday, and made public yesterday, involved Camelot Music, which was bought by the Trans World Entertainment Corporation of Albany last year for $451.9 million.
Camelot took out life insurance from the Hartford Group beginning in 1990 on its 1,430 workers. The company paid for the insurance, taking a deduction for this expense, and then borrowed back the premium through a loan against the insurance policy. On its corporate income tax returns the company took $13.8 million of deductions in 1990 through 1993 tax returns for interest it paid on the loans.
Judge Schwartz said that there was no buildup in the cash value of the insurance policies and because of the way the loans were structured there was no reasonable prospect that the company would profit from buying the insurance.
He called the arrangement "a factual sham" that "lacked objective economic substance and a subjective business purpose other than the tax benefits flowing from the interest deductions."
The judge said the deal "crossed the line" on permissible deductions by such a wide margin that the Internal Revenue Service was right to impose penalties for filing an inaccurate tax return.
John Sullivan, Trans World Entertainment's chief financial officer, said that if the decision stood it would cost the company about $8 million plus interest. "I'm surprised by the ruling," Mr. Sullivan said, adding that he expected the company would appeal the decision.
The Camelot Music and American Electric Power cases are similar to the corporate-owned life insurance policy tax shelter of Winn-Dixie Stores, a big supermarket chain, that a tax court judge demolished last year in an 81-page opinion.

HEADLINE: MANAGEMENT: Getting Religion On Corporate Ethics;
A Scourge of Scandals Leaves Its Mark

BYLINE: By AMY ZIPKIN 

 BODY:
Archer Daniels Midland pleaded guilty to a price-fixing conspiracy that cost consumers millions of dollars a year in higher prices for soft drinks and detergents. It agreed to pay a $100 million fine.
Royal Dutch/Shell scrapped plans for sinking a North Sea oil rig that environmentalists contended was contaminated. Later, Shell was accused of colluding with the Nigerian government in the oppression of the Ogoni people and failing to speak out against the execution of one of their leaders. 
 And now, Bridgestone/Firestone and the Ford Motor Company are apologizing to American consumers for a pattern of deadly tire failures, while blaming each other for the debacle.
Almost every year, it seems, some scandal envelops a Fortune 500 company and causes a new spasm of public distrust of big corporations. This year's occurrence probably should not be surprising; in the competitive marketplace, the temptation to cut ethical corners can be hard to resist.
Lately, however, corporate America seems to be doing more than just paying lip service to standards of management behavior. For all the controversy surrounding the Firestone/Ford tire recall, and the questions it raises about the potential for corporate wrongdoing, a growing number of big companies are enacting strict ethical guidelines and backing them up with internal mechanisms to enforce them. While some consider the changes little more than window dressing, there is no doubt that change is afoot.
The corporate title of ethics officer, for example, almost unknown a decade ago, has become almost as familiar as chief information officer. The Ethics Officer Association, a trade group in Belmont, Mass., says membership has soared to 706 today from 12 in 1992.
Moreover, the job description of ethics officers has expanded from ombudsman to policy maker, corporate governance experts say. "Instead of being a corporate policeman, ethics officers are becoming corporate coaches for ethical decision making," said Martin Taylor, vice president for corporate services at the Institute for Global Ethics in Camden, Me.
And ethical matters are now debated at much higher levels. A 1999 Conference Board study of 124 companies in 22 countries found that directors are now much more involved in the creation of ethical standards. While only 21 percent of the policies in existence in 1987 showed board involvement, participation had increased to 41 percent in 1991 and now is up to 78 percent of the cases.
Critics say, however, that the rush by corporations to portray themselves as exemplary citizens often leads nowhere. A strongly written ethics policy "will be acknowledged as positive simply by its being there," said Barbara Ley Toffler, a management consultant who has written about ethics.
Skeptics also say the ethics movement has a dark side: intrusion into the private lives of employees. In their zeal to discourage workplace misbehavior -- from using company e-mail for personal purposes to sexual harassment -- some companies are snooping on employee's e-mail and telephone use and even installing video cameras.
"When American workers go to work they lose almost all of their personal privacy," said Charles J. Sykes, a research fellow at the Hoover Institution in Palo Alto, Calif.
Nobody doubts that companies are motivated to join the ethics crusade partly to polish their image. But the commitment goes deeper than that for a very practical reason, corporate governance experts say: taking a strong ethical stand helps shield senior officers from legal troubles.
First came the publication in 1991 of the Justice Department's sentencing guidelines, which in effect promised more lenient treatment for convicted corporate executives if their companies had established good-citizenship ethics programs. Then in 1995, the Delaware Court of Chancery warned that corporate directors could be held personally liable for subordinates' wrongdoing if they had failed to establish programs to ensure compliance with the law.
In addition to legal considerations, public opinion is prodding corporations to be more vigilant about their social and environmental responsibilities. "There's a feeling corporations are more powerful and larger all the time, using the power for their own narrow selfish concerns," said Daniel Yankelovich, the chairman of DYG Inc., a market research firm. "For the last 15 years, business has had a respite from mistrust and suspicion because there's a great deal of growth in the economy, but that's beginning to change. There's a yellow light flashing."
An increasing number of companies are conducting so-called social audits of their policies and practices. In these studies, they try to identify ethical lapses committed in the past and set directives for avoiding similar missteps in the future.
In response to criticisms of its actions in Nigeria and elsewhere, for example, Shell has issued "The Shell Report." The paper opens with a pledge by its chairman, Mark Moody-Stuart, to pursue a business strategy "that generates profits while contributing to the well-being of the planet and its people."
The report, which Shell has posted on the Internet, identifies initiatives that it is taking to prevent wrongdoing by employees. For example, it said enforcement of its policy against bribe-taking had resulted in four dismissals and one resignation, though it did not provide details.
And Shell says it has hired the accounting and consulting firms KPMG and PricewaterhouseCoopers to verify the steps it is taking to ensure the health and safety of its workers and to protect the environment, like cleaning up oil spills.
"There was no book on this. We had to invent it for ourselves and looked at business principles line by line, clause by clause," said Mark Wade, a founding member of the task force that developed the company's environmental and social policies and issued the report.
Mattel Inc., the toy maker, embarked on a social audit three years ago that it named the Mattel Independent Monitoring Council. An advisory panel, made up entirely of company outsiders, including Murray Weidenbaum, the former chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, spent a year creating 200 workplace standards, including the length of breaks and the number of restrooms for workers at its plants.
Mattel said it especially wanted to make sure none of its overseas plants were exploiting workers. While the company said that it found none that were, it did uncover accounting infractions and air-quality abuses at some factories and made sure the local managers corrected them. The panel detailed those incidents in its report.
Elsewhere, companies are requiring employees to take ethics classes. Lockheed Martin, for example, has created a newspaper called Ethics Daily that runs articles based on ethical problems people at the company have faced, then uses those accounts as grist for its training programs. When employee feedback showed more than half the employees surveyed did not report misconduct that they had observed because they feared retaliation, management used the information to create a program on trust.
The Boeing Company requires its rank and file to undergo at least one hour of ethical training a year, and senior managers five hours. Participants must decide the best way to respond to a moral problem, like an outside vendor's offer of free baseball tickets. (The correct answer, even in late October: refuse them.)
"The perception of favoritism is bad in the company," said Gale C. Andrews, Boeing's vice president of ethics and business conduct. "It's important to have a conversation about why employees can't go."
At the McMurray Publishing Company in Phoenix, all 75 employees attend a mandatory meeting every other Monday on workplace ethics. Recently, they discussed their views on how to handle a vendor who had mistakenly delivered real rather than simulated wood and who was requesting an additional $200 to meet the cost. Some said the company should pay the extra money in accordance with its stated principle to "do the right thing," while others argued that it should refuse, to live up to its dictum to "make a reasonable profit." After a split vote, the conversation turned to the topic of resolving conflicting values.
Nonprofit advocacy groups, meantime, are leaning on corporations to make ethics a higher boardroom priority. The Coalition for Environmentally Responsible Economies in Boston, whose members include environmental, public-interest, labor and religious organizations, spent 18 months developing guidelines and spun off a separate group called the Global Reporting Initiative.
Forty-eight companies volunteered to respond to the guidelines, and 21 -- including Bristol-Myers Squibb, Ford, General Motors, Procter & Gamble and Shell -- were selected to analyze and refine them.
The United Nations started a campaign to instill ethical values in the global marketplace. In July, it completed a nine-point Global Compact for protecting the environment, abolishing child labor and supporting free-trade unions, and invited corporations to support it. So far, 44 have.
There is even a movement afoot to make corporations' ethical behavior subject to the same disclosure rules as their financial dealings. The Corporate Sunshine Working Group, made up of social investors, environmentalists and labor unions, is pressing the Securities and Exchange Commission to require companies to release more information about their social and environmental practices to the public.
The two-year-old group says it has held low-level talks with the S.E.C., though so far the discussions have been mostly exploratory. Some experts doubt they will go much beyond that. After all, said Lynn S. Paine, an ethics professor at Harvard Business School, "it took 300 years to develop financial standards."
Even so, ethical standards may be the wave of the future, if only because the right thing to do can also be the profitable thing to do. A 1999 DePaul University study found that companies that publicly proclaimed their commitment to ethical principles did better financially than companies that did not.
"Companies believe social and environmental groups are still outside the mainstream and are looked upon as tree-hugging radicals or aging hippies, but it's a myth," said Curtis C. Verschoor, the accounting professor who wrote the study. "Companies are slow to realize that good ethics is good business."

HEADLINE: Medicare Bill That Favors H.M.O.'s Faces a Veto

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17

 BODY:
The White House said today that President Clinton would veto the latest version of a bill restoring money to Medicare because it gave too much money to health maintenance organizations.
The Clinton administration insisted that Congress shift money from H.M.O.'s to hospitals, home health care agencies and other health care providers. 
 Hospitals would presumably be the chief beneficiaries of the administration's veto threat.
But Richard H. Wade, senior vice president of the American Hospital Association, said tonight, "We are not supporting the veto threat."
Richard J. Pollack, executive vice president of the association, said a veto could imperil billions of dollars in relief for health care providers and the patients they serve.
"We would hope there could be a bipartisan approach to resolve the differences here," Mr. Pollack said. "A veto threat does not engender the bipartisan cooperation needed to enact this important legislation."
If no bill becomes law this year, elderly people could still receive health care under Medicare, but payments to providers would be cut by a 1997 law.
President Clinton contends that many H.M.O.'s are already overpaid by Medicare.
John D. Podesta, the White House chief of staff, said today, "Instead of passing an enforceable patients' bill of rights, Congress is on the verge of giving billions of dollars of Medicare money to the same H.M.O.'s that have fought tooth and nail to defeat patient protections."
Donna E. Shalala, the secretary of health and human services, and Jacob J. Lew, director of the Office of Management and Budget, said they would recommend that President Clinton veto the Medicare bill unless Congress reduced the increases in payments to H.M.O.'s. White House officials said Mr. Clinton would follow that advice.
In a letter to Speaker J. Dennis Hastert, Republican of Illinois, the administration demanded that Congress require H.M.O.'s to stay in the Medicare program and preserve existing benefits for three years.
Chris Jennings, the health policy coordinator at the White House, said: "We insist on accountability. H.M.O.'s say they need more money so they won't have to drop coverage or benefits. We want an assurance that, if they receive more money, they will continue to provide coverage and benefits."
In recent years, many health plans have pulled out of Medicare or reduced benefits, saying their costs outstripped the payments they received from the government. By increasing those payments, Congress hopes to reverse the exodus.
The Medicare bill would raise payments to health care providers by $26 billion to $28 billion over five years. Mr. Podesta said that H.M.O.'s would get "well over a third" of the money.
Representative Bill Thomas, Republican of California, who is chairman of the Ways and Means subcommittee on health, rejected the administration's veto threat as so much bluster.
"A veto of the Medicare relief bill would deny millions of seniors critical access to the health care they need," Mr. Thomas said. "Nearly one million Medicare beneficiaries were dropped from their current health plans last year through no choice or fault of their own."
Medicare provides health care to 39 million elderly or disabled people. To slow the program's growth, Congress in 1997 cut payments to doctors, hospitals and other health care providers. The savings far exceeded what Congress intended.
Members of Congress from both parties have drafted numerous proposals to restore some money cut from Medicare. Payments to hospitals are increased each year to reflect changes in the cost of the goods and services they use. In 1997, Congress ordered that the annual inflation update be cut 1.1 percentage points in 2001 and again in 2002.
Republicans have decided to pay the full update in 2001 and to restore half of the money cut in 2002. The White House said that this was not enough, and that hospitals should receive the full inflation allowance for both years.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: A FLORIDA RACE;
2 Senate Candidates Eagerly Woo Moderates

BYLINE: By RICK BRAGG 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Oct. 12

 BODY:
The nominees for United States Senate here in Florida are grappling for votes from the ideological center by trying to shove each other away from it, the Democrat pushing the Republican farther to the right, the Republican nudging the Democrat toward the left.
It has made for a sometimes nasty contest in one of the year's most closely watched races, where two political veterans seek to fill the vacancy opened by the retirement of a two-term Republican incumbent, Senator Connie Mack. 
 The Democratic nominee, Bill Nelson, former six-term member of the House and now state insurance commissioner, often labels the Republican, Representative Bill McCollum, who has served in the House for 20 years, an extremist who would sacrifice the elderly, the poor and the working class to coddle the rich.
Mr. McCollum, in turn, paints Mr. Nelson as a liberal who would "tax everything that moves, and some things that don't."
In this hardly unique strategy of digging for votes in the middle, Mr. Nelson may have the advantage, because, political experts say, he has much less distance to cover along the spectrum.
As a congressman, "he was known as a fairly moderate Democrat," said Aubrey Jewitt, a professor of political science at the University of Central Florida, "and right now that's a good ideological place to be."
Mr. McCollum, by contrast, has consistently won approval mostly from conservative Republicans, on issues like abortion and gun control.
The race here is crucial to national Democrats' hopes of narrowing the margin of the Republican advantage in the Senate, or perhaps even regaining control there. And a recent statewide survey conducted for The St. Petersburg Times by Schroth & Associates, a polling firm based in Washington, found Mr. Nelson ahead of Mr. McCollum, 45 percent to 34 percent.
Mr. Nelson, of Melbourne, enjoys name recognition around Florida, having run for statewide office four times, unlike Mr. McCollum, of Longwood, near Orlando, who is in his first statewide race.
Mr. McCollum did gain attention as one of the House impeachment prosecutors who made the case for conviction of President Clinton before the Senate. And at one point he was expected to receive a lift from the presidential campaign of Gov. George W. Bush, brother of Florida's governor, Jeb Bush, and initially considered the solid favorite to lay claim to the state's 25 electoral votes. But the Bush campaign has had to fight hard to try to hold off a strong Florida effort by Vice President Al Gore.
Mr. McCollum concedes that he would have been helped had Mr. Bush led strongly throughout the race and then gone on to win here "by 10 or 12 points." But, he adds, he never planned to run on Mr. Bush's momentum.
"We're running our own race," he said. "We have to educate the voters on who I am," and on the difference between himself and Mr. Nelson.
"I believe in better government, not bigger government," Mr. McCollum continued. "He believes in bigger government, more taxation and control over people's lives."
Mr. Nelson readily acknowledges that he has been helped, and his opponent hurt, by Mr. Gore's good fortunes here.
"This was going to be a walk for Bush," Mr. Nelson said, and if that had happened, "I knew it was going to be difficult. It makes me a little more comfortable knowing Al Gore is doing so well."
Mr. Nelson said that his opponent had no choice but to paint him as "liberal, liberal, liberal" but that "that's not my record." At the same time, Mr. Nelson said, "he's trying to make himself into a raging moderate."
Television advertisements do show Mr. McCollum appealing to moderates, saying he is much closer than Mr. Nelson to their ideals.
Those commercials show the candidate tieless. "He's trying to portray a more casual image," Dario Moreno, a professor of political science at Florida International University, said of Mr. McCollum, whom voters have described as too stiff, too brittle, too judgmental.
The two combatants represented neighboring districts as young congressmen back in the 1980's, and voted alike more than half the time.
But by the time Mr. Nelson left the House in 1990 to run for governor, unsuccessfully, Mr. McCollum had long been compiling a solidly conservative record, and not just on social issues. As a member of a committee that investigated the Iran-contra affair, he found nothing wrong in the actions of the Reagan administration. He would go on to harshly criticize the Clinton administration's handling of the attack on the Branch Davidian compound near Waco, Tex., and to vigorously seek the impeachment and removal of Mr. Clinton, an outcome that, polls found, a majority of Florida voters did not want.
"I played a role I was assigned," Mr. McCollum says now of his task as an impeachment prosecutor, "and I'm proud of the role I was assigned. Character, integrity and principles do matter."
But nether he nor Mr. Nelson has talked much about impeachment during the campaign; polls have also shown that people are tired of hearing about it.
Mr. Nelson and Mr. McCollum side with their parties' presidential nominees on most issues: the environment, the economy, education, abortion and more. Mr. McCollum backs Mr. Bush's plan to apply a big part of the federal budget surplus to a $1.3 trillion tax cut; Mr. Nelson favors a $500 billion cut similar to the one proposed by Mr. Gore.
Although both men say they like to talk about the issues, they spend a great deal of time talking about each other. Mr. McCollum has accused Mr. Nelson, as insurance commissioner, of allowing premiums in Florida to skyrocket in the aftermath of Hurricane Andrew, and Mr. Nelson has shot back, noting that an arbitration panel created by the Republican-controlled Legislature has final say on insurance-rate increases.
"Mr. McCollum's friends insist on an arbitration panel," Mr. Nelson said in a debate in Delray Beach, "and what they're doing is sticking it to the consumers."
And although talk of impeachment has been set aside, that is not to say Mr. Clinton's name never emerges. In recent e-mail to his supporters, Mr. McCollum wrote that "with the exception of Hillary's New York race, my defeat is Bill Clinton's highest political priority."
Mr. Clinton has in fact raised money for Mr. Nelson, and stumped for him against Mr. McCollum. Campaign experts say it is not personal. Just politics.

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (98%);

CITY: MIAMI, FL, USA (79%);

HEADLINE: Reckonings;
We're Not Responsible

BYLINE: By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
However this election turns out, future historians are likely to see this as the year that America failed a big political test.
After decades of bipartisan irresponsibility, by the 1990's the United States had, miraculously, started to look like a grown-up nation -- a nation able to plan ahead, to take advantage of good times to prepare for the rainier days to come. But it was an illusion: We were, it turns out, just playing at being grown-up. 
 The basic rule of fiscal responsibility for a national government is pretty much the same as the rule for a family: Pay off your debts and build up financial reserves when things are good, so that you can draw on those reserves later. And these are the best of times for America's government, in at least three ways.
First, we are at peace, with no significant military rivals. You don't have to believe in a new cold war to think that things are unlikely to stay this easy, that one way or another defense spending will eventually have to rise from its current low.
Second, our demography is as good as it's going to be for the foreseeable future. The modern U.S. government is in large part in the business of insuring the income and medical expenses of older citizens. Starting just 10 years from now, the population eligible for Medicare and Social Security will start rising, and rising, and rising, with no end in sight. And so will the bills. If taxes on the diminishing fraction of our population that isn't retired are to stay tolerable, we'd better start saving now.
Finally, right now the U.S. economy -- and indirectly the federal budget -- benefits from the perception in the rest of the world that America is the place to invest your money. Huge inflows of foreign capital have been keeping U.S. interest rates down and stock prices up, both of which also keep the money flowing into federal coffers. Some economists think that these capital inflows, like the similar inflows into Asian nations before 1997, are only setting us up for a future crisis -- and I won't say that I'm not worried. But even without a crisis we know that foreigners (and American investors too) will eventually discover more opportunities outside the United States, that the inflows will someday become outflows, and that we will be sorry if we haven't prepared for that day.
So the responsible, sensible thing for the U.S. government to do is to run very big surpluses right now. Indeed, budget analysts who take the long view argue that even without the tax cuts and spending initiatives proposed by the presidential candidates we would not be running as large a surplus over the next decade as we should -- that if anything we should be raising taxes and cutting spending.
But how do you explain that long view to the public? The truth is that our leaders never really tried. Instead, even politicians who were trying to be responsible resorted to half-truths. All that business about putting Social Security and Medicare in "lockboxes" is an attempt to sell fiscal responsibility to the voters without really trying to explain why it is necessary. So maybe we should not be surprised that we have ended up with the worst of all worlds. On one side the public feels, correctly, that politicians like Al Gore, who use those half-truths to push for half-responsible policies, are talking down to them. On the other side the public feels, quite wrongly, that politicians like George W. Bush, who tell them that they can have their cake and eat it too, are men of the people.
Mr. Bush's willingness to trust in the public's innumeracy continues to boggle the mind. In the second debate he offered possibly the biggest misrepresentation yet, this time declaring about his tax plan that "most of tax reductions go to the people at the bottom end of the economic ladder." (That sound you hear is the giggling of millionaires and the guffawing of multimillionaires.)
But the gleefulness of the crowds who picked up that Orwellian chant of "no fuzzy numbers" (Orwellian because what it really meant was "no clear numbers -- we don't want to know") suggests that this country just wasn't ready for the hard thinking that would have let us act responsibly. Maybe better politicians could have made a better case for the right policies. Or maybe the fault is not in our politicians but in ourselves.

HEADLINE: New Advice for Parents: Saying 'That's Great!' May Not Be

BYLINE: By PAM BELLUCK 

DATELINE: MONROE, Iowa

 BODY:
Five-year-old Cristina bounced up to her preschool teacher in this quiet Iowa farm town, waved her crayon drawing dotted with brightly colored stickers and asked, "What do you think of my picture?"
The teacher, Sharon Doolittle, looked enthusiastically, but was careful not to offer praise. 
 Instead, she said: "I see you drew a black wagon. What are you going to put in that black wagon?"
In a classroom in Moorpark, Calif., when the preschoolers successfully clean up the play kitchen, Jennifer Parker does not tell them, "good job," she said. "I say, 'I notice you put all of the dishes and all of the food back where it belongs. Next time you want to play with those, you'll be able to find them.' "
And in Manhattan, Fran Spector, a first-grade teacher at the Ethical Culture School, took a similar tack on a bus trip to the Central Park conservatory garden. After a couple of her students offered their seats to people who were standing, Ms. Spector said, "I did not say 'That was great.' I said, 'Did you notice how appreciative the people were?' "
For years, parents and teachers got the message that children should be praised at almost any opportunity, that saying "good job" for everything from sharing snacks to sliding down a slide raises self-esteem. Some guides said praise encouraged desirable behavior, like buckling a seat belt or cleaning one's room. Some schools displayed posters saying "Praise every child every day."
But in a sea change from the gestalt of recent decades, many educators and child psychologists are concluding that less praise is often better and frequent praise for unexceptional actions can actually have a negative impact on children.
"Praising every time lowers a child's motivation," said Dr. Ron Taffel, a Manhattan psychologist and author of "Nurturing Good Children Now." "It cheapens the praise, and children become dependent on praise."
For example, Dr. Taffel said, he sees children sledding in Central Park with parents "screaming at the top of their lungs: 'great job, phenomenal sledding, that was the best I've ever seen.' The children were being praised for responding to the laws of gravity."
Some child-rearing experts say a steady stream of praise can turn children into praise addicts who lack confidence because they dismiss the value of the compliments. They say praise intended to reinforce good behavior can make children feel manipulated and less likely to keep up good habits in the long run. And they say sometimes children praised for a creative or academic task become less motivated to pursue it, because they feel pressure or are afraid they will not live up to expectations.
"In the effort to help children feel good about themselves, parents will praise more than is appropriate," said Fretta Reitzes, director of the Goldman Center for Youth and Family at the 92nd Street Y.M.-Y.W.H.A., who thinks praise caught on partly because working mothers want their time with their children "to be full of smiles and hugs," she said. "Being a whole human being means having strengths, but also realizing that others may be better tennis players or better clarinetists. When kids begin to really experience their own frailty, parents are often disappointed -- 'What did I do wrong? I praised you and praised you. I told you you were wonderful and you're falling apart.' "
These experts do not advocate more criticism, and say genuine praise for noteworthy effort or accomplishment is good. But often, they say, it is better to give encouragement, offering descriptions or asking questions in a way that shows interest, yet allows children to judge themselves. Avoid praise that evaluates the child ("You're so smart") or injects the speaker ("I like the way you behaved").
"What is helpful is when something they've actually done is recognized and acknowledged -- and the particulars are mentioned," said Dr. Richard M. Ryan, a psychology professor at the University of Rochester. "Less good and even harmful is praise that feels to the child evaluative and controlling. If a parent says, 'I love the way your room is so clean right now,' it has this feeling like 'you're controlling me.' "
In addition to anecdotal experience, a smattering of studies suggest that children praised for doing well at something were less interested in pursuing it, or did less well at subsequent tasks. One study found that when science teachers gave less praise, children spent more time figuring out experiments on their own. Dr. Joan Grusec, a University of Toronto psychology professor, found that children praised for making charitable donations were less likely to be generous than children told that they seemed to like helping others, a descriptive response.
The shift toward less praise is related to the booming economy and tragedies like the Columbine massacre, said Sally Lee, editor in chief of Parents Magazine, which recently published an article on praise.
"In the last two or three years, there's a sense of let's start raising kids who are not so individualistic," Ms. Lee said. "In a bad economy, everyone wants to raise this Horatio Alger. Now we want to raise kids who are good citizens who will help people."
Ms. Lee said her own tendency to praise her daughter, 3, had become almost "a nervous tic: saying 'good job' when she went down the slide, when she picked herself up from the playground. So when I said 'good job' when she did something big like set the table by herself for the first time, I guess there wasn't much difference."
Alfie Kohn, an author and a strong critic of routine praise, calls it a "verbal doggie biscuit," similar to tangible rewards, like stickers or gold stars, which he considers disrespectful, manipulative and only temporarily effective.
Some psychologists and teachers disagree.
Dr. Barry Lubetkin, director of the Institute for Behavior Therapy in Manhattan, believes that while some parents overpraise, "most parents don't praise enough. Praise is extremely important in building up a sense of children's own abilities. For psychologists to suggest that you should limit praise really undermines the idea of how we encourage children to feel good about themselves."
Kim Hunt, a second-grade teacher in Des Moines, often praises children to convince others to behave, saying things like, "Oh, do I like the way Emily has already started solving those math problems. She's using her brain," Ms. Hunt said.
"Praise is almost a contagious virus in a classroom because if you can catch one child doing something good and if you can verbally praise that child in front of his or her peers, it's going to spread like wildfire and the rest of the children are going to automatically do exactly what that model student is doing because they want the positive attention," she said.
But proponents say substituting questions or descriptions for praise stimulates children to think, create and feel good about their own work.
"This recurring, high-octane level of praise sometimes gets in the way" of learning, said Teresa Rosegrant, a preschool teacher in Arlington, Va. Saying something like "I see you're figuring out how to turn the pieces to put that puzzle together," she said, encourages and motivates a child, while "allowing them to feel happy about their own accomplishments."
At Monroe Elementary School in this community about 30 miles southeast of Des Moines, some parents are impressed by Mrs. Doolittle's approach.
Renae Tool routinely praised her son Jacob because "you want to tell them they did a good job on everything," she said. But when he started preschool two years ago, she noticed he "would hurry through art projects. As soon as a buddy of his was done, he would just sort of scribble through or just paste it down."
What helped was that instead of praise, Mrs. Doolittle would say, "Jacob, is that your best work?" Mrs. Tool said.
"I really think after Jacob came here he had more self-confidence," said Mrs. Tool, who was so impressed she enrolled her daughter, Dani Sue, 5, and became a classroom aide.
Mrs. Tool is also glad Mrs. Doolittle rejects the school's practice of giving children yellow slips for good behavior and blue for bad, and was uncomfortable this year when Jacob's first grade teacher gave him a yellow slip praising him for playing with a disabled boy.
Some parents, however, have not been pleased.
Last year, Mrs. Doolittle said, a mother said her son's behavior problems were caused by Mrs. Doolittle's not praising him enough. He ultimately left the class.
And, Mrs. Doolittle said: "If we've had a really good day, I still resort to, probably more for the parents than the children, giving them a 'we had a good day' badge. If you never bring home any positive things, the parents start to wonder."

HEADLINE: Profit Declines at Bank One And Rises at Wells and Fleet

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Wells Fargo & Company and the FleetBoston Financial Corporation posted third-quarter earnings yesterday that were in line with Wall Street estimates, while the Bank One Corporation, still reeling from problems with its credit unit and poor commercial loans, met reduced expectations despite a 37 percent drop in profit.
At Wells Fargo, which is based in San Francisco, third-quarter profit rose 11 percent, to $1.07 billion, or 64 cents a share, from $962 million, or 57 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. 
 The results matched analysts' estimates, according to First Call/ Thomson Financial.
The performance continued a string of solid results posted by Wells Fargo since its sale to Norwest in November 1998. As the largest bank based in the West, Wells Fargo continued to benefit from the region's economic boom, particularly in California.
Still, the bank's loan losses climbed during the quarter, but Wells Fargo said its volume of problem assets remained at levels below normal. In the third quarter, the bank wrote off $267 million in loans, a 9 percent increase compared with the period a year earlier.
Ross Kari, the chief financial officer, warned that loan losses would probably continue to climb in the next few months, but only by a small amount.
Shares of Wells Fargo fell $1.88, to $41.69.
FleetBoston Financial reported that its net income rose to $841 million, or 90 cents a share, from $711 million, or 74 cents a share, in the period a year earlier.
Excluding special items -- a gain for a divestiture and integration charges -- earnings were up 10 percent, to $782 million, or 84 cents a share. That was in line with analysts' estimates, according to First Call.
The company said profit was lifted by higher levels of capital markets and revenue from investment services.
Shares of Fleet fell $1.88, to $25.
Bank One, which is based in Chicago, reported its fourth consecutive quarterly decline as fees from its credit card unit fell and the company set aside more money to cover the possibility of bad loans. Net income was $581 million, or 50 cents a share, compared with $925 million, or 79 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. The earnings met analysts' estimates, according to First Call.
James Dimon, the company's chief executive, called the earnings performance unacceptable. But he said Bank One remained on target to reach its goal for the second half of this year and 2001.
Shares of Bank One fell $1.81, or more than 5 percent, to $32.81.

HEADLINE: Thomas Labrecque, 62, Dies; Ex-Chief of Chase Manhattan

BYLINE: By RIVA D. ATLAS 

 BODY:
Thomas G. Labrecque, the former chairman and chief executive of the Chase Manhattan Corporation, died Monday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York.
Mr. Labrecque died of lung cancer, which was diagnosed in early September, a spokesman for his family said. He was 62 and lived in Fair Haven, N.J. 
 Mr. Labrecque joined Chase's management training program in 1964 and rose quickly through the ranks. In 1976, he was appointed to Chase's management committee, where, at age 38, he was 10 years younger than any other member. Mr. Labrecque also served at the request of David Rockefeller, then Chase's chief executive, on the committee to resolve New York City's fiscal crisis.
He was named president and chief operating officer of Chase in 1981.
By 1990, Chase was ailing from losses on loans to real estate developers and less-developed countries. Chase's board turned to Mr. Labrecque, naming him chairman and chief executive.
He sold underperforming businesses and increased the profits of such core areas as credit cards, trust and custody, and mortgage banking. But Chase's stock still lagged, prodding an activist shareholder, Michael F. Price, who then headed the Mutual Series mutual fund company, to purchase 6.1 percent of Chase in April 1995, and urge the bank to "increase shareholder value."
Four months later, the Chemical Bank Corporation announced an $11 billion merger with Chase. Mr. Price said yesterday that he appreciated Mr. Labrecque's abilities. "Of all the companies we've ever invested in, he was by far the best C.E.O.," Mr. Price said.
Rodgin Cohen, the chairman of the law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell, which advised Chase on its merger with Chemical, said: "He probably doesn't get enough credit for turning the bank around. He put Chase in a position where it could attract a strong partner."
As part of the merger agreement, Mr. Labrecque relinquished the top spot of chairman and chief executive to Chemical's chairman and chief executive, Walter V. Shipley. Mr. Labrecque took the No. 2 position of president and chief operating officer of the combined company, which took the Chase name. Nor did the merger agreement provide for Mr. Labrecque to succeed Mr. Shipley.
"There were other possible partners at that time where he could have been guaranteed succession," Mr. Cohen said of Mr. Labrecque. "He did what was best for the bank."
Unlike many executives who vacate the top slot after a merger, Mr. Labrecque stuck around, and not merely as a figurehead. During the financial crisis in the fall of 1998, he was the bank's main person in coping with Russia's loan default. He also represented Chase in negotiations to restructure the Long-Term Capital Management hedge fund.
Mr. Labrecque was known for his quiet competence and modesty, traits that may have led him to be underappreciated by Wall Street. He was also noted for his patrician good looks and appropriate traits at a bank that was for years controlled by the Rockefeller family. But in fact, he came from humbler beginnings.
Mr. Labrecque was born on Sept. 17, 1938, in Long Branch, N.J. He was the third of eight children born to New Jersey Superior Court Judge Theodore J. Labrecque, who was of French Canadian descent. Mr. Labrecque graduated from Villanova University in 1960. He attended the Graduate School of Business at American University and the New York University Graduate School of Business Administration.
Mr. Labrecque spent four years in the United States Navy, rising to the rank of full lieutenant. He served on a destroyer at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, in 1960 and in the Mediterranean and the Baltic during the building of the Berlin Wall. During the Cuban missile crisis, he headed a section of the Office of Naval Intelligence, deploying ships in the blockade off Cuba.
After his retirement from Chase in June 1999, Mr. Labrecque served as chairman of Chase's International Advisory Council. He also served on the board of trustees of the University of Notre Dame. Mr. Labrecque was a director of Pfizer Inc. and Delphi Automotive Systems and a trustee of the Hospital for Special Surgery.
He is survived by his wife, Sheila; four children, Thomas Jr., Douglas, Karen Shea and Barbara Corbin; five grandchildren; three brothers; and four sisters.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN;
CAMPAIGN BRIEFING

BYLINE: Compiled by B. Drummond Ayres Jr.

 BODY:

THE GREEN PARTY
 
SHUNNED CANDIDATE SPEAKS OUT -- Just as Ralph Nader, the Green Party candidate, was not permitted to join the two major-party candidates in last night's presidential debate in Missouri, so Jeff Gates, also a Green Party candidate, was not permitted to join the two major-party candidates in the Senate debate in Georgia on Monday.
But unlike Mr. Nader, Mr. Gates decided not merely to grumble and sue.
At the beginning of the debate in Albany between Senator Zell Miller, a Democrat, and former Senator Mack Mattingly, a Republican, Mr. Gates stood up and demanded to be included, shouting: "This is what democracy looks like. This is what democracy feels like."
The outburst, broadcast on statewide television, prompted a police officer to handcuff Mr. Gates and hustle him out of Albany Municipal Auditorium. He was charged with disorderly conduct and spent much of the rest of the night in jail before being released after posting a $181 bond. David Firestone (NYT)
 
THE DEMOCRATS
 
HIGH-TECHNOLOGY POLITICS -- Both parties have aggressively courted the computer industry this year, with Vice President Al Gore and Senator Joseph I. Lieberman arguing that they are the ticket with the best understanding of the new, high-technology economy and its needs. Mr. Gore even took some controversial credit at one point for helping develop the Internet.
Whatever the case, he and Mr. Lieberman got some solid support yesterday when 400 of the industry's leaders endorsed them.
"I wouldn't be here without Al Gore having done everything he's done in the last 25 years," said one of the most prominent in the group, Marc Andreessen, a founder of Netscape. Richard Perez-Pena (NYT)
 
THE BALLOT QUESTIONS
 
DEVELOPMENT ON COLORADO BALLOT -- Among all the choices Colorado voters have next month, nothing has stirred passions more than a ballot initiative that would require local governments to put development plans before voters each year.
Recent polls show that a majority of Coloradans favor the measure. But record amounts of money are pouring in to fight it, with the opposition group, Coloradans for Responsible Reform, raising $5.1 million. That is more than eight times the $633,000 that initiative supporters have raised.
The bankers, builders and real estate developers who oppose the initiative say it would curb the supply of affordable housing units and stunt a booming economy. But the Sierra Club and other environmental groups contend that without stricter oversight, new development will overwhelm roads, schools and other government services. Michael Janofsky (NYT)
 
THE ELECTORATE
 
THE VOTERS ARE CHATTING -- Maybe the voters have not really vanished. Maybe they were just a bit slow to take interest.
Harvard University's Vanishing Voter research project, which seeks to understand how to get more of the American electorate involved in politics, got some encouraging results in its latest poll, conducted last week. Nearly half of adults reported having discussed the campaign with someone within the past 24 hours.
The project had previously found that, on average, only about 22 percent of adults said they had talked with someone about the campaign within the past 24 hours. But once the presidential debates started, that figure quickly more than doubled. Carey Goldberg (NYT)

HEADLINE: Resolved: That High School Debate Is Back

BYLINE: By TARA BAHRAMPOUR 

 BODY:
Standing at a school desk, wearing shiny high-heel boots, Stacey Martin, 17 years old, rapped her fist on the table, looked straight into the judge's eyes and spoke with the aplomb of a seasoned lawyer and the dizzying speed of an auctioneer.
The words flowed in rapid-fire succession -- drug use, suspicion, probable cause -- but they were part of a coherent, well-researched argument. She and her teammate at a national-level tournament at the Bronx High School of Science last weekend were arguing in favor of the United States Coast Guard's participation in the war on drugs. 
 High school debate teams like Ms. Martin's, which won several rounds before being eliminated last weekend, have long trained the nation's elite in critical thinking and public presentation. Although aides to Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, who debated on national television last night, said the candidates had not been on their high school teams, many politicians and public speakers cut their oratorical teeth in high school tournaments.
But in the early 1980's, as urban schools faced budget cuts, debate teams were one of the first casualties. By the 1990's, only four public schools in New York City had teams, and only two -- Stuyvesant and Bronx High School of Science -- competed in policy debate, the most rigorous form.
But in New York and other big cities, debate is making a comeback, and its newest participants are coming from nontraditional quarters. With long hours of research and often prohibitive entry fees for competitions, debate was for many years a bastion of financially comfortable white males. But in New York City, debaters are as likely to be low-income, nonwhite and female. Ms. Martin, who was raised by a single mother after her father died, attends Franklin K. Lane High School, a largely black and Hispanic school in Woodhaven, Queens, where 43 percent of students receive free lunches and 39 percent graduate in four years.
Franklin K. Lane, Washington Irving High School in Manhattan, Wadleigh Secondary School in Harlem, Ralph McKee Vocational High School in Staten Island and the High School for Legal Studies in Brooklyn are among 34 New York City public high schools that recently started debate teams. All are members of the Urban Debate League, a pilot program financed by George Soros's Open Society Institute to help introduce debate into inner-city public schools.
The program, which is based on a similar one in Atlanta, started its first teams in New York City in 1997 and has since branched out to 12 cities. Of a $2 million annual budget, about $500,000 goes to New York schools.
Coming in, the students knew little about debate. Some were lured by the prospect of travel; one freshman said he attended his first meeting after a scary-looking older student cornered him and ordered him to go. One attraction was the prospect of challenging top-level schools to do intellectual battle.
"We went to New York and said, 'Before the year is out you will have beaten Bronx Science or Stuyvesant at least once,' " said Melissa Maxcy Wade, who founded the original Atlanta league and is director of forensics at Emory University there.
That happened the second semester. By the second year, an Urban Debate League school, Grace H. Dodge Vocational High School in the Bronx, was the junior varsity state champion. Last year, Franklin K. Lane High School came in third all around in the state, with the fourth and fifth positions also taken by Urban Debate League schools.
"Once that happens, the self-esteem they get, you can't buy that in a store," Ms. Wade said. "Because these kids are basically led to believe they cannot compete with those schools."
Urban Debate League debaters have also seen their grades rise and discipline problems fall. Many report an increased sense of confidence, an ease with the world beyond the neighborhoods they grew up in.
"You get familiarized with what's going on in your society," said Daymean Lewis, 15, a member of Lane's junior varsity team. "And you just get this tone in your voice, you feel more forceful, that you can do anything." Many league debaters say they would like to use their debate skills to become lawyers or teachers.
For some, public speaking comes naturally. "In the African-American tradition, oratory is taught in the church," Ms. Wade noted. "You're supposed to be eloquent; your job is to be Martin Luther King." As a result, she said, "kids can speak well, but they're content-light." So coaches focus on research skills as well as teaching the foreign language of argumentation.
The league teaches the most difficult form of debate, policy debate, which draws on fields like history, politics, economics and science. Policy debaters nationwide focus on a different topic each year. This year it is privacy, with students tackling issues like Internet privacy and a favorite of the presidential candidates: racial profiling.
Some students drop out, daunted by the hours of research and meticulous organization of evidence into wash-basin-size plastic tubs that have to be lugged to each tournament. But for those who stay, the payoffs are many. Socially, they say they are more confident, and many find themselves resolving personal conflicts through logic and argument rather than force.
Debate helps with schoolwork, too. "I've learned a lot of big words lately," said Julia Monegro, a Lane student who immigrated from the Dominican Republic 5 years ago and had failed two classes before she started debating. "I got a 91 on my report card in English, and I'm not that good at it."
Ms. Wade credits the Internet with opening debate to less affluent students who can now do the needed research. "Computers have been a profound way to level the playing field," she said. So have scholarships for intensive summer training programs, which can run $3,000 to $4,000 for a 3-week session.
By senior year, many urban debaters are hotly pursued by universities. "I have college coaches coming up to me, saying, 'Who's graduating?' " said the Lane coach, Shawn Robertson, who is also an English teacher at the school. Noting that past students have gone on to Middlebury, Brandeis and State University of New York at Stony Brook, he said, "It's a good feeling as a coach to know that your students are wanted."
It also feels good, he added, "to see students go from concerns about their sneakers to concerns about 'Is this missile defense something we should do?' "
League debaters are not the only beneficiaries. When tournaments and camps throw together the affluent with less affluent, both sides learn, Ms. Wade said.
Ms. Martin recalled students she met at a debate camp at Northwestern University last summer. "They tried to do things that they thought we would like," she said. "One girl, because I'm black, she thought I'd like rap. I said 'Blink 182's cool,' " referring to a white alternative rock band, "and she's like 'Oh my God, you like Blink 182?' "
Ms. Martin's teammate, Patricia Socorro, said interactions with suburban students had opened her mind. "The way I used to think about them and they used to think about me, once you get together, that's abolished," she said. "At first I thought, 'they're so snotty.' But they weren't snotty, they were cool."
Rafael Bruno, 14, recently spent his first night away from home when local debaters' families in suburban Monticello, N.Y., played host to the team. "I was scared," he admitted. "There was nothing but forest around there." But after his host started asking him about how debate works, he said, he forgot his fears.
"Debate is like a link to different places," he explained. "Half my family didn't graduate high school. I don't want to take the easy way; I wanted to take the hard way."

HEADLINE: Caterpillar Beats Lowered Expectations

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: PEORIA, Ill., Oct. 16

 BODY:
Caterpillar Inc., the maker of earth-moving equipment, said today that its third-quarter profit narrowly beat recently lowered estimates after softness in important markets, higher costs and unfavorable currency translations took their toll.
Caterpillar said it expected revenue in 2000 and 2001 to rise 2 to 7 percent. Further increases in United States interest rates could, however, threaten that outlook. 
 "At the moment, we do not have anything plugged in for continued increases in interest rates, so you could say there would be a risk if rates started to rise again," Caterpillar's chief financial officer, F. Lynn McFeeters, said in an interview.
The company, which warned analysts two weeks ago that it would not meet third-quarter profit forecasts, said it earned $216 million, or 62 cents a share, on revenue of $4.78 billion in the latest quarter. That compares with $219 million, or 61 cents, on revenue of $4.72 billion in the period a year earlier.
Analysts surveyed by First Call/ Thomson Financial, expected profit of 58cents a share. Analysts cut their estimates by 10 cents after the company issued its warning.

HEADLINE: Transportation Bond Act Gets Mixed Reviews From Fiscal Watchdog Groups

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
New York City's two most influential fiscal watchdog groups gave contrasting reviews yesterday on the $3.8 billion transportation bond act on the state's Nov. 7 ballot.
The separate reports, by the city-financed Independent Budget Office and the private Citizens Budget Commission, said the borrowing proposal would provide city residents with a windfall in transit financing, but would also push the state's debt load dangerously high. While the budget office took no position, it pointed out financial advantages for city residents. The commission, on the other hand, recommended voters reject the bond issue. 
 Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani gave the bond act a lukewarm endorsement last week, but it has been condemned by other officials, including the Staten Island borough president, Guy V. Molinari, who say it provides too few specifics on how the money would be spent.
If approved, the act would authorize state officials to raise $3.8 billion through general obligation bonds, with the proceeds to be divided almost evenly between state highway and bridge projects and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. The money dedicated to the M.T.A. would reduce the amount of the agency's own borrowing, and would pay for several subway and commuter rail projects, including engineering work on the proposed Second Avenue subway in Manhattan.
The report yesterday by Independent Budget Office, a nonpartisan arm of city government that was created in 1996, said taxpayers in the city would pay 40 percent of the debt payments on the state bonds, but would directly benefit from 44 percent of the transportation projects that would be financed.
The Independent Budget Office estimated that city residents would pay 48 percent of the debt payments if the bond act is defeated.
The Independent Budget Office estimated that city residents would pay 48 percent of the debt payments if the bond act is defeated and the debt payments are assumed by the M.T.A. and the State Department of Transportation.
Although the Citizens Budget Commission did not provide detailed analysis of how money would be distributed under the bond act, it said voters should reject it on principle, citing what it called a "danger zone" in debt financing. It said the debts of both the city and state had more than doubled since 1990, and recommended that the state reduce its level of borrowing.
"It is often assumed that if government is not in danger of defaulting on its debt, then its debt is not too large," said Charles Brecher, the group's research director. "A jurisdiction's debt level, however, has a great impact on its competitiveness."
In an interview, Ronnie Lowenstein, the chief economist for the Independent Budget Office, said, "There is no question that the biggest reason to vote against the act would be concern over the state's debt position."
But if the act is rejected, she said, alternative financing would probably not be found for all the transportation improvements now contemplated by city and state agencies.
Diana Fortuna, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, said the Independent Budget Office's report "misses the point" in its comparison of benefits for city and state residents.
She added that "city taxpayers should be as worried as any other taxpayers in the state about a debt level that is just too high."

HEADLINE: Metro Business Briefing

 BODY:

BLAME FOR HIGH BILLS -- A consultant to the Independent System Operator, a group that administers the wholesale energy markets in New York State, yesterday attributed much of the summer increase in electricity prices in the metropolitan area to the shutdown of a Con Edison generating plant. The consultant, David B. Patton of Capital Economics, challenged Con Edison's position that much of the increase resulted from the group's rules, which discourage economical imports of electricity. Mr. Patton said the shutdown of the Indian Point 2 power plant after an accident in February forced Con Ed to buy more expensive replacement power. A Con Ed spokesman, Joseph Petta, said the utility stood by its position. Joseph P. Fried (NYT) 

HEALTH CARE SPENDING RISES -- New York State had 6.7 percent of the nation's population in 1998 but 8.4 percent of its personal health care spending, a study by the state Conference of Blue Cross and Blue Shield Plans says. The study, released Monday, said part of the difference could be attributed to nonresidents' coming into the state for health care services. The study found that per capita health care spending in New York rose to $4,720 in 1998 from $2,454 in 1988, a 92 percent increase, compared with a nationwide rise to $3,760 from $2,033, an 85 percent increase. Hospital care accounted for 35 percent of such spending in New York in 1998, the largest slice, while the services of doctors and other professionals accounted for 22 percent. Joseph P. Fried (NYT)
 
REFUNDS COMING -- Verizon Communications has agreed to reimburse $1.5 million to 34,000 long-distance customers in New York State and pay $250,000 to the government under a consent decree. In March, the company and the Federal Communications Commission investigated the improper handling of electronic records used to confirm that a consumer has asked to switch long-distance carriers. They found that in some cases, a third party used to verify orders was given incorrect information by the Verizon representative or entered wrong information into its databases. Verizon said it would reimburse the customers for calls made while it dealt with its record-keeping errors. (AP)

HEADLINE: Pataki Says a Tax Increase Is No Way to Help Nassau

BYLINE: By AL BAKER 

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki, who in May offered a state bailout to help Nassau County out of its fiscal crisis, yesterday criticized Nassau Democrats' plans to raise the county portion of municipal property tax bills by 16.3 percent next year.
"I think a massive property tax increase is clearly the wrong way to go," Mr. Pataki said at a news conference in the Capitol in Albany. "The state didn't come in to help Nassau County so that it could continue to spend too much and to tax too much; that is not the goal. I certainly would be personally opposed to any significant property tax increase." 
 But Mr. Pataki said he would reserve final judgment until the state board overseeing the bailout plan gave its opinion on the Democrats' tax proposal, part of its plan to balance the books through 2004.
His fellow Republican, County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta, who has the power to veto any tax increase, said yesterday that the 16.3 percent figure proposed by the Democrats who control the County Legislature was too high. But he said he was willing to work with the Democrats before deciding whether to veto any part of their proposed budget.
Yesterday, the Democrats submitted a draft of their budget and a financial plan for the next three years to the state oversight board, the Nassau Interim Finance Authority, and said that they, too, would heed the board before voting on the budget tomorrow.
In the meantime, they revealed other details about their plans, saying they would try to repair what they called years of financial mismanagement by raising $95 million in additional county property taxes on houses and businesses next year while cutting spending by about $145 million.
The Democrats said they would raise the county's share of the property tax -- which makes up just 19 percent of the overall property tax bill -- by 16.3 percent next year. That includes a 3.8 percent rise in taxes that Mr. Gulotta included in his 2001 budget proposal last month after years of resisting even minimal tax increases that would have kept pace with the rate of inflation.
For the average household, which now pays $1,050 annually in county property taxes, the tax increase would add $165 a year to the cost of living in one of the most expensive places in the nation.
The Democrats have accepted Mr. Gulotta's proposal for 3 percent property tax increases in each year from 2002 through 2004.
Aides to Judith A. Jacobs, a Democrat and the legislature's presiding officer, said the 2001 budget totals $2.23 billion, slightly higher than the $2.21 billion budget proposed a month ago by Mr. Gulotta and slightly less than last year's adopted budget.
They also said the Democrats' budget would produce an $18.9 million surplus next year.
"The plan presented today sets forth a framework for Nassau County to emerge from a broken, fiscally mismanaged county into a vibrant, healthy county," Ms. Jacobs said. "We believe that in this time of World Series time, we have hit a home run with this budget."
She said she planned to brief Mr. Gulotta and Peter J. Schmitt, the Republican minority leader, yesterday on the budget, but added that the plan could still be modified after all sides, including the Nassau Interim Finance Authority, weigh in. The board expects to receive a separate budget plan from Mr. Schmitt by today.
In May, Mr. Pataki offered the county $100 million in aid and a restructuring of its crushing $2.6 billion debt if it cut hundreds of millions of dollars in costs through 2004.
Mr. Pataki said then that the county's financial problems could be resolved without a tax increase. Democrats agreed, until a projected shortfall of $233 million for 2001 grew by $66 million early last month and $19 million in unanticipated borrowing costs came to light in recent weeks. The governor's comments yesterday came in response to a reporter's question about the size of the proposed tax increase.
Mr. Gulotta said the proposed tax increase greatly exceeded the amount the county's 1.3 million residents should be asked to shoulder, even as the county teeters on the brink of bankruptcy and faces the threat of losing day-to-day fiscal authority to the state board.
"I submitted my budget on Sept. 15 and they have reviewed it backwards and forwards and inside out," Mr. Gulotta said of the Democrats. "They have critiqued it and commented on it, and here we are two days before NIFA expects a consensus document, and for the first time I have received the proposal of the Democratic majority. That is not right."
Although Frank G. Zarb, the chairman of the state board, has warned the various factions of county government for weeks to drop the political bickering and work together, the bitterness and blame among them seemed only to intensify yesterday.
Mr. Gulotta said the Democrats had planned an even higher tax increase, citing a public notice they placed in Newsday that says their budget includes a 40 percent county property tax increase and a $184 million increase in overall spending. But Darren S. Bloch, the chief of staff to the Democratic lawmakers, said Mr. Gulotta was "completely misleading the public." He said such public notices have traditionally inflated the budget figures to allow room for possible increases in taxes and spending. He said the final budgets never come close to those figures.
Phoebe B. Goodman, the executive director of the Nassau Citizens Budget Committee and a longtime county budget critic, said she found the tax increase proposal refreshing. She said the Republicans' refusal to increase taxes incrementally in the past contributed to the county's current problems.
"I think it is probably realistic," Ms. Goodman said. "I assume it is more realistic than either Gulotta or the legislative Republicans trying to balance the budget without a tax increase. Sooner or later, you have to raise taxes; there is an increased cost of living. I just wish they had all come to agreement on a budget."
