Sir, did I misread your response and are you really, really proud of the fact that Texas is number one in executions?
 
MR. BUSH -- No, I'm not proud of that. The death penalty's very serious business, Leo. It's an issue that good people obviously disagree on. I take my job seriously. And if you think I was proud of it, I think you misread me. I do.
I was sworn to uphold the laws of my state. During the course of the campaign in 1994, I was asked do you support the death penalty? I said I did if administered fairly and justly. Because I believe it saves lives, Leo, I do. I think if it's administered swiftly, justly and fairly, it saves lives.
One of the things that happens when you're a governor, often times you have to make tough decisions. And you can't let public persuasion sway you because the job's to enforce the law. And that's what I did, sir. There've been some tough cases come across my desk. Some of the hardest moments since I've been the governor of the state of Texas is to deal with those cases.
But my job is to ask two questions, sir. Is the person guilty of the crime? And did the person have full access to the courts of law? And I can tell you looking at you right now, in all cases those answers were affirmative.
I'm not proud of any record. I'm proud of the fact that violent crime is down in the state of Texas. I'm proud of the fact that we hold people accountable. But I'm not proud of any record, sir. No.
 
MR. LEHRER -- Vice President Gore?
 
MR. GORE -- I support the death penalty. I think that it has to be administered not only fairly with attention to things like D.N.A. evidence, which I think should be used in all capital cases. But also with very careful attention. If, for example, somebody confesses to the crime and somebody's waiting on death row, there has to be alertness to say, wait a minute, have we got the wrong guy? If the wrong guy is put to death then that's a double tragedy -- not only has an innocent person been executed, but the real perpetrator of the crime has not been held accountable for it and in some cases may be still at large.
But I support the death penalty in the most heinous cases.
 
MR. LEHRER -- Do both of you believe that the death penalty actually deters crime? Governor?
 
MR. BUSH -- I do, it's the only reason to be for it. I don't -- let me finish. I don't think you should support the death penalty to seek revenge. I don't think that's right. I think the reason to support the death penalty is because it saves other people's lives.
 
MR. LEHRER -- Vice President Gore?
 
MR. GORE -- I think it is a deterrence. I know that's a controversial view, but I do believe it's a deterrence.
 
MR. LEHRER -- All right. Next question is for you, Vice President Gore. And Thomas Fisher will ask it. Mr. Fisher.
Q. -- Yes. My sixth-grade class at St. Claire's School wanted to ask of all these promises you guys are making and all the pledges, will you keep them when you're in office?
 
MR. GORE -- Yes. I am a person who keeps promises. And you know, we've heard a lot about -- from the governor about not much being done in the last eight years as if the promises that I -- I made eight years ago have not been kept.
I think the record shows otherwise. We have gone from the biggest deficits eight years ago to the biggest surpluses in history today. Instead of high unemployment, we now have the lowest African-American unemployment, the lowest Latino unemployment ever measured, 22 million new jobs, very low unemployment nationally. Instead of ballooning the debt and multiplying four times over, we have seen the debt actually begun to be paid down.
Here are some promises that I'll make to you now. I will balance the budget every year. I will pay down the debt every year. I will give middle-class Americans tax cuts, meaningful ones. And I will invest in education, health care, protecting the environment and retirement security.
We both made promises in this campaign. I promise you I will keep mine. Let me tell you about one of the governor's. He has promised a trillion dollars out of the Social Security trust fund for young working adults to invest and save on their own, but he's promised seniors that their Social Security benefits will not be cut. And he's promised the same trillion dollars to them. So this is the Show Me State, reminds me of the line from the movie: "Show me the money." Which one of those promises will you keep and which will you break, Governor?
 
MR. LEHRER -- Governor Bush?
 
MR. BUSH -- Thank you for your question. I -- there's an old high school debating trick, which is to answer something and then attack your opponent at the end. You asked about promises. You were promised that Medicare would be reformed and that Social Security'd be reformed. You were promised a middle-class tax cut, 1992. It didn't happen. There's too much bitterness in Washington. There's too much wrangling. It's time to have a fresh start.
One of the reasons I was successful as the governor of Texas is because I didn't try to be all things to all people. When I campaigned in a race a lot of folks didn't think I could win -- including, by the way, my mother. I said I'd do four things: tort reform, education reform, welfare reform and juvenile justice reform. And I won, and I had the will of the people in my state behind me. And then I brought folks together to get it done. And that's what we need, I think, in this election. To me that's what it's all about.
I know, listen -- I'm sure your sixth grade kids are listening -- these guys'll say anything to get elected. But there's a record, and that's what I hope people look at. And one of my promises is going to be Social Security reform and you bet, we need to take a trillion dollar -- trillion dollars out of that $2.4 trillion surplus. Now, remember Social Security revenue exceeds expenses up until 2015. People are going to get paid. But if you're a younger worker, if you're younger, you better hope this country thinks differently, otherwise you're going to be faced with huge payroll taxes or reduced benefits. And you bet we're going to take a trillion dollars of your own money and let you invest it under safe guidelines to get a better rate of return on the money than the paltry 2 percent that the federal government gets for you today. That's one of my promises. But it's going to require people to bring both Republicans and Democrats together to get it done. That's what it requires. There was a chance to get this done. There was bipartisan, bipartisan approach, but it's been rejected. I'm going to bring them together.
 
MR. LEHRER -- Both of you, to both of you on this subject. There are other questions that also go to this skepticism, not necessarily about you but all people in politics. Why is that?
 
MR. GORE -- Well, first of all, Jim, I'd like to respond to what the governor just said because the trillion dollars that has been promised to young people has also been promised to older people and you cannot keep both promises. If you're in your mid-40's under the governor's plan Social Security will be bankrupt by the time you retire if he takes it out of the Social Security trust fund. Under my plan it will be -- its solvency will be extended until you're 100. Now that is the difference. And the governor may not want to answer that question, he may want to call it a high school debating trick, but let me tell you this: This election is not about debating tricks, it is about your future. The reason Social Security, he says it gets 2 percent. You know, it's not a -- a bank account -- it -- that -- that just pays back money that's invested. It is also used to give your mothers and fathers the Social Security checks that they live on. If you take a trillion dollars out of that Social Security trust fund, how are the checks going to be -- how are you going to keep faith with the seniors?
Now, let me come -- let me come directly to your question --
 
MR. LEHRER -- No, I think we're -- we have to go to the closing statements and --
 
MR. BUSH -- Well, could I answer that?
 
MR. LEHRER -- Sure.
 
MR. BUSH -- One reason people are skeptical is because people don't answer the questions they've been asked. The trillion dollars comes out of the surplus so that you can invest some of your own money. There's just a difference of opinion. I want workers to have their own assets. It's who you trust, the government or people.
 
MR. LEHRER -- All right, now we're going to go to closing statements.
 
MR. GORE -- Right.
 
MR. LEHRER -- Vice President Gore, you're first. You have two minutes.
 
MR. GORE -- Thank you very much, Jim, and I'll begin by answering your questions, your last question. I believe that a lot of people are skeptical about people in politics today because we have seen a time of great challenge for our country since the assassination of our best leaders in the 60s, since the Vietnam War, since Watergate. And because we need campaign finance reform.
I'd like to tell you something about me. I keep my word. I have kept the faith. I've kept the faith with my country. I volunteered for the Army, I served in Vietnam. I kept the faith with my family. Tipper and I have been married for 30 years. We have devoted ourselves to our children and now, our nearly 1 1/2-year-old grandson. I have kept the faith with our country. Nine times I have raised my hand to take an oath to the Constitution. And I have never violated that oath.
I have not spent the last quarter century in pursuit of personal wealth. I have spent the last quarter-century fighting for middle-class, working men and women in the United States of America. I believe very deeply that you have to be willing to stand up and fight no matter what powerful forces might be on the other side.
If you want somebody who is willing to fight for you, I am asking for your support and your vote and, yes, your confidence. And your willingness to believe that we can do the right thing in America and be the better for it.
We've made some progress during the last eight years. We have seen the strongest economy in the history of the United States, lower crime rates for eight years in a row, highest private home ownership ever. But I'll make you one promise here: You ain't seen nothing yet. And I will keep that promise.
 
MR. LEHRER -- Governor Bush, two minutes.
 
MR. BUSH -- Well, Jim, I want to thank you and thank the folks here at Washington University and the vice president. Appreciate the chance to have a good honest dialogue about our differences of opinion, and I think after three debates, good people of this country understand there is a difference of opinion, it's the difference between big federal government and somebody who's coming from outside of Washington who will trust individuals.
I've got an agenda that I want to get done for the country. It's an agenda that says we're going to reform Medicare to make sure seniors have got prescription drugs and to give seniors different options from which they can choose. It's an agenda that says we're going to listen to the young voices in Social Security and so we're going to think differently about making sure we have a system, but also fulfill the promise to the seniors in America -- a promise made will be a promise kept should I be fortunate enough to be become your president.
I want to rebuild the military to keep the peace. I want to make sure the public school system in America fulfills its promise so that no child, not one child, is left behind. And after setting priorities, I want to give some of the -- some of your money back. See, I don't think the surplus is the government's money. I think it's the people's money. I don't think the surplus exists because of the ingenuity and hard work of the federal government. I think it exists because of the ingenuity and hard work of the American people, and you ought to have some of the surplus so you can save and dream and build.
I look forward to the final weeks of this campaign. I'm asking for your vote. For those of you for me, thanks for your help. For those of you for my opponent, please only vote once. But for those who've not made up their mind, I'd like to conclude by this promise, should I be fortunate enough to become your president, when I put my hand on the Bible I will swear to not only uphold the laws of the land, but I will also swear to uphold the honor and the dignity of the office to which I had been elected, so help me God. Thank you very much.
 
MR. LEHRER -- A closing piece of business before we go. The debate commission wants reaction to the three kinds of formats used in the debates this year and you may register an opinion at their Web site, www.debates.org.
Thank you, Vice President Gore, Governor Bush. From St. Louis, I'm Jim Lehrer. Thank you and good night.
 
MR. BUSH -- Good luck, good luck.
 
MR. GORE -- And to you.

HEADLINE: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: ASIA;
WARNING SIGNS IN SINGAPORE EXPORTS

BYLINE: By Wayne Arnold 

 BODY:
Falling demand for computer disk drives and chemicals offset rising demand for semiconductors to crimp Singapore's export growth last month, the government said. Nonoil exports rose 11.7 percent in September compared with the level for September 1999, below expectations, with slower shipments to the United States and Europe. Although economic growth in Singapore has been quickening this year, the data heightened concerns in financial markets that slumping global demand for electronics could mean trouble for Singapore and Southeast Asia's other export-dependent economies. Wayne Arnold

SECTION: Section G; Page 7; Column 1; Circuits 

LENGTH: 813 words

HEADLINE: Geeks, Proud of the Name, Start a Volunteer Corps

BYLINE: By SHAILA DEWAN 

 BODY:
SARAH WUSTNER, a Seattle software engineer, thought about joining the Peace Corps when she graduated from the University of California at San Diego in 1998. But, she said, "they didn't have anything that really fit my skills."
Now, with a stint at Microsoft on her resume, she has taken a leave of absence from her job at Oxygen Media to live in Ghana for three months. Ms. Wustner is part of the pilot team of six volunteers for Geekcorps, a high-tech version of the Peace Corps. Instead of teaching math, as technologically adept Peace Corps workers often do, Ms. Wustner, 24, will help a Ghanaian software company teach its workers the Java and Unix programming languages. 
 "I want the satisfaction of feeling that all of the expensive education that I got helped someone in a really real way," she said.
Geekcorps was the idea of Ethan Zuckerman, 27, who made a modest fortune ("enough to buy myself time," he said) when the Internet company he helped start, Tripod, was bought by Lycos in 1998. Lacking economic expertise, he consulted with Elisa Korentayer, 25, who has been both an investment banker and a poverty relief worker; she became a co-founder of Geekcorps.
The idea for Geekcorps came when Mr. Zuckerman was in Ghana in 1993 on a Fulbright fellowship to study African music. Because of a strike at the University of Ghana, he spent a lot of time in the library and noticed that it did not have many books published later than 1957, when Ghana became independent from Britain.
"I thought, If there was just an Internet connection," he said, "you could more than double this library."
In 1999 he left Lycos and began looking for a way to harness the philanthropic urges of his newly rich friends. The budget for Geekcorps's first year, $350,000, was financed largely by Mr. Zuckerman and people he knew from Tripod. Geekcorps is based in North Adams, Mass., in the dot-com corridor of the Berkshires.
Geekcorps is not unique. Volunteer programs designed to bridge the "digital divide" have been proliferating. The term itself, once used primarily to describe the gulf between Internet haves and have-nots within Western countries, refers more and more frequently to the huge disparity in access between the world's economic giants and its fledgling economies. Nearly 400 of every 1,000 Americans are Internet users, according to the International Telecommunication Union, as opposed to 3.5 of every 1,000 Africans.
Since Aug. 1, the United Nations has sent 37 high-tech volunteers to countries like Benin, Botswana and Ecuador. The State Department's version, called the Global Technology Corps, began in late 1998 and has sponsored more than 20 projects in Kosovo, Nigeria, Poland and other far-flung locales. Still another project, Net Corps America, focuses only on Latin America and the Caribbean. And in August the Peace Corps began to include information technology among its specialties, sending 10 volunteers to Belize.
These programs reflect the idea, enunciated this summer by the United Nations and the Group of Eight, that the Internet can provide medical information, economic opportunities and online courses that will enable developing countries to leapfrog ahead. But there are an infinite number of ways to chip away at the obstacles to total connectivity, including putting computers in schools and rewriting telecommunications regulations.
Geekcorps, although tiny, has attracted the attention of people like Denis Gilhooly, the director of information and communications technology for the United Nations Development Program. "The key to information infrastructure is a dual approach of bottom-up development, exemplified by Geekcorps," he said, "and top-down efforts, which would be exemplified by the UNDP Global Network Readiness and Resource Initiative." What Geekcorps is doing, he continued, is "seeding the next generation of entrepreneurs, and that's invaluable in these countries."
Both Mr. Zuckerman and Ms. Korentayer, who is the Geekcorps program director, said they had been pleasantly surprised by the number of Ghanaian businesses -- including an art gallery, a graphic design firm and a software company -- that asked for help. "There were so many companies that were so well positioned to receive the kind of help that we can offer," Ms. Korentayer said.
In the future Mr. Zuckerman plans to pursue high-tech companies as donors and to persuade "venture philanthropists" like the Noaber Foundation, which gave Geekcorps a grant, to pump capital into Geekcorps's Ghanaian clients.
The main thing that sets Geekcorps apart from other volunteer efforts, Ms. Korentayer said, is the fact that it was started by dot-com insiders.
"Geekcorps is far better positioned to appeal to the techie sector in the U.S.," Ms. Korentayer said. "Our competitive advantage is that a lot of techies have heard of us."

SECTION: Section E; Page 1; Column 2; The Arts/Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 1868 words

HEADLINE: Public Theater's Uptown 'Party' Leaves a Hangover

SERIES: MUCH ADO ABOUT A VISION -- Second of two articles.

BYLINE: By ROBIN POGREBIN 

 BODY:
On Jan. 26, just three weeks into rehearsals for the Broadway musical "The Wild Party," the Hollywood producer Scott Rudin wrote a letter to George C. Wolfe, the producer of the Joseph Papp Public Theater, to tell him that he was pulling his money out of the show.
"When we agreed to go forward together, I fully understood that you guys were going to be the lead producers on the venture, which I never had a problem with, provided that the criteria we agreed upon were put in place and adhered to," Mr. Rudin wrote. "To be told yesterday 'George is an artist and doesn't have time for producing issues' so contravenes the understanding, that I feel it is pointless to try and continue." 
 Mr. Rudin was ultimately persuaded to stay on, a decision he later said he regretted. Although the show opened in April and went on to receive nominations for seven Tony Awards, it won none and quickly closed.
The commercial failure of "The Wild Party" raised broad questions both about the Public and about Broadway's capacity to handle unorthodox fare. An examination of the musical's short, troubled life highlights those issues and the problems that can arise in the increasingly frequent partnerships between nonprofit theaters and commercial producers.
Although many say "The Wild Party" might have had an easier time starting at the Public rather than high-stakes Broadway, the Public Theater wanted to produce it uptown from the beginning. The production, which Mr. Wolfe wrote with the composer Michael John LaChiusa and also directed, was the season's second adaptation of the 1928 poem by Joseph Moncure March, which chronicles a debauched evening of orgies, shared misery and murder. Manhattan Theater Club did the first "Wild Party," written and composed by Andrew Lippa, in January.
The Public considered the Wolfe-LaChiusa version to be Broadway-caliber material, particularly because Vanessa Williams had initially agreed to star.
The Public's board chairman, Kenneth B. Lerer, said that going straight to Broadway also made economic sense because the Public planned to put up just $2.4 million, or half the cost of the show, only $900,000 more than it would have cost to produce it downtown at the Public on Lafayette Street.
And to do the show justice, Mr. Wolfe and Mr. LaChiusa said, they needed an orchestra pit and sizeable proscenium stage. (In addition, they said, their female star, Toni Collette, who replaced Ms. Williams when she became pregnant, would agree to appear only on Broadway. Ms. Collette's agent, Adam Isaacs, however, said this was "totally untrue.")
To help bring the show to Broadway, everyone working on it agreed to work for below-Broadway rates, said John Breglio, the Public's lawyer. The Public knew it could not afford to produce "Wild Party" on Broadway without outside financial help, given that musicals usually cost from $5 million to $10 million these days and that the Public spent $8 million on a failed revival of "On the Town" last year. So Mr. Wolfe approached Mr. Rudin, who in turn invited three other commercial producers to take part: Roger Berlind, Elizabeth Williams and Anita Waxman.
Mr. Rudin's team put up half of the show's $4.8 million cost while the Public provided the other half and agreed to cover any overruns, which ultimately amounted to more than $1 million. The Public agreed to split the profits almost evenly with the commercial producers.
Mr. Rudin said that he was initially enthusiastic about the project and that he expected Vanessa Williams's name to sell tickets. "I thought it had great artistic promise, although the subject matter made it a tough bet," he said.
Those present at the show's first rehearsal remember the excitement in the air. Still, board members say they were realistic about the show's financial prospects. "We never thought of 'The Wild Party' as another 'Chorus Line,' never thought it would be a commercial hit," Mr. Lerer said. "In my wildest dreams I thought it would break even."
Mr. Rudin saw the Public's attitude toward potential losses as cavalier, which is partly what soured him on the partnership. "George Wolfe invited me and my colleagues into this project because he said he wanted a partner in producing this show with the Public Theater," Mr. Rudin said. "In fact what he wanted was investors to hand over the money and walk away and not care where it was spent, how it was spent or whether there would ever be even the possibility of a return."
More than a clash of nonprofit and commercial cultures, Mr. Wolfe said, it was a clash of personalities. "The theater is fundamentally about collaboration," he said. "It was not a good collaboration with Scott because Scott is not a good collaborator. He needs to be in charge. If he is not in charge, it tends to color his passion and his generosity of spirit."
Mr. Rudin said that over time he came to feel that the show was badly managed because Mr. Wolfe closely guarded all decisions on elements like marketing, advertising and publicity, disregarding the commercial partners' expertise and stretching himself thin.
Mr. Rudin said he became exasperated with Mr. Wolfe's unavailability and wrote the letter after he tried to plan a promotional event for the show at Joe's Pub and was told over the phone by a Public executive that Mr. Wolfe did not have time for such things. . In response Mr. Lerer, a senior vice president of America Online, together with Michael Lynton, another board member, went to see Mr. Rudin and assured him that his concerns would be addressed.
Mr. Wolfe conceded that there were "unquestionably times when the artistic demands of the show were all-consuming," but he said he felt that it was important for the Public to hold the reins as part of its mandate.
"Ultimately the producer of 'The Wild Party' was the Public Theater," Mr. Wolfe said. "And we had agendas that are informed by fiscal realities. But we also have an unbelievable number of agendas that are about the mission of this institution, that are about our relationship with artists, that are about our sense of responsibility to the communities of this city."
Despite the assurances from Mr. Lerer and Mr. Lynton, Mr. Rudin said, the situation remained unchanged, and soon there were other flash points. High among them, he said, was the erratic behavior onstage of the show's male lead, Mandy Patinkin, who also regularly missed performances, more than 20 over all.
Mr. Rudin said that Mr. Wolfe abdicated responsibility. "Decisive action needed to be taken to make the other 15 actors onstage feel they were as important as Mr. Patinkin," Mr. Rudin said. Mr. Patinkin declined to comment. Mr. Wolfe would only say he believed he acted appropriately.
With conflicts far from resolved, "The Wild Party" opened on April 13 to mixed reviews. John Lahr wrote in The New Yorker, "The enormous energy that comes across the footlights feels more like theatrical hyperventilation than revelation." Linda Winer, in Newsday, described the show as "explosive and entertaining, if not completely satisfying." Ben Brantley of The New York Times, called it "a cause for sorrowful head-shaking," in a review that many at the Public blame for the show's demise, given the influence of the newspaper's chief theater critic.
Even though he was no longer obligated financially, Mr. Rudin said he felt that the producers should close the show. He said he sent a strong message to Mr. Lerer through a colleague. "I told him, every cent you spend two weeks after the show opened you're going to lose," Mr. Rudin said. "You're throwing money in the street."
But the Public's board said it had a duty to keep the show running until the Tony nominations were announced on May 8. After "Wild Party" received seven nominations, including one for best musical, the Public hunkered down to hang on until the awards ceremony on June 4.
To the extent that it is financially possible, Mr. Lerer and other board members say, a nonprofit theater must stick by its artists, particularly its leader. In deciding to keep the show open, the Public had the support of at least one of Mr. Rudin's fellow commercial producers.
"I thought we were all pretty unified in feeling -- after we received mixed reviews, some raves and some not good reviews -- to let word of mouth build," said Elizabeth Williams, who also produced "The Real Thing" and "A Moon for the Misbegotten" last season. "We needed to make the commitment, financial and otherwise, to stay open through the Tonys when we got so many nominations."
People involved in the show agreed to take salary cuts. Mr. LaChiusa, the composer, waived his royalty fee. And Mr. Lerer appointed a committee of three board members to oversee the show's finances: himself, Larry E. Condon and Ken Auletta.
The Public says it ultimately put up an additional $1.1 million to cover the costs of keeping the show open. That included $200,000 Mr. Lerer raised from private investors -- including Robert W. Pittman, the president of America Online and the Public's former board chairman -- and from Mr. Lerer himself.
The Public's board members say that the project fulfilled their artistic expectations. "I think George completely lived up to his side of the bargain," said Mr. Lynton, the president of AOL International. "He put on a good production. It was cast well, well produced. Whether people came or not is a separate issue."
As far as Mr. Rudin is concerned, however, whether people come or not is decisive. And they were not coming in large enough numbers; the show, which cost $450,000 a week to run, was losing $150,000 a week, he said.
On June 6, two days after "Wild Party" was shut out at the Tony Awards, the producers announced that the musical would close on June 11. Soon afterward Mr. Lerer invited Mr. LaChiusa down to the Public to meet with the board.
"He said, speaking for the board, how much they believed in this piece, that it was the type of show they wanted to do, and I always had a home there," Mr. LaChiusa recalled. "It was one of the most moving things I've ever been through in my life."
Mr. Wolfe said he had no regrets, that he believed in "The Wild Party" and felt it belonged on Broadway, although he said he was left asking himself, "Can challenging work happen in that landscape?"
Tonya Pinkins, one of the show's lead actors, said, "Sometimes you have to be taking an audience to the next level."
The comments point up the divide between the nonprofit theater world and many entrepreneurs.
Mr. Rudin, still irritated by the experience, said it was "childish and amateurish" to hold the notion that a show is "too good for Broadway."
"The Broadway environment raised an expectation for the show that the show simply did not deliver," he said. "And despite the fact that there was tremendous talent involved in it on- and offstage, audiences simply didn't like it in large enough numbers to keep it running."
In Mr. Wolfe's view, "The Wild Party" might have taken off had it had more time to find an audience. "We lost the commercial battle," he said. "But I firmly believe this show is going to have a future life because it's a good piece."

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
Utopia, and the Rest of All Possible Worlds

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN 

 BODY:
Why do we keep dreaming about utopia?
That's not exactly the question posed by "Utopia: The Search for the Ideal Society in the Western World," a pensive extravaganza, if one can imagine such a thing, at the New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street. Hundreds of books, manuscripts, maps, prints, photographs, bits of music, film, Nazi paraphernalia, Soviet propaganda, 1960's antiwar buttons, rock album covers and other curiosities spill across galleries on two floors. 
 The show, a collaboration between the library and the Bibliotheque Nationale in Paris, begins with a gigantic subject and enlarges on it. It is an ambitious strategy: serious, stylish, amusing, charming even, but occasionally aggravating. French, in other words.
Like most library exhibitions, it is more of a reading event than a show about visual pleasure, and as a near free-for-all it touches on what seems like almost every vision in Western history of a better world, including what Hitler and Stalin imagined.
So a visitor gets Eden, Renaissance architecture, the discovery of America, Voltaire's "Candide," the Declaration of Independence, the Paris Commune, Quakers, Soviet gulags, streamlined ocean liners, Levittown, the gay rights movement and Woodstock. By the end I found myself wondering why "Lucy in the Sky With Diamonds" was included but not Beethoven's Ninth, before I came to my senses. If you make it that far, you may lose track, too.
But the show has its multiple pleasures and benefits. And as the exhibition makes clear, everyone's idea of utopia is different; so, too, presumably, is everyone's idea of a utopian exhibition.
The word, we are reminded, was coined in 1516 by Thomas More as a pun meaning both a good place and no place. No place is a perfectly good place. Utopia began from this pessimistic assumption, and one could argue that it has remained on some level a negative concept. As opposed to heaven, it is what people dream about when they have lost faith in the certainty of a paradise to come. It's what we imagine to be perfection in a fallen world, the best of a bad situation.
The worse the situation, the better. Bloodshed and war have been boons to the utopia industry. The show is full of books and treatises emerging from conflict and chaos.
Also urban blight. Hellish cities, rapidly expanding during the industrial 19th century and into the 20th, caused architects and civic philosophers to cook up utopian alternatives. Le Corbusier, Bruno Taut, Frank Lloyd Wright, Tony Garnier. Le Corbusier famously wanted to tear down and rebuild Europe from scratch, to remake central Paris as a gigantic housing project of widely spaced skyscrapers. Au revoir, Opera. Howdy, Co-Op City.
Utopian architecture in this respect has imagined itself to be a sublime engine of social change physically enforced; change the physical conditions of an imperfect thing, a city, and you will make it better. We might think about this for a moment.
Le Corbusier's vision of a clean, disease-free, perfectly regulated urban environment and Hitler's plan for Berlin as an ethnically cleansed, perfectly obedient capital are not the same thing, but the distinction may not be quite as vast we might want to think.
Pierre Charles L'Enfant, the planner of Washington, expressed this thought about the model that Jefferson proposed as a design for the capital of the new United States of America: such regular plans might look good on paper, he said, but on the ground they become "tiresome and insipid."
Or worse. Regularity carried to its logical conclusion is oppression. In the show's catalog, Lyman Tower Sargent of the University of Missouri, St. Louis, points out that some historians view Sparta as utopia's fountainhead. This is an alarming thought because it may be true. Sacrifice, labor and renunciation were Sparta's watchwords. They have been become part of utopia's vocabulary.
Later utopian writers usually promised personal satisfaction for those who stuck to the plan. But the plan still counted above all, which is why utopia and dystopia have not always been easy to tell apart.
Even exceptional 19th-century utopian reformers like Charles Fourier were basically control addicts, although in some ways Fourier was so odd that one might think he was making a mockery of the idea of utopia, not genuinely imagining it.
The show has a whole section on socialist thinkers like Claude-Henri de Saint-Simon, Robert Owen and Fourier. Via a kind of private psychological calculus, almost unfathomable now, Fourier divided people into 810 personality types, differently combining what he considered 12 essential passions.
A Fourierist phalanx, or community, was to have one man and one woman of each type: 1,620 people walking around in uniforms with plumes and epaulettes that he designed to designate the different passions, with everyone trading jobs, sometimes several times a day, and bartering with other phalanxes for goods and living in a constant state of sexual stimulation. Before modern capitalists settled on the minimum wage, Fourier proposed a minimum of sexual pleasure as a condition of citizenship.
He remains best known as an economic reformer, but one wonders whether he most richly deserves our attention as a utopian speculator in human relations. His colorful legacy is to the vast history of utopian literature roughly what Plato's Retreat is to the history of social custom in New York, and also a reminder that utopia, any way you want to define it, is about desire of one sort or another.
Somehow, as Fourier illustrates, utopia seems inevitably to slouch toward dystopia. What began with the Garden of Eden and with fantasies of terrestrial paradise became, after the discovery of the New World, speculation about noble savagery and the land of opportunity. The Age of Exploration, which provoked an efflorescence of utopian writing, yielded to reality after the settlers started trying to split up the land. Reveries about perfection on earth soon devolved into colonialism. A clean slate, utopia's most essential component, became another market to exploit.
So the cycle has evolved. Now we have the Internet, a virtual society, the first real no place, speeding from its original state of infinite promise toward some indefinite commercial end. Cloning has also become reality. And we have become more cynical after a century of dystopian catastrophes.
But we still keep dreaming, not necessarily because we believe in the idea of a secular utopia's possible fulfillment but because, well, we seem to need to.
The show's catalog quotes Frederik L. Polak, the Dutch sociologist and utopian philosopher: "If Western man now stops thinking and dreaming the materials of new images of the future and attempts to shut himself up in the present, out of longing for security and for fear of the future, his civilization will come to an end.
"He has no choice but to dream or to die, condemning the whole of Western society to die with him."
There's an answer. Or maybe we keep dreaming up impossible schemes of perfection to remind ourselves that the real world, in its messiness, is the best thing after all.

HEADLINE: Modern Unveils Design for New Outpost in Queens

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN 

 BODY:
The Museum of Modern Art, which is to close in the summer of 2002 for a full architectural overhaul, unveiled the design for its temporary home in Long Island City, Queens, yesterday.
How long the museum will display its artworks at the provisional site, a former Swingline stapler factory, depends on how long it takes to finish its Midtown Manhattan renovation, designed by the Japanese architect Yoshio Taniguchi. That project, which won unanimous approval yesterday from the City Planning Commission, is scheduled to be completed in late 2004 or early 2005. 
 During the intervening years, the former factory will become a mini-museum, a kind of architectural understudy where part of the permanent collection will be displayed and temporary exhibitions housed. At 45-20 33rd Street, off Queens Boulevard, it is just outside the 33rd Street subway stop on the No. 7 line.
The Queens building is to open in the summer of 2002 with an exhibition of some of the Modern's best-known masterworks. Other shows planned include a major Matisse-Picasso show that is to run from mid-February 2003 through May of that year.
Designed by the Los Angeles architect Michael Maltzan, the Queens building will provide 25,000 square feet of temporary galleries. Most of it will be almost raw warehouse space, with 20-foot ceilings and walls that will be rearranged on an exhibition-by-exhibition basis. The columns of the original factory will remain as echoes of the building's former life.
A mezzanine with a cafe and a gift shop will open out onto an airy foyer with 22-foot ceilings and a long, leisurely S-shaped ramp leading from the street entrance to the building's ticket booth.
But many visitors' first glimpse of the building will be a giant rooftop "MoMA" sign visible from the elevated No. 7 train as it nears the 33rd Street station from Manhattan.
"From the No. 7 train, the roof is the first facade," said Mr. Maltzan. "I was trying to create a museum space that is iconographically very different, very modern, that is not a destination but a threshold where the movement of the visitor doesn't stop until you come up to the art itself."
Once out of the subway station, visitors will cross Queens Boulevard and walk under a 150-foot-long canopy that will run above the sidewalk, leading to the temporary museum's entrance on 33rd Street.
Mr. Maltzan, 40, a Long Island native who was formerly a senior associate with the firm of the Los Angeles architect Frank O. Gehry, said he wanted the building to reflect what he called the "middle landscape" between the urban and the suburban.
"I was trying to walk a fine line between the anonymous architecture of the area and the clear identity of the museum," he said.
The Modern's expansion project, the most ambitious by a New York museum in decades, will cost $650 million, 10 percent of it provided by the city.
The museum estimates the cost of the Swingline building conversion, including its purchase price, at $28.7 million.
When the artworks return to 53rd Street, the Swingline building will become a study and conservation center, office space and a storehouse for artworks now stored around the city.

HEADLINE: MAKING BOOKS;
A Dialogue From Auschwitz

BYLINE: By Martin Arnold 

 BODY:
Books are still man's greatest invention, despite the nonsense so often published between their covers. But their singular marvelousness, I guess, is that there will never be a Harry Potter movie that can reveal the wonder of the story the way the books do. Nor will there ever be a movie, no matter how skillful, that can capture the horror of the concentration camp the way a book can.
I am reminded of the power of this wondrous conception once again by the recent publication of yet another book that gives witness to life in the camps. It's a slim volume, but in reality it is one-half of a conversation across the decades between two men now dead who survived Auschwitz in quite different ways. The unfriendly partners in this dialogue are really discussing, in their separate books, a weighty, barbarous question: How much of one's humanity can a person give up to save his own life? And still be called human? 
 The new book is "Speak You Also: A Survivor's Reckoning" (Metropolitan Books) by Paul Steinberg, who in 1943, at 16, was gathered up in Paris and sent to Auschwitz. It is a disturbing, honest and unapologetic self-examination in response to those questions. This book would never have been written, and indeed no one would ever have heard of its author, had he not been written about by a fellow prisoner, Primo Levi, the Italian novelist, poet, nonfiction writer and chemist, and perhaps the most articulate and literate survivor of the camps.
Here is how he described Steinberg: "inhumanly cunning and incomprehensible like the Serpent in Genesis." That harsh declaration is in Levi's heroic book, "Survival in Auschwitz: The Nazi Assault on Humanity" (Collier, 1961), first published in the United States in 1959 as "If This Is a Man" (Orion Press).
Levi gives Steinberg the name Henri, a young man who was "eminently civilized and sane, and possesses a complete and organic theory on the ways to survive in Lager." Henri saw "three methods open to man to escape extermination which still allow him to retain the name of man: organization, pity and theft."
Henri, Levi wrote, practiced all three. He gained favors (food and cigarettes) from the relatively well-treated English P.O.W.'s. "Seducing" them (not sexually), Levi called it; "cultivating" was Henri's word. Levi explained: "In exchange for a single English cigarette you can make enough in Lager not to starve for a day. Henri was once seen in the act of eating a real hardboiled egg."
Levi wrote that Henri's ability to sympathize with and flatter a person who could help him, be it an English soldier or a German guard, was so natural a gift that "there is no heart so hardened that Henri cannot breach it."
So Henri's protectors were English soldiers, French, Ukrainian and Polish civilian workers, German "politicals," a cook, an SS man, inmate camp leaders, and doctors who, "immediately before selections, and in periods of most laborious work," take him in the hospital "whenever he wants and with the diagnosis he wants." Henri called these hospitalizations periods of "hibernation."
Levi conceded that "to speak with Henri is useful, and pleasant . . . even affection seems possible," but reminds himself that "the next moment his sad smile freezes into a cold grimace . . . and here he is again, intent on his hunt and his struggle; hard and distant, enclosed in armor, the enemy of all."
Now all this seemingly mundane characterization takes place within a world so horrific that among picture makers perhaps only Goya could have captured its charnel house essense.
In such conditions, what is a man's responsibility? To survive, Steinberg says in his own book. He was a tough teenager in that Lager who decided from the first that he was going to live. "I've withdrawn inside my shell; all the vital energy I have left is mobilized for my own survival," he wrote. "I'm at the age where one adjusts, and I economize on everything by getting rid of moral suffering, emotions, memories -- and regrets as well, a crucial imperative."
He goes on: "It's wasteful to give your affection to ghosts on reprieve. Why set yourself up for tears the next day?" Levi does not accuse Steinberg of betraying prisoners, but Steinberg tells of reaching his nadir when, at 18, he was made a camp trusty and one of his duties was to inspect a row of beds to see if they had been properly made up.
He records this scene: An elderly Polish Jew is lying on his bunk. Steinberg orders him out of the bed, but the man cannot move. Steinberg wrote: "Furious, I raise my hand without thinking and slap him. At the last moment, I hold back and my hand grazes his cheek. In that fraction of a second, I sound the abyss." He adds, "If only I could get rid of this memory, sweep it away with my hand."
Primo Levi died in 1987 at 67 in what is generally believed to be a suicide. Paul Steinberg died last December at 73, having lived to see his book published in French, German, Italian and Spanish but not in English. Levi had written: "I know that Henri is living today. I would give much to know his life as a free man, but I do not want to see him again."
Steinberg's editor, Riva Hocherman, said that the writer "actually started trying to write his story as fiction in the 60's, but couldn't do it."
"He underwent some sort of breakdown when he started to confront it," she said. It wasn't until later that he learned of Levi's book when another survivor directed him to it, she said. Ms. Hocherman said that Steinberg's family believes that finally there was correspondence between Levi and Steinberg. Either the family could not find it or has declined to make it public, she said.
It's an unsettling book, from the first page showing Steinberg's fierce will to survive. "He doesn't apologize," Ms. Hocherman said, "but then there's a line he did not cross. He did not betray his own people; he did not send anyone to their death."
In the end, Steinberg concedes that Levi was probably right about him, and says, "I'll never know whether I have the right to ask clemency of the jury." He asks, "Can one be so guilty for having survived?"

HEADLINE: Medicare Premiums and Social Security Will Rise

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18

 BODY:
Medicare premiums will rise nearly 10 percent next year, to $50 a month, and Social Security checks will grow by 3.5 percent, to cover increases in the cost of living, the government said today.
The cost-of-living adjustment in Social Security will be the largest since 1992. 
 For retired workers, the average Social Security benefit will increase next year by $29 a month, to $845 a month, from $816.
Medicare premiums, which are ordinarily deducted from Social Security checks, will rise $4.50 a month. The increase may jolt beneficiaries, who have become accustomed to stable premiums in recent years. The monthly premium is now $45.50, just as in 1999. It was $43.80 in 1997 and 1998.
Medicare provides health care for 39 million people who are 65 or older or disabled. The cost-of-living adjustment in Social Security will raise benefits paid each month to 49.4 million people: 45.2 million in the old age, survivors and disability insurance programs, and 4.2 million with low incomes who receive Supplemental Security Income.
Social Security payments are increased to reflect changes in the Consumer Price Index. Medicare premiums rise with spending in Part B of Medicare, which covers doctors' services, outpatient hospital care, medical equipment and some home health care.
Marilyn Moon, an economist at the Urban Institute, said the rise in Medicare premiums came as elderly people faced increases in many health care expenses.
Those costs, Ms. Moon said, include the patient's share of the bill for services covered by Medicare; premiums for private insurance to supplement Medicare, and prescription drugs, which are generally not covered outside a hospital stay.
Taken together, Ms. Moon said, the increase in Medicare premiums and other health care costs would eat up much of the increase in Social Security benefits.
But Thomas R. Saving, an economist at Texas A&M University, said, "Some Social Security recipients will be better off than they were before because the cost-of-living adjustment overcompensates for the actual rise in prices."

HEADLINE: Pace of Inflation Picks Up Even as Economy Seems to Slow

BYLINE: By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
Inflation is now on pace for its largest annual jump in a decade, the government reported yesterday, although the price increases remain largely confined to energy costs.
The report further complicates the picture of an economy that seems to be slowing even as inflation, one of the most common effects of rapid growth, is rising more rapidly than economists have anticipated. 
 The Consumer Price Index rose 0.5 percent in September and is now growing at an annual rate of 3.8 percent, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported. The last year in which inflation topped 3.5 percent was 1990, when it reached 6.1 percent.
The closely watched core rate of inflation, which excludes volatile energy and food costs, stood at 0.3 percent in September, up from 0.2 percent, where it has been since April. Much of its growth came in the costs of clothing and tobacco. Analysts said the change reflected conditions specific to those industries and did not suggest that the tripling of oil prices over the last two years is causing widespread price increases in other sectors.
"Over all, the numbers aren't good, but the details are less alarming," said Ian Shepherdson, the chief domestic economist at High Frequency Economics in Valhalla, N.Y.
The report adds to the uncertainty about whether the 10-year economic expansion is waning. On the one hand, stock prices have been falling for much of the last six months, and several big-name companies, including I.B.M. on Tuesday, have recently announced lower-than-expected sales. On the other, the United States unemployment rate fell to 3.9 percent last month, tying a 30-year low, while inflation is rising about twice as quickly as it did in the late 1990's.
The Federal Open Market Committee has kept short-term interest rates steady at 6.5 percent at its last three meetings. Most recently, the committee said it was more likely to raise rates in the coming months, to ward off inflation, than it was to lower them in an attempt to give the economy a boost.
Separately, the Social Security Administration announced yesterday that it would lift retirees' benefits by 3.5 percent in December, based on inflation data for the last 12 months. That is the largest cost-of-living adjustment since 1991.
Still, few economists saw major reason for alarm in the inflation numbers. Energy prices -- which account for about one out of every $14 that consumers spend -- rose 3.8 percent and are almost 20 percent higher than they were last year. But crude oil prices have fallen somewhat in the first half of this month, suggesting that gasoline and home heating costs will drop as well, said Patrick C. Jackman, an economist at the Bureau of Labor Statistics who specializes in the consumer index.
Furthermore, there is only slight evidence that rising energy prices have caused companies to charge more for other goods, as happened during the oil shocks of the 1970's.
The evidence is mainly in the service sector, where prices have risen over the last year by 3.7 percent. "This does reflect some spillover from higher energy costs," said Mark Vitner, a vice president at the First Union Corporation in Charlotte, N.C.
Over the last year, hourly wages in the United States have grown about 2 percent -- or 1.5 percentage points less than inflation -- and workers are starting to demand raises to help them cover the new costs, Mr. Vitner said. Wages represent the largest portion of costs for many services companies.

INDUSTRY: NAICS 213112 OIL & GAS INDUSTRY (78%);

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Gyrations in a Confused and Divided Market

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
Some investors gave up and got out yesterday morning, creating one of the worst openings ever for the American stock market. Prices soon rallied, but the Dow Jones industrial average still closed under 10,000 for the first time since March.
The wild gyrations reflected one of the most confused and divided stock markets in memory, in which hopes that the market is about to rise again are balanced by worries that weakness in technology stocks may presage a bear market and a sharp slowing in the economy that will decimate corporate profits. 
 "People are asking themselves if this is the end of the sell-off," said William Rhodes, the chief equity strategist for Williams Capital. At the same time, he added, there is fear that stock prices had reflected overly optimistic expectations about earnings growth in coming years.
During the last six weeks, stock prices have fallen sharply across much of the market, with some well-known stocks, like Yahoo and Apple Computer, losing more than half their value amid signs that growth is slowing for many technology companies. That weakness, amplified into 80 percent or larger declines for some smaller stocks, has led to forced selling as some investors tried to contain their losses.
Worries about high oil prices -- which were intensified by a report of low inventories released Tuesday night -- also have contributed to the nervousness of investors. Oil for November delivery rose 49 cents yesterday to $33.48 a barrel.
At the opening yesterday, the selling was intense. The Dow Jones industrial average fell more than 435 points, or 4.3 percent, within the first 19 minutes of trading, bottoming at 9,654.64. The more volatile Nasdaq composite index was off 5.8 percent.
And then the market turned around. Within a couple of hours, the Nasdaq index had erased its entire loss and was up a bit for the day. The Dow was still down, but all of the decline could be attributed to two stocks with bad news: I.B.M. and J. P. Morgan. I.B.M. reported disappointing revenue while J. P. Morgan was hurt by losses in venture capital investments at Chase Manhattan, which is acquiring Morgan.
By the close, the Dow was down 114.69 points, to 9,975.02. But nearly all of that decline was caused by I.B.M., and there were as many Dow stocks with gains as there were with losses. The Nasdaq index ended down 1.3 percent, a relatively small move in this very volatile time, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was off just over 0.5 percent.
The Wall Street rebound had immediate international effects as well. European stocks, which had been sliding, generally turned around about the same time. But, perhaps in an indication that some of the buying of American stocks came from abroad, the euro also began to fall, hitting a record low against the dollar for the first time since central banks intervened to support the currency last month. The euro traded as low as 83.3 cents.
I.B.M., which ended the day down $17.56, to $95.44 a share, disappointed investors with a profit report that showed revenue running below expectations. But even as I.B.M. was plunging in early trading, the Dow was getting some support from Intel, which ended up $2, to $38.19. Its actual profit report was not as bad as it had led analysts to fear last month, and that strength helped to buoy investors.
"You do see companies that are trying to find bottoms here," said Giri Devalupally, a technology analyst at T. Rowe Price, a mutual fund company. He pointed to the gains yesterday in both Intel and Dell Computer, each of which has lost more than half its value since peaking earlier in the year.
Coming into yesterday, much attention was focused on Sun Microsystems, which was scheduled to release profits after the market closed. But in mid-morning it put a bullish headline about its earnings on its Internet site, sending the stock leaping 10 percent, to $118.75, in 20 minutes, as analysts struggled to extrapolate the underlying profit numbers from a headline. Trading was soon halted, and the full profit release was issued. Sun rose a bit more, then sagged as some analysts voiced concern that its gross profit margins had fallen. By the close, the shares were back down to $110.31, off $1.06 for the day.
Even while technology stocks have bounced wildly in recent weeks on each new piece of evidence regarding the state of demand, other shares have been helped by the fact that optimism for the overall stock market remains strong among many investors.
Ever since the 1987 crash -- whose 13th anniversary is today -- big falls in stocks have been viewed as buying opportunities, and investors have been willing to come in when prices fall sharply. Ameritrade, an online brokerage firm, reported that during the nine trading sessions before yesterday, its traders were net buyers on every day except last Friday, when some took profits on a strong rebound that gave the Nasdaq market its second-best day ever.
David Bowers, the chief global investment strategist for Merrill Lynch, noted that some investors were taking heart from the fact that both the Dow and the Nasdaq indexes had approached the spring lows last week, and again yesterday, before stabilizing and turning up.
Trying to analyze the market now is difficult because the end of October is the time that most mutual funds close their tax books for the year. That has created selling pressure as some funds have taken capital losses that can be used to offset capital gains taken earlier in the year on other stocks.
Just which stock funds have losses can vary widely, reflecting the huge gains many had before stocks began to fall. Lucent Technologies, for example, is down more than two-thirds from the high it reached late last year, but it is still trading for more than twice its value of four years ago. Intel is down about half from the peak it reached in September, but is still twice where it was two years ago. Microsoft traded at a two-year low this week for the first time in its history, but is still far above where it was three or four years ago.
All those stocks still have Wall Street adherents and clearly will remain major companies for years to come. The worst losses have come as nearly all investors have abandoned some of last year's Internet plays. For example, Stamps.com, a company that sells postage over the Internet, has seen turmoil in top management ranks and now sells for less than $3 a share, down from a high of $98.50 last November and less than half the amount of cash per share the company has in the bank.

HEADLINE: Microsoft Handily Beats Estimates, Aided by Windows

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

 BODY:
Pointing to the strongest quarter ever for its Windows operating system, Microsoft yesterday surpassed analysts' earnings estimates for the latest quarter.
After the stock market closed, the company reported first-quarter earnings of 46 cents a share, up from 40 cents a year earlier and handily topping analysts' expectations of 41 cents, as reported to the First Call/Thomson Financial market research firm. 
 While the world's largest independent software company repeated its familiar cautions about potential perils of the global economy, it also said the quarter's results indicated that no slowdown in the desktop personal computer market loomed on the horizon.
The subject of whether the PC industry is moving away from its historical double-digit growth rate and toward becoming a replacement business and whether Microsoft will become a victim of the much heralded "Post-PC Era" is a perennial one for analysts who follow the company.
The company's revenue growth, year to year, jumped from 8 percent to 11 percent, said John Connors, Microsoft's chief financial officer.
"It feels good to be back in double-digit growth," he said. "The king is not dead."
Analysts, however, cautioned that while Microsoft's numbers for the quarter were strong, they were not stellar and that in the future the company would continue to grapple with the fact that its desktop software business is a mature one.
"When all is said and done, the quarter was a little better than expected," said Andrew Brosseau, an analyst at SG Cowan Securities in Boston. "But while you can push these numbers around, the company is still pulling a legacy business which accounts for 70 percent of their revenue, and that is not likely to accelerate."
For its first fiscal quarter, which ended Sept. 30, the company announced income before an accounting change of $2.58 billion, compared with $2.19 billion for the quarter last year. Revenue for the quarter reached $5.8 billion, up from $5.38 billion a year ago.
In a conference call with analysts, the company said it believed it would be able to maintain its growth rate.
"It seems likely that revenue will be up in the low teens" year to year, Mr. Connors said, and up in the high teens quarter to quarter.
Microsoft stock closed at $51.75, up $1.31, on volume of 55.3 million shares in Nasdaq trading. The shares rose a further 5 percent in after-hours trading. Mr. Connors also said he expected Microsoft earnings for its full fiscal year to come in slightly higher than the current consensus analyst estimate of $1.88 a share because of stronger-than-expected performance in its first quarter.
Microsoft did not reveal the adoption rate of its new Windows 2000 operating system, which is aimed at the corporate market, or its Windows ME program, intended for home users.
Windows 2000, introduced this spring, has generally received high marks from corporate users, though many analysts have said those users have been cautious.
In contrast, Windows ME has generally played to lackluster press reviews.
Yesterday the company gave some indication of large corporate commitments to the Windows 2000 program, citing customers like NASA, Siemens and Motorola, each of which is planning to deploy tens of thousands of copies of the program.
During the conference call the company also referred to weakness in its European business, which is experiencing both slower growth and currency conversion issues. Revenue in Europe, the Middle East and Africa declined from $1.18 billion for the first quarter of 1999 to $1.08 billion in the latest quarter.
Microsoft had its strongest growth in Asia, where revenue rose 19 percent, to $708 million. The company said that much of the growth reflected language-specific versions of Office 2000 and its corporate NT and Windows 2000 operating systems.
The company also said that first-quarter income from its investment portfolio increased to $1.13 billion from $550 million in the first quarter of the prior year.
In a speech at an industry conference yesterday in Orlando, Fla., Steven Ballmer, Microsoft's chief executive, said the company expected to win its battle with the Justice Department.
Microsoft is now appealing a federal judge's order to split the company into competing operating systems and applications businesses.
"We remain convinced we will not be broken up," Mr. Ballmer said, "and we are not putting a lot of energy on it. It is not really a question we spend time dwelling on. It is not actionable for us."
Mr. Ballmer said the company's most significant challenge remained finding and keeping talented people.
"The greatest challenge is in attracting, retaining and developing incredible people," he said. "The transient nature of the work force has been a challenge for us."

HEADLINE: In Streets and Parliament, Calls for Philippine President's Ouster

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: MANILA, Oct. 18

 BODY:
Cries for the ouster of President Joseph Estrada resounded in the halls of power and on the streets here today as opposition legislators filed a resolution to impeach him on charges of taking bribes from gambling rackets.
A few hours later, about 15,000 demonstrators massed in Manila's financial district to demand Mr. Estrada's resignation. Confetti streamed from the windows of the stock exchange as the ebullient crowd chanted and waved banners that said "Oust Estrada" and "No to corruption and cronyism." 
 For all the clamor, there is a growing recognition here that the drive to remove Mr. Estrada will be long and grueling and may well fail. The Philippine peso and the stock market plunged to fresh lows today as the political establishment appeared to dig in for a protracted siege.
"I think this will drag on, and the economy will continue to suffer," said Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, the Philippine vice president, who broke with Mr. Estrada and now heads a coalition of opposition leaders.
The lawmaker who introduced the impeachment resolution, Heherson T. Alvarez, conceded he did not have enough votes to move it out of the House of Representatives, which is dominated by allies of the president.
Mr. Alvarez said he hoped that enough of those legislators would defect from the increasingly discredited Mr. Estrada to pass the resolution. But even in the Senate, which would conduct a trial, a loose alliance of supporters could enable the president to escape conviction and keep his job.
"He's hoping this will blow over, like the other scandals blew over," said Feliciano Belmonte, the House minority leader.
Mr. Estrada, 63, has denied accepting any kickbacks from gambling rings. Today, he again refused to resign. Speaking to a friendly audience of former squatters who had been helped by a government housing project, he said: "I will help you all the way. Hopefully, you will do the same for me."
The president's troubles began last week when a provincial governor, Luis Singson, accused him of accepting more than $8 million in kickbacks from illegal gambling rings. Mr. Singson portrayed the president as a rapacious man who lives a twilight existence of heavy drinking and marathon mah-jongg games.
Advisers to Mr. Estrada noted that Mr. Singson, who says he made illegal payoffs to the president, was hardly a reputable witness. They said Mr. Estrada would respond to his claims in the impeachment proceeding.
Some political analysts said legal machinations would have little bearing on the president's survival. They said Mr. Estrada would lose his grip on power only if the economy suffers so badly as a result of the scandal that the country's poor begin to feel the pinch.
"The most immediate impact is the downward pressure on the peso," said Walden F. Bello, an economist at the University of the Philippines. "This hurts us because we are so dependent on imports."
Aware that their country is competing with Indonesia for the title of sick man of Asia, opposition leaders are uniting behind Vice President Arroyo, who would succeed Mr. Estrada if he steps down or is removed from office. They said they planned to develop policies that could be swiftly carried out by a new government.
Mr. Estrada was elected to a six-year term that expires in 2004; he cannot run again.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: SUBWAY SERIES;
If Yankees And Mets Are Up, Dow Isn't

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
Investors, watch out. There's a Subway Series coming. And that has meant, in the past anyway, that the stock market will most likely have a subpar year. Even worse, the Mets are going to be in it. When the Mets make it to the World Series, it is usually a good time to get out of the stock market.
Perhaps that reflects the fact that New York, the financial capital of the country, is distracted from its usual focus -- making money -- by the excitement of an interborough fight for baseball dominance, or even by the novelty of seeing the often-hapless Mets winning a pennant. 
 Or, more likely, it means nothing at all. The idea that baseball results should affect the stock market is not, on its face, an especially reasonable one.
Nonetheless, the record is there, and the Dow did have a bad day yesterday, the day after the Yankee victory Tuesday night confirmed that there would be a Subway Series.
This will be the 14th subway World Series, albeit the first since 1956 and the first involving the Mets. After, the previous 13 such series, 10 won by the Yankees, two by the New York Giants and one by the Brooklyn Dodgers, the Dow Jones industrial average rose by an average of 6 percent from the end of October through the end of the following October, when a new World Series champion was crowned.
That is not a horrible performance, but it is not nearly as good as the record in years when there was not a Subway Series. In those years, encompassing the years following 82 World Series (the Series wasn't played in 1904 and 1994), the average gain has been 7.6 percent.
In other words, having a Subway Series means that the stock market will, on average, do 1.6 percentage points less well than if there is not a Subway Series.
The Mets have never been in a Subway Series before, and they have only been in three previous Series. The first came in 1969, during what was then the longest economic expansion in American history, one that had lasted more than eight years. As it happened, that expansion ended a month after the Mets had surprisingly beaten the Baltimore Orioles, and a recession began in December 1969. By the end of October 1970, the Dow was down 11.7 percent. The current economic expansion, which is now more than nine years old, has replaced the 1961 to 1969 period as the longest expansion in history.
The next Mets appearance in the World Series came in 1973, when they lost to the Oakland A's. That same month saw an Arab-Israeli war, followed by an Arab oil embargo. Oil prices shot up to previously unheard of heights and the economy fell into a recession in November, the month after the Mets lost the World Series. By the end of October 1974, the Dow was down 30.4 percent as Wall Street entered its worst bear market since the Great Depression.
The Mets' third World Series appearance -- and the only one not quickly followed by a recession -- came in 1986, when the Mets defeated the Boston Red Sox. The stock market rallied impressively in the months after that series -- only to crash in October 1987. Still, the stock market ended October 1987 up 6.2 percent from a year earlier. That is a bit below par, but a lot better than after the Mets' first two World Series appearances.
The Yankees have, of course, been in more World Series than any other team. This will be the 37th World Series featuring the Bronx Bombers, who have won 25 World Series. In general, a Yankee World Series appearance has been a good omen for the stock market -- so long as the National League was represented by a team from out of town. In the years after a Yankee appearance against a non-New York team, the Dow has risen by an average of 12.4 percent, or more than twice as well as it has done following the average Subway Series.
The most recent Subway Series, in 1956, also came during the month of an Arab-Israeli war -- this one the Israeli invasion of the Sinai Peninsula after Egypt had seized the Suez Canal. The Yankees won that series, and the stock market fell 8.1 percent over the next year.
In fact, whether the opponent was from New York, the Dow has tended to do better when the Yankees lost in the World Series than when they won. And while the market has not done very well after any Mets appearances, its worst showing was after the Series they lost. The conclusion: any investor who believes that baseball can influence the stock market should be rooting for the Mets.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY;
AOL and Time Warner Slightly Beat Profit Estimates

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
With just a month or two before their proposed merger is expected to be consummated, America Online and Time Warner each posted quarterly earnings yesterday that were largely as expected. But the top management of both companies spent much of the day trying to counter the pessimism on Wall Street.
They argued that they would not be hurt by any slowdown in advertising by Internet companies and indeed had already discovered ways that their combination would accelerate their growth. 
 "We will be able to achieve more value creation for shareholders together than either of us could achieve alone," Gerald M. Levin, Time Warner's chief executive, said in a two-hour meeting with analysts yesterday morning at the Time Life Building in Manhattan to discuss Time Warner's results. That was followed by a lunch for journalists and an hourlong conference call yesterday afternoon to discuss America Online's results.
The executives were reacting to the increasing doubts about the companies' prospects implicit in their stock prices. On Tuesday, Time Warner's shares fell 16 percent and America Online's shares fell 17 percent. Both media and Internet stocks have been hard hit as investors worry that economic uncertainties, particularly the dot-com downturn, could hurt ad sales.
Stephen M. Case, the chairman of America Online, argued that the advertising client lists of both companies were quite diversified, with established companies outnumbering start-ups. "We have looked at our vulnerability to the dot-com sector, and only a few percentage points are potentially at risk," Mr. Case said in an interview. "Some businesses don't succeed, but other ones come to take their place. That's no different on the Internet than on television or with billboards."
Yesterday, as media company shares gained but most Internet companies saw their stocks fall further, the shares of Time Warner and America Online rebounded. Time Warner's stock rose $3.69, to $69.25, and America Online was up $3.31, to $46.91. After hours, America Online's shares rose as high as $51.
Mr. Levin also sought to reassure investors that the companies were "highly confident" that they would pass their review by federal regulators without debilitating conditions and would close the deal before the end of the year.
Last week, the merger was approved by European regulators, but only after Time Warner withdrew its proposed joint venture in music publishing with EMI. Mr. Levin said the companies hoped to renegotiate a deal with EMI and submit it again to European regulators next year.
Analysts said the results posted by both companies were mixed but generally on track with expectations. Both slightly beat their earnings-per-share forecasts. But Time Warner fell short of expected revenue. And America Online's closely watched advertising backlog -- a measure of contracts for revenue in future quarters -- showed no growth in the quarter. But in a period when companies big and small are announcing significant shortfalls, analysts took that as good news.
"In this market coming in at expectations is significant when so many companies are not able to do that," said Paul W. Noglows, an analyst at Chase H&Q.
Specifically, America Online earned $345 million, up from $181 million a year earlier, an increase of 91 percent. Its revenue grew 34 percent, to $2 billion.
Excluding one-time items and certain tax breaks, the company earned 14 cents a share, higher than the 13 cents analysts expected.
Time Warner earned $85 million, down 76 percent from a year earlier. Last year, Time Warner had a number of unusual items including a $477 million gain related to the sale of cable systems. Its revenue was $6.9 billion, up 3 percent, but substantially shy of Wall Street's expectations of $7.3 billion.
On a per-share basis, excluding one-time items, the company earned 7 cents a share, higher than the 4 cents that Wall Street expected.
In any case, the company prefers for investors to look at its operating cash flow -- earnings before taxes and some noncash accounting charges -- adjusted to remove one-time items. By that measure, the company's operating cash flow was $1.27 billion, up 13 percent.
The companies said they had completed a joint business plan and budget, in anticipation of the merger, and they reiterated their aggressive targets for future growth.
Mr. Levin said the combined company wanted its operating profit to increase 30 percent next year and 25 percent in subsequent years.
"It's significant, given everything that is happening in the market, that they didn't back away from their forecasts," Mr. Noglows said. "This company wants to grow faster than other diversified media companies, which have growth rates in the high teens and low 20's."
Both companies said advertising represented their fastest-growing source of revenue. Time Warner's advertising revenue grew 17 percent, to $1.3 billion. The same category at America Online increased 80 percent, to $649 million.
Subscriber growth at America Online continued to be brisk, despite even more aggressive competition from Microsoft's MSN service. Its flagship America Online service added 1.4 million subscribers in the quarter to 24.6 million worldwide, as international growth made up for a slowdown in the United States.
At Time Warner, cable systems and networks, which include HBO and CNN, were the strongest divisions. Cash flow declined 6 percent in the company's movie studio, its largest division by revenue. But its Warner Music division, which has been struggling, increased cash flow by 10 percent.

INDUSTRY: SIC7379 COMPUTER RELATED SERVICES, NEC (90%); SIC7375 INFORMATION RETRIEVAL SERVICES (90%);
