HEADLINE: SENATE APPROVES EASING SANCTIONS ON FOOD TO CUBA

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES with LIZETTE ALVAREZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18

 BODY:
The Senate today overwhelmingly approved a bill easing nearly four decades of sanctions on the sale of food to Cuba, all but assuring the measure will become law.
But in doing so, the lawmakers added restrictions that will make it difficult, perhaps impossible, for food shipments to be made to Cuba in the near future, many farmers, lobbyists and trade group officials said of the 86-to-8 vote. 
 Politically powerful agricultural interests, eyeing a potential market, pressed hard for the removal of sanctions against food sales. But when it came to altering this abiding vestige of the cold war in an election year, opponents pushed back.
Anti-Castro Cuban-Americans in Florida, a hotly contested state in the presidential election, were able to win new restrictions on travel to Cuba and prohibitions on United States government credit and private financing for any sales.
"Wait till these farmers who think that they were given a great new market to deal in, wait till they try to get a visa to go there or try to get financing, they're going to be furious," said Senator Christopher J. Dodd, a Democrat from Connecticut, who voted for the bill.
The easing of sanctions passed by the Senate today was contained in a $78 billion agriculture spending bill approved by the House on Oct. 11.
President Clinton has indicated that he will sign the bill, despite reservations over language he views as infringing on executive authority by barring a president from imposing sanctions on food and medicine without Congress's permission.
Cuban government officials have been sharply critical of the legislation, portraying it as a missed opportunity and stating flatly that Cuba has no plans to buy food from the United States.
In Havana today, President Fidel Castro led a large protest against the bill, which he called insulting. "They have included a load of restrictions which are humiliating for the country, and make it impossible in practice," Mr. Castro said before the demonstration. Page A9.
Indicative of the political sensitivity of the issue, the campaign of Vice President Al Gore had no immediate comment on today's vote, and his rival, Governor George W. Bush, condemned the Senate action. "Governor Bush opposes changing the sanctions against Cuba until Fidel Castro or the Cuban government allow free elections, free speech and freedom for political prisoners," said Ray Sullivan, a spokesman for Mr. Bush.
 The agriculture bill includes a measure to allow pharmacies and wholesalers to reimport cheaply priced American-made prescription drugs that had been exported, with certain restrictions.
In addition to the provision on Cuba, the bill permits the sale of food and medicine to Iran, Sudan, Libya and North Korea, transactions that are in large part already permitted. Those countries may request United States government credits and private financing, conditional on a presidential waiver.
Cuba may not ask for such a waiver, but farmers and agribusiness officials nonetheless described the bill as "a crack in the door," in the words of Van Yeutter of Cargill Inc., a large commodities company.
Advocates of more open trade with Cuba foresee returning to the issue next year when the tricky politics of the presidential campaign have passed.
"I don't think you'll have the political dynamic with Florida and the Cuban-American community and their basic impact," said Senator Pat Roberts, a Kansas Republican who strongly supports easing sanctions. "You're talking about 7 percent of the electorate in a state that has very close elections for the House, the Senate and the presidency."
The United States government first imposed a ban on trade with Cuba in 1962, after the Communist government seized more than 6,000 American-owned properties. While Cuba is a small market -- 11.2 million people -- its nearness to the United States and the fact it imports most of its food makes it an enticing market for American farmers.
Choosing their words carefully, farmers -- along with most Democrats and some farm-state Republicans -- said they would have much preferred the Senate's original version of the bill. That version lifted sanctions on food and medicine outright and received a large bipartisan vote in the Senate. A similar bill also was initially approved by wide margins in the House.
But House Republican leaders succeeded in weakening the final bill, drafted by Representative George Nethercutt, a Washington Republican, at the behest of two Republican Cuban-American lawmakers from Florida. The two lawmakers -- Representatives Lincoln Diaz-Balart and Ileana Ros-Lehtinen -- claimed victory on the issue.
Under the compromise in Congress, Cuba would be barred from receiving United States government credit and private financing to buy food from American farmers. Instead, Cuba, a considerable credit risk, must either persuade a foreign bank to lend it money or pay cash. "The fact of the matter is it's going to be a difficult road in putting together business," Mr. Yeutter said. "Financing is a big issue. The country doesn't have much money today."
Cuba withdrew from the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund in the 1960's and so is barred from any financing from them. And while Cuba now imports a number of goods from France, Canada, China, Mexico, Argentina and other countries, the sales are heavily subsidized.
"Which banks will want to take the risk of the Cubans defaulting?" asked Wayne Hammon, director of government relations for the National Association of Wheat Growers.

HEADLINE: Cubans March Against U.S. Bill on Embargo

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: HAVANA, Oct. 18

 BODY:
Waving placards with portraits of Abraham Lincoln, hundreds of thousands of Cubans marched today in hopes of convincing Americans that legislation passed by both houses of Congress will make it harder for them to visit the island.
The march was being held to show the world, "and especially American public opinion, what our people think of the gross lie that the genocidal blockade has been softened," the Communist daily Granma said. 
 Wearing his usual olive green uniform with white athletic shoes for marching, Fidel Castro led a crowd that the government estimated at 800,000 down Malecon coastal highway. Such a crowd would total 40 percent of the capital's population.
The Havana government insists that the legislation passed by the House last week and by the Senate today will toughen rather than ease the nearly four-decade embargo against the island. The bill has been described in Washington as offering the first opportunity in 38 years for American farmers to sell food to Cuba, as well as the first step in the easing of trade sanctions.
But because the legislation would bar the United States government and banks from financing the food sales, Cuba would have to pay cash or get credit from a third country.
"In practice, it will be totally impossible to buy food and medicine from the United States," read an editorial published on Monday in state newspapers. In protest, "our country will not buy a single cent of food or medicine from the United States," it asserted.
Among the authorities' biggest complaints about the legislation is that it will further restrict American travel to Cuba. Most Americans are already effectively barred from visiting Cuba because of spending restrictions imposed by the embargo, and the Congressional proposal would codify those regulations.
The Cuban government has also complained that support among Americans for the lifting of the embargo has been eroded in recent months by election-year politics. It worries that many Americans believe the current measure will do much more to ease sanctions than it actually will.
"Down with the blockade!" a series of speakers chanted today over a public address system set up outside the American mission here. "Long live the revolution!"

HEADLINE: Metro Business Briefing

 BODY:

LUXURY BUILDING
A $50 million luxury building for the elderly, the first in Manhattan developed specifically for that purpose, opened its doors yesterday. Monthly fees -- which cover breakfast and 20 dinners, activities and housekeeping -- for the building, the Hallmark at Battery Park City, range from $3,990 for a studio apartment to $9,290 for two bedrooms and a den. Ulrich R. Wall, the executive director of the Hallmark, said 88 of the 197 apartments for independent living had been rented, as had 2 of the 20 units set aside for people who require more assistance. The building is owned and operated by Brookdale Living Communities, a national company based in Chicago. Terry Pristin (NYT) 

DEVELOPER SOUGHT IN QUEENS
The Giuliani administration is seeking a developer to buy and expand a city-owned garage and commercial building in an area of Long Island City, Queens, where major rezoning is proposed to spur commercial revitalization. The five-story building, with about 180,000 square feet of space, now houses a public garage with 1,100 parking spaces, a furniture store and offices. The proposed rezoning, which would increase the size of buildings permitted on many sites in the area, would allow for about one million square feet of space to be added at the garage site, the city's Economic Development Corporation said. The site, near the end of the Queensboro Bridge, is bounded by Queens Plaza South, Jackson Avenue, 42nd Road and 28th Street. The rezoning proposal requires City Council approval to become law, which could come more than a year from now. But a corporation spokesman, Gregory Miley, said, "We're confident it will receive all the necessary approvals." Joseph P. Fried (NYT)
 
HIGH-SPEED TRAIN
Amtrak's long-delayed high-speed train, the Acela Express, will begin service between Washington and Boston on Dec. 11, railroad officials announced at a news conference yesterday in Washington. Acela trains will travel up to 150 m.p.h., compared with other Amtrak trains, which reach a top speed of 125 m.p.h. The high-speed trains will shorten the typical four-hour trip between Boston and New York by one hour. The first train's arrival was was highlighted during the news conference, and 19 more have been ordered for next summer. The service was scheduled to begin last October but premature wheel wear and problems with the technology that helps the train negotiate curves were among the causes for the delay. The railroad is under a congressional order to become financially self-sufficient by 2003. High-speed service in the Northeast Corridor is projected to earn $180 million a year. (AP)

HEADLINE: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: EUROPE;
BRITISH UNEMPLOYMENT FALLS

BYLINE: By Alan Cowell 

 BODY:
For the 19th consecutive month, British unemployment fell, reaching a 25-year low of 3.6 percent, in another reflection of the strength in the economy. But there have been recent signs that growth could ease. The Bank of England said its monetary policy committee voted unanimously this month to hold the benchmark interest rate at 6 percent because reduced growth in the United States and the Continent's euro zone and falling stock prices and rising oil costs raised risks of a slowdown. Alan Cowell

SECTION: Section A;Page 14;Column 3;Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1250 words

HEADLINE: WORLD BRIEFING

BYLINE: Compiled by Terence Neilan

 BODY:

EUROPE
 
ITALY: VOTING ABROAD -- A constitutional amendment was approved to allow Italians overseas to elect their own legislators, including candidates who live abroad. Twelve seats in the 630-seat lower house and six in the 315-seat Senate are to be allocated to representatives of Italians abroad, of whom there are about 4 million, with more than 300,000 in the United States and Canada. First, however, a law must be passed setting up candidates' procedural rules. Voting by absentee ballot is not allowed. Alessandra Stanley (NYT)
 
FRANCE: CABINET RESIGNATION -- Martine Aubry, the cabinet minister who shepherded the introduction of the government's 35-hour workweek policy, has quit her cabinet post to run for mayor of Lille. The widely expected move is seen as a steppingstone to run for higher office in 2002. If Prime Minister Lionel Jospin, who is expected to run for president in 2002, were to win, Mrs. Aubry could well replace him as prime minister. Mr. Jospin named his justice minister, Elisabeth Guigou, to take over Mrs. Aubry's portfolio. Suzanne Daley (NYT) 

RUSSIA: AMERICAN'S TRIAL DELAYED -- A Moscow court granted a one-day delay in the espionage trial of Edmond Pope, the American businessman accused of trying to buy secret plans for a torpedo, so lawyers could draft specifications for an evaluation of Mr. Pope's bone cancer. Lawyers argue that Mr. Pope, in jail since April, has been denied proper medical care. Judges denied other requests in the closed-door trial, including a plea for a jury. Michael Wines (NYT)
 
BRITAIN: TORTURE REPORT -- Amnesty International said torture is increasing around the world, in dictatorships and democracies. At a news conference, Pierre Sane, secretary general of the London-based rights group, said it had uncovered evidence of beatings, rape, electric shock and other forms of torture in more than 150 countries, including Britain and the United States. Between 1997 and 2000 there was evidence of widespread torture by state agents in more than 70 countries, the group said. Sarah Lyall (NYT)
 
AUSTRIA: TALKS ON NUCLEAR PLANT -- Chancellor Wolfgang Schussel and Prime Minister Milos Zeman of the Czech Republic plan to meet on Oct. 31 in the Czech city of Brno to try to resolve a dispute over a nuclear plant in Temelin, some 35 miles from the Austrian border. The Czech foreign minister, Jan Kavan, said the meeting would take place only if a suspended blockade of the border by antinuclear protesters was officially called off. Victor Homola (NYT)
 
SWITZERLAND: PRESIDENT TO QUIT -- President Adolf Ogi said he would resign this year, leading to speculation of a change in the traditional coalition-style government. Mr. Ogi was at odds with the rightward turn of his Swiss People's Party, which did well in last year's elections on an anti-refugee platform. The anti-Europe views of a leading party figure, Christoph Blocher, differed from Mr. Ogi's. With Mr. Ogi gone, Mr. Blocher may again try to win a seat on the country's governing council. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)
 
MIDDLE EAST
 
EGYPT: VOTING BEGINS -- Elections for the 444-seat People's Assembly got under way, with scattered reports of harassment or arrests of people supporting independent candidates. The governing National Democratic Party was expected to maintain its overwhelming majority in the Parliament, where a handful of small opposition parties together control only 6 percent of the seats. Voting will also take place on Oct. 29 and Nov. 8. Abeer Allam (NYT)
 
IRAN: KHATAMI HITS OUT -- President Mohammad Khatami denounced the "sick" campaign against his reform movement and warned of an explosion of popular anger if his rivals continue to ignore the will of the people, the state news agency said. In an emotional defense before an audience of students, Mr. Khatami made a rare direct attack on conservatives who have hobbled his efforts to liberalize Iran's social and political life.
 (Agence France-Presse)
 
AFRICA
 
NIGERIA: RIOTS SPREAD -- Soldiers joined the police in patrolling the streets of Lagos after riots that have already led to more than 100 deaths spread throughout the commercial capital. The security forces fired shots in the air to disperse rioters, many of whom appeared to be unemployed youths known as area boys. The violence began with clashes between a Yoruba group and Hausa merchants. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)
 
ZIMBABWE: PROTESTS IN THIRD DAY -- Protesters angered by soaring food prices clashed with the police in the townships near Harare for a third day. Police officers and soldiers patrolled several townships, searched houses and sprayed tear gas when protesters tried to block roads. With the economy unraveling, inflation is soaring, and the price of bread and sugar surged by 30 percent this month. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)
 
THE AMERICAS
 
CANADA: BACKTRACKING ON MOUNTAIN -- Bowing to western pressure, the government is backtracking on a decision to rename the nation's highest peak, Mount Logan, after Pierre Elliott Trudeau, the former prime minister who died on Sept. 28. With sympathy for Mr. Trudeau low in the west, Prime Minister Jean Chretien, who is expected to call an election for Nov. 27, has indicated that he now supports a Yukon Territory proposal to name a sub-peak of Mount Logan after the French Canadian. James Brooke (NYT)
 
MEXICO: TABASCO VOTE IN DOUBT -- With two rivals claiming victory, and the leadership of Mexico's long-governing political party in the balance, results of Sunday's election for governor in the state of Tabasco will not be known before the weekend, election overseers said. Preliminary results gave a 1 percent lead to Manuel Andrade, the hand-picked successor to Gov. Roberto Madrazo, who wants to be the next national leader of the Institutional Revolutionary Party. His opponent, Raul Ojeda, of the left-leaning Party of the Democratic Revolution, says the lead was built by fraud.
 Tim Weiner (NYT)
 
CHILE: TRUCK STRIKE CONTINUES -- Striking truckers obstructed roads throughout the country for a second day, and concern grew over possible food and fuel shortages. Leaders of the National Confederation of Truck Owners, who transport 92 percent of the freight hauled in Chile, said more than 7,500 vehicles were involved in the protest against a tax on diesel fuel. The government put the figure at 2,000 vehicles. (Reuters)
 
ASIA
 
CHINA: FALUN GONG DEATHS -- Three more followers of the outlawed Falun Gong spiritual movement have died in police custody, bringing the known total to 57 since the group was banned last year, according the Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy, based in Hong Kong. A 61-year-old man in Shandong Province died last week after he was arrested for distributing Falun Gong literature, the group said. Another follower jumped from a train and died while being repatriated to Shandong, while a third follower died after he fell from a building during police questioning. Erik Eckholm (NYT)
 
SRI LANKA: PRESIDENT'S BROTHER IS SPEAKER -- President Chandrika Kumaratunga's estranged brother, Anura Bandaranaike, was elected speaker of Parliament. The sister and brother come from the country's leading political dynasty. Both their parents served as prime minister. Mrs. Kumaratunga heads the ruling coalition, which has just returned to power. Her brother is a leader of the opposition United National Party. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

PUB-DATE: October 20, 2000

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 42; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 4771 words

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE

 BODY:
A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.
 
Museums
 
"AMAZONS OF THE AVANT-GARDE," Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through Jan. 7). A concise exercise, monographically arranged, this show focuses on six Russian women who painted around the time of the revolution. Several continued to work much later and do more than paint, but this is a tendentious affair, plausibly so. If only a couple of the women, Natalia Goncharova and Liubov Popova, were truly great painters, the exhibition still isn't a case of special pleading. The Russian avant-garde wouldn't have been what it was without them collectively. The story as it unfolds here seems, if anything, more remarkable, not less, for having as little to do with sex as it does and almost everything to do with painting. Many of the works have a surprising fortitude. Revolution. A brave new art world. The dream persists even though the form it takes keeps changing. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 9 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $12; $8 for students and the elderly (Michael Kimmelman). 

 "A BRUSH WITH NATURE: THE GERE COLLECTION OF LANDSCAPE OIL SKETCHES," Frick Collection, 1 East 70th Street, (212) 288-0700 (through Nov. 12). Most of the artists in this show -- English, French, Italian, German, Belgian and Scandinavian, from the 17th to the 19th centuries -- are barely known today. In their own age they did something quite offbeat: they left studios to paint outdoors, registering transient moments of light and atmosphere by sketching quickly in oil from nature. Until recently it was assumed that this plein-air approach, used to train hand and eye for more ambitious compositions, began with the Impressionists. These canvases today are sought-after prizes. The 68 on view here were assembled by a pioneering scholar and collector in the field, John Gere (1921-1995), former Keeper of Prints and Drawings at the British Museum, and his wife, Charlotte. Mostly painted in Rome and the surrounding countryside, they capture such painterly events as the seamed face of a rock, the rush of water through a valley, the play of sunlight on a ruin, the quirky architecture of a building or a wall. Tune your eye to small when you look at this show, and you'll find it a treasure. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 6 p.m. Admission: $7; $5 for students (over 10) and the elderly (Grace Glueck).
 
 * "THE EMBODIED IMAGE: CHINESE CALLIGRAPHY FROM THE JOHN B. ELLIOTT COLLECTION," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Jan. 7). In China the written word has traditionally been the highest art form and a source of political and emotional power. To see that power in action, check out this grandly scaled exhibition, which brings together two superb calligraphy collections -- from Princeton University and the Met -- in the most comprehensive survey yet seen in these parts. The dozens of scrolls covered with hand-written words collectively radiate a kind of conversational buzz and suggest a richly varied cast of personalities: fastidious court functionaries, impulsive social agitators, unworldly monks, visionary poets. Together they offer an ice-breaking introduction to an art that can all too easily seem, to non-Chinese speakers, unapproachable. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:15 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 8:45 p.m. Admission: $10; $5 for students and the elderly (Holland Cotter).
 
 "AN ENGAGEMENT WITH FOLK ART: CYRIL I. NELSON'S GIFTS TO THE MUSEUM OF AMERICAN FOLK ART," 2 Lincoln Square, at West 66th Street, (212) 595-9533 (through Jan. 7). This show celebrates the largesse of Mr. Nelson, a book editor and folk art collector, who has given 113 objects to the museum with the promise of more. The works, from the late-18th to the mid-20th centuries, cover the traditional areas of folk art -- portraits, landscapes, sculptures, painted and decorated furniture -- but the focus is on American needlework: quilts, coverlets, blankets and the like. Among the quilt spectaculars is the "Samuel Steinberger Log Cabin Quilt, Courthouse Steps Variation," by a 19th-century immigrant. Painted furniture, too, shines in this show. The painting and sculpture pieces make a more modest impression, but overall, what's on view represents a refined, solid ensemble that is very visitable. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11:30 a.m. to 7:30 p.m. Free (Glueck).
 
 "IN THE PRESENCE OF SPIRITS," African Art From the National Museum of Ethnology in Lisbon, Museum for African Art, 593 Broadway, near Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 966-1313 (through Dec. 31). Shown in quantity for the first time in the United States, this collection from the former Portuguese colonies of Angola, Mozambique and Guinea-Bissau was assembled by the Portuguese government, starting in the 1960's. The more than 140 objects on view relate to the secular and the supernatural in African culture: masks, power figures, dolls, decorated stools and chairs, pipes, posts and other artifacts. Outstanding is a group of initiation masks made from wood and more fragile materials like feathers, fabrics and barkcloth fibers; ranging from fierce to benign in expression, they are giddily imaginative. Impressive, too, is a selection of dolls, important in the socialization of girls, from the Ambo people of southwestern Angola. The objects in the show were chosen for their high aesthetic value, and it doesn't disappoint. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $2.50 for children, students and the elderly (Glueck).
 
 LEE KRASNER, Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Jan. 7). Despite its restless energy and moments of formal power and elegance, Lee Krasner's career in this economical retrospective looks more like one of tantalizing frustration than real fulfillment. In the 1950's and early 60's, Krasner painted splattery, ambitious Abstract Expressionist works, but they look indebted to other artists, Pollock and de Kooning mainly. Where she looks most herself is in collage; a set of large collages on canvas from the early 50's have raw density or explosive buoyancy. Collages made in the 1970's using 40-year-old charcoal drawings have a beautiful Cubistic elegance; they are the best works of her career. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. (until 11 p.m. on the first Saturday of each month); Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $4; $2 for students and the elderly (Ken Johnson).
 
 "OPEN ENDS," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53rd Street, (212) 708-9400 (through Jan. 2). The third and final cycle of "MOMA 2000," the year-and-a-half-long, millennium-marking rethinking of the Modern's permanent collection, is off and running, with the first of three staggered floor-through sections in place. The dates covered are 1960 to the present, so there's some sense of how a bastion of modernism is dealing with a postmodern world. Pretty well, judging from recent acquisitions of work by Pipilotti Rist, Matthew Barney and Cai Guo-Qiang. The real interest, though, is in smart theme shows that play with such contemporary fixations as childhood innocence and adult experience, and the blend of art, abjection and design. (The third-floor galleries open on Nov. 5.) Hours: Saturdays through Tuesdays and Thursdays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 8:15 p.m. Admission: $10; $6.50, students and the elderly (Cotter).
 
 "PIERRE ET GILLES," New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, near Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 219-1222 (through Jan. 7). No history of postmodern photography, fashion photography, celebrity portraiture, record album covers or the highbrow beefcake tradition would be complete without the work of the French photo team known as Pierre et Gilles, who have collaborated on over-the-top, tightly styled, hand-finished photographs since 1976 and become wildly famous in Europe in the process. In their first American museum retrospective, their work feels more than a little embalmed, existing behind a not-so-invisible shield of artistic conservatism. Certain images come to life as art objects -- most notably, one of a beautiful young sailor up to his chest in water with an iridescent night sky behind him -- but those are few. Hours: Wednesdays and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Thursdays through Saturdays, until 8 p.m. Admission: $6; $3 for students, artists and the elderly (Roberta Smith).
 
 * BRIDGET RILEY, "Reconnaissance," Dia Center for the Arts, 548 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, (212) 989-5566 (through June 17). Once overly identified with Op Art, this British abstract painter never got her due in anti-Op New York, but this beautifully installed show of 40 paintings from 1961 to 1984 should change things. Concentrating on the early black-and-white paintings that made Ms. Riley famous, it presents stringently pure yet accessible works that have, at their best, extended the optical potential implicit in the work of Mondrian, Josef Albers and Ad Reinhardt. At their weakest, their meticulously calibrated patterns can be so aggressive that they virtually kidnap the eye, take it on a joy ride and leave it in a crumpled heap. Either way, the overall effect is of an artist of unusual dedication who has remained loyal to the original premises of her art and yet steadfastly refused to repeat herself. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $6; $3, students and the elderly (Smith).
 
 "RUSKIN'S ITALY, RUSKIN'S ENGLAND," Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street, (212) 685-0610 (through Jan. 7). This show commemorates the 100th anniversary of the death of John Ruskin (1819-1900), artist, art and architectural critic, social reformer, educator and the first official professor of art in England. From its own collections, the Morgan has mined a biographical medley of letters, manuscripts, photographs, drawings, paintings and artifacts relating to the life of this Victorian giant, whose published writings run to 39 volumes. Although not really an art show, it includes paintings and drawings by Ruskin and artists he admired, among them J. M. W. Turner and the Pre-Raphaelites John Everett Millais, William Holman Hunt, Edward Burne-Jones and Dante Gabriel Rossetti. It touches on his widely influential books of criticism, his beautifully finished sketches of architectural structures, his teaching and his monographs on proposed social reforms. Not omitted are his 1877 attack on James McNeill Whistler, his failed marriage and attraction to young girls and his sad end after a long siege of mental illness. But there is much to celebrate in his life, and this show doesn't stint. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, 10:30 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays, 10:30 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $8; $6 for students and the elderly; free for children under 13 with an adult (Glueck).
 
 * SCYTHIAN GOLD. "The Golden Deer of Eurasia: Scythian and Sarmatian Treasures From the Russian Steppes," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Feb. 4.). "Gold of the Nomads: Scythian Treasures From Ancient Ukraine," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Jan. 21.). Certain kinds of art are box-office gold. Art made of gold is one of them, and there's a Fort Knox-size supply of the precious stuff in these two opulent exhibitions. The Brooklyn show is a survey-style glimpse at some exquisitely wrought 14-carat objects drawn from museums in Ukraine, where the Scythians put down roots in the first millennium B.C. The Met has drop-dead museological rarities from the State Hermitage Museum, but the focus here, which gives the proceedings a kind treasure-hunt thrill, is on a cache of objects excavated fairly recently from tombs belonging to non-Scythian people whose identity is something of a mystery. Ideally, the two shows should be seen together: they offer a really substantial archaeological update on the last big Scythian showcase in these parts, the Met's smash-hot "In the Land of the Scythians" of 25 years ago. Hours and admission: See above( Cotter).
 
 * EDWARD STEICHEN, Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3676 (through Feb. 4). A big, thorough exhibition, maybe a little too big and glossy, of one of the great photographers in American history, a restless, benign, flawed genius. Steichen also painted, made films, designed textiles, organized aerial reconnaissance photography in two world wars and put together the most popular photography exhibition ever, "The Family of Man." We'll see how people respond to someone whose eclectic work can look, if anything, almost too elegant and self-regarding. Steichen ultimately seemed to reduce everything and everyone to props to demonstrate his own refined and stage-savvy sensibility. But what refinement. His best work has a finesse that borders on the erotic. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $12.50; $10.50 for students and the elderly (Kimmelman).
 
Galleries: Uptown
 
DAN FLAVIN, Zwirner & Wirth, 32 East 69th Street, (212) 517-8677 (through Nov. 4). Flavin's simple, fluorescent-light works from the 60's illuminate this posh new gallery to simultaneously matter-of-fact and mystically radiant effect. The white ones have classic Minimalist rigor; examples consisting of just two or three colors are almost hedonistically sumptuous (Johnson).
 
 JOHN GOSSAGE AND HERMANN VOGEL, "Empire," Roth Horowitz, 160a East 70th Street, (212) 717-9067 (through Oct. 28). A veteran Conceptualist photographer, Mr. Gossage has orchestrated a dry but sly installation that intersperses his own oblique, fragmentary photographs of famous American memorials (shot on surveillance film using a hand-made telephoto lens) with beautiful, mid-19th-century photographs of Egyptian archaeological sites by the German photographer Vogel. This produces a suggestive layering of histories and politics (Johnson).
 
 "REMBRANDT AND THE VENETIAN INFLUENCE," Salander-O'Reilly Galleries, 20 East 79th Street, (212) 879-6606 (through Nov. 18). The Venetian influence in Rembrandt's later paintings has long been noted; this show is an attempt to demonstrate by specific examples. But the topic is more suited to a museum presentation; this one mounts only a dozen paintings, three by Rembrandt and one labeled "Studio of Rembrandt," along with oils by Titian, Tintoretto and Veronese. It is too small and catch-as-catch can to make the case. The most salient example here of Venice in Rembrandt is his great painting "Flora" (circa 1654). Next to it, the other works in this show pale (Glueck).
 
Galleries: 57th Street
 
MAGDALENA ABAKANOWICZ, Marlborough, 40 West 57th Street, (212) 541-4900 (through Oct. 28). This pre-eminent Polish sculptor's regiment of 95 life-size, headless shells of human figures in rough bronze confronts the visitor here, creating a theater of tragic existentialism. On the terrace, giant, simplified dinosaur heads suggest a deep background of primordial terror (Johnson).
 
 * RINEKE DIJKSTRA, Marian Goodman Gallery, 24 West 57th Street, (212) 977-7160 (through Oct. 28). This Dutch artist's solo debut in the United States includes a video (much seen elsewhere) of dancing teenagers in European clubs and a series of photographs she has been taking since 1997 of children in parks. In the video the youngsters preen touchingly. The photographs, color pictures along the lines of Thomas Struth's but more casual and less chilly, are heroic portraits, acutely sympathetic (Kimmelman).
 
Galleries: SoHo
 
LARRY CALKINS, American Primitive, 594 Broadway, near Houston Street, (212) 966-1530 (through Oct. 28). Mr. Calkins, who is based in Washington State, is self-taught but his work in various media has a professional-looking sophistication. Flat, child-size dresses on hangers -- one sprouting big nails, another festooned with little discs bearing the image of a moth -- are materially rough but poetically graceful. The surfaces of small paintings made of soot swarm mysteriously with ghostly images of flying insects (Johnson).
 
 MONIKA KULICKA, John Gibson, 568 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 925-1192 (through Oct. 30). As a protest against modern civilization's mechanization of the world, this young Polish artist who now lives in New York has slathered real, mossy green chlorophyll over five pieces of old wood furniture in a quixotic attempt to restore the dead wood to life. The absurdity of the gesture is amusing and yet somehow a little sad (Johnson).
 
 "LIFE, AFTER THE SQUIRREL," Location One, 26 Greene Street, (212) 334-3347 (through Oct. 28). This nutty fun house of a show begins with Filipe Miguel's rustic shed, supposedly inhabited by post-apocalyptic squirrels. The main exhibition space has a squishy plastic floor and a ceiling of inflated pine trees. Works include Tony Tasset's stuffed "Dead Bluejay"; Aernout Mik's video of old men horsing around; a hypnotic video by Pipilotti Rist; John Neff's deadpan video recital of Hal the computer's last speech; and Vincent Pruden's provocative makeup table for applying blackface (Johnson).
 
 ALICE MAHER, Nolan/Eckman, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 925-6190 (through Oct. 28). An Irish sculptor who creates evocative metaphors in a variety of media, Ms. Maher is having her first New York exhibition. "Gorget" consists of two sets of nine potato-size, smoothed-over female heads that look like archaeological treasures; one set is of solid crystal, the other, of chrome-plated bronze, looks as though it were made of mercury. On paper, the artist draws fields of interwoven loopy lines that look like undulating expanses of netting (Johnson).
 
 "PARADISE NOW: PICTURING THE GENETIC REVOLUTION," Exit Art, 548 Broadway, near Prince Street, (212) 966-7748 (through Oct. 28). "We are at a threshold," declares the text panel at the start of this show. And we are, you know. Never mind that most of the art isn't great, because with more and more artists tapping into science, something big is bound to happen soon. Think of this as a preliminary report. The works span a decade and run the gamut from paintings and sculptures to the collecting of sperm and the breeding of very tiny exotic frogs. The artists fret predictably about tampering with Mother Nature and stress identity politics, also predictably, but the spirit of the show, an intangible, tips the scales in a positive direction (Kimmelman).
 
 DAVID RABINOWITCH, Peter Blum, 99 Wooster Street, (212) 343-0441 (through Nov. 18). Restricting his vocabulary to circles, ovals and straight lines, and his means to pencil, ink or colored pencil, this Constructivist-Minimalist sculptor produced this series of extremely spare drawings during the early 1970's. Called "Construction of Vision," they are resolutely abstract and quasi-scientific. But the ellipses and angled lines, cleanly drawn with mechanical drafting tools, have a subtly playful animation (Johnson).
 
 CHRIS VERENE, American Fine Arts, 22 Wooster Street, (212) 941-0401 (through Nov. 11) and Paul Morris, 465 West 23rd Street, (212) 727-2752 (through Oct. 28) With often piercing intimacy, this 31-year-old photographer chronicles the lives of friends and relatives in his hometown of Galesburg, Ill. Each of 60 richly colored, squarish images in this two-gallery show has a brief handwritten text added by the artist. Under the picture of a cousin, Steve, and his young daughter at a McDonalds, the text says, "His wife had just left them to go to a battered woman's shelter." A dozen prints, at Paul Morris, tenderly document the daily existence of Mr. Verene's grandfather (Johnson).
 
 * NEIL WINOKUR, Janet Borden, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 431-0166 (through Oct. 28). For this delightful portrait of his hometown, Mr. Winokur has produced a series of 32 still-life photographs, each a crystal-clear, deadpan picture of an ordinary but richly iconic object against a bright colored backdrop. A Greek-style paper coffee cup, a Chinese food container, a Giants pennant, an old Broadway playbill, a Con Edison orange cone, a hot dog, a rat, a toy-size Empire State Building: these images produce a resonantly evocative cross section of New York experience (Johnson).
 
Galleries: Chelsea
 
DAMIEN HIRST, Gagosian Gallery, 555 West 24th Street, (212) 741-1111 (through Dec. 16). Welcome to the Damien Hirst Universe. It's a big shiny place with mathematical grid paper printed on the walls, pale pristine dot paintings and many large vitrine sculptures, including two outfitted as gynecological examining rooms and filled with water and fish. It shows the artist moving beyond the dead animals and putrefying flesh that catapulted him to fame while clarifying and enriching the grandiose themes of his art: life and death and their complex, sometimes oppressive relationship to science and commerce. It contains some undeniable duds, but if it doesn't win over those who have resisted the work of this notorious young British artist, it won't be for lack of trying (Smith).
 
 * PETER HUJAR, "Photographs, 1980 to 1987," Matthew Marks Gallery, 523 West 24th Street, (212) 243-0200 (through Oct. 28). A show of 98 photographs from Hujar's estate, some never shown before. The prints, on a particularly warm paper that is no longer made, are quite beautiful. One would not use that adjective for the images, which are powerful and quietly, deeply disturbing, full of pain but resolutely refusing to dramatize it, now and again touching, now and again amusing in an elegiac sort of way. They are portraits of friends, some nude, some in costume, some engaged in odd enterprises like biting into a strawberry. They are portraits -- they cannot be called anything else -- of animals. They are images of destruction: collapsed houses, the flayed carcasses of slain cows, a dead dog on a heap of trash. They are intense and reticent at the same time. They are memorable (Vicki Goldberg).
 
 ALBERT RENGER-PATZSCH, Tatintsian, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 633-0110 (through Oct. 28). If the German photographer Renger-Patzsch (1897-1966) were working today, he would probably make his formally perfect, subtly poetic pictures of industrialized landscapes, medieval church interiors and close-up plant studies into glossy, sofa-size Cibachromes. These small black-and-white vintage prints from the 1920's and 30's offer a welcome, intimately evocative respite from today's overly showy photo-aesthetics (Johnson).
 
Other Galleries
 
"RE-DRAWING THE LINE," Art in General, 79 Walker Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-0473 (through Oct. 28). This unfocused show of works in which line figures, literally or conceptually, includes an invigorating giant doodle by Diana Cooper; whited out ledger pages by Peter Wegner; the image of a scribble cut from brown felt by Arturo Herrera; a dripped line from a performance by Francis Alys; a string sculpture by Pae White; and tangled plastic zip ties by Mungo Thomson. The importance of line in obliquely conceptual works by Alessandro Balteo and Sophie Tottie is harder to see (Johnson).
 
Last Chance
 
SUZANNE ANKER, Universal Concepts Unlimited, 507 West 24th Street, (212) 727-7575 (through tomorrow). One of those Leonardo types who like to combine art and science, Ms. Anker presents silk-screened paintings and sculptures addressing the representation of genetics. Silk-screen panels display silvery, gridded fields of chromosome symbols with little human images mixed in. The 500 silver-painted, three-dimensional letters A, C, T and G piled on a glass panel refer to DNA. (Johnson).
 
 LOUISE FISHMAN, Cheim & Read, 521 West 23rd Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-7727 (through tomorrow). Ms. Fishman's Abstract Expressionist painting is still tough and gritty in its bluntly gestural, grid-based physicality, but now it has a lusciousness of color that verges on the hedonistic. "A Stranger," with its web of impulsively made, wide slate-gray lines over a salmon pink field, is a voluptuous yet still excitingly raw picture (Johnson).
 
 PETER GOULD, Kagan Martos, 515 Broadway, near Spring Street, SoHo, (212) 343-4293 (through tomorrow). This young Pop-Conceptualist presents two neat, small parklike installations based on fast-food restaurant landscaping. Grass is represented by green Formica and bushes by silhouettes cut from thin flat panels; stacked red bricks provide architectural framing. These cartoonlike abstractions of the modern, corporate oasis are quietly funny and oddly touching (Johnson).
 
 "IN THE EYE OF THE BEHOLDER," Kaikodo, 164 East 64th Street, (212) 223-0121 (through tomorrow). Kaikodo's sales exhibitions are always a treat, and the sheer number of Chinese and Japanese paintings in this one is a major lure. These days New Yorkers rarely get to see material in this quantity and variety outside museums. Highlights include an album painting of a flower attributed to the 13th-century artist Qian Xuan (it's very fragile, so you have to ask to see it); a 17th-century calligraphic scroll by the fractious Fu Shan; and a witty four-panel portrait of a family of gibbons, gold-medal acrobats all. Devotees of ceramics and textiles will also find much to admire (Cotter).
 
 BARBARA KRUGER, Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3600 (through Sunday). A lot has changed about the art world in the 20 years or so since Barbara Kruger came on the scene with her snappy photomontages, but a lot has not changed about her work. Her trademark red, white and black text-and-photograph montage is a brand product of the immediate past. Dense and noisy, this retrospective, including audio embellishments, has an intended carnival atmosphere without frivolity. Your reaction will necessarily depend on a blend of generational sympathy, political concord, aesthetic expectation and tolerance for sarcasm. Ms. Kruger in a sense helped pave the way for her own diminished currency, which for a political artist like her may be viewed as a kind of success. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $12.50; $10.50 for students and the elderly (Kimmelman).
 
 GERHARD RICHTER, Barbara Mathes, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 752-5135 (through tomorrow). This exhibition of small works by the enigmatic and hugely influential German painter features a group of canvases from the 80's and 90's bearing his familiar brand of beautifully scraped, dragged and squeegeed Abstract Expressionism and an intriguing six-part photographic self-portrait in which blurry shirtless men -- the artist himself multiply exposed -- do mysterious things in dim, empty rooms (Johnson).
 
 BRIDGET RILEY, "Paintings 1982-2000 and Early Works on Paper," PaceWildenstein, 32 East 57th Street, (212) 421-3292 (through tomorrow). This show picks up where the small survey of Bridget Riley's paintings at the Dia Center for the Arts in Chelsea leaves off, following her continued involvement with color through nine recent canvases, while a group of gouache studies from the 1960's documents the transition from black-and-white to color, through subtly vivid tones of gray (Smith).
 
 DAVID SMITH, "The Last Nudes," Gagosian, 980 Madison Avenue, at 76th Street, (212) 744-2313 (through tomorrow). Made in 1964 and not seen during the great modernist sculptor's lifetime, "The Last Nudes" is a series of paintings of naked women, each rendered in a loose, drippy black line on white easel-scale canvas. Smith used an enamel-loaded ear syringe to make them. The Freudian implications may be amusing -- the emission of vital fluids triggered by female flesh -- but the pictures, though not without a certain graphic vitality, are barely worth a glance (Johnson).

SECTION: Section F; Page 1; Column 1; Automobiles 

LENGTH: 1194 words

HEADLINE: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Safety;
Checking Tire Pressure From the Driver's Seat

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
WHATEVER the flaw that causes some Firestone tires to shed their treads, with sometimes lethal results, the company says that failure is highly unlikely if the tires are inflated properly.
Because the flaw remains unknown, that contention is unproved, but Congress evidently agrees with Firestone. An auto safety bill that both houses overwhelmingly approved last week made headlines mainly for increasing penalties for executives who hide safety defects. But it also included a provision that would eventually require systems to let a driver read the tire pressure on the car's instrument panel, similar to the dashboard warnings for low oil levels or high coolant temperature. 
 Several variations of systems that monitor tire pressure already exist. In the past, they have been marketed as a way to avoid flat tires. Now, there is an additional safety angle, because of the seeming propensity of a Ford Explorer to roll over if one of its tires falls apart.
Some new cars come from the factory with such devices, and systems will soon be available that can be added on to older cars.
"How often do you check your tire pressure?" asked Phillip G. Zaroor, president and chief executive of Advantage Enterprises Inc. of Harrisonville, Mo., which makes a device that checks tires every four seconds. Few drivers regularly monitor tire pressures, he said. And most cannot identify an underinflated radial tire at a glance, as they could with earlier bias-ply tires.
Underinflation can cause tire failure, according to Firestone, because if the tire sags too much, the sidewalls flex as the tire rotates, building up heat. The statement is drawn from simple observation, because Firestone says the mechanism that leads to tire failure is still unknown.
Mr. Zaroor's device, called PressurePro, is a simple add-on: a Chap Stick-size device that screws unto each valve stem, in lieu of the cap. Inside is a battery pack, consisting of three button cells, a pressure monitor and a radio transmitter. The system comes with a receiver that could be mistaken, at first glance, for a radar detector. It plugs into the cigarette lighter for power.
The transmitter works whenever the vehicle is traveling 10 miles an hour or faster, and its signal carries 100 feet, so it works well on a trailer hauled behind a recreational vehicle, Mr. Zaroor said. The receiver unit can be programmed to emit a warning beep at a certain pressure level.
Like garage door openers, each transmitter sends a coded signal, to avoid being picked up by the wrong receiver. More than 4,000 have been sold, mostly for recreational vehicles and trucks, he said.
But the original model is a bit long, and, if installed on the valve stem of a car tire, which is set at a 15-degree angle, it would protrude beyond the edge of the tire and could be damaged if, for example, the car scuffed the curb. In addition, if the unit failed, it could deflate the tire. (The stems on truck tires are typically not angled, which allows the device to stay within the wheel area.)
That system had a retail price of $179, but is probably not available on store shelves any longer, he said.
A new version, intended to have a retail price of less than $100, is due out in February. Because it uses more advanced microelectronics, it is smaller and does not protrude from the tire. It also uses less power, and so requires only one battery instead of three, and that battery is supposed to last for two years, twice as long as those in the original device. And, he said, the device cannot deflate the tire.
Another company, Schrader-Bridgeport, part of Tompkins P.L.C., sells SmartValve, a unit that alerts the driver when a tire is low, for $275; a model that specifies which tire, and by how much, is $363. The company, best known for its conventional pencil-type tire-pressure gauges, as well as for its tire valves, also provides the tire-monitoring units that are standard equipment on the Chevrolet Corvette and Plymouth Prowler. The company's Web address is www.schrader-bridgeport.net/ssv.
SmarTire Systems Inc., of Richmond, British Columbia, has been making tire monitors for years, but is only now nearing mass production of a system that is likely to have wide appeal. Its technology was first used on gigantic vehicles in open-pit mines, where big tires can cost tens of thousands of dollars each.
In 1997, tire makers came to SmarTire to develop a system that would warn the driver of a car with "run flat" tires that a tire was actually flat, said Charlene Krepiakevich, a spokeswoman for the company.
"Run-flat tires are designed to allow you to continue to drive safely," she said. "But if you don't know it's gone flat, eventually you'll be stranded."
To prevent that from happening, the company developed a temperature and pressure monitor that is strapped inside the wheel. Like Mr. Zaroor's device, it broadcasts to a monitor in the passenger compartment.
But run-flat tires have not yet caught on. And partly because installation of the SmarTire unit is complicated, the system had sold for about $300 for light vehicles and $400 for vehicles that are heavier or have more than four wheels.
Now, Ms. Krepiakevich said, SmarTire is anticipating a booming market, and mass production should lower prices. A new, refined version of its hardware will go into mass production soon, she said. It has a battery that will last seven years, which, she said, is almost certainly longer than the life of the tire.
Temperature and pressure usually move in tandem, so measuring one should generally be adequate, but SmarTire measures both. John I. Bolegoh, manager of technical services at the company, said that if a tire developed a slow leak on the highway, the normal rise in temperature during highway driving might mask the leak by indicating stable tire pressure. SmarTire would give early warning of a problem, he said. Or if a brake was dragging, the temperature of one tire might rise much higher than the others', another early warning sign.
The company plans to distribute the device through after-market auto parts stores. It has also signed a deal with TRW, a big parts supplier, to try to have its product included on new cars. That would permit a variety of built-in display systems, Ms. Krepiakevich said. A description is available at www.smartire.com/fl/.
Maintaining tire pressure would have other benefits, including less tire wear, lower fuel consumption and better handling.
And a factory-installed model could also establish the appropriate inflation for a new car. A study by the AAA Foundation for Traffic Safety found that most people inflate their tires to the maximum pressure stated on the sidewall, not to the manufacturer's instructions in the owner's manual or on the door post, two more obscure locations.
 Just what the Federal rule will require will not be clear for months. Congress gave the Transportation Department a year to develop rules requiring a warning system for tire pressure. The rule would be applied to new cars two years after it was published.
Until then, of course, one can always use the old-fashioned tire-pressure gauge.

HEADLINE: Does an International Bear Market Mean World Recession?

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
REMEMBER 1998? As Asian currencies crumbled and stock markets crashed, panic spread around the world. Amid fears of global recession, the Federal Reserve aggressively eased credit. Markets recovered as it became clear that disaster would be averted.
Now those gains have been wiped out. Measured in dollars, half the value of stock markets in such countries as Indonesia, the Philippines, South Korea and Thailand has melted away this year, leaving them close to their 1998 lows. Japan has lost a quarter of its value. In this hemisphere, the markets of Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Mexico and Peru are all down by 15 percent or more. 
 And you were upset that the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is down 5 percent.
"Nobody is really thinking about the weakness of the world outside the United States and Europe," said Michael O'Higgins of O'Higgins Asset Management in Miami. "It means the world economy is a lot weaker than people think. The markets smell trouble ahead."
There are signs of worry in this country, too. Junk bonds are trading as if recession and huge defaults are just around the corner, at premiums to Treasury bond yields that exceed those of the 1998 panic.
All this is happening as the world economy hums along with high demand pushing up prices of oil and copper. Even Japan is showing signs of rising domestic confidence and demand. The Japanese central bank's decision to raise interest rates was widely scorned, but the expected damage has not appeared.
The conventional wisdom is that the world is slowing, whatever the current numbers say. High oil prices are hurting growth while the Fed's tightening earlier this year alarmed overseas investors who recall it was the Fed that bailed out the world in 1998. Signs of a technology slowdown scare investors in such computer-component exporters as Taiwan and South Korea. In Taiwan, down 42 percent this year, the government yesterday announced its second package in a week aimed at shoring up stock prices. Part of the package is an increase in the amount foreigners are allowed to invest there, a change that might be more effective if it came at a time when foreigners wanted to do so.
The implicit investment thesis that has developed is that the United States stock market is the safest place for money in a slowing world. Our market is populated by growth companies that are supposed to do well even in a slowdown, while parts of Asia have replaced the American Midwest as the region that makes the products whose sales would plunge during a recession.
David Bowers, the chief global investment strategist at Merrill Lynch, says investors face a major decision on asset allocation. "Have we overestimated the slowdown?" he asked. If so, this would be a good time to look for investments in depressed markets.
Whether or not the markets are exaggerating the risks, it is amazing how little attention has been paid to the possibility during the current election campaign. In part, that reflects the comfortable assumption that the United States will escape the worst of any slowdown.
The unsettled nature of world markets may help to explain the wild rides the American market is experiencing as traders try to figure out if this is a turning point in the global economy. The rebound yesterday was reassuring, while the opening plunge on Wednesday was scary.
As they say in China, we live in interesting times.

HEADLINE: Export Surge Helps Reduce Trade Deficit

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19

 BODY:
The nation's trade deficit narrowed in August to a six-month low as a surge in exports of aircraft engines, computer chips and other capital goods reduced the effect of record imports, government figures showed today.
The $29.4 billion trade gap in goods and services came after a record deficit of $31.7 billion in July, the Commerce Department said. While imports rose 0.8 percent, to $122.5 billion, the highest ever, exports rose 3.6 percent, to $93 billion, also a record. The value of oil imports fell 1.5 percent. 
 Imports of capital goods increased as well, suggesting that businesses' investment in productivity-enhancing equipment should keep inflation in check. Unemployment at a 30-year low of 3.9 percent keeps consumer spending strong. A dollar that is up more than 10 percent against a mix of currencies since the start of the year has held down prices for merchants turning to foreign sources for holiday gifts and other goods.
"This is welcome relief," said Christopher Low, chief economist at First Tennessee Capital Markets in New York. Analysts still cautioned that a surge in oil prices last month threatened to widen the gap again.
Analysts also say the narrower trade gap will spell faster economic growth in the third quarter than previously estimated. Gross domestic product probably grew at closer to a 4 percent annual rate, compared with a previous estimate of 3.4 percent, many of them said.
In a separate report, the Labor Department said new applications for state unemployment benefits decreased last week. Initial jobless claims fell by 7,000, to a seasonally adjusted 307,000 in the week ended Oct. 14, after rising to a revised 314,000 the previous week.
The August trade deficit was the smallest since $27.5 billion in February. Through August, the trade deficit totaled $235.5 billion this year, up from $164.6 billion during the first eight months of 1999. The August deficit puts the annual shortfall on track to reach $379 billion, compared with the record $265 billion in 1999.
A 4 percent increase in exports of nonmilitary capital goods other than automobiles, to a record $31.9 billion, paced the jump in shipments abroad. Exports of computers, semiconductors, aircraft parts and engines and railway equipment all rose.
The decline in crude oil imports, to $8.2 billion from the previous month's record in volume and value, reflected lower prices. The volume increased to a record 310 million barrels in August.
Imports of consumer goods rose 0.8 percent in August as companies stocked up for the holiday season.

HEADLINE: The Empty Center of Campaign 2000

BYLINE: By Andrew Kohut; Andrew Kohut is director of the Pew Research Center for People and the Press.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
If you are expecting to soon find out what the election will turn on now that the debates are over, you're going to be disappointed. In fact, you may be puzzled about the whys of the outcome even after we know the winner of campaign 2000.
This is a very different kind of election. Not only is it a close race, but it's one of the few elections in which the lead has gone back and forth. The presidential contests in 1960, 1968 and 1976 were all tight in the end, but they were not seesaw races. There were changes in the leader over the course of the 1980 campaign, but ultimately this was not a close election, and the message voters were sending was clear. 
 Campaign 2000 is a difficult one for voters because this election is not about anything very much, even though we want it to be about something. Consider what the voters face. There are no overarching issues. Yes, people are concerned with health care, education, Social Security, Medicare and other issues, but they feel far less urgency than in past elections, when big foreign threats loomed or the economy was less robust. And the failure of health-care reform in 1994 and the Gingrich revolution in 1995 have soured the public's appetite for big changes from Washington.
Voters generally judge this year's candidates favorably -- in fact, they give the field a better rating than they did in 1992 and 1996. But there is not a lot of strong feeling one way or the other about Al Gore versus George W. Bush. Neither man has been more able than the other to make a compelling case for his candidacy. Add to this the fact that the central question of most elections is not being raised. Voters are not being offered a referendum on the administration in power; that question is being sidestepped by both camps. President Clinton's name was hardly mentioned in the third presidential debate.
No wonder as many as one in four voters still might change their minds, and many could sit out the election altogether. Ordinary Americans have nothing to hold onto this year unless they are partisan or ideological. That is why all of the groups without strong political leanings have been, and continue to be, on the fence. Independents, middle-income voters, suburbanites, white Catholics and other swing groups have been evenly divided or just leaning one way or the other since the end of the primaries last spring.
The swing groups are likely to have a variety of reasons for coming to their final decisions. Some strongly favor Mr. Gore on health care and other high-anxiety issues, but have trouble with his personality. Others think Mr. Bush might provide a refreshing change in tone in Washington, but worry about his qualifications and some of his positions on issues.
While the choices that different groups of swing voters make won't be based on whim, they might be highly idiosyncratic and may not provide the tight thematic narrative that analysts look for. That probably won't slow down the pundits. These days the meanings of elections are often overread, if not misread, in a rush to blather. (Think about the hard time today's pundits might have had in 1960: Was Kennedy's win about Quemoy and Matsu or the missile gap -- or was the election a personal showdown between Kennedy's style and Nixon's downbeat persona?)
There is a striking disconnect here. With Supreme Court nominations on the line, and control of Congress as well as the White House up for grabs, voters could be remaking Washington this Election Day. But if that happens, they will have ambled in the new direction, rather than striding there purposefully.

HEADLINE: Iraq Poverty Said to Undermine Food Program

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 19

 BODY:
The administrator of the United Nations "oil for food" program in Iraq said today that although that distribution system ranked among the world's best, the lot of ordinary Iraqis has failed to improve because their living conditions remain mired in chronic deprivation.
"People have become so poor in some cases that they can't even afford to eat the food that they are given free, because for many of them the food ration represents the major part of their income," the administrator, Tun Myat, said. 
 With the average income of a junior public employee eroded to barely $2 or $3 a month, he said, "to sustain their livelihood, they sell part of what they get" in food and medicine to pay for clothing and other necessities.
Despite an individual ration of 2,470 calories a day, Mr. Myat added, "the upturn in nutrition that we would want to be seeing is not happening."
Mr. Myat, a Burmese-born lawyer who previously worked for the World Food Program, came here from Baghdad to brief the Security Council sanctions committee and encourage it to release $2.25 billion in contracts for civilian goods that the Iraqi government has requested. The United States and its allies have blocked the sale, contending that the goods could be used for other than relief purposes.
Mr. Myat said, for example, that more than 34 percent of applications to buy equipment for Iraq's battered electricity grid were pending.
Since 1996, when Baghdad accepted the Security Council conditions for selling oil to pay for food and medicine, $33 billion worth of Iraqi oil has been exported in quantities that are now unlimited. The aid deliveries, which started in 1997, have gone beyond basic needs to encompass oil-pumping machinery, electrical transformers and a wide variety of other equipment to renovate Iraq's physical plant, which was badly damaged in the Persian Gulf war and subsequent airstrikes.
In an average month, Mr. Myat said, Baghdad imports 150,000 to 200,000 tons of food and other goods through the program, to feed a population of 23 million.
"I think the Iraqi food-distribution system is probably second to none that you'll find anywhere in the world," he said. "It gets to everybody whom it's supposed to get to in the country."
But he followed up with a caveat. "You can give all the food and medicine you want," Mr. Myat said, but living standards would not improve unless housing, electricity, clean water and sanitation and other essential services were restored.
Mr. Myat said medicine was bought in bulk and distributed through a network of pharmacies and hospitals. But some inhalers imported for Iraqis suffering from asthma have turned up for sale in Damascus and Beirut.
"Human nature being what it is," Mr. Myat said, "I'm quite sure there must be a few enterprising people who might have taken it across the border, and that's what I'm trying to find out."
Mr. Myat's observations were useful because, as Secretary General Kofi Annan told the Security Council last month, Baghdad has not allowed independent experts into the country to assess the effects of the sanctions in place since Iraqi forces invaded Kuwait in 1990.
The Council said sanctions would be lifted after it had determined that Iraq no longer had chemical, biological and other weapons of mass destruction, as well as the means to make them. But President Saddam Hussein has refused to let United Nations arms inspectors return to resume the verification broken off nearly two years ago.
Mr. Myat was appointed the United Nations humanitarian coordinator for Iraq in March after two predecessors, Denis Halliday and Hans von Sponeck, quit in protest against what they described as the suffering that sanctions inflicted on the Iraqi people.
Mr. Myat told reporters that he would keep doing his job because if the oil-for-food program foundered, Iraqis would have nothing to fall back on. "Let's not forget that's the only game in town," he said.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Says Oil Prices Haven't Done Much Harm

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19

 BODY:
The low-inflation new economy is up against an old-economy challenge -- a surge in oil prices -- and so far the new economy is holding its own, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said today.
Mr. Greenspan said the effects on the economy from higher oil prices have been modest so far. And the Fed chairman said there had been almost no effect on inflation expectations, reducing the chances the oil prices could set off a destabilizing spiral of rising wages and prices. 
 In an address here to a conference on monetary policy sponsored by the Cato Institute, a conservative research group, Mr. Greenspan suggested that he saw nothing happening in the economy that would lead the Fed to raise interest rates anytime soon -- or reduce them.
He repeated his optimistic view that the growth rate of productivity was still accelerating as technological advances work their way through the economy. Higher productivity growth means that companies are producing more with the same amount of labor, allowing them to pay higher wages and maintain or expand profit margins without raising prices. But he warned about long-term challenges to continued prosperity. One is that the surge in productivity will eventually abate. The other is that the benefits to the economy of the federal government's running a large budget surplus are likely to be tempered because the two parties seem intent on using much of the projected surplus for tax cuts or new spending.
Under Mr. Greenspan, the Fed has bet over the last several years that the economy is capable of higher rates of noninflationary growth than traditional economic theory would allow. The country has been rewarded by a drop in the unemployment rate to 3.9 percent, a 30-year low; rising wages; and subdued inflation.
But against a backdrop of a rapidly changing economy, Mr. Greenspan said, "it is essential that we not be deluded into believing that we have somehow discovered the Rosetta stone of monetary policy."
For one thing, economists get reams of data about old-line manufacturing activities but are still struggling to get good information about developments in the technology side of the economy, especially in fields like software development, the Fed chairman said.
"So it is with some irony that just as we are adapting our old-economy models to the new realities, in drifts an apparition from the past -- a spike in oil prices that has potential implications for economic stability and for monetary policy," Mr. Greenspan said. The economy today is far less dependent on energy than it was in the early 1970's, when an oil price shock set off a recession, Mr. Greenspan said.

HEADLINE: Tajik Tangle: Odd Alliances Worry Neighbors

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: KAFIRNIGANSKY REGION, Tajikistan

 BODY:
The winding road from the capital ends here, for anyone who would not like to risk becoming the hostage of a warlord named Umar.
Barely 20 miles from Dushanbe, the capital, four young mujahedeen fighters brandish Kalashnikov rifles at a checkpoint a quarter-mile from Mr. Umar's base, in a former auto-repair factory surrounded by cotton fields and persimmon orchards. 
 Umar, they say, is not receiving guests today. Besides, one advised, he is an unpredictable man and it is "not recommended" that visitors call on him lest he decide to rob them, or shoot them, as one warlord is suspected of doing to four United Nations workers killed on this road two years ago.
Umar's deployment of Islamic fighters on the only route out of Dushanbe to the rebellious Karategin Valley underscores the lawlessness in Tajikistan. Two years after a national reconciliation that followed a devastating civil war, Tajikistan is still a land of clan-based paramilitary forces, Islamic revivalism and regional enmities.
The man standing astride the divided politics of the country is President Emomali Rahmonov, a former collective-farm manager and Communist Party apparatchik who rules with enduring support from Russia and by sharing power and money with the enemies his army could not defeat on the battlefield.
Through financial inducements, and sometimes just brute force, Mr. Rahmonov is reconstructing central authority in Tajikistan by deepening relations with Russia and the West, who have pursued the closer ties with their own interests in mind.
Fighting Islamic extremism and drug trafficking has become the highest priority for both Central Asian and Western governments. In addition to asserting his authority against former enemies at home, Mr. Rahmonov has tried to prevent Islamic militants based in Afghanistan from expanding their guerrilla warfare and terrorism across Tajikistan's frontiers to Kyrgyzstan and Uzbekistan.
"Tajikistan is a key state," said Robert P. Finn, the United States ambassador in Dushanbe. With Afghanistan to the south and all of Central Asia to the north, a destabilized Tajikistan "is a danger for all of its neighbors."
Such concern is well founded. The long and violent civil war after the breakup of the Soviet Union has made Tajikistan unique among Central Asian states.
"It was like a revolution in our country," said Hizomov Mirzokhuzha, a deputy commander of Tajikistan's police force in Soviet times. He took up arms against Mr. Rahmonov in 1992 as a top military commander of the United Tajik Opposition, a loose coalition of Islamic forces, democratic movements and regional bosses long excluded from power who were seeking to overthrow the post-Soviet hangers-on and the regional clans they served.
"During the time of the Soviet Union, I could never have imagined that I would become a rebel," Mr. Mirzokhuzha said in an interview at his home in Dushanbe. "No one wants to end up fighting, but the life of a person is written -- and sometimes, if you don't fight, you are going to be killed."
And there was plenty of killing, with estimates of 30,000 to 50,000 dead and up to one million refugees.
Today Mr. Mirzokhuzha is minister for customs taxation in Mr. Rahmonov's cabinet, a post that belies his real power as he helps the government enforce the peace by advising how to integrate rebellious warlords once under his command into the armed forces, where the reward for peace is a paycheck.
"The republic is now democratic, and it is on that foundation that we are working," Mr. Mirzokhuzha said.
But the process is anything but smooth, as Umar's roadblock demonstrated. While the handful of mujahedeen controlled the road here, Tajikistan's armed forces rumbled into the Karategin Valley to suppress and disarm the last of the rebellious warlords there, Mullo Abdullo, who fought as a field commander with the opposition during the war. On Sept. 11, about 40 of his estimated 100 Islamic fighters surrendered; others melted into the mountains.
Mr. Abdullo's grievance was simple: He was not happy that his forces were not offered jobs in Tajikstan's army, as required by the peace protocols. Government officials were loath to offer him and his men positions because they are suspected of the execution-style killing of the United Nations workers in 1998.
But some compromise was reached in September. After Mr. Abdullo's surrender, Mr. Rahmonov surprised many by touring major cities in Karategin Valley, pressing the flesh in town-hall-style meetings that received extensive television coverage. The visit was his first to the heartland of Tajikistan's Islamic revolt.
"The president's trip to the northeast shows that the situation in the area is stable," said Amirkul H. Azimov, secretary of Tajikistan's national security council, though he conceded that "some people were very nervous" that an attempt would be made on Mr. Rahmonov's life.
While Tajikistan may be more stable than ever before, the threat from Islamic extremists seems to be increasing. For that reason, some Western governments seem content to overlook Tajikistan's dismal human rights record. Freedom of the press has ceased to exist, with more than 30 journalists killed since 1992 and 150 or more forced into exile.
In September, Russian military officials who command 25,000 troops along the Tajik-Afghan border reinforced their positions after fighters for the Taliban, the fundamentalist movement that rules most of Afghanistan, scored fresh victories against the "northern alliance" of Ahmed Shah Masoud. Russia and Tajikistan provide rear-area support to Mr. Masoud's forces.
Neighboring Uzbekistan has also been a concern. The State Department placed the Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan on the list of terrorist organizations in September, asserting that its leader, Juma Namangani, was receiving support from Osama bin Laden, whose Afghanistan-based group is suspected in the bombings of two American embassies in Africa.
Mr. Namangani fought alongside Tajikistan's Islamic rebels during the civil war and has conducted guerrilla-style campaigns against Kyrgyz and Uzbek Army forces for the past two summers. Former colleagues here say Mr. Namangani has taken up arms in response to the repressive, antireligious policies of the Uzbek president, Islom Karimov.
"I know Juma Namangani very well," said Mr. Mirzokhuzha, the former opposition leader. "The people where he is from complained that the government came to their village and started arresting those who were going to the mosque and praying. They arrested his relatives, too, and that is why he founded this group -- to liberate them."
Mr. Namangani's support from Mr. bin Laden may include helicopters that now transport Mr. Namangani's rebels across Tajik territory, Western officials say, as well as financial aid that has allowed Mr. Namagani to buy food from villagers when his troops are in the field, a tactic that has improved his support.
Tajikistan's neighbors have charged that President Rahmonov or members of the Islamic opposition who now sit in his cabinet provide bases for Islamic fighters attacking Kyrgyzstan and Uzbekistan, but Mr. Rahmonov says his security forces have worked to block attacks from Tajik territory.
"There were never such bases in Tajikistan and there are not now," said Mr. Azimov, the security council adviser.
As other Central Asian leaders have formed security arrangements, Mr. Rahmonov has tied his country's economic and security interests most prominently to Russia's. When the leaders of Uzbekistan, Kyrgyzstan and Turkmenistan canceled their trips to Yalta in August for a summit meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, Mr. Rahmonov dutifully showed up to discuss plans to establish a permanent Russian military base in Tajikistan.
"Russia was, is and will be our main partner for the future," Mr. Azimov said.
