HEADLINE: More Bang for the B.T.U.;
New York Ranks Near the Top For Efficient Use of Energy

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

 BODY:
The term "energy efficient" sounds jarringly incorrect in describing New York. Big, sprawling, arrogant, corrupt -- those are things people expect. "Efficient" seems a little too Jonathan Livingston Seagull and not enough Damon Runyon.
But New Yorkers are in fact astonishingly stingy in their use of electricity and fossil fuels. According to a recent study, only the residents and businesses in Hawaii used less energy per person, in proportion to the state's population and its economy. 
 The study, by a Washington energy research group called the American Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy, said that based on federal figures from 1997, New York State's residents and businesses also burned fewer hydrocarbons like gasoline or natural gas in proportion to the gross state product than all other states but Connecticut and the District of Columbia.
And who gets the credit?
Energy experts say the results are heavily skewed by the huge impact of New York City itself, where mass transit moves millions of people, thus saving uncounted gallons of gasoline that are burned in other metropolitan areas. Dense, high-rise housing is also often far less profligate of energy use for things like heat than the single-family homes that dominate most of the nation. And the housing is often cramped as well, with less room for energy-draining appliances.
New York's economy also has less dependence on energy-intensive industries like steel making or petroleum refining than the nation as a whole. Driven by the city's numbers, New York State had a lower percentage of households with clothes-washers, or dryers, or dishwashers, or freezers in 1997 than the national average, the efficiency study said.
In general, the report found that in states with higher energy prices, like Hawaii and California and most of the Northeast, people and businesses tend to use less energy or find ways to make it go further.
Energy-guzzling states at the bottom of the list, by contrast, tend to have low energy prices and huge empty rural spaces that require lots of driving, like Alaska, in 51st place, and Wyoming, in 49th, or an economic dependence on companies that use lots of energy, like Louisiana, which came in 50th place largely because of its huge petrochemical industry.
Another surprise -- contrary to all conventional wisdom -- has come from the State University of New York in Albany, where researchers have concluded that the Northeast, particularly a narrow band stretching through the metropolitan area and into southern New Jersey, is a prime potential location for solar energy.
Richard Perez, a senior research associate at the university's Atmospheric Sciences Research Center, said that his solar insight began with a simple observation: the sunniest, hottest days in New York were also the days when the electricity system was pushing the limit of capacity because of higher air-conditioning use. Mr. Perez realized that solar energy could be the perfect add-on generating mechanism at those exact moments when it was needed most.
So he analyzed satellite and weather data, correlating sunshine with energy use, and redrew the conventional solar power map. Suddenly, the New York region was almost as attractive as Arizona as a place to use the power of the sun.
Last year, when 200,000 residents of upper Manhattan lost power for 18 hours on the hottest day in July, the available sunshine level was at 93 percent of maximum, Mr. Perez said. A few thousand small-to-medium-size buildings with rooftop solar panels would have been enough, he said, to have avoided the power loss.
Technical feasibility alone has not yet carried the day, Mr. Perez conceded. Although he was encouraged by some recent announcements about buildings in New York that had made a commitment to try solar generation, the public's skepticism, both economic and meteorological, runs deep, he said.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE MILITARY;
BUSH WOULD STOP U.S. PEACEKEEPING IN BALKAN FIGHTS

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20

 BODY:
If elected president, George W. Bush plans to tell NATO that the United States should no longer participate in peacekeeping in the Balkans, signaling a major new division of labor in the Western alliance, according to Mr. Bush's senior national security aide.
Under this arrangement, peacekeeping in Bosnia and Kosovo would become a European responsibility, as could peacekeeping in other conflicts. The United States, in contrast, would focus on deterring and fighting wars in the Persian Gulf, Asia and other distant trouble spots. 
 Mr. Bush's plan would represent the most important revision of NATO tasks since the cold war. His aides say the change is long overdue and would let the American military concentrate its training and financing on traditional combat missions.
"The governor is talking about a new division of labor," Condoleezza Rice, the security adviser, said in an interview. "The United States is the only power that can handle a showdown in the gulf, mount the kind of force that is needed to protect Saudi Arabia and deter a crisis in the Taiwan Straits. And extended peacekeeping detracts from our readiness for these kinds of global missions."
In outlining the approach, Ms. Rice was providing the strategic rationale behind many of Mr. Bush's general comments in the campaign about using American military power and his repeated contentions that extended peacekeeping missions and humanitarian operations had undermined military readiness. In sharp contrast, his opponent, Vice President Al Gore, has said that if anything, Washington should take a more active role in using troops to prevent conflicts abroad.
Ms. Rice acknowledged that revising NATO's military tasks was delicate. Although Mr. Bush plans to make the redivision of military tasks a major objective, if elected, he plans to consult the Europeans and is not planning "precipitous" actions.
Many European allies have been insistent that the United States share the risks of Balkan operations. Britain is quite likely to be extremely concerned about suggestions that Washington might withdraw its forces from the Balkans, NATO specialists said, while the French may see it as opportunity to diminish the American influence in Europe.
Some European critics also said securing the peace in the Balkans was NATO's premier post-cold-war mission, one that has given the alliance an important rationale after the collapse of the Soviet threat.
"The Balkans is the new NATO mission," said Terence Taylor, assistant director of the London-based International Institute for Strategic Studies. "The United States has infantry and tanks in Germany. And if it is not going to send them to the Balkans, what are they are there for, anyway? Stopping the former Warsaw Pact from rolling westward? It is almost as if they are going back to the cold war."
The Balkan peacekeeping debate is part of a broader election-year dispute over the use of American power. The often partisan debate has also featured differences over military readiness, Pentagon spending and missile defense.
The peacekeeping debate has especially powerful implications for the NATO alliance and raises a number of critical questions. Should the leader of the alliance share the same risks and burdens in the Balkans as its European allies? Or would the West's security be better served if the American military did not have to worry about Balkan peacekeeping and could focus on other missions?
Can the United States continue to shape Western policy toward the region if it no longer has troops on the ground? Can it continue to exert the same degree of influence in European security policy?
American policy toward the Balkans has a tortured history. When President Clinton ran for office in 1992, he complained that the Bush administration had stayed on the sidelines as the Serbs turned Bosnia into a killing ground. But in office, the Clinton administration was initially slow to act.
Unlike the Europeans, Washington at first drew the line at sending peacekeeping troops to Bosnia. As the civilian toll rose, however, the administration pressed for a NATO bombing campaign. That succeeded in pressing the Serbs to go along with a Bosnia accord.
In 1995, Washington sent 25,000 American troops to help police the region, saying the troops would be stationed there for a year.
Today, the United States is still involved in Bosnia peacekeeping and is carrying out peacekeeping duties in Kosovo, as well. Still, the size of the American contingent has shrunk, and the Europeans are bearing most of the burden.
The United States peacekeeping force in the Bosnia and Kosovo totals 11,400 troops, according to the Pentagon. That is less than one-fifth of the 65,000-member NATO peacekeeping force in the region, and it is a fraction of the 120,000-member American military presence in Europe.
In budgetary terms, the Balkan mission accounts for a small part of Pentagon spending. The United States allocated $3.5 billion in the fiscal 2000 budget year for Balkan peacekeeping, slightly more than 1 percent of the Pentagon's annual $280 billion budget.
Longtime NATO hands say the American effort in the Balkans is extremely modest, given the United States' role as leader of the Western alliance and the fact that Balkan security has emerged as a primary mission for the alliance.
"If we want to have any influence in NATO on the Balkans, we are probably at the bottom line," said Wesley K. Clark, the retired United States Army general who commanded NATO in the Kosovo campaign. "When allies are putting in more than 80 percent of effort, there is not much room for an argument about burden-sharing. If we want to be part of this, we can't do much less."
In the campaign, Mr. Gore has taken a similar stance. For him, Balkan peacekeeping is one of NATO's primary tasks and an example of the operation that the American military needs to undertake to support American diplomacy in the post-cold-war world.
In addition to deterring and fighting wars, Mr. Gore says, the armed forces should prepare for peacekeeping missions, delivering relief supplies and rebuilding institutions in war-ravaged nations, activities that the Pentagon calls nation building.
To help the military carry out such a broad array of tasks, Mr. Gore says, he would earmark $80 billion of the federal surplus for military programs over 10 years. An additional $20 billion would be spent on international programs.
Mr. Bush says he would spend $45 billion of the surplus on the military over 10 years.
"The linchpin of our policy is forward engagement," said Gordon Adams, a senior adviser to Mr. Gore on military issues and a former top Clinton administration budget official. "We have a wide range of instruments to deal with the problems, diplomatic, economic and military.
"If you say you can use everything except the military, you have deprived yourself of one of those instruments. The Bush team has a curiously old-fashioned view. We will have a well-funded military that is designed to go nowhere and prepared do nothing, because they are only there to fight the nation's wars, and we are not having any."
Mr. Bush has contended that the military has been run ragged by peacekeeping and humanitarian work, missions that are taking a toll on morale and readiness.
Although Mr. Bush does not oppose all involvement in peacekeeping, he and his advisers say prolonged peacekeeping operations make it more difficult for the armed forces to prepare for major wars.
"This comes down to function," Ms. Rice said. "Carrying out civil administration and police functions is simply going to degrade the American capability to do the things America has to do. We don't need to have the 82nd Airborne escorting kids to kindergarten."
In outlining a new division of responsibilities for NATO, Ms. Rice said the United States would not immediately withdraw from the Balkans but would inform NATO that its goal is to turn over the entire responsibility of stationing peacekeeping troops to its European allies.
The United States would continue to provide intelligence, help with communications, transport and do other logistical work after withdrawing its peacekeeping troops. In outlining that approach, aides to Mr. Bush have in mind East Timor, where an Australian-led peacekeeping mission received United States logistical support. Although East Timor represents one possible approach for Mr. Gore, it seems be the main model for Mr. Bush.
"We are not withdrawing from Europe," Ms. Rice said. "We are not withdrawing the kind of support we can provide, like air power. But when it comes to nation-building or civilian administration or indefinite peacekeeping, we do need for the Europeans to step up to their responsibilities. We are not going to do anything precipitous, but unless we set this as a firm goal we will never get it done."
In Europe, many allied officials complain that the American debate on the Balkans overlooks their contribution. They say that their forces are also stretched thin by the Balkan operation and that Americans do not seem to appreciate that they provide most of the economic aid.
Some also said Mr. Bush's program might give impetus to Europeans' efforts to develop their own military arrangements, perhaps more of a stimulus than Washington might like, given its goal to influence security policy in Europe.
Many allied officials are also haunted by the early 1990's, when they had troops in Bosnia and the United States did not. That case led to bitter disputes over strategy, and many Europeans are determined that it should never be repeated.
When the Clinton administration first suggested lifting the arms embargo on the beleaguered Bosnian Muslims and carrying out bombing strikes on Serbian forces, European allies complained that the plan would endanger their troops while the United States watched from a safe distance. As a result, many allied officials said, NATO should do everything to avoid a situation where European and United States officials do not face comparable risks on the ground.
Ms. Rice said that the Balkan situation was far more stable now and that the United States would not leave its allies to face a dangerous threat on their own. But European anxieties remain.
"There is a huge difference between providing logistics and air support and having your forces at the sharp end where a conflict might arise," Mr. Taylor said. "It is not burden-sharing to say, 'You guys go out and take the risk of getting killed, and if there are problems we will provide air support.' Putting American forces at risk is a fundamental to assuring that there is a political commitment from Washington. American feet on the ground is vital."

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 4; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: More Bang for the B.T.U.;
Against High Costs, A Better Light Bulb

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

 BODY:
High-strung, high-maintenance New York may never surpass laid-back Hawaii as the nation's most energy-efficient state, but a thunderclap of events in recent months in the Northeast have created what energy experts say is a glittering opportunity to try.
And it is all because a sharp rise in the prices of heating oil, natural gas and electricity in the last few months -- especially in the Northeast -- has thrown open the door for the return of the oldest environmental idea around: conservation. 
 Three months ago, the Amalgamated Housing Cooperative -- 1,500 families spread across 11 buildings just off Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx -- began replacing every old fluorescent light fixture in every hallway in every building with high-efficiency bulbs that use 45 percent less electricity. The co-op's directors calculated that the $45,000 investment would pay itself back in about two years.
Then came the summer of utility shock. With electricity rates up more than 40 percent in the New York region, the co-op's investment will be recouped after only eight months, or early next year. What had seemed pretty smart in early summer, said Amalgamated's general manager, William M. Schwarz, suddenly looked brilliant.
Most energy-saving technology is not much more sophisticated than that. Things like better bulbs and more insulation around a furnace room, experts say, can cut energy use as much as or more than expensive tools like motion sensors that turn off the heat or lights in empty rooms. Although the focus of conservation is probably still on the suburban homeowner, Amalgamated's experience has shown that urban conservation can have a huge impact.
"The best part is, it's not rocket science -- it's good Victorian engineering, rediscovered," said Amory B. Lovins, the chief executive for research at the Rocky Mountain Institute, an independent research center in Old Snowmass, Colo., that advocates alternative energy and higher efficiency.
Mr. Lovins and other experts say that for most Americans, higher energy prices and the impulse to conserve are probably still no more than a blip on the radar and not -- as they were in the 1970's -- a full-scale social movement. Leaders at the Amalgamated co-op say their motivations are mixed as well, one part penny-pinching, one part social consciousness.
The co-op was founded in the 1920's as part of the socialist utopian movement then thriving in the garment workers' union, whose ranks included many of the original tenants. Income ceilings limited the co-op's apartments to middle-income families, and there was always a social agenda. From the struggles of the labor movement, the co-op's social impulse morphed into environmentalism. Members embraced recycling before it was mandatory and trash compacting before it became city law.
Last year, as New York State was moving to deregulate its electricity system, Amalgamated's board approved an ambitious five-year retrofitting plan that includes everything from its lights to the testing or replacement of the estimated 5,000 motors that pump water and run elevators and distribute steam in the complex to a rooftop solar power system. A high-efficiency $150,000 water cooler for the air-conditioning system will go in before next summer.
"It's kept us who we are," said the co-op's president, Ed Yaker.
Energy entrepreneurs and researchers say that the widespread prosperity in the 1990's usually required conservation and efficiency to be dressed up as something else, like luxury. The Maytag Corporation came up with a superefficient front-loading washing machine several years ago called the Neptune that uses far less water and electricity than a conventional top-loader. But the company positioned it as a top-of-the-line European-style machine that was gentler on clothes and tacked on a price that was twice as high as its regular washers. Sales took off.
In New York, real estate developers have also positioned several new luxury residential and commercial buildings as "green" and done well in sales.
But many inventors hoping to get a piece of the market have cried in the wilderness for years.
Carmine F. Vasile, an inventor who lives on Long Island, vividly recalls April 28, 1980, when he accidentally touched a drainpipe in his basement in Medford, N.Y., while his wife was upstairs taking a shower. He burned his hand and realized that a lot of heat was escaping through the sides of the pipe.
Mr. Vasile, a former researcher in the aerospace defense industry with nearly 30 patents to his name, has spent 20 years trying to sell the patented device born of that accident -- a coiled heat recovery apparatus that recycles captured thermal energy back into the hot-water tank. The construction industry, he said, has mostly cared not a whit. "It's been a saga," Mr. Vasile said.
Some business executives say that higher energy prices could mean profitability for all sorts of old and new ideas.
Raymond G. Saleeby, who is the president and chief executive of myutility.com, a Manhattan energy management company founded last year, says that he expects the New York region's high energy costs to continue to worsen through the next year, and that the success of his company is predicated on that upward movement of prices. He says that he can cut a small-to-medium-sized company's energy bills in half, and he plans to hit where prices are rising fastest -- beginning next month in New York City, and then next year in California.
Other companies are trying to build a kind of commodities market in the metropolitan region in which reduced energy use -- and the resulting cleaner air quality -- will itself become a salable product that could further impel the conservation movement.
The company that put together Amalgamated's energy plan, First Rochdale, a two-year-old cooperative, is in the process of creating a pilot project: it is working with the Federal National Mortgage Association, the housing lender, and Cantor Fitzgerald, a brokerage firm, to form a commodities market for clean-air credits. The idea, to be tested first at the Amalgamated co-op, is to adapt the existing system, in which companies can buy and sell pollution credits, for the residential market in New York City.
But higher energy prices are a mixed blessing for conservation efforts. They are also battering local budgets, and that could mean less money in residential buildings available for conservation.
At Amalgamated, the second energy shock hit last month: drastically higher heating oil prices, up 51 percent over last fall. The increase has thrown every budget calculation into disarray, said Mr. Schwarz, the general manager. He is now being forced to consider an increase in common charges -- the monthly fees residents pay for things like heat and maintenance -- that could take effect next spring.
The tightening energy equation also means that plans, like the rooftop solar panels on the complex's two highest towers, will have to be strictly justified in financial terms. Social agendas are important, said Mr. Yaker, the co-op's president, but economics are what he will have to take to his board for the final decision.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE RUNNING MATES;
Lieberman Declares His Party Built the Boom

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 20

 BODY:
Calling the Democrats "the party of fiscal responsibility and economic growth," Senator Joseph I. Lieberman today claimed for them the credit for the nation's extraordinary economic boom, and said only they would sustain it.
"Over the last eight years of the Clinton-Gore administration," Mr. Lieberman said, "we have come to understand that what we can do begins with being fiscally responsible, that when government balances its books, it not only stops draining capital out of the markets because it's in hock, but it creates a sense of confidence generally, and that is one of the conditions for growth." 
 Vice President Al Gore and Mr. Lieberman, his running mate, have signaled that they will make prosperity their core issue in the final push toward the election on Nov. 7. But Mr. Lieberman's remarks were a continuing reflection of the ticket's publicly split personality regarding President Clinton and his legacy.
Mr. Gore has tried to distance himself from his partner of the last eight years, and he and Mr. Lieberman frequently say they want to be judged more on their plans for the future than on the record of the past. But the vice president clearly wants to take credit for the good times, although without mentioning Mr. Clinton by name -- a task that more often falls to Mr. Lieberman.
"We've gone from the largest deficits in America, the federal government has, now to the largest surpluses," the senator said here in remarks to employees of FreeMarkets Inc., an Internet auction house for businesses. "It started right in '93. The Clinton-Gore administration said, 'We're going to get serious about coming out of debt; here's our budget proposals that are controversial.' It passed without a single Republican vote; Al Gore had to break the tie in the Senate. And it turned the corner."
Speaking at FreeMarkets and at a senior citizens' center here, the senator argued that while Mr. Gore's proposed tax cuts and spending plans fit comfortably within the projected government surpluses of the next decade, Gov. George W. Bush's would mean a return to deficit spending.
"That will take us back to debt and higher interest rates," he said, "and higher interest is a kind of stealth tax increase, because it affects your mortgage payments, your car payments, your student loans, your credit cards."
Most independent analysts agree that Mr. Gore's plans are more likely to keep the government within its means, but many believe that both candidates' proposals run the risk of overspending the surpluses.
Mr. Lieberman's visit here, and appearances he plans in the Philadelphia area on Sunday night and Monday, attest to the tightness of the race and a growing worry in the Gore camp. A month ago, polls indicated that Pennsylvania was solidly for Mr. Gore. But even as Mr. Bush has pulled slightly ahead in most national surveys, this state once again appears to be a toss-up in need of the Democrats' cultivation.
Mr. Lieberman also plans to campaign next week in Florida, another hotly contested state. And on Tuesday he is to be at the University of Notre Dame for what his aides call a major speech, on topics close to his heart: faith and values. The senator, the first Jewish candidate on a major party's national ticket, has for much of his career denounced what he describes as the corrosive influence of much of popular culture, and called for a greater role for religion in public discourse.
Mr. Lieberman, who does not campaign on the Jewish Sabbath, from sundown Friday to sundown Saturday, will be out of action this weekend until sundown Sunday. He will be observing Simhat Torah, the last of a series of Jewish holy days that have taken him off the campaign trail for several days this month.
As Mr. Lieberman visited an Internet company today, so did the Republican vice-presidential nominee, Dick Cheney. At Intranet Solutions Inc. of Eden Prairie, Minn., a Minneapolis suburb, Mr. Cheney told more than 100 employees that Mr. Bush's economic plans would do more to help "the rising generation" of 18- to 34-year-olds who work there.
For a person in his 30's, Mr. Cheney said, the Bush proposal allowing workers to divert part of their Social Security taxes into private accounts could mean an extra $150,000 by retirement.
Noting that he and Mr. Bush had both held leadership posts outside government, Mr. Cheney called Mr. Gore's approach "old school" and said the vice president's proposals were "diametrically opposed" to the guiding principles of the "new economy."
At a rally later in Green Bay, Wis., Mr. Cheney depicted the Democrats as unworthy guardians of the economic boom.
"They can't wait to get their hands on that surplus," he said, "so they can spend it."
 
In His Own Words
 
JOSEPH I. LIEBERMAN
Speaking yesterday to employees of FreeMarkets, an online, business-to-business auction service in Pittsburgh:
"What we've learned again is that government doesn't create jobs -- in America, it's always the private sector that creates jobs -- but that government can create the environment which is conducive for jobs to be created. If I may go back to an agricultural metaphor, government can turn the earth and provide some nutrients, but then it's the private sector that comes along and, you know, plants the seeds and nurtures the crops.
The central question before the voters this year is:
Do we want to see the country moving forward? Do we want to keep the prosperity going -- which Al Gore and I believe we're best able to do, and not only to keep the prosperity going but do it in a way, through better education and some of the tax incentives I've talked about, to expand the winner's circle to more of America's families? Or do we want to go back?"

HEADLINE: For Mrs. Clinton, Health Plan Left Lessons and Questions

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20

 BODY:
To this day, puzzling questions hover over Hillary Rodham Clinton's effort to remake the nation's health care system in 1993 and 1994, the most ambitious project of her public life.
Mrs. Clinton mastered the complexities of health insurance, and she dazzled Congress with her command of facts and figures. But, even her allies say, she seemed to have a deaf ear for the politics of the issue in Congress. 
 She disregarded early warnings that her plan was headed for trouble on Capitol Hill. She plowed ahead, showing little of the knack for compromise that is often the soul of the legislator's art.
That experience is relevant now as Mrs. Clinton runs for the Senate from New York. She says she learned important lessons from the debacle of 1993-94, including the need to pursue grand goals by incremental steps. And, she says, she applies those lessons in her Senate race.
But the puzzle remains: how, friends ask, could someone so smart, so knowledgeable about the arcane details of the health care system, have been so obtuse about the politics of the issue on Capitol Hill, where she now aspires to work?
"We were politically naive," Mrs. Clinton said in an interview in September 1994, after the administration's proposal died in Congress. "We made a lot of miscalculations."
Mrs. Clinton expertly diagnosed the problems she tried to solve: soaring health costs, millions of Americans without insurance. But she got nowhere near persuading Congress that she had a workable solution.
Her opponent in the New York race, Representative Rick A. Lazio, will not let her forget. He calls her health plan "an unmitigated disaster." Likewise, Gov. George W. Bush chides Al Gore, saying the vice president joined Mrs. Clinton in fighting for "a government-run health care system" in 1993.
Mrs. Clinton has often acknowledged errors. But mostly she suggests that the president's plan, which she developed, was not packaged and sold well. By contrast, her critics and some of her allies say that the product itself was the problem, and that she failed to see its flaws because of the frantic, secretive process by which it was devised.
Her opponents suggest that Mrs. Clinton was personally responsible for the health care fiasco. That may be an overstatement. President Clinton was with her every step of the way.
But, some White House officials say, Mrs. Clinton was in charge of the project and could have altered the administration's course. Her allies say they doubt whether she could have blunted Republican opposition. In any event, she says, she never had much of a chance to discuss deals with Republicans because, at some point in 1994, their cooperation "just shut off like a spigot."
Mr. Lazio, like many of Mrs. Clinton's critics, says her record in the battle over health care shows she lacks the temperament and experience to do the job for which she is now running. They note that her health care plan died in a Democratic Congress, and one reason, they say, is that she failed to work with Congress, even with committee and subcommittee chairmen of her own party.
George Stephanopoulos, a top adviser to the Clintons, said that "having Hillary run health care was a mistake," in part because "compromise didn't come naturally" to her.
In his memoirs ("All Too Human," Little, Brown, 1999), Mr. Stephanopoulos said that Mrs. Clinton's health plan "reflected both her strengths and her weaknesses," for it was ambitious, idealistic and highly logical, but also inflexible and overly complex.
Mrs. Clinton's defenders say the health plan fell victim to Republican partisanship and to relentless attacks by insurance companies, drug companies and small businesses. When Mrs. Clinton took up her assignment in 1993, Republicans, especially in the Senate, said they were eager to work with her. But by the end of the year, the tide began to turn.
In December 1993, conservative theorists like William Kristol were urging Congress to reject the Clinton plan, and their advice emboldened other Republicans. In response to Mr. Clinton's State of the Union Message in January 1994, Bob Dole, the Senate Republican leader, said, "Our country has health care problems, but no health care crisis."
In February 1994, the White House suffered a damaging blow when the Congressional Budget Office said that the Clintons had understated the cost of their proposal and the premiums needed to pay for it.
By the summer of 1994, many Republicans had made a strategic decision to oppose the Clinton plan, partly because they saw it as a vivid symbol of big government, and partly because they sensed that its defeat would help them win control of Congress. Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, said the president's plan would pass only "over my cold, dead political body."
Theda Skocpol, a professor of government and sociology at Harvard, said Mrs. Clinton suffered the fate of many strong women. "She was singled out as a witch-type figure," said Ms. Skocpol, who wrote a book on the Clinton health plan ("Boomerang," Norton, 1996).
Mrs. Clinton was a victim of "vicious ridicule" and "misogynist mockery," Ms. Skocpol said.
Sara Rosenbaum, a professor of health law and policy at George Washington University, who supervised the drafting of the Clinton administration's health care bill in 1993, said she still wondered about Mrs. Clinton: "How does a woman get to be so hated by people who have never met her? A lot of people were intimidated by her. She has a formidable personality."
But Mrs. Clinton's problems ran much deeper.
By her own account, she underestimated the magnitude of the task she had set for herself, redesigning the health care system and rearranging one-seventh of the nation's economy. She overestimated the mandate of a president who had been elected with 43 percent of the popular vote. And, by her own admission, she was a novice in dealing with Congress.
"I didn't understand the rhythm of the place," Mrs. Clinton said of Congress in the 1994 interview. "I didn't understand the institutional constraints."
President Clinton took office on Jan. 20, 1993. Five days later he named Mrs. Clinton to lead a task force that was supposed to devise a detailed proposal to control health costs and guarantee health insurance for all Americans. Mr. Clinton said he would submit the proposal to Congress within 100 days of his inauguration -- by April 30.
But the deadline slipped again and again. Mr. Clinton placed a higher priority on pushing his budget through Congress, over Republican opposition.
"Mrs. Clinton was not allowed to go forward with health care reform at a time when the president's power was at its height," Ms. Rosenbaum said.
Originally, Mrs. Clinton said in September 1994, "we thought we were going to get health care reform" enacted as part of the budget package. "I personally miscalculated," she said, "because of my experience dealing with state legislatures, which handle a huge array of problems in a compressed period of time."
Congress, she found, "can do only one big thing at a time."
The president and Mrs. Clinton delivered the text of their legislative proposal, a 240,000-word document, to Congress on Oct. 27, 1993.
In a recent interview, Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who was then chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said, "Mrs. Clinton was so committed to trying to get the entire bill through Congress that she created some blind spots for herself."
Mr. Rostenkowski said he had told Mrs. Clinton that it would have been wiser to "give us some parameters and guidelines" and let Congress fill in the details.
White House officials felt they would not be taken seriously unless they fleshed out their ideas.
In addition, Mr. Rostenkowski recalled, he urged Mrs. Clinton to be more flexible, saying: "Hillary, you're not in Arkansas now. You're dealing with legislators who have varied views. Compromise is what will get this bill passed."
Mrs. Clinton met frequently with members of Congress, but, they said, she did not assimilate their comments or criticism into her work.
The White House team "came over and saw us all the time, but ignored what we said," said Representative Pete Stark, the California Democrat who was then chairman of a powerful subcommittee responsible for health legislation.
Mr. Stark said he urged Mrs. Clinton to be less secretive. He challenged her estimates of the savings that could be achieved in a more competitive health care market. And he cautioned that the structure of her proposal, which called for the purchase of insurance through huge "regional alliances," was too convoluted to work. But his advice did not lead to significant changes in the proposal.
Many potential allies complained about the secrecy of Mrs. Clinton's task force. After a White House meeting in March 1993, Dr. Quentin D. Young, national coordinator of Physicians for a National Health Program, a champion of universal health care, said, "It was a magnificent exercise in pseudo-openness."
When Mrs. Clinton visited Congress in February 1993, Newt Gingrich, the Georgia Republican who was then minority whip, articulated the concerns that swamped the president's plan 19 months later.
Mr. Gingrich said then that Mrs. Clinton's proposal looked like "washed-over old-time bureaucratic liberalism, or centralized bureaucratic socialism."
Looking back in September 1994, Mrs. Clinton said she had been surprised by the ferocity of the opposition to her plan.
"I totally missed the coming wave of partisanship," Mrs. Clinton said then. "I just missed it. And I am still kind of puzzled about how it happened."
Members of both parties tried to send warning signals to the White House.
In May 1993, Representative Stark said the premise of Mrs. Clinton's proposal -- the concept of managed competition -- was "a fairy tale." That approach, which relied on market forces to hold down costs and expand coverage, had never been tried, Mr. Stark said, and he likened it to a unicorn, "a beautiful animal in fairyland, but unseen on earth."
Then in September 1993, just three days before Mr. Clinton presented his plan to a joint session of Congress, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, said its financing was based on a "fantasy." Estimates of savings in Medicare and Medicaid were overly optimistic, he said.
A year later Mrs. Clinton said, "That was probably the single most damaging moment in the entire health care debate," and she described Mr. Moynihan's comment as "a killer."
Some budget experts inside the administration had expressed similar doubts about the financing of the Clinton plan. But they said it was difficult for them to criticize a plan devised by the president's wife.
Mrs. Clinton is now running for the seat Mr. Moynihan holds. His comments in 1993 carried weight because he was chairman of the Finance Committee and had a reputation for independent thinking and plain speaking.
Senator Moynihan worried, as he later wrote, that "the administration bill would devastate the New York City hospital system" by reducing the number of foreign medical graduates in city hospitals. And he lamented "the fatal complexity and coerciveness" of the administration's plan.
Mrs. Clinton now calls teaching hospitals "the crown jewels of America's health care system," and she supports Mr. Moynihan's effort to provide financing for medical schools and teaching hospitals.
Mr. Lazio says the Clinton health plan would have cost New York 72,000 jobs.
In 1993-94, Mrs. Clinton often emphasized her willingness to negotiate. But she was inclined to demonize critics and opponents, just as they demonized her.
Mrs. Clinton displayed a combative, adversarial style. She not only criticized the policies and practices of insurance companies and drug companies, but accused them of price-gouging and criticized their motives and morality.
In May 1993, in a campaign-style speech to the Service Employees International Union, Mrs. Clinton said she would "take on every special-interest group," and she denounced "price-gouging, cost-shifting and unconscionable profiteering" by the health care industry.
Mrs. Clinton appeared to relish the prospect of a populist crusade. "If the forces arrayed against reform want a real battle in which their self-interest is exposed and their real agenda is made public, they will get it," she vowed in November 1993.
But Mrs. Clinton did not build the coalitions or round up the votes needed to win that battle. Indeed, she turned a cold shoulder to moderate Democrats, complaining that their proposals would not guarantee coverage for 100 percent of the population.
In a curious way, events over the last six years have borne out the concerns of both Mrs. Clinton and her critics. Events suggest she was right to worry about health costs and the uninsured. Costs are surging again, and the ranks of the uninsured grew by an average of more than a million a year from 1994 to 1998.
But events also suggest that Mrs. Clinton's critics were right in asserting that the government could never perform the large role she envisioned for it. The government cannot figure out how much to pay health maintenance organizations caring for 6.2 million Medicare beneficiaries, lawmakers say, so it could hardly have set premiums and supervised insurance arrangements for more than 270 million Americans.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: SUBWAY SERIES;
1956 vs. 2000? It's Deja Vu All Over Again, Except for When It's Not

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
During a desperately contested presidential election, in the media and cultural capital of the world, in a boom town where Broadway theaters were flourishing and entrepreneurs were pioneering a fledgling new video industry, New Yorkers took to the subways to cheer on pennant winners from rival boroughs as they waged World Series war.
The year, of course, was 1956. 
 There are enough similarities between Eisenhower-era Gotham and millennial New York to suggest that the intervening 44 years have been a valley to the peaks that were two Subway Series. In both of these baseball snapshots, New York stands revealed as a pre-eminent world city in its economic, artistic and athletic heyday. Both are times when city residents actually do have good reason to arrogantly assume that they are at the center of the universe.
And yet, a comparison of today's MetroCard Series with the last subway-token Series finds a chasm separating Ed Sullivan's New York from Regis Philbin's. It's not just that day games have been transformed into night games, that city workers' blue collars have been morphed into white, that suburbanites once desperate to leave are now desperate to score a city co-op, or that a white-skinned town has now become more demographically diverse.
New York in 1956 was a complex, before-the-economic-deluge city in a complicated time when schoolchildren did hydrogen-bomb duck-and-cover drills under their desks, where blacklisted writers worked under pseudonyms in the era of the silent generation, and where blacks, Hispanics, Asians and women were not encouraged to apply.
"The cold war was at its zenith, heading toward the 1962 missile crisis, there was the specter of McCarthyism and a nascent civil rights movement," said Ken Burns, the documentary film historian.
The contemporary roster of political and social ills notwithstanding, Mr. Burns and several historians suggest that New York and the nation as a whole confront a more palatable menu of disasters.
"I think we live in a much simpler, and much calmer, time right now," said Mr. Burns, whose nine-episode series, "Baseball," ran on Public Television in 1994. "The enemies of good history are nostalgia and sentimentality."
Some of the other contrasts with 1956 are more obvious. It isn't only that most every male was sporting a fedora in 1956, or that the 15-cent price of a subway ride would be 10 times as much by the millennium. Series fans paid a top price of $10.50 for box seats in 1956 and spent only $2.10 to become bleacher creatures; this year, the ticket-price spread is $50 to $300 in some luxury boxes.
The pre-suburbanized, pre-television-dominated, pre-automobile-oriented New York of 1956 was the nation's "leading manufacturing city," said Dr. Kenneth T. Jackson, a professor of history at Columbia University, editor of the Encyclopedia of New York City. A premier port city in the pre-container era, New York was where the great liners still docked and the great trains still roared into the terminals.
Employment was characterized "by the white male union blue-collar worker," said Dr. Mike Wallace, a professor of history at John Jay College and co-author of "Gotham: A History of New York to 1898," which won a Pulitzer Prize for history in 1999. "Now the labor centerpiece involves white-collar, female, nonunion people of color."
During the last Subway Series, New York was a town where neighborhoods, parishes and ethnic communities were much more the center of life. The city's relationship with its baseball gods was also more intimate.
"The connection between players and fans was more personal and exciting," given the localized nature of New York in 1956, said Doris Kearns Goodwin, the historian and political scientist, who was 13 when she avidly followed the last Subway Series.
Back in that facial-hair-free era when ears were unpierced and tongues were unstudded, many players lived among the folks. In 1956, the Dodger legend Pee Wee Reese occupied a modest brick duplex on Barwell Terrace in Bay Ridge, pitcher Sal Maglie lived in Riverdale and many Yankees occupied an apartment hotel on the Grand Concourse in the Bronx.
In their heyday, Dodger stars earned something like 10 times the $3,948 yearly average salary of the 1956 working man -- not an inconceivable difference, about $250,000 in today's dollars -- whereas even journeyman players bring down $2 million today.
If there was more complexity in the tenor of those times, New York baseball in the 1950's seemed comfortingly uncomplicated. There was but one fierce loyalty and that was your family's, your neighborhood's, your borough's, team. Today it is baseball that has the high degree of difficulty, being but one option in a complex menu of sports entertainments. In the bloated new regional Big Apple, home-team allegiances are more shifting and fraught than ever.
Languishing at the center of the new dynamic are the players themselves, all caught "in the great celebrity hiding machine," as Roger Angell, who has written about baseball for The New Yorker since 1962, put it in an interview. "Today we look at them with the glazed-over interest that we apply to all celebrities."
In contrast, even the 1950's stadiums themselves permitted minor-league intimacy. Gone are the days when fans could see (for free) the great expanse of sacred Yankee Stadium turf from the 161st Street subway platform. Gone are the afternoons when Alan M. Dershowitz, now a Harvard Law School professor, was able to camp out on the roof of his grandmother's house "and see over the right-field wall at Ebbets."
Since phalanxes of rabid Mets and Yankees fans are front and center whenever the video-lights go on, passions today seem deep enough, but they aren't those of 1956. Traditional borough nationalism has attenuated in the decades since baseball was truly America's pastime. And many of both team's fans now come from the suburbs.
But in the 1950's, "the team you rooted for was as much a part of your identity as your religion was," Ms. Goodwin said.
Such was the presence of the Dodgers and Yankees in 1956 that it took a significant act of will by neighborhood Benedict Arnolds to avoid rooting for the borough team.
"Growing up in Brooklyn you were unable not to be a Dodger," said Sanford Teller, a Manhattan public-relations consultant who used to take the trolley from Borough Park to Ebbets Field. "Giant fans were pummeled."
In Our Lady of Lourdes parish on the Upper West Side not far from the Polo Grounds, "it was all Giants," said Peter Maas, the Manhattan author, who grew up in the neighborhood and attended the 1956 Series as a reporter for Collier's magazine. "Ebbets Field seemed to be in the Middle East somewhere. The Yankees were too rich and we saw the Dodgers as an alien force."
The exception that proves the rule is that Brooklynite Yankee defector, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
In today's game, Latino fan rivalries are expected to add drama to the battle for New York. In 1956, the Hispanic player presence in the Series was limited, even though there were 650,000 Spanish-speaking residents in the city in 1956, 90 percent of whom were Puerto Rican. (The only Hispanic who played was the Havana-born Dodger Sandy Amoros; there were no Asians.)
In 1956, "the Dodgers were the Jewish and Italian and black team," according to Mr. Dershowitz, whose synagogue actually gave a blessing to the pitcher Sandy Koufax. "The Yankees got their own borough, and the WASPs."
The borough loyalty of the 1950's may also be a casualty of fans' perception that today's Yankees and Mets are generic collections of hired millionaires.
Patrick McEnroe, the 34-year-old sportscaster and tennis-league entrepreneur, grew up in Queens, 15 minutes from Shea Stadium, "but I always rooted for the Yankees, and I knew other kids who did," he said. "Maybe that tells you that there isn't as much identification with the teams, because so many players come and go."
New Yorkers may be glued to their pocket color televisions today, but the 1956 Series was a testament to the ubiquity of radio. "You could walk down the street from house to house and never miss a single play of the game," Ms. Goodwin said.
Though the first color-television sets were sold in 1954 (for $1,000) the 1956 donnybrook was, for the average fan, a black-and-white-screen, tin-foil-on-the-rabbit-ears experience. In a town where innovators were pioneering live television drama and comedy, "network executive offices weren't worrying that the New York demographics were too insular and parochial for national audience ratings," said David Halberstam, author of "Summer of '49" and "October 1964," who grew up seven blocks from Yankee Stadium.
In autumn classics then, the game-day afternoon was exactly that: a day game. Life in the boroughs was a scene out of "The Day the Earth Stood Still," when everything stopped. But thanks to evening scheduling, many millennial New Yorkers will be spared the crisis of every 1956 baseball Hamlet: to cut school or to call in sick at work?
If the city of 1956 was an alternate universe, "it is remarkable that New York has changed less than most other American cities since then," Dr. Jackson said. He said that Detroit and St. Louis lost half of their populations during the last four decades, while cities like Cleveland, Buffalo and Baltimore lost nearly a third. New York's population of 7.4 million isn't too much lower than that of 1956, if the number of illegal aliens is factored in.
"In the '50's, the economy was booming, but people thought that the future was in the suburbs," Dr. Jackson said. "Now there is a sense of energy in the city that is more appealing to young people than the suburbs."
But aspects of the lost New York live again. Already, the Series is a political opportunity (with the Republican Senate candidate, Rick A. Lazio, hyping the Mets, and Hillary Rodham Clinton, the Democrat, promoting the Bombers). It isn't the first time. In 1956, President Dwight D. Eisenhower arrived at the first game in an open campaign car and Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democratic nominee, was cheered at the next game.
Just as writers, painters, photographers, designers, musicians and celebrity chefs have put millennial New York on the cutting edge of innovation, the Dodger-Yankee town was a festival of modern dance experimentation, abstract expressionism, bold Broadway musicals, culinary creativity pioneered by the likes of James Beard, transgressive jazz and doo-wop on the street corners.
While the 14th Subway Series introduces a new generation to a 79-year-old city tradition, it will surely provoke a rush of memories for New Yorkers older than 50. "It's feeling a lot like deja vu all over again," said Yogi Berra, reprising one of his more celebrated Yogi-isms.
In the end, maybe the first Subway Series between the Yankees and the Mets is a triumph of continuity and revival for a city rich in both history and baseball. Or maybe it's just another occasion to brag.
"We purport to be the best, and it's nice to see that actually validated," Mr. Maas said. "The Subway Series is a symbol of New York's renaissance, and it will drive the rest of the country nuts."

SECTION: Section 7; Page 8; Column 2; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1116 words

HEADLINE: There's There There

BYLINE: By Alain de Botton; Alain de Botton's new book is "The Consolations of Philosophy." He is also the author of "How Proust Can Change Your Life" and "On Love."

 BODY:

 PARIS TO
 THE MOON
 By Adam Gopnik.
 338 pp. New York:
 Random House. $24.95. 
 In 1957, the French critic Roland Barthes published a book, "Mythologies," that remains essential reading for anyone trying to understand modern France. In a series of extremely short essays, some no more than 500 words, Barthes seized on neglected, even trivial aspects of French life and drew out of them magisterial analyses of his society. He wrote on, among other subjects, steak and fries ("fries are the alimentary sign of Frenchness"), the Citron DS, the soap powder Omo and the Blue Guides. Barthes's genius was to bring the eye of a journalist for the contemporary together with the analytical power of a sociologist and to write in the clear, aphoristic prose style of great French writers like Chamfort or Stendhal. Since 1957, there have been many books on the territory of "Mythologies," but almost all have suffered from impenetrable jargon or annoyingly breezy journalese.
But now, in this reviewer's mind at least, Roland Barthes has a worthy successor in the shape of Adam Gopnik, essayist for The New Yorker and its correspondent in Paris from 1995 to 2000. "Paris to the Moon" is a collection of essays originally written for the magazine that have been seamlessly integrated with new and often more personal material. There are profound and hilarious reflections here on French cafes, cooking, strikes, fax machines, Christmas trees, plugs, toys, football and hospitals -- and much else. The result is the finest book on France of recent years.
In the opening chapter, Gopnik accounts for what drew him to France, and more specifically Paris, in the first place. "I've wanted to live in Paris since I was 8," he declares, but in the nature of many love affairs with other countries, the reasons for Gopnik's passion remain vague and, he would be the first to admit, rather sentimental. As a child growing up in Philadelphia, he'd seen charming images of Paris in a book adaptation of the film "The Red Balloon," by Albert Lamorisse. As a teenager he'd gone on a trip to Paris with his family and had the best meal he could remember in a simple restaurant near his hotel. A few years later, he'd been back to Paris with his girlfriend (and now wife), Martha, and had felt like an adult for the first time. And, living in Manhattan, he'd felt drawn to the idea of providing his son with a French childhood -- Babar, puppet shows in the Luxembourg gardens, etc. -- in contrast to what he felt was the depressing Gameboy culture predominant in the United States.
The Gopnik family hadn't exactly chosen the best moment to move to France, as Gopnik concedes; living in France "was a hard romance to sustain in most of the last five years, when almost everybody else thought that Paris was going straight to hell." It has indeed been fashionable (until very recently) to write France off as a country wrecked by obsolete working practices and unable to adjust to the new economics (what the French call, usually with utter disdain, "the Anglo-Saxon model"). In the last five years, French politics have been rocked by a succession of scandals, there have been almost monthly strikes, the unemployment rate has stuck firmly above 12 percent, French filmmakers and writers don't seem to produce anything decent and, what is perhaps worst of all, it's now often said that you can eat better and cheaper in London.
But this feeling of being in the right place at the wrong time did not deter Gopnik, who threw himself into the task of describing and interpreting his beloved country. He excuses the absence in his book of some of the more typical journalistic assignments: high politics, local corruption, crime. What really interested him about France was how people ate, where they bought their washing machines, where they went on holiday and so on -- the details of everyday bourgeois life.
The distinctive brilliance of Gopnik's essays lies in his ability to pick up a subject one would never have imagined it possible to think deeply about and then cover it in thoughts, making connections with literature, sociology and philosophy -- all treated in a highly readable way. "It is as if all American appliances dreamed of being cars while all French appliances dreamed of being telephones," he writes, trying to account for why his refrigerator in Manhattan looks so different from the one in Paris. He argues that the French are obsessed by telephones because they love to communicate, and then goes on to point out that the way they use their phones is very distinctive and quite un-American. They favor a clipped, epigrammatic style of phone conversation, as opposed to the flabby, endless digressions of Americans. Then follow some reflections on the French and their plugs. Gopnik makes much of the fact that the French have "light, dapper, rounded three-prong plugs with two little cylindrical probes," while the Americans usually leave their plugs ungrounded, a symptom of an un-nannying approach by the American authorities, but also of a very un-French tolerance of risk.
Some of Gopnik's finest pieces relate to eating. In an essay entitled "A Tale of Two Cafes," he tackles head-on one of the great mysteries of life on the Left Bank of Paris: why it is that in the Place St.-Germain there are two cafes, almost identical in atmosphere and food, one of which is deemed the epitome of chic (Cafe de Flore), the other of which (Les Deux Magots) is derided by anyone in the know and is abandoned to the lowest of the low in the natives' eyes, American tourists. Gopnik's analysis of this mystery takes in most of the major figures and events in the history of modern France. He mentions the Vichy government, relations between Camus and Sartre, semiology, Voltaire and Michel Foucault. He is truly able to see the whole world in a grain of sand.
Another virtue of this book, and what makes it peculiarly French despite the nationality of the author, is the way it is written. Gopnik writes essays in the French rather than the Anglo-Saxon style, by which I mean that he fuses a personal voice (we get to know and like him in the course of the book) with an essentially serious intellectual project. It is this mixture of the personal and the intellectual that places him in the tradition of nonfiction writing that starts with Montaigne and includes the essays of Baudelaire, Camus and of course Barthes himself.
"Paris to the Moon" is purportedly about France, but by the end we feel we have learned about more than just one country, we've learned -- through the prism of France -- about differences among societies, and so too about our own particularities.

LENGTH: 1090 words

HEADLINE: A Life Like Old Postcards

BYLINE: By Richard Eder; Richard Eder writes book reviews and articles for The Times.

 BODY:

 A New World
 By Amit Chaudhuri.
 192 pp. New York:
 Alfred A. Knopf. $22. 
 Sleep can be a refuge from intolerable anguish; but it is thin and vulnerable, restless and soon over. Humiliated when his wife leaves him for another man -- partly bald, moreover, and with bad breath -- Jayojit Chatterjee takes leave of his life in California to spend the summer with his parents in Calcutta. Amit Chaudhuri portrays this retreat into childhood reassurance as a sleep of its own: briefly consoling and mournfully fragile.
Author of a trilogy of novellas that evoke the amiable languor and stagnant poisons of his native city, Chaudhuri employs both art and risk in "A New World." Mirroring Jayojit's somnolence, the story fades away at times; mirroring its sweetness, the writing is lovely; mirroring the shards of painful memory that pierce the lethargy -- nails through a fakir's mattress -- the languor of the summer narrative is interrupted by snippets of the year-round realities Jayojit has temporarily shed.
Jayojit works to give substance to the daily details of his Calcutta holiday, as if they, not his broken marriage and position as an economics professor, were his real life. He clings to them like a dream that fights awakening.
With his young son, Bonny, whom he has managed to wrest from his ex-wife, Jayojit lands at the airport after an interminably circuitous flight on a Bangladeshi airline, chosen to save money. He feels light and floating, his burdens unshouldered. When the taxi driver overcharges him, he laughs as if the fare were play money.
Calcutta promises respite and cosseting. As soon as Jayojit and Bonny arrive, sticky and tired, his mother offers to assemble a greasy breakfast. They lack the energy to touch it. (Her cooking, Chaudhuri writes, in one of many phrases that give wings to this purposely still story, "was safe and insipid, and had a tranquillity about it.") "Have a bath, then, you two," offers the father, a retired admiral. Bathing is nourishment in the steamy city.
The days pass, easy and torpid. Bonny, whose displaced-child docility the author suggests without ever mentioning it, plays with his set of plastic dinosaurs. Jayojit takes naps and baths, rambles through the neighborhood, chats with the neighbors, does small errands. Some of the chapters are nothing but errands, accomplished slowly.
"Snapshots" is too active a word for Chaudhuri's portraits of life in his family's middle-class apartment compound. "Old postcards" is more like it: a dog barking, the slumbrous watchman at the gate, the drivers hanging about the tea-stall outside, the pavilion from where the building's laundry is delivered crisp each day. "There were few things to rival washed clothes in their undisappointing recurrence."
At times nothing moves at all: not in Jayojit's summer days, not in the pages of the book. It is a dead calm, and it can be trying for the reader. Gradually it becomes trying for Jayojit, as he begins to outsleep himself. And from his restless rest, Chaudhuri assembles a moving portrait of aging parents and a son whose troubles mark them, just as their decline marks him.
The apartment is decent but cramped. Evenings, the sound of television ("a form of public dreaming") drifts from next door. Admiral Chatterjee -- a rear admiral, actually -- is living on a pension whose value is shrinking and on investments too cautious to profit from the securities boom. Jayojit, an economist of some small repute (his bugbear is Americans who ask him about Amartya Sen), is an occasional consultant to the Indian government. He is helpless, as economists tend to be, when his father shyly hints that he could use some financial advice.
Admiral Chatterjee speaks a bluff naval English (though he was an independence nationalist as a young officer). He used to frequent the officers' club; now diabetes and a small stroke have sapped his energy. More profoundly, so has his loss of position, perks and deference. He schools himself to be simply one more old man to bank clerks and shop attendants. There is a fragile habit of command, still, but puzzlement beneath it. He feels threatened by his wife's quiet plea for a washing machine; they must make do with the part-time help that is all they can afford. It is change he fears. As for Mrs. Chatterjee, change might be welcome -- perhaps in everything except deference to her husband.
Jayojit's holiday has a little while to go but it is over, in fact. Even on holiday, life intrudes. Jayojit will buy a washing machine for his mother; he has a purposeful though wonderfully indirect talk with the family doctor, an old friend, about his father's health.
The artfully -- perhaps too artfully -- hidden thread that runs through Jayojit's Calcutta story is, of course, what happened to his marriage. Until Bonny's birth, he and Amala had been passionate and seemingly loving. "Then unfamiliarity set in, though no one else would notice it, and they got used to even that. The child, instead of bringing them together, actually enabled them to separate into their own spheres of desire and loneliness."
Amala moved out, sued for divorce and got full custody of Bonny. Jayojit -- tigerish in California, a tiger tranquilized at his parents' -- fired his lawyer, hired another, brought an unusual action in an Indian court and won vacation rights. Chaudhuri feeds us these things one scrap at a time, spaced between the Calcutta errands, naps and walks. Frustratingly, it never quite makes a full meal, though it infuses tension into the stillness. It also represents, perhaps oversubtly, Jayojit's own need to blot the story out for a while.
In fact, the real weight of the breakup is conveyed not in the brief, grudging facts, but in what it has done to Jayojit's father and mother. Again, the disclosures are scattered, but they are devastating. "In a strange way, they felt abandoned," Chaudhuri slips in at one point. Overweight and failing, the admiral has begun to take conscientious morning walks. He doesn't much want to live longer, but "he felt this need to see Jayojit through."
Most quiet and affecting is an aside about the parents' television habits. They had been addicted to soap opera romances. Then, during Jayojit's custody battles, they stopped watching. "They'd found they could no longer immerse themselves, or even find a center, however temporary, in a proxy existence." Holmes's dog that didn't bark illuminated a murder; the Chatterjees' unwatched TV illuminates a different death.
