PUB-DATE: October 22, 2000

SECTION: Section 6; Page 74; Column 2; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 4640 words

HEADLINE: The Next Court

BYLINE: By Jeffrey Rosen; Jeffrey Rosen, an associate professor at the George Washington University Law School and the legal affairs editor of The New Republic, is a frequent contributor to the magazine. He is the author of "The Unwanted Gaze: The Destruction of Privacy in America."

 BODY:
'The next president is going to appoint three, maybe even four, justices of the Supreme Court," Al Gore declared in a moment of enthusiasm during the first presidential debate. But Gore and George W. Bush said little about their visions of the court, except to dance around the one question that has obsessed presidential candidates since 1980. "The main issue is whether or not the Roe v. Wade decision's going to be overturned," the vice president announced. "This is a very important issue, because a lot of young women in this country take this right for granted, and it could be lost." Bush countered with echoes of Richard Nixon's campaign rhetoric from 1968. He promised to appoint judges "who will strictly interpret the Constitution," as opposed to "liberal, activist judges who will use their bench to subvert the legislature."
In fact, both candidates are repeating slogans from old debates that may not turn out to be central during the next four years. Consider abortion. There are now six justices on the court who support the core principle of Roe v. Wade -- namely, that abortions can't be banned before fetal viability. Only three justices believe, as Justice Antonin Scalia declared as recently as June, that Roe "must be overruled." For Roe to be overturned, Bush would have to replace two pro-Roe justices -- say, John Paul Stevens and Sandra Day O'Connor -- with two committed anti-Roe justices. Given the uncertainties of Supreme Court retirements, he might not have this opportunity. What's more, overturning Roe wouldn't lead to a national ban on abortion. Although some state legislatures would vote to restrict abortion, many would maintain the status quo. 
 Even if we assume conservatively that the next president will have only one court appointment, however, the stakes in November's election are high. There are a number of issues on which the court is more closely divided along ideological lines than it is over abortion. One is affirmative action, where the vote of a single new justice could decide whether or not race-conscious admissions in public schools and universities are permitted in America. Another key issue concerns the balance of power between the federal government and the states.
The word "federalism" tends to make most people's eyes glaze over. But although the issue gets less attention than affirmative action and abortion, it is no less important. During the past five years, the Supreme Court has struck down all or part of 25 federal laws, from the line-item veto to the Brady gun-control law. In many of these cases, the court decided -- by slim 5-to-4 margins -- that Congress or the president had encroached on states' rights or on the separation of powers. The election of 2000, therefore, could redefine the shape of the federal government. If Gore wins, the court might well abandon its recent attempts to impose meaningful limits on Congress's power. If Bush wins, however, the court could embark on a concerted attempt to roll back the boundaries of the modern regulatory state.
How would the country be changed by such an effort? Some of the laws that the court has struck down so far -- like the decorously named Violence Against Women Act -- might be viewed as symbolic laws, designed to please powerful constituency groups rather than to solve national problems. (It is arguable, for example, that violence against women is already regulated adequately by the states.) But the court in recent years has begun to impose more serious limits on federal authority -- preventing Congress from authorizing senior citizens to sue the State of Florida for age discrimination, for example, and preventing the Food and Drug Administration from regulating tobacco as a drug. If the court continues much further down this path, the effects on national politics could be profound. The federal government might have much less discretion to regulate water and air quality and to control the spread of viruses that haven't yet crossed state lines. Indeed, Congress might be hamstrung in its efforts to enforce national solutions to a host of problems that can be only dimly imagined today -- involving crime, privacy and the regulation of cloning and other genetic technology. Even if you applaud the idea of serious limitations on federal power, you might be wary about having them imposed by the Supreme Court.
Many people are familiar by now with the constitutional arguments for and against legalized abortion and affirmative action. But the debate over federalism tends to be too abstract to get even the hearts of lawyers pounding. In the hope of making the issue more concrete, I visited two judges who have written influential opinions on opposite sides of the debate: J. Michael Luttig, an appellate judge in Virginia; and David S. Tatel, an appellate judge in Washington. This choice of judges was not made casually. Luttig is considered a leading candidate for a Supreme Court appointment in a Bush administration; Tatel is among those who are similarly well regarded by the Gore camp. Conversations with each of them, therefore, offer insights into the very different directions the Supreme Court could take in a Bush or Gore administration.
'Michael Luttig is a conservative's conservative," says Clint Bolick of the Institute for Justice in Washington. "He's not afraid to be a risk-taker and to look behind the meaning of statutes and use the judicial power to rein in the federal government." Luttig is an idol of the conservative legal movement today, which can be summed up with the following battle cry: No more Souters! Having appointed five out of the past seven justices with the express purpose of over-turning the landmark decisions of the Warren and Burger Courts -- Roe v. Wade, Miranda and the school-prayer decisions -- conservatives are understandably frustrated that this aspect of the counterrevolution failed. Their frustration is focused, in particular, on Justice David Souter, whom they view as having committed a dastardly betrayal by morphing into a vision of his predecessor, the liberal hero William Brennan. Among conservatives, Luttig is widely viewed as the anti-Souter, the absolutely reliable nominee.
Having read Luttig's opinions, which display a relish for eviscerating the logical flaws of his colleagues, I was surprised and charmed by his self-deprecating friendliness and emotional accessibility. He is an extremely likable man. Unlike Justice Scalia, for whom he clerked, Luttig is intelligent without being a showoff. Born and reared in Texas, he has a down-home unpretentiousness that might very well appeal to George W. Bush.
Luttig, 46, showed me around his chambers on the ninth floor of the federal courthouse in Alexandria, Va., which are adorned with autographed pictures of Supreme Court justices featuring unusually intimate inscriptions. As a Department of Justice official in the Bush administration, Luttig worked tirelessly for the confirmation of David Souter in 1990 and Clarence Thomas in 1991. Thomas's gratitude is evident in several pictures, one of which shows him in shirt sleeves with his arm around Luttig's shoulder. Another picture has an inscription from "Clarence," which reads: "This would not have been possible without you! Thanks so much, buddy!"
Luttig's speedy progress from law clerk for Chief Justice Warren E. Burger to White House aide to federal appellate judge -- he was appointed by President Bush at the improbable age of 36 -- has given his opinions a confident, relentlessly logical quality, like those of a bright, young law professor who has never been chastened by life outside the academy. Luttig, who studied Ludwig Wittgenstein in college, is known for making mathematically precise arguments, especially in cases involving the limits of federal power.
Six years ago, however, Luttig suffered a personal tragedy, which he agreed only reluctantly to discuss. In 1994, Luttig's father was brutally murdered in his garage in Tyler, Tex., by three young carjackers who shot him twice in the head as he got out of his car. After watching her husband's murder, Luttig's mother survived by playing dead.
"I loved him more than life," Luttig told me as we sat in his office. "Everything he said and did, I respected. He is the single-most important influence in my life. He is my hero." The experience of sitting through the federal and state trials of his father's murderers, Luttig suggests, helped him to sympathize with a defendant's family. "When my mother walked in the courtroom, she walked past the mother of one of the people who killed my dad," he said. "There was a look on her face: 'God, how did this happen?' My mother hugged the woman, and I followed -- I hugged the woman. It forced you to think about things at the outer margins of life. There was a bond established between my family and her family."
One of the carjackers was convicted and sentenced to death. The death sentence is now being reviewed by the United States Court of Appeals, and Gov. George Bush may ultimately be responsible for deciding whether the execution should proceed.
Two years ago, Luttig was asked to recuse himself from a death-penalty appeal by the defendant's lawyers, who argued that Luttig couldn't be impartial in light of his father's death. But Luttig rejected the request, arguing persuasively that judges shouldn't recuse themselves from capital cases merely because they had "experienced the fullness of life -- good and bad." In 1938, when Earl Warren was a district attorney, his own father was murdered by a burglar. Warren went on to become chief justice and rule on many capital cases. Nevertheless, Luttig's ordeal could hardly have made him more conservative in death-penalty cases: even before the tragedy, he was already the most conservative judge on the most conservative appellate court in the nation. In his nine years on the bench, Luttig has never voted to reverse a death-penalty conviction.
Luttig was also asked to recuse himself in a recent case involving restrictions on abortion. In 1998, Virginia became one of many states that passed laws forbidding so-called partial-birth abortions. Luttig wrote an opinion allowing the law to go into effect. In June, however, the Supreme Court, in a 5-to-4 decision, disagreed with Luttig's analysis. When it came time for Luttig to re-evaluate Virginia's law in the wake of the Supreme Court decision, he rejected a request by abortion rights lawyers that he step aside. Luttig held his nose and applied the Supreme Court decision with which he disagreed.
"As a court of law," he wrote, "ours is neither to devise ways in which to circumvent the opinions of the Supreme Court nor to indulge delay in the full implementation of the court's opinions." Luttig told me that it was important that different justices, appointed by different presidents, had decided to reaffirm Roe after it had been the subject of vigorous debate. "If you don't believe in the disruption of society, reliance on precedent is important," he said cautiously. "At the other end of the spectrum is the magnitude of the analytical errors. In each case there's a heavy choice -- not heavy as in brooding, but heavy -- with the need for incremental movement, so the court doesn't lose respect." This pronouncement -- that judges should generally respect precedents, except those that are flamboyantly wrong -- will hardly reassure partisans of Roe v. Wade.
Luttig's confirmation hearings might focus on his views about abortion, but his most important legacy as a lower court judge has been his enthusiasm in applying the Supreme Court's recent decisions restricting federal power. It was Luttig who wrote the lower court decision striking down the Violence Against Women Act, which the Supreme Court reaffirmed by a vote of 5 to 4. The Constitution authorizes Congress to "regulate commerce . . . among the several States," and between 1941 and 1995 the Supreme Court didn't strike down a single federal law on the grounds that it exceeded this broad power. But recent Supreme Court decisions have construed Congress's power to regulate interstate commerce more narrowly. Although Congress concluded (rather tendentiously) that violence against women affects interstate commerce by impairing their productivity, Luttig reasoned that any economic effects of violence against women were too remote to be taken seriously.
In a concurring opinion, Luttig's colleague J. Harvie Wilkinson 3rd reflected on the dangers of what he candidly called "judicial activism" by conservatives. Wilkinson, a well-respected moderate conservative, is himself mentioned as a leading Supreme Court candidate in a Bush administration. A former law professor and newspaper editor in Virginia, Wilkinson argued that any time courts refuse to defer to the decisions of legislative bodies, their decisions must be called activist. But he insisted that the Supreme Court's recent decisions limiting the scope of federal power were more defensible than than those of previous eras of judicial activism, the 1930's and 1960's, because the court was merely acting as a "structural referee" between federal and state governments. Looking to the future, however, Wilkinson cautioned that "if modern activism accelerates to a gallop" -- leading to a "wholesale invalidation of environmental, civil rights and business regulation" -- then the new conservative judicial activists would be just as discredited as their predecessors.
When I asked Luttig what he thought of Wilkinson's warning, he said he disagreed with his colleague's definition of judicial activism. "It's not true that every time you strike down a law, that's an act of judicial activism," Luttig said. "In fact, it can take any form, including striking something down, but also not striking something down when you are exercising your own policy objectives."
The debate between Luttig and Wilkinson continued in a case decided in June. Wilkinson, writing for the majority, upheld an application of the Endangered Species Act to prevent landowners from killing or trapping red wolves on private property. In a vigorous dissent, Luttig insisted that this application of the Endangered Species Act was unconstitutional because "the killing of even all 41 of the estimated red wolves that live on private property in North Carolina" would have only a trivial effect on interstate commerce. "The interpretation of this clause of the Constitution, no less so than any other, must ultimately rest not with the political branches, but with the judiciary," Luttig wrote. Wilkinson declared that Luttig's aggressively limited view of national power would "place in peril the entire federal regulatory scheme for wildlife and natural resource conservation." But Luttig sees his view as unflinchingly logical. "I don't think there's a scholar out there who believes that the commerce power is without check," he told me confidently.
If Bush judges are likely to question the scope of federal power, Gore judges are not. Although Gore has indicated that he would appoint liberal justices like Thurgood Marshall and William Brennan, it is not yet clear if Gore is more willing than President Clinton to expend significant political capital to appoint judicial liberals rather than judicial moderates. At the very least, however, it seems probable that Gore justices, like the moderate Clinton appointees Ruth Bader Ginsburg and Stephen G. Breyer, would share a distaste for sweeping exercises of judicial power and a reluctance to strike down federal laws in the name of states' rights. One judicial moderate who fits this mold is David Tatel, appointed by Clinton to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.
Not long ago, I visited Judge Tatel in his chambers in Washington. "Nice to see you," Tatel said as he greeted me at the door. "Come on in, have a seat." Ushering me toward a chair, he sat down on a comfortable sofa, behind a coffee table with nothing on it except a copy of Gerald Gunther's biography of Judge Learned Hand.
I asked what he thought of the book. "Isn't it great?" he said. "There's actually a quote here that I wrote down for my clerks." Tatel picked up a small keyboard with six large black keys. He placed an earpiece into his left ear and tapped a few times on the keyboard. "Here it is, from Page 289: Hand was 'uncertain about the proper result in most cases, even after decades of judicial experience."'
It is easy when talking to Tatel to forget that he is blind. A degenerative eye disease, retinitis pigmentosa, began to destroy his sight when he was in his teens, and he became legally blind in the 1970's. But he maintains ordinary eye contact when he speaks and walks freely around his chambers; the keyboard is the only evident sign of his disability.
"My kids call this my Fisher-Price toy," he said. "I can use it to take an opinion home on disk and work on it myself. It's a great little machine, and it gives me an enormous amount of independence. But it has a terrible voice." Reaching over to a telephone on a stand at his right, Tatel punched in a number for a newspaper-reading service for the blind that has a voice he prefers. The voice began to recite the letters to the editor from that day's New York Times so quickly that the words were like high-pitched gibberish. "That's the speed I like to listen to," Tatel said. "It sort of sounds like your Swedish aunt."
Suddenly, Tatel got up from the couch, walked across the room, sat down in the swivel chair behind his desk, reached under his computer stand, picked up a small device and walked back across the room, reaching only once to touch the bookcase against the wall. "This holds 5,000 pages of text," he said, settling back again on the couch. "I'm using it to read a whole bunch of Supreme Court cases from last term." In the next year or so, Tatel's court will be one of the first to receive briefs and submissions on computer disks, and Tatel will be able to listen to the digital submissions on his portable keyboard. For now, however, Tatel's briefs are read to him by a reader provided by the court. "I suspect the other judges preparing for this case will prepare for it in two or three hours," he said. "This will take me five or six hours to do it, just because I have to have everything read to me."
Tatel, who is trim at 58, swims three mornings a week at the Y, where a clerk meets him to walk to chambers. Until last December, for 30 years he jogged regularly with a friend, navigating the familiar course by tying their arms together with a cord. "I quit not because of my eyes but because of my back," he explained. He is also an enthusiastic skier and has trained his children to ski behind him, calling out the turns on a radio headset. But when I pressed for more details, he asked me to ensure that his blindness wouldn't become the focus of this article. "Somebody once said that I viewed myself as a judge who happens to be blind rather than a blind judge," he said. "If you get too much into the jogging and the skiing, it becomes an article about my blindness. I don't believe it's like the race issue. I think you can make a very powerful argument that having a black judge is important for the judiciary, or women judges, but it's not like that issue. I hope I wasn't put on this court because of my disability, because I actually don't think it's particularly relevant, whereas I think the race and gender issue can be. Everybody has a lot of experiences in their lives that affect how they look at things. I don't think it's a big deal, and I'm uncomfortable having it be a big deal."
Judge Tatel is as deferential to Congressional power as Judge Luttig is willing to rein it in. The differences in their approaches to federal authority is best summed up in a decision that Tatel's court decided last year and is now being reviewed by the Supreme Court.
Tatel's conservative colleagues voted to strike down the part of the Clean Air Act that authorizes the Environmental Protection Agency to regulate ozone and other forms of air pollution. Resurrecting a judicial doctrine that has not been applied since before the New Deal era, the conservatives held that the Clean Air Act's broad instruction to the E.P.A. to set air-quality standards that will "protect the public health" is an unconstitutionally vague delegation of Congress's authority, because no one knows precisely what "the public health" is. (To pass muster, the conservatives suggested, the law should have more carefully constrained the E.P.A.'s discretion in choosing one pollution level over another.)
In a strong dissent, Tatel suggested that the conservatives' reasoning would also call into question the constitutionality of many other broad federal regulations, from the Federal Communications Commission's authority to regulate TV networks to the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission's authority to determine "just and reasonable rates" for electricity. "Not only did the panel depart from a half-century of Supreme Court separation-of-powers jurisprudence," Tatel wrote in a related decision, "but in doing so, it stripped the Environmental Protection Agency of much of its ability to implement the Clean Air Act, this nation's primary means of protecting the safety of the air breathed by hundreds of millions of people." Tatel's position may well be vindicated by the Supreme Court later this year. But during the next decade, battles over the scope of the federal government's power to regulate will probably be fierce.
Although Tatel has been reluctant to use his authority as a judge to second-guess the political branches, he first made his name as a lawyer by arguing for vigorous judicial intervention in cases involving civil rights. Tatel served as director of the Office of Civil Rights at the Department of Health, Education and Welfare under President Carter and then as national director of the Lawyers' Committee on Civil Rights Under Law. As a private lawyer, he went on to represent school districts in litigation to promote school desegregation, and he was responsible for negotiating a pioneering desegregation settlement between the N.A.A.C.P. and the City of St. Louis.
But time appears to have modulated Tatel's view that courts should be the primary engines of social change; he now seems to feel that courts can enforce constitutional rights but should not impose heavy-handed remedies in an effort to remake society. This year, Tatel applied his insights about the limits of judicial activism when a Maryland district judge appointed him to be mediator in a longstanding lawsuit claiming that handicapped children in Baltimore weren't getting the special education to which they were entitled. After ordering the school district to pay millions of dollars and trying to supervise the district himself, the judge, Marvin J. Garbis, finally decided that the parties should set educational goals for the school. With Tatel's help, both sides quickly came to an agreement. Tatel told me that such "mediated" discussions were a "more effective use of judicial power" than the old mode of forcing change by judicial fiat.
Tatel's views about judicial power are not minimalistic across the board. He favors a strong role for the courts in protecting individual rights against infringements by Congress as well as by state legislatures and is particularly committed to individual privacy. He dissented from a decision to deny President Clinton the attorney-client privilege during the Monica Lewinsky investigation for conversations with Bruce Lindsey, a White House aide. He struck down part of a recent federal regulation that requires phone companies to turn over to the police information about all the digits that have been dialed after a suspect's call is connected, including voice-mail passwords and bank account information. And he dissented from a decision to uphold the District of Columbia's Juvenile Curfew, which forbids children 16 and under to be in a public place without adult supervision between 11 p.m. and 6 a.m. Children have a "fundamental right to free movement," Tatel concluded, and parents have a fundamental liberty "to direct the upbringing and education of children under their control."
Tatel's reasoning suggests that he would be more inclined than a judge like Luttig to recognize a constitutional right to personal autonomy, which isn't found explicitly in the Constitution. How broadly he would interpret this right is impossible to say. But Tatel seems no more likely to engage in a freewheeling Roe v. Wade-style expansion of the right to privacy than Justices Ginsburg or Breyer, both of whom joined the unanimous Supreme Court in refusing to recognize a broadly defined constitutional right to doctor-assisted suicide. There is, at this moment in our legal culture, little support among judges of either party for the aggressive creation of new constitutional rights. Instead, Democratic and Republican judges are focused on conserving their judicial victories of the last generation and are divided about whether to accept their defeats. While Tatel might not vote to overturn the recent decisions limiting the scope of federal power, he certainly would not vote to extend them. In a recent opinion defending judicial restraint, Tatel noted, "The Constitution presumes that, absent some reason to infer antipathy, even improvident decisions will eventually be rectified by the democratic process and that judicial intervention is generally unwarranted no matter how unwisely we may think a political branch has acted."
There is a political subtext to this high-minded debate about federalism. The idea that Congress's power to regulate commerce "among the several States" could be interpreted to justify any federal legislation first took hold during the New Deal. Back in 1937, in the face of F.D.R.'s court-packing plan, the conservative justices decided to get out of the business of enforcing constitutional limits on Congress's power. As a result, the modern regulatory state was born. Sixty years later, however, the New Deal is no longer a sacred cow. And it is clear that today's conservative judicial revolution is, in many ways, a response to the New Deal itself. Although "strict constructionist" judges like Luttig oppose the use of the courts to create individual rights, these same conservatives are eager to use the courts to resurrect limitations on federal power that have been ignored since the 1930's.
This election, for better or for worse, will determine whether or not the premise of the New Deal -- that federal power is essentially unlimited -- will remain in force in the 21st century. Although Judge Luttig is correct that the Constitution doesn't seem to anticipate a federal government of unlimited power, Judge Tatel is correct that ever since the New Deal, efforts by judges to enforce those limits have threatened to strike at the heart of what Washington does. And even those who shudder at the excesses of the regulatory state might hesitate before encouraging courts to dismantle it. For more than 50 years, liberals and conservatives agreed that the tyranny of elected representatives was less dangerous than the tyranny of unelected justices of the Supreme Court.
It isn't at all unusual that the candidates and the voters aren't paying attention to the central question the election will resolve. After all, how many of the people who voted for Nixon and Reagan expected their candidates to go to China and end the cold war? As the shortsighted focus on Roe v. Wade shows, presidential campaigns often end up resolving wars that few people noticed were still being fought. But at least in the election of 2000, the constitutional choices are clear.

HEADLINE: A Caribbean Campus Where Relaxation Is a Major

BYLINE: By JENNIFER MOSES; JENNIFER MOSES is the author of "Food and Whine: Confessions of a New Millennium Mom" (Fireside/Simon & Schuster).

 BODY:
I'D never before been to Jamaica, and didn't know quite what to expect. Before my husband, Stuart, and I left, my mother-in-law, an inveterate reader of travel magazines, had warned us that every criminal in the country was lying in wait for American tourists. But what we found upon landing at Montego Bay and rounding the corner into customs, was a group of musicians, in native garb, greeting us with a hokey welcome song.
At first, barely awake after our dawn departure from Louisiana, I thought I was experiencing some kind of traveler's hallucination. But no, the cheery welcome band was flesh-and-blood, and an hour or so later, as I plunged into the famously clear blue Caribbean Sea, it dawned on me that there are worse things than getting up early.
It was late September, and we were staying at the Half Moon Golf, Tennis and Beach Club, just a few miles from Montego Bay. The huge resort sprawls out behind high stucco walls on 400 acres of coastline, looking north toward Cuba. 
 Though Stuart and I don't play golf at all and not much tennis, we figured that we could, at the very least, loll around on a couple of chaises in the shade of a palm or a coconut tree on the beach, and indulge in some competitive novel reading. Aside from a rather languorous middle-aged couple, both blond and sporting tiny bikinis, lying face up in the full sun a few palm trees away, we practically had the entire broad white, picture-perfect beach to ourselves.
But first things first. The swim in that impossibly blue salty sea -- in the warm gentle waters of a protected bay -- effectively cured most of our minor ills. And what the swim didn't take care of, the Bloody Marys at lunch, at the resort's Seagrape Terrace restaurant, did. As I took my first sip, and looked around at the gorgeous terrace with its classic mahogany furniture, with the glistening white sand of the beach and the sparkling water beyond, I began to think that even I might relax enough to stop worrying about our three kids at home.
Our junior suite was so beautiful that a part of me wanted to memorize its every detail, perhaps to emulate it at home. But I also wanted to get out and explore a bit. Perhaps I'd come across the likes of Queen Elizabeth or Eddie Murphy (both of whom have been guests). So off we set on a self-guided tour.
There were flowers everywhere -- in vibrant island colors: pink, red, purple, white -- growing in beds along the meticulously maintained brick pathways and on overhanging vines, bursting out of pots. There were arches of flowers -- hibiscus, oleander, camellia and bougainvillea -- formed by trained vines. Also trees: lemon, almond, all-spice, coconut palms.
We wandered down a covered, brick walkway past two-story stucco-faced beach-front blocks of guest rooms, sniffing the perfumed air, and thanking the Creator for having invented the 747.
We walked past first one swimming pool (circular, with an island in the middle) then the next (Olympic-size), and then the next (smaller, half hidden), and then the next. The resort has 53 swimming pools, some not much bigger than a big Jacuzzi, and many tucked discreetly within the flanks of the guest cottages.
Half Moon also has 13 tennis courts, a riding stable, an 18-hole Robert Trent Jones golf course, and a total of 419 bedrooms in a variety of combinations -- from standard hotel rooms, to villas with as many as seven bedrooms and staffed by butler, maid and cook -- every last one of them decorated slightly differently.
There are also several restaurants, snack bars and bars, a night club, a soccer field, a nature reserve, a shopping village, conference rooms, a putting green, a croquet lawn, nursery, children's playground, commissary, basketball and volleyball courts, and a fitness center, even a small hospital with a dialysis unit.
Think of a somewhat sprawling college campus that happens to be in the tropics, decorated in high English colonial style with a twist of Mary Emmerling, staffed by an army of helpers, and filled with people majoring in tennis and golf, and you begin to get the idea. (The resort offers tennis lessons, and has a branch of the David Leadbetter Golf Academy.)
Tuition? Not for the faint of pocketbook. Some offerings -- like playing tennis or working out in the spa's Nautilus room -- come at no extra cost, but many others are a la carte. There's snorkeling on a slightly off-shore reef, sailboats, wind-surfing, paddle-boats or bicycling around miles of bicycle and jogging paths. There are squash courts, a pavilion devoted to chess, fitness trainers and aquasizing (water exercise) classes.
And then there are all those enticing spa offerings. A facial, with calming, healing aloe vera and lavender oil? Why not? It sounded good. Real good. I just didn't know where to start.
"How about a nap?" my husband said.
We managed to navigate ourselves back to our room, in a white stucco cottage set back from the beach. It had a porch, with a table and chairs for dining and a chaise longue; inside was a sitting room with a television, a large bedroom with a king-size bed, and a big, tiled bathroom.
There was also the requisite fully stocked minibar (was it self-indulgent to drink Champagne in the middle of the afternoon?) and an old-fashioned console-style radio. The floor, like those throughout the resort, was black and white tile, covered with Oriental area rugs. The white plaster ceiling arched above the bed like a tent, the walls were fancifully painted in a sponged pattern of swirling sky-blues, and the bed spread and curtains were of a bright floral pattern.
It was, in short, the most fanciful hotel room I'd ever seen. Later, I learned that most of the handsome Queen Anne style mahogany furniture throughout the resort was made on the premises.
By the next morning, we were sufficiently chilled out to start the day bright and early in the fitness center, where we'd signed on for a yoga class. At 8 a.m., the resort was in full swing, with men raking the beach and pulling seaweed from the sea floor to make bathing that much more delightful. Maids pushed cleaning carts and other employees carried room-service trays to and fro on bicycles.
At the fitness center, our teacher was depressingly young and gorgeous, with the kind of body that you wouldn't think could occur via natural selection alone. She made us stretch our ankles and toes, our necks and shoulders, our inners and our outers, and when the class was over, asked if we were O.K. We were, but we were also, by then, very hungry. So we wandered back through the open-air reception area and settled down for breakfast at the central restaurant, the Seagrape Terrace.
The food at Half Moon, particularly at the Seagrape, was a bit of a disappointment; the kitchen was somewhat uneven, the offerings a bit unimaginative. But breakfast was another story: fluffy scrambled eggs and omelets, stir-fried mixed green vegetables, muffins, French toast, dumplings, croissants, jellies, jams, fresh melon, fresh fruit salads, oatmeal, olives, yogurt.
After breakfast, we settled in for a long morning of reading in the shade. By the time we'd emerged from our cottage in our bathing suits, the blond middle-aged couple were already out, soaking up the sun and drinking tall brightly colored drinks, and a waitress was taking drink orders. Just as I was beginning to doze off on my chaise, it was time for lunch again.
Stuart wanted English fare, and so we hopped on a resort van for the Royal Stocks, a surprisingly authentic looking English pub in the resort's shopping village, but operated independently. The hamburgers (in the end, we decided against pub fare) were absolutely delicious.
After lunch, we headed over to the luxurious spa, where each of us had signed on for a deep body massage. Situated in its own building, the spa is a warren of small and large rooms, all artfully decorated down to the attractive hand-cream containers and brass toilet-paper holders in the women's room, and the vase of flowers in the entry foyer. We were ushered into separate rooms and presently my masseuse knocked. After about 15 minutes of having my tensions beat out of me, I began to appreciate my physical being in a way I hadn't before.
It's amazing how quickly time passes when you're basically doing nothing, because before we knew it, it was once again time to dine. Up the beach, a cocktail party for the guests was in full swing under a dazzlingly starry sky. A steel band played "Yellow Bird," and waiters circulated with hors d'oeuvres.
I had a glass of Champagne, and then we caught a van to an off-campus restaurant, Belfield 1794. Out the gates and onto the main highway we went, and then up and down hills, around bends and through crowds, past shanties and half-completed government-subsidized housing, under villas built high up in the hills, skirting the flanks of mountains, through a valley and then up again into the hills on the other side of Montego Bay.
It was worth the trip. The Belfield is an independently owned establishment on the resort's "dine around" plan, which allows you to charge meals at six restaurants to your resort bill. It is on the site of what had once been the sugar mill of the 3,000-acre Barnett estate, which dates from the days when the entire economy of the island was based on sugar cane, and Europeans were making money hand over fist from the labor of African slaves. Diners can visit the Great House, just steps from the restaurant, and get a glimpse of plantation life, but we skipped the history lesson in favor of immediate gratification.
The restaurant -- an open-air round building under a thatched roof, situated above the dirt floor of the original mill -- is strikingly dramatic. As for the Jamaican cuisine: it was simple but delicious -- spicy, rich, tender and fresh. I had something called chicken stuff-stuff, which came with spicy yams and cassava, and Stuart had curried goat. Even the waiter was impressed by how well we'd cleaned our plates.
Jamaica is a big island -- nearly the size of Connecticut -- and lushly beautiful: rolling green mountains, morning mists, turquoise sea, fantastic flowers. It wasn't until 1962 that Jamaica ended its colonial status under the British to become a self-governing member of the Commonwealth. Happily, we American tourists didn't have to convert our money (Jamaica is suffering terrible inflation, the Jamaican dollar losing value before your eyes), but instead could rely on our American dollars.
Which we discovered the next day, when we took a 15-minute drive into Montego Bay, the island's second largest city. The streets were sultry, baking in the sun, and we seemed to attract the keen attention of just about every shopkeeper in town, all of whom seemed to be feeling the pinch of the off-season.
On Gloucester Avenue -- known as the "hip strip" -- with its glitzy bars, hotels, hole-in-the-wall restaurants, and innumerable T-shirt and souvenir shops, I was approached by a half-dozen women who offered to braid my hair, Jamaican-style, for $30. But we were on a serious shopping expedition, having promised our children something from the Caribbean.
At last, gifts in hand (beads for our daughter, and noisemakers for our sons), we headed for lunch, at the poetically named Pork Pit. About as inelegant a setting as you can imagine, it had molded plastic orange tables and chairs, plastic cutlery and tissue-thin paper napkins. But oh, the food! We devoured our platters of jerk chicken, rice and beans, and roasted yams, accompanied by first-rate ginger beer.
As we left, I was approached by yet another woman who offered to braid my hair. This time I said yes. I followed her down the road to her shop in the open-air crafts market, took a seat, and proceeded to undergo torture.
Three women worked on me at once: I felt like I was getting scalped, and at one point started doing Lamaze breathing exercises. A half hour later, they were finished.
"You look just like Bo Derek," they said. "Beautiful."
And I did, except, of course, that I'm a half-foot shorter, 25 pounds heavier, 20 years older, and Jewish. My husband looked skeptical, too.
Back at the Half Moon, the blond couple were still lying on the beach, only this time they'd both flipped over. People were sipping tall sweet rum-based drinks in brilliant shades, sailboats dotted the horizon, birds were singing in the trees, and the air smelled wonderful.
But by the next afternoon, the Half Moon -- in all its extravagant and almost unworldly beauty, its rarefied luxury -- was a thousand miles behind us, and the sound of the Caribbean gently lapping against the beach had been replaced by the sound of traffic. The kids, however, loved their presents, and my $30 worth of beaded braids jangle when I walk.
 
A resort, or an exclusive town?
To visit Jamaica, Americans must have either a current passport or a certified birth certificate and some form of state-issued photo identification, like a driver's license. There is a departure tax of $26 a person.
The Half Moon Golf, Tennis, and Beach Club, Half Moon Post Office, Rose Hall, Montego Bay, Jamaica, West Indies, is a few miles from Sangster International Airport in Montego Bay. Reservations and information: (800) 626-0592 or (876) 953-2615, fax (876) 953-2731; or go to www.halfmoon.com.jm.
The resort offers a wide range of room types, meal plans and inclusive plans. For example, guests can choose to be on a breakfast plan, modified American plan, or full American plan. Likewise, there's a choice of a number of activity plans, like a Golf/Spa Plan, the Leadbetter Golf Plan (with lessons at the David Leadbetter Golf Academy), and a Spa Plan.
Because my husband and I visited the resort during the off-season, breakfast was included with our room, a junior suite ($350 for both of us a night, for a total of $1,050 for three nights). But since we were not on any special plan, all our other meals, as well as spa treatments ($5 to $60), boat ($15 to $35 and hour) and bicycle ($10 to $15) rentals, exercise classes (about $25), and drinks at any of the resort's many bars or from our room's minibar were a la carte. Golf greens fees are $100.
There is no extra charge for use of the resort's 53 pools, the Nautilus exercise room or gym, the 13 tennis courts, croquet lawn or the 18-hole putting course. The manager's punch party on Monday and Friday nights, and transportation around the resort -- as well as to the Belfield restaurant in Montego Bay -- were also included in the price, as were taxes and service charges.
Counting the villas, the resort has a total of 419 bedrooms in 252 units. From Dec. 15 through April 15, rates range from $390 a night (double occupancy) for a standard room, to $1,190 for an Imperial Suite. In the off-season, these rates are $240 to $790 a night.
The villas in high season are $780 a night for a two-bedroom with a garden view to $2,340 a night for a six-bedroom with an ocean view, a maid, butler and cook. Off-season rates are nearly 50 percent less.
Reservations for Belfield 1794, on the Barnett Estate, Fairfield, Grandville, can be booked through the resort or by calling (876) 952-2382. Dinner for two with drinks was about $60. Closed Sunday.
The Pork Pit restaurant is a simple place with great food on the eastern end of Montego Bay's "hip strip," at 27 Gloucester Avenue; (876) 952-1046. Lunch for two with soft drinks was under $15.JENNIFER MOSES

SECTION: Section 6; Page 38; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 907 words

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 10-22-00: On Language;
Enjoy!

BYLINE: By William Safire

 BODY:
Alissome Japanese waitress at the Yosaku restaurant in Bethesda, Md., presented me with a bowl of Nabayaki Udon -- thick noodles in broth with bits of chicken and shrimp -- smiled and said, "Enjoy."
That is not a Japanese word. Indeed, that invitation to pleasure in eating is not an Asian attitude. According to my Times colleague Nicholas D. Kristof, author with his wife, Sheryl WuDunn, of "Thunder From the East: Portrait of a Rising Asia," servers of food in Japan are likely to say honno okuchi yogoshi de gozaimasuga, "here's a little something that will make your mouth dirty." The idea is to apologize for the meal and to suggest humbly that it will not be enjoyable at all to the honored guest. The Chinese equivalent, as a mouthwatering repast is placed before the eater, is meishemma cai, or "this food is nothing much." 
 In American eateries, however, and in restaurants around the world that cater to English-speaking patrons, the new server's imperative -- enjoy! -- can be heard. The mock-stern but cheerful command is spreading like the Asian leguminous vine kudzu, rivaling the readily understood O.K. and the widely accepted no problem as a major American contribution to a universal language.
Waiters (or servers, as the unisexy prefer to be called) in every culture have their national phrases to accompany the placement of a plate. Bon appetit, say the French, and the wish for a hearty appetite is expressed in Greek as kali orexi, in Spanish as buen provecho and in German as guten Appetit.
A German waiter is as likely to say simply bitte, which usually means "please," and the same idea is expressed in New York's Russian Tea Room as pozhaluista. The closest translation of these would be the neutral comment of American hash slingers as they plonk down the plate: "There you go."
A British butler is likely to warn, "The plate is hot, Madam." Until a decade or so ago, the Yiddish term was es gezunterheyt, "eat in good health"; the Gaelic equivalent is slainte, "health."
But then along came the imperative, intransitive enjoy! That exhortation has become so ubiquitous that in a Diner's Bill of Rights concocted recently by Zagat's restaurant survey, one of the inalienable rights of patrons was "for the waiter NOT to say 'enjoy' after the food is served."
How did it all begin? In his 1958 book, "For 2 Cents Plain," Harry Golden wrote: "When my mother served our meals . . . she would always say, 'Enjoy, enjoy.' . . . The word enjoy was seldom used by itself. It was always repeated." Accordingly, Golden's next best seller was titled "Enjoy, Enjoy!" In 1968, the New York Times reporter Marylin Bender quoted the furrier Jacques Kaplan on the effects of inflation: "Whenever they felt money would lose its value, people would gorge themselves. It's a dancing over the volcano attitude, an enjoy-enjoy philosophy."
Even as the dialectically duplicated verb lost its duplication on its journey to general usage, lexicographers noticed the way the hortatory "Enjoy!" did not transmit action to an object. Lillian Feinsilver wrote in her Yiddish dictionary in 1970 that enjoy as an intransitive verb "has become fairly common in recent years. . . . Enjoy yourself' was abbreviated to the simple 'Enjoy' by the solicitous Jewish mother." She noted the oddly intransitive usage by the violinist Mischa Elman: "I get a great kick out of life. I know how to enjoy."
Now, as a service to philological scholars, we examine the grammatical puzzlement contained in this seemingly simple food fiat. Enjoy yourself, meaning "have a good time," is clearly reflexive, turning the verb's action back on you, the understood subject. But the simple and now far more common enjoy! poses the question: Enjoy what? The food? Yourself gorging the food? The object is indeterminate; the verb's action does not know where to go.
"When used solely in the imperative mood," says Mike Agnes, editor in chief of Webster's New World Dictionaries, "the intransitive verb 'enjoy' may well qualify as a 'defective paradigm,' whereby a word fails to exhibit the full range of expected inflections. How odd that a word of such felicitous intent seems to reveal itself only in the stern imperative."
Jeffrey McQuain, the new editor of the newsletter Copy Editor, calls the new use of enjoy! "the implied intransitive" because it has no direct object but implies there should be one. He tracks the construction back to the ancient "Eat!" or the Italian "Mangia! Mangia!"
"The implied intransitive is especially popular in sports shorthand," McQuain says. "Coaches and fans yell their advice in the imperative mood without the subject (you) and without the object." Thus, "Bunt!" could mean either "Bunt the ball" or "Bunt, you miserable hitter."
Beware the loss of clarity in the defective paradigm or the implied intransitive. Until recently, verbs could be transitive (I love you) or intransitive (I love). Ron Meyers of New York deplores the de-transitivizing trend, using as his examples "please wait while your credit card is authorizing" and "this book usually ships in three days." What subject of the sentence is doing the authorizing or shipping? What object is the verb's action being done to?
Grammarians, lexicographers and all those living in syntax will find delectation in plunging into a deep, delicious analysis of this emerging phenomenon. And to those happy linguists we can only say. . . .

HEADLINE: The Guts Of Times Square

BYLINE: By Herbert Muschamp

 BODY:
Stephen Wilkes photographs of Times Square document some seldom-seen corners of what Guy Debord once called the spectacular system -- the conversion of the public into consumers of banal visual experience. In the late 20th century, the spectacular system became increasingly decentralized. Television, superhighways, suburban malls and multiplexes displaced city streets as channels for communication. Eventually, however, the systems specialists came to realize that there should be the occasional urban center, in the traditional manner of 19th-century industrial cities. These have now been deployed around the globe. Planners call them social condensers. They are designed to give consumers the impression that there still exist places where they can sample the fragrant atmosphere of cosmopolitan freedom, even though that atmosphere now comes canned.
Times Square is the world's leading exemplar of these manufactured centers. And Wilkes's pictures show us the hardware that operates this colossus of urban animatronics -- the hidden spaces that house the social condenser's electric circuitry. Command posts where human operators serve electronic brains. The lifts that transport the electricians who keep the spectacle glowing. As expressions of contemporaneity, this covert architecture far outshines the new skyscrapers in Times Square. It is the real world urban matrix, where human energy still has its uses amid electrified grids. 
 Debord took a dim view of what we call urbanism: street furniture, signage, zones for art and entertainment. Planners envision such projects as the fullest expression of the civic spirit, a reinforcement of the city's historic role in modern democracy.
 Not surprisingly, Debord regarded urbanism as an instrument of control. Where planners see public space, Debord saw isolation, the fragmentation of citizens into shopping units, their identities derived from a limited selection of brands. In Times Square, the crowd is an urban product to be consumed along with the signs. The crowd is itself a sign, the icon of a public that has passed into history along with the muggers, drug addicts and prostitutes that once gave Times Square its bleary edge.
Brainwashed American and image shopper that I am, I am a big fan of the new Times Square. I think it is true to its name, perhaps the most chronologically attuned chunk of real estate in the world. The invasion of media giants -- Disney, Conde Nast, Bertelsmann, Virgin -- has heightened the synchronization of time and place. Never before have the producers and consumers of media been brought into closer proximity. They rub shoulders in the street, linked by a zest for the ephemeral that I fully share.
Debord, whose "Society of the Spectacle" was published in 1967, was prophetic. Decades before the New Economy, long before the digitalization of absolutely everything, he foresaw the oligarchic uses to which these technologies might be put. In this sense, Times Square is completely monstrous, the gigantic maw of the New Economic beast. With the cylindrical Nasdaq sign, the beast even has a pretty nose.
But the evolution of Times Square continues. Recently, rumblings have been heard to the effect that the new Times Square is becoming too much like the old Times Square. While crime has not returned, there's too much loitering. People from the wrong neighborhoods are getting off the subways. These complaints are music to my ears. They mean that Times Square is still contested space and that people actually have a place in this "people" place. The circuits run in more than one direction. The vital signs give cause for hope.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

GRAPHIC: Photos: The Nasdaq Sign: Times Square's biggest, most technologically advanced sign is constantly moving, flashing ads for Nasdaq 100 companies, live coverage of financial events and, during market hours, up-to-date stock prices. A network of computers masterminded by Gene McCarthy (left) projects about two ads a minute onto the cylindrical screen, from 7 a.m. to 1 a.m. daily. Sometimes McCarthy is asked by the Nasdaq people to broadcast a special event, and he has to head to the control console and reprogram the system. Charles Sperazza (opposite), the electrician responsible for the upkeep of the 10-month-old sign, is engaged in a less high-tech pursuit. He spends his days climbing around the insides of the tower. When it comes to finding balky spots on the $20 million sign, the computer isn't much help; someone has to stand outside and radio to Sperazza the location of the glitch. Unlike the Nasdaq of late, the sign is doing well: $1 million buys two minutes an hour of advertising for a year; one minute costs $500; minimum: 10 minutes.; The Discover Sign: Before it was dismantled earlier this fall, the Discover sign at the top of 1 Times Square offered a great view north, especially if one of its 12-inch-by-18-inch panels happened to have been removed (as it was on the May night the photograph on the opposite page was taken). Today all 1,140 sections of the 55-by-55-foot sign have been taken down to make way for a new L.E.D. sign; the 77,000 six-watt incandescent light bulbs that made up Discover's traditional lighted sign are being replaced with light-emitting diodes capable of shooting out millions of colors. "Nothing in that old sign could be used for the new one; it's a whole different kind of technology," explains Anthony Calvano, president of Landmark Signs and Electrical Maintenance Corporation, which expects the new sign to be ready next month. "Everybody's looking for clarity and sharpness, and today that means L.E.D." The old sign, located atop the building from which the ball drops on New Year's eve, was installed about seven years ago. At the rate technology is advancing -- in four years, the number of colors offered by L.E.D. has jumped from 10 to 1.07 billion -- the new sign will not be around nearly that long.; The Coke Sign: "A man can barely fit in there," Bob Jackowitz, a project manager for Artkraft Strauss Sign Corporation, says of the 10-foot-wide interior of the Coca-Cola bottle hanging 70 feet above 2 Times Square. But workmen like Rob Martini, pictured above crouching to replace a lamp, jam themselves at least three times a week in the space, which is chock-full with steel girders, ladders, platforms, hot lights and 60 miles of fiber-optic cable. Built by Artkraft in 1990, the sign has an intentionally retro look: the top pops off the bottle; color wheels change the hue of the bottle so that it appears to fill up and then to empty; a cascade of more than 5,000 lights offers a changing array of Coke logos. Laszlo Szabo (above center) sits 20 blocks away from the high-wattage, in a room at the Artkraft offices, programming messages for Coke and two more of Times Square's biggest signs -- Suntory Whisky and the Biography Channel. Life for Szabo, a 46-year-old native of Hungary known to his colleagues as Laszlo the Wizard, is about to get even more interesting. Sign designers are working to create signs with ever-more advanced L.E.D. panels, signs that people will be able to communicate with as they walk by, and -- the Holy Grail of signage -- signs that will use holograms to catch our attention. -- reported by Hope Reeves; (Stephen Wilkes)

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 5; Arts and Leisure Desk
