HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE;
A Rare Opportunity For Real Architecture Where It's Needed

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP

 BODY:
WE were getting a lot of mail from readers complaining that I never write about New York buildings, so my employers decided to build one. Not just any building, but a work of architecture, a project with the potential to raise the quality of building in New York. Last week, when I learned that Renzo Piano had been chosen to design the new headquarters for The New York Times, I knew that we had such a project.
The intended site is the east side of Eighth Avenue, between 40th and 41st Streets, across from the Port Authority Bus Terminal. The plan depends on the approval of the board of directors of The New York Times Company, as well as city and state permits to lease the site. Piano was chosen from among three finalists. The others were the British architect Sir Norman Foster and Cesar Pelli of New Haven. The architects of a fourth proposal, Frank O. Gehry and David Childs of Skidmore Owings & Merrill, withdrew from the competition several weeks before the final choice was made. 
 The images of all four plans presented in these pages, including Piano's, are studies. The goal of the selection process was to choose an architect rather than a design. In a process like this, it is common for a proposal to undergo substantial revision after the architect is chosen. Architect and client may even decide to start again from scratch. The client is looking for a set of intangibles: a texture of thought, a feeling of compatibility, the sense that something historical has been set in motion by the first encounter.
It is too soon to evaluate Piano's design, and it will never be possible to assess what the other finalists might have done. But it is not premature to talk about some of the issues raised by the proposals, and by the selection process itself. Nor is it too soon to state that Piano has been given the chance, and unquestionably possesses the skills, to design the most important corporate skyscraper to be built in New York since Eero Saarinen's CBS Building in 1965.
I am a part of this story, a footnote who gets to tell the tale. At the invitation of Michael Golden, the vice chairman of The New York Times Company, and with the approval of my editors, I met periodically, over a six-month stretch, with the group responsible for choosing an architect for the new Times building.
I had serious reservations about crossing the line from the news department to the corporate side of the paper. The Times does not permit its critics to serve on arts juries. This policy is wise, not only because it constrains us from abusing the authority of the newspaper and from potential conflicts of interest. More important, sitting on a jury removes us from our natural habitat -- the realm of ideas and values and their artistic expression -- where we go in search of stories. That realm is our reality.
I am not a disengaged critic. The cultural dimension of building stirs me emotionally. I have minimal interest in personalities or politics, except as these play out on a symbolic or allegorical plane. Architecture's practical dimension is one of the things that make it exciting to write about, but the practicalities do not lack outspoken advocates. The metaphoric dimension is less easily grasped, particularly in a city like New York, which has seen solittle thoughtful architecture in recent years.
THIS is where a critic can be useful. The symbolic level is where architecture itself kicks in. When it does, land use rises above the level of real estate speculation. Buildings earn the space they occupy on other than economic terms. Defining those terms is what a critic does. More important, his job is to insist that those terms, while not quantifiable, are as substantial as the materials from which buildings are made and the money it costs to build them. My job is to say: architecture is real. Over the months, I had ample opportunity to do my job. I also learned about factors that have eroded New York's status as a city where serious architecture is possible.
The selection of an architect for The Times building was conducted as a 50-50 partnership between The New York Times Company and Forest City Ratner, a real estate development firm whose projects include Metrotech, the office complex in downtown Brooklyn. The Times building will be slightly under 700 feet, or 45 stories, tall. The lower half of the tower will be occupied by the paper's newsroom, its business division and corporate offices. Space in the top half will be leased to outside tenants. A six-story base will include an atrium for shops and restaurants and an auditorium for lectures, forums and other public events. Forest City plans to occupy one floor of office space. The Times assumed primary responsibility for selecting an architect.
I attended meetings of the Design Advisory Group, composed of staff members of The Times and Forest City, occasionally joined by representatives of the 42nd Street Redevelopment Authority, a subsidiary of the Empire State Development Corporation, and of the Economic Development Corporation, a city agency. A smaller group was designated to arrive at a consensus on the final choice.
I'm not going to report on what transpired behind closed doors. Here, I want to sort out some thoughts that occurred to me in the course of looking at the four finalists' designs At the last meeting I attended, when there was movement to revive a proposal that had been previously passed over, someone present observed aloud that we seemed to be on shifting ground. I felt I had been on shifting ground the entire six months.
In fact, architecture itself is always on shifting ground. Architects try to pin down ideas that are floating in the cultural atmosphere, chief among them, perhaps, the evolving relationship of self to community in a modern democracy. There's nothing inherently stable in that relationship, or in the processes architects and clients use to articulate it in urban space.
The guidelines for the selection process were prepared by the client partners and presented in impressively large, handsome books. The guidelines struck me as a road map to mediocrity. In the criteria for evaluating previous work of the firms being considered, "architecture" was folded in with objective standards, like whether a firm produces works within budget and has extensive experience with skyscraper design. The truth is that architecture can't be quantified. And to judge from recent additions to the New York cityscape, prior experience with skyscraper design struck me as possible grounds for disqualification.
Architecture, meanwhile, was defined as "compatible/compelling design vocabulary." If compatible meant contextual, this standard was an open invitation to all kinds of mischief. Architecture should contribute to, rather than fit in with, its surroundings. Compelling, besides being generally incompatible with compatible, suggested to me a standard of formal values more suitable for architectural photography and rendering than for architecture itself. The concept is oblivious of the relational values from which architecture is made: of outside to inside; top to bottom; structure to expression; content to form.
Somehow, however, we got from that unpromising start to a stunning outcome. Renzo Piano's design embodies those relational values, and others, in radiant form.
Piano, who has offices in Genoa and Paris, is the world's greatest living practitioner of what I call "normative" architecture. Others call it "the classical humanist tradition," which sounds more dignified. But why not just come out and say it? He's Italian.
Piano's aesthetic is as much urban as it is architectural. All Italians know that when you get a bit of money, you do something to ornament the city. You put up a church, create a nice civic square, commission a statue. Then, when the money goes away, the church is still standing. The statue remains. As Piano mentioned to me, "even when people are poor, they don't have to live in a poor way." They still have the richness of their surroundings. He has brought that philosophy to projects in Berlin, Paris, Sydney and other centers of cosmopolitan life.
We're at the crest of a building boom in New York. The city is feeling very rich. But with a few exceptions -- Columbus Center, the Rose Earth and Space Center at the Museum of Natural History, LVMH Tower -- I see few buildings that will be worth preserving for the future. In fact, if it were possible to cancel most of the current construction, the world would be a better place. The 1980's, too, were a time of vast mediocrity. What Piano brings to the job, apart from his talent, is a deeply ingrained sense of civic responsibility, a conviction that The Times must give back, through architecture, the good fortune it has enjoyed.
I don't want to make too much about Piano's Renaissance humanist lineage. He lives in different times. Nonetheless, he shares with Michelangelo, da Vinci and Brunelleschi the belief that art and science exist within the same cultural continuum. This idea has been evident from the first building that brought Piano wide recognition: the Pompidou Center in Paris, designed in collaboration with Richard Rogers and completed in 1977. Controversial when new, the this exoskeletal structure set off a debate that helped make it the most visited tourist attraction in Paris. For The Times project, Piano will employ new techniques in structural engineering, vertical circulation and curtain wall construction, in association with Fox & Fowle, the architects of the Conde Nast and Reuters buildings in Times Square.
ISEE The Times project, in its present form, as a work of urban landscape. The building's base, which Piano describes as Baroque, is made of concrete slabs that float, at 11 different levels, around three sides of a central atrium. The programming of this space needs work. The Baroque idea (to draw people in) is valid. Once there, people should experience something beautiful. Current renderings, however, show something like a media mall, in a Fun Palace configuration that recalls the work of the British architect Cedric Price from the 1960's. There is too little contrast with the city outside.
Anyone who has gone for a ride on the Pompidou's escalator knows that Piano is a great poet of circulation. Now he is playing with ways to organize the tower's elevators. Instead of a central elevator core, he prefers a side arrangement that would give office floors the spaciousness of a piazza. What I'm waiting for, however, is to see how he plans to connect the building to the Eighth Avenue subway and Port Authority station. The connection could turn the tower into an infrastructural midtown gateway.
Piano has planned additional landscape features for two upstairs levels. He envisions the roof of the base as the site for a water park, a shallow pool that would reflect the tower on its surface and bounce sunlight back up onto the tower's skin. This poetic device could become a setting for instant squalor, not to mention a source of leaks. There will be a garden on the roof, protected by extensions of the glass curtain wall above the building envelope.
What is New York's cityscape about? Escaping gravity and heaviness without losing touch with the ground. The Brooklyn Bridge, Central Park, the Seagram Building and other New York landmarks embody this idea. For The Times tower, Piano has designed a triple-skin wall that lifts the material city's grid into a metaphysical realm. A thermal wall of double-pane panel is shielded on the exterior by a sunscreen of white ceramic rods. These last are interrupted at eye-level by bands of fixed, slender blinds. Inside the offices, movable blinds or shades will increase the layers to four.
Piano has used this system before, usually in combination with orange masonry panels. Here, the metal, glass and ceramic surface will shimmer without interruption across the entire expanse of wall. Indentations at the corners will allow the expression of the walls as independent planes. This effect will be heightened by the extension of the glass high above the roof line.
Piano uses terms like vibration, breathing and magic to describe what he calls the "immaterials" of architecture. It is with these qualities that the reality of his architecture resides. But he comes from a family of builders. And he works within a tradition of close collaboration between architects and those who fabricate their work. He reminds us that the term design originated in the Renaissance with the Italian word for drawing. The concept signified the architect's emergence as a specialist apart from building. From it, we derive the conception of architecture as the meeting ground for matter and mind. Piano will invite New York to revisit that ground.
Cesar Pelli designed a perfect bullseye for those who can't help enlisting The Times as a target for resentment. Pelli is the house architect of the monoculture, a designer of iconic corporate towers that bear less relationship to their surroundings than to other corporate icons around the world. To create these, he often borrows forms from the iconography of ancient authoritarian regimes. At the World Financial Center in Battery Park City, for example, the four towers are variously crowned with a pyramid, a ziggurat, a dome and a mastaba.
Pelli's use of these symbols reflects the formalist idea that they have been cleansed of their original meanings by subsequent usage and can now be appreciated as abstract geometric shapes. I never bought this idea, and Pelli's design for Petronas Towers in Kuala Lumpur, based as it is on regional motifs, suggests that Pelli himself is prepared to abandon it when he chooses. In any case, the triumph of formalism was never so complete that viewers aren't free to locate meanings even where the architect chooses to deny them.
For The Times proposal, Pelli selected the obelisk, that most ancient authoritarian symbol. Since its appearance in ancient Egypt, the obelisk has been recontextualized many times over. Its meaning has changed in each context. In Baroque Rome, it represents the triumph of the Christian church over pagan superstition. In Washington, it is a tribute to the symbolic founder of the first modern democracy. In New York, it is the archetypal skyscraper, a sign of material aspiration.
But we are living in a time when our liveliest minds are engaged in challenging forms of authority and the codes that represent it. Hierarchy, paternalism, control: visual symbols cannot, after all, be detached from the power relationships that govern social behavior. Indeed, globalization, and its monocultural effects, have made it ever more urgent to reject the idea that symbols can be used as purely abstract forms. It is an assertion of social and artistic responsibility to insist that forms have meanings.
One of the things we know about the monoculture is that it is protean. Its appearance constantly morphs. This mutability diverts attention from the fact that the underlying economic power relationships remain the same. Pelli's design, for example, draws from a recent avant-garde preoccupation with folded planes. This motif has appeared in the work of Peter Eisenman and others. A high-style French version of it materialized in New York last year in Christian de Portzamparc's glass facade for the LVMH Tower on 57th Street.
PELLI has regularized the folded plane motif, and in doing so turned its meaning into the opposite of that intended by architects associated with this motif. Others have used the folded plane to challenge classical notions of hierachy. Pelli's obelisk affirms them. It is symmetrical. It is without scale. The pattern of its window mullions is nearly identical throughout. From top almost to bottom, it is an authoritarian object.
On the ground floor, the motif changes. The obelisk rests on a "happy face" base of retail shops. This, too, is part of the monocultural structure. Buy a pair of khakis. Consume the festival atmosphere. Literally support what some might call your oppressors, the folks who peer down from the structure's upper floors.
I was disheartened by the inclusion of Pelli among the finalists. Evidently, my message about the reality of architecture wasn't getting through. I could accept that this slick corporate object might represent a developer's view of The Times. I could not accept that it represented the paper's view of itself. Yes, The Times is a powerful institution, but of a particular kind. It is not part of so-called "black car" culture. We take subways. The newsroom reaches daily toward the Enlightenment ideals of free speech and independent inquiry, however imperfectly. The newsroom itself, as well as its coverage of news, has been powerfully affected by debates over authority that have unfolded in architecture and throughout the culture. The paper has the responsibility to challenge and correct, not blindly affirm, the corporate world's view of itself.
Pelli's obelisk stood as aloof from these issues as it did from the site's physical context. Aloofness, in fact, is what clients hire Pelli to provide. This arm's-length attitude extends to Pelli's relationship to his own buildings. The architect, an agreeable man, likes to tell potential clients that, in his native Spanish, pelli means skin, and thus he naturally came to think of the building skin as the essence of architecture. He leaves most of the rest to specialists in other fields.
It is true that there are many historical precedents for emphasizing facade design over space and structure. It is also true that Mr. Pelli has designed some attractive building skins. But the thing to bear in mind is that the equation of architecture with building skins is what most developers want to believe. They want the image of architecture without the expense and inconvenience of the real thing. Pelli provides that image for people whose interest lies in denying architecture's reality. This denial goes far toward explaining why New York architecture is in such bad shape. Why go through this process to end up with more of the same?
Norman Foster also creates power fetishes, but they are unquestionably works of architecture. Their elegance is mathematical as well as esthetic. Sir Norman Foster thinks holistically. He gets his mind around structure, space, program and image, making of them an integrated system. He turns problem-solving into art. And he is acutely responsible to the well being of those who inhabit his buildings.
His proposal for The Times didn't work for the clients, who saw it as not sufficiently flexible to accommodate the building's lease tenants. The design is a space frame in the shape of a right triangle. Along the hypotenuse, winter gardens were planned at intervals of seven stories. Each seven-story segment was conceived as a village in a vertical urban stack. The effect was an apotheosis of the New York set-back.
The combination of three (sides) and seven (floor intervals) illustrates the mystical-mathematical fascination of Foster's work. What I liked best about this plan was the implied shapes that would result if the triangle were multiplied. Double, turn upside-down, and you get a rectangular solid. Double this, and you arrive at a square. Viewers may well have perceived these ghost shapes in the midtown context.
Anyone who is less than 100 percent enthusiastic for a Foster building in New York must feel like the ingrate of all time. I prize few qualities higher than rational thought. But I don't fully trust its architectural expression. My generation was strongly influenced by Robert Venturi's 1966 book, "Complexity and Contradiction in Architecture." We came to appreciate the non-straightforward, the hybrid, the slightly deranged. Some of also us came to suspect that pure rationality too often serves to mask a highly irrational will to power.
At my last meeting with the group, someone asked which of the four proposals I preferred. I replied that if I were in their shoes, I would find it painful to choose between Piano and Gehry/Childs. The two teams had not designed equally good versions of the same thing. They had designed two different things. Two entirely different beasts. One rational and classic, the other Romantic and Gothic. Unlike the 19th-century critics who debated which style was best, we know that classical and Gothic represent more than different tastes. They correspond to different mental faculties, the right and left sides of the brain. Yet Piano's design is clearly sensuous, and Gehry/Childs's design incorporates the classicism of the International Style.
The truth is, I was madly in love with the Gehry/Childs proposal. Gehry's work will do that to you. It doesn't want you to keep your distance. From the outset, Gehry had told the clients he intended to design them "an object of desire." He and Childs made good on the promise. As I sit here, I'm looking at a six-inch-tall glass model of their design. Am I a masochist, or what?
I will have the opportunity to write about the Gehry/Childs proposal next May, when models and sketches of it will be part of the Gehry retrospective at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation. I need the distance, after all. For now, my attraction to it is based on my preoccupation with dualisms, on the cultural as well as the psychological plane. I believe collaboration between "name" architects is the wave of the future. The Gehry/Childs plan was a true collaboration, by two outstanding architects of different cities, skills and outlooks, who between them produced a major miracle.
There has been speculation about why the Gehry/Childs team withdrew. Mine is that the proposal was defeated by the very factors that made it great: the attempt to create a shared reality from four different points of view. However much they may have agreed on economic and practical matters, The Times and the developers represented two cultures. This made for unusual discussions with all the teams but Pelli's, who alone among the four finalists has embraced with something like passion the pragmatics of commercial real estate development. With the Gehry/Childs proposal, the structure changed shape. What was, in effect, a three-way conversion was enlarged to four. The lines of communication increased exponentially.
Partnerships between two firms are common in architecturally ambitious projects. Usually, however, tasks are divided between a signature, so-called "design architect" and an "executive architect," reponsible for more detailed drawings and other construction documents. This will be the arrangement between Renzo Piano Building Workshop and Fox & Fowle. The Gehry/Childs team, however, was not usual. The two firms had to devise novel ways to implement a pioneering arrangement. They, too, represented two cultures. The clients had to believe that the arrangement between them could work in practical terms.
Could four cultures intertwine? Where would the design work be done? Would the architects' two staffs get along? Would David Childs feel overshadowed by Frank Gehry? Would there be overlap between tasks? Would this affect fees? The share value of Times stockholders? Who would be in charge? Would the curtain wall work? Could the clients accept that, under any circumstances, architecture cannot be achieved by relying on standard real estate procedures? Given the ambition of this proposal, and the city's virtual innocence of all things architectural for many years, such obstacles to realization were inevitable.
Another factor must be confronted. Its name is love. In a 1959 essay on "The Sublime and the Good," Iris Murdoch writes: "Art and morality are, with certain provisos, one. Their essence is the same. Love is the perception of individuals. Love is the extremely difficult realization that something other than oneself is real."
Frank Gehry has always insisted that to do his best work, he needs a close relationship with a strong client. What he is really saying is that he needs a client's love. This is not a diva thing that suddenly came over him when he became the It Architect. To judge by a 1969 interview about the client-architect relationship, published in Designers West, Gehry has been saying the same thing all along. His job is to empathize with the client's reality. He expects the same
IT has always been clear that Gehry packs emotion into his work. What is less apparent is that much of this emotion emanates from his relationship to the client. In the case of the Times project, Gehry believed that he had demonstrated his affection for the paper by entering a competition in the first place (something he no longer does), by devoting much time, money and energy to the design (the Gehry/Childs design was the most highly developed of the four), and by producing a work that differs substantially from the Bilbao Museum and is in no sense inferior to it.
Gehry felt that his feelings were not reciprocated. This I understand completely. I once offered my resignation here for the simple reason that I felt I wasn't appreciated in proportion to the energy I was putting in. I was wrong, and so was Gehry. From the day he and Childs presented the project at 229 West 43rd Street, the tide of opinion began to shift in their direction.
For me, this shift was the most extraordinary part of the process. Just a week before, the clients had regarded Gehry with suspicion, as someone who might produce something unacceptably funny, weird or arbitrary. By the time the presentation was over, roughly half the people present had psychologically moved into the building. (Or so indicated a poll that was taken shortly therafter.) In fact, there is a great deal of passion circulating through 229 West 43rd Street. But The Times does not typically wear its heart on its sleeve. And I suspect that any developer's "due diligence" procedures are about as tender and heartwarming as a visit from the I.R.S.
This episode brings to mind a poem of Auden's:
If you see a fair form, chase it
And if possible embrace it,
Be it a girl or boy.
Don't be bashful: be brash, be fresh.
Life is short, so enjoy
Whatever contact your flesh
May at the moment crave:
There's no sex life in the grave.
But is this lusty philosophy suitable for what is still widely thought of as the newspaper of record?
Great buildings break rules. Piano will give us something subtler, more refined -- more normative -- than the design conceived by Gehry and Childs. Yet I'm confident that Piano's will be great. Since the 1970's, the reigning law in New York building has been: thou shalt not commit architecture here. That rule will now be shattered by Piano -- with luck, beyond repair.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
At SUNY in Farmingdale, a New Bioscience Park

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN

DATELINE: FARMINGDALE

 BODY:
THE State University of New York at Farmingdale on Route 110 here has been given both a new grand entrance and a new mission with the recent opening of the first building at its Broad Hollow Bioscience Park.
The park, planned as an incubator designed eventually to nurture start-up companies in a supportive, relatively inexpensive university-related environment, is a collaborative venture of the college and the nearby Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, a leading biological research institution. 
 The 50,000-square-foot, $15 million structure, which opened in September, is the first of what is hoped will be a cluster of similar buildings on the campus. The plan is that the other buildings will be devoted to helping fledgling bioscience companies bring science developed at research institutions like Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory to commercial application.
Biotechnology uses living organisms, genetic studies and biological techniques developed through basic research to detect and treat disease. Products have included antibiotics, interferon, and insulin used in the treatment of diabetes.
The idea of bringing a biotechnology incubator to the Farmingdale campus was initiated by the college in 1997. An 11,000-square-foot pilot incubator for start-up manufacturing companies has been operating on the campus since 1996, and now houses eight start-ups.
The school, with 3,000 full-time students and 2,200 part-timers, changed from a two-year to a four-year institution in 1993. It wanted to have a place on campus where students could have hands-on experience using the technology they will be learning in the classroom, said Dr. Michael J. Vinciguerra, the school's acting president. The experience, Dr. Vinciguerra said, would be provided through internship programs and other interaction with commercial companies, "so we floated the idea of developing a research park on campus."
Dr. Pearl M. Kamer, chief economist for the Long Island Association, a Commack-based business group, was asked to prepare a study for the college. It found that the proposed park would help foster the college's already extensive role in preparing skilled workers for the technology-based manufacturing jobs that had become the bedrock of the Long Island economy.
"We were already experiencing a shortage of skilled workers," Dr. Kamer said, "and developing a technical skill base was very important to help stimulate business activity around Route 110 and throughout Long Island."
The study caught the attention of the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, which had been looking for ways to keep the companies it licenses to develop commercial applications of its scientific discoveries from moving to areas like the 41-year-old Research Triangle Park in the Raleigh-Durham, N.C., area. Out of 11 companies formed around technology developed at the laboratory, only four had remained on Long Island, said Dr. Kamer, who is on the board of the bioscience park.
ESTABLISHING a close-by bioscience business park where companies could become part of a cluster of science-based enterprises similar to those found in Raleigh, Boston, Princeton, N.J., and other areas was a way of "keeping our science and our scientists on Long Island," said John P. Cleary, chairman of the board of the bioscience park. New York State also saw the potential, and $15 million in state financing was approved for the first building.
Owned by the New York State University Construction Fund, the structure occupies 5 of 20 acres on the 380-acre campus that have been earmarked for the new park. The building is fully leased, with an anchor tenant, OSI Pharmaceuticals, taking 41,000 square feet under a 20-year lease, and the remaining space leased to three smaller tenants.
The smaller tenants pay annual rents of $15 to $17 a square foot, about 30 percent below the market rent of $23 a square foot that OSI, as an established company, will pay when it moves in about a year from now. As part of their leases, companies must agree to contribute through student internship programs and with guest lecturers to a biotechnology curriculum that the college expects to begin offering next year.
Although most of the new space has been taken by one large tenant, the 20-acre site allows up to 200,000 square feet of additional space to be built in two buildings that will be earmarked for small companies, said Greg Blyskal, the executive director of Broad Hollow Bioscience Park. The hope is to get a new building under way within 18 months. The cost, which will depend on size and design, and the financing have not yet been determined.
"The vital thing is to get a second building going and to continue the development of the cluster idea, because collaboration is one of the reasons companies move to North Carolina, the West Coast and other areas," Mr. Blyskal said. "Science is moving so fast that companies must develop a relationship with other companies in order not to fall behind."
Long Island already has several incubators, and more are in the planning stages. The State University of New York at Stony Brook was the first to develop the idea, and now has two such buildings, one devoted to biotechnology, the other to software start-ups. The university would also manage a proposed business incubator at Calverton, for which $3 million in state financing has been secured. Transfer of the 50-acre Calverton site, owned by the Town of Riverhead, requires approval of the town board. A public hearing is to be held on Nov. 8.
A 17,000-square-foot software incubator managed by the Long Island Software and Technology Network, known as LISTnet, a private membership group devoted to promoting Long Island's high-tech industry, opened at Briarcliffe College in Bethpage last year. And the North Shore/Long Island Jewish Health System has unveiled plans for an incubator program that would provide 25,000 square feet of new space for start-up companies in biotechnology and biomedical technology. The venture has received a $4.5 million state grant and will be situated on the North Shore University Hospital campus in Manhasset.
"The incubator concept is definitely growing, because it is such an important concept," said Peter Goldsmith, the president of LISTnet, which started with 50 members three years ago and now has 900. "It's not just the money," he added, referring to the fact that incubators usually charge below-market rents. "It's really about getting the support network that growing companies need."
Einhorn Yaffee Prescott Architects of Albany, working with Urbahn Associates of New York City, designed the Farmingdale building as a multitenant structure with 537-square-foot laboratory-equipped modules that could be interconnected depending on how much space a tenant wanted. The main entrance is through a lobby with a 30-foot-high atrium. Two wings lead out from the central spine.
THE decision to lease all but one wing to OSI Pharmaceuticals grew out of concerns that the company, which had outgrown its 35,000 square feet in Uniondale, might leave Long Island if it could not find suitable new space. Additionally, a large mature company serving as an anchor "will develop a momentum" and will help attract small start-up companies, said Mr. Blyskal, the park's executive director, likening the idea to a shopping mall where a quality anchor tenant helps attract satellite stores.
"We are cutting back on incubator space for the short term but we are not giving up on the longer-term goal of developing a biotech industry," he said.
OSI, established in 1983, grew out of research developed at the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory. Its products include cancer-fighting drugs and pharmacological agents. Recently it also took over the management of clinical trials for one of its own drugs used to fight a broad spectrum of cancers, including lung cancer.
An additional $8 million in state funds has been obtained for a 13,500-square-foot extension of the Farmingdale building, to be built in the next year, that OSI is to use for its administrative offices, and to tailor the 41,000 square feet in the existing building to the company's requirements.
The building's three other tenants are BioSupplyNet, which moved into 1,070 square feet last month; Immuno-Rx, which expects to move into 535 square feet on Nov. 1; and a stem cell company, so new it has yet to be named, that is taking 4,280 square feet and is expected to arrive by the end of the year. Stem cells, the primordial cells from which all others emerge, have the ability to divide indefinitely and offer breakthroughs in treating serious disease. The other 3,000 square feet in the building is common space.
Two of the three companies grew out of work begun at the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory. One, BioSupplyNet, publishes a business directory called the Source Book that lists all the materials on the market that scientists might need. The other is the stem cell company.
Immuno-Rx, which is headquartered in Manhattan and is relocating its research laboratory from Tampa, Fla., to Farmingdale, works on medications that boost the immune response against cancer and certain viral diseases. The original research was developed at the University of South Florida Medical School in Tampa by the company's founder, Dr. John W. Hadden.
"Having a facility that will house a critical mass of scientific people and that has the support of Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory was very important to us," said Dr. Harvey J. Brandwein, the company's president, explaining why Immuno-Rx chose to come to Farmingdale.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/New Jersey;
Rivals Combine to Develop Exxon Mobil Campus

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

DATELINE: FLORHAM PARK

 BODY:
CORPORATE mergers breed real estate opportunities. Such an opportunity recently attracted two development companies that over the years have been both rivals and neighbors to become partners as well.
The Rockefeller Group Development Corporation of Manhattan and Gale & Wentworth, a real estate services and investment company of Florham Park, emerged earlier this month as the successful bidders for the former Exxon campus -- Exxon Mobil since last year -- along Route 24 and Park Avenue in this Morris County borough. The two-building 473-acre complex, which once housed Exxon's engineering division, was declared surplus when Mobil and Exxon merged last Nov. 30. So was Exxon's international headquarters site, a 47-acre four-building complex a half mile away, which is now being sold. 
 Most of the 1,000 employees at the larger site were relocated to Fairfax Va. Empty, it became one of the last prime commercially zoned parcels of any size left to develop in Florham Park, which like Morris County as a whole, has been the focus of considerable office construction in the past few years.
Each of the development partners has an office park flanking the Exxon site, on which they have joined forces to create a $400 million office park with 2.2 million square feet of space and such amenities as a day-care center, health club and hotel conference center. It will be built in the next five to seven years, with construction expected to start as early as next year, according to the partners.
Cooper, Robertson & Partners of Manhattan is developing the master plan for the project, which will be presented to the borough's planning board in the next 90 days. The Hillier Group of Princeton is the architect. A new interchange along Route 24 is also envisioned as part of the plan and would address existing traffic in the area -- a major community concern.
"A lot of work still needs to be done, but we're looking at the site's redevelopment as a positive," John N. Corica, the borough administrator for Florham Park, said, noting that if the interchange "can be done, it would solve many regional traffic issues."
The partners will close on the site after they secure local approvals. In addition, the interchange is subject to approval from the state. No one involved would disclose the price for the property, but real estate executives put it about $66 million.
While the project is seen as a natural extension of the partners' existing parks, it also reflects the continued evolution of the Route 24 office market. The artery, a 12-mile stretch completed about eight years ago, linked eastern Morris County to Newark International Airport via Interstate 78 in 15 minutes instead of 30 and spurred development around major crossroads.
To the north of the former Exxon parcel is Park Avenue at Morris County, the 100-acre 1.1 million-square-foot corporate center that Gale & Wentworth developed for the J. P. Morgan Investment Management Company in Manhattan, the park's owner. The park, which real estate executives say initiated the area's change to an office corridor, is fully leased. Gale & Wentworth is also developing two other projects in the county, with different investment partners, ultimately totaling one million square feet.
To the south is the Rockefeller Group Corporate Park, a 142-acre campus being developed by the Rockefeller Group, which is owned by Mitsubishi Estate and which formerly managed the landmarked Rockefeller Center for the Rockefeller family interests. The company still owns or manages four buildings on the west side of Avenue of the Americas that it considers part of Rockefeller Center. But its historic buildings on the east side of the Avenue have been owned since 1996 by an investment group led by Goldman Sachs, which is now selling them.
The Rockefeller Group in recent years has refocused on its role as a real estate developer. At its Rockefeller Group Corporate Park, the company has renovated two buildings, totaling 390,000 square feet, and is constructing a 220,000 square foot speculative building on the property, which could accommodate an additional structure the same size. In Mount Olive, farther west in the county, the group is developing the International Trade Center, where half of an eventual seven million square feet of office and industrial space has been built since construction at the 684-acre site began in 1984.
INITIALLY, the Rockefeller Group and Gale & Wentworth pursued the Exxon tract separately. But Leslie E. Smith Jr., senior vice president at the Rockefeller Group, said, "We're better off as a team, given we surround the property and the enormity of the project." Combining the expertise and financial resources of the companies reduces the risk to each one, he said, noting that "we are both long-term players."
Stanley C. Gale, chairman of Gale & Wentworth, said the partnership also provided the seller with "a comfort level and the assurance of our gaining all the approvals needed to proceed." In addition, "we have the staying power, to sustain and maintain the project," if the real-estate market were to experience a slump, he said.
Barry Wood, a spokesman for Exxon Mobil, which has its headquarters in Dallas, said the ability to get approvals was a factor in his company's evaluation of potential buyers, as were the price and the development proposed for the site.
The joint venture is not a surprise in light of the location of the site and the similar corporate cultures of the companies, said Peter Blanchard, a principal at the Garibaldi Group, a brokerage in Chatham that is handling the sale of the smaller Exxon property. "Each didn't want to lose the site," he said. "There's a threshold to how high the bids could go before its redevelopment was no longer economical."
Joining forces also enables each to capitalize on the county's strong office market, where projects totaling 2.25 million square feet are in various stages of development. Most of the projects are in Parsippany as well as towns along Route 24, according to the Parsippany office of GVA Williams, the commercial brokerage.
The partners are confident that their new project will not compete with those projects nor their existing ones, and commercial brokers agreed. The pace of construction "is cautious, yet aggressive," Eric Witmondt, chief executive of GVA Williams, said, noting the buildings will be brought to the market at varying times.
Among the Route 24 projects is a 135,000-square-foot building that the Kushner Companies of Florham Park is constructing at the corner of Columbia Turnpike and Vreeland Road in Florham Park. Also, the Wm. Blanchard Company of Springfield is building a 150,000-square-foot speculative structure on Park Avenue at Columbia Turnpike and Route 24 in Hanover. Brokers said the building had been leased, a report company principals would not confirm.
Other developers have plans to start buildings. East of the Blanchard site on Route 24 in Florham Park, the M. Alfieri Company of Metropark is to start construction next spring on the initial phase of a 750,000-square-foot office park. The four buildings at the smaller Exxon Mobil site, the sale of which is believed to be imminent, are also expected to be renovated, according to brokers. The buyer is said to be the Advance Group of Bedminster. The company declined to comment.
Most of the buildings are leased before they are completed, Mr. Witmondt said, noting that as of the third quarter, the county's office vacancy rate was 7.7 percent and average rents had risen to $25.13 a square foot.
"Many companies from New York and Bergen County are moving west to Morris County, and those here are expanding, keeping the demand, particularly for large blocks of space, ahead of the supply, " he said. And users prefer a full-service campus environment because in a tight labor market it is seen as a way to attract and retain employees, he added.
That is what both Mr. Smith of the Rockefeller Group and Mr. Gale of Gale & Wentworth are betting on for the office park they will build on the former Exxon property. Mr. Gale said that if existing companies in the 165 million square foot northern and central New Jersey office market grew by 10 percent, this would generate a need for 16 million square feet. "And the state's core industries -- telecommunications, pharmaceuticals and financial services -- are growing, never mind outside companies moving in," he said.
Mr. Smith added that three companies needing 500,000 square feet each were interested in the site, and the developers hope to begin construction next year on up to 500,000 square feet, subject to borough approval. The intent, he said, is either to retrofit the site's two existing buildings, totaling 500,000 square feet, or raze them and build an equal amount of space, which could be supported by the existing road system.

HEADLINE: Making the Hudson Live Inside a Museum

BYLINE: By ROBERTA HERSHENSON

DATELINE: YONKERS

 BODY:
THE Hudson River Museum sits amid green fields and river views, in a setting as gracious as the Victorian mansion from which it sprung. Until now, however, the river was merely a timeless backdrop, or the subject of paintings that hung on the museum's walls.
By next summer, however, the Hudson River will be a living presence at the museum, as fully described, illustrated and interpreted -- if the museum's education department fulfills its plans -- as any ecological system can be. The museum has announced a permanent installation called Hudson Riverama, a $1.25 million project expected to open next July. 
 "Our hope is that after seeing Riverama, our visitors will not look at the river the same way again," said Cathy Shiga-Gatullo, the museum's education director, who spearheaded the project.
Much of the building's first floor will be devoted to the interactive exhibition, which has been financed largely by a $500,000 grant from the National Science Foundation and $350,000 in state grants.
To accommodate the installation of six Hudson River habitats, a river lab and a resource area, several changes are planned. Two large open wells, architecturally distinguished by their balcony views, will be filled in to make room for the 4,575 square feet of exhibition material. In addition, the museum's western wall will be opened to offer a picture-window view of the river and its sunsets, providing a "portal onto the Palisades," as Fred Ellman of Roundtable Design in Tarrytown, the project's design company, put it.
An environment simulating a journey down the length of the river, from the Adirondacks to New York Harbor, is planned to encircle the Andrus Planetarium (which will be closed for two weeks when construction begins in February). Visitors will pass through habitats like highlands, tidal marsh, sandy bank and developed shore. Ambient sounds, light and video will accompany strollers. A "touch wall" in the form of a bas-relief will provide a sensory story without words, Mr. Ellman said, giving information about the flora and fauna comprising the food chain. In addition, the museum plans a ship-to-shore radio to allow visitors to communicate with passing ships.
The lab area will offer interactive videos, microscopes for viewing marine life and computer stations for recording weather and tidal data. Demonstrations and other activities will be conducted by a staff of volunteers.
The expected audience is school groups, families with young children and older adults, Ms. Shiga-Gattullo said.
She said the museum was not abandoning its artistic focus but, rather, elevating the science program to the level of the art and history programs. A strong environmental mission also underlies the project.
"One of our goals is to develop a sense of stewardship about the river in our viewers," she said.
The announcement was made in a museum gallery showing large watercolors of the river by Don Nice. John P. Cahill, commissioner of the state's Department of Environmental Conservation, was among the officials who attended. "The Hudson River symbolizes the renaissance of an environmental movement in New York State," he said.
Missing from the group was Philip Verre, the former museum director, who left last month to become the deputy director of the High Museum of Art in Atlanta. A nationwide search for a new director -- someone who "can move between disciplines" -- is under way, Ms. Shiga-Gattullo said.
The museum, which still has $400,000 to raise for the the exhibition, has been approved for participation in the state's economic development zone tax credit program. Contributors who give more than $500 for Riverama qualify for a 25 percent tax credit against personal or corporate state income tax. In addition, the contributors may be eligible for a federal and state charitable deduction.
Mr. Ellman promised that Riverama would be "really cool."

HEADLINE: POLITICS;
Rivals for Congress Debate Who's More Middle Class

BYLINE: By COREY KILGANNON

 BODY:
Even before Larry Otis Graham officially declared last spring that he would challenge Representative Sue W. Kelly for her Congressional seat, the incumbent went on the offensive.
In a fund-raising letter sent out by her supporters last year, Mrs. Kelly, the Republican who has represented the 19th Congressional District since 1994, attacked Hillary Rodham Clinton as "a carpetbagging opportunist" and referred to Mr. Graham, a Democrat, as a "liberal journalist" recruited by the Clintons to defeat her. 
 If anything, relations between the two sides have deteriorated since then.
Until last week, the candidates had not met to debate the issues, and now they are not only questioning each other's politics but also their truthfulness and their economic and social backgrounds. Each is claiming, in effect, to be more middle class than the other and more in touch with voters.
There's no question that Mr. Graham, 38, has a certain star power for a first-time political candidate.
A graduate of Princeton University and Harvard Law School, he has written 13 books on education, labor and racial issues and has been a television commentator. He is perhaps best known for his 1992 article in New York magazine about posing as a busboy at the Greenwich Country Club to find out about racism and anti-Semitism there.
His efforts to research discrimination in large corporations helped lead to the successful class-action lawsuit against Texaco in 1997. His wife, Pamela Thomas-Graham, is chief executive of CNBC.com. They live with their 2-year-old son in Chappaqua, several blocks from the Clintons' house, and Mr. Graham said he has received campaign advice from the president.
Still, Mr. Graham faces an uphill battle.
With $650,000 in her campaign treasury, Mrs. Kelly has twice as much money as Mr. Graham. And the district, which covers part of White Plains and all of Westchester to the north, as well as Putnam County and parts of Orange and Dutchess Counties, is predominantly Republican.
Mrs. Kelly, 64, a former real estate broker, won the seat in 1994 and was re-elected handily in 1996 and 1998. She succeeded Hamilton Fish Jr., a moderate Republican, who held the seat for nearly three decades.
Mr. Graham has been campaigning since May, trying to convince voters that Mrs. Kelly has sided with the conservative Republican leaders of Congress, voting against the interests of the district.
"She claims to be a moderate, but she has not offered anything in moderation to this district except for service," he said in a forum last month in Chappaqua. He criticized her environmental record and her effectiveness in fighting for Medicare and aid to education.
He also said she has received almost half her funds from special interest groups, like the National Rifle Association.
He has called for more federal spending for education, specifically prekindergarten programs, and strengthening gun-control laws, including banning assault weapons.
He called Mrs. Kelly's failure to attend debates and candidate forums "a slap in the face of constituents who want dialogue."
Mrs. Kelly called such criticism innuendo and fear tactics. "I've worked really hard for the people in this district," she said, "and I think they know that."
She said she could not take part in debates before this week because she was "down in Washington, working for the people of my district." And she denied being in lock step with Republican leaders or being influenced by special-interest money.
Her priorities include saving Social Security and reforming Medicare to give the elderly different plans to choose from and coverage for prescription drugs. She also favors tax breaks for college tuition and eliminating the inequity in income tax rates for married people and the inheritance tax.
Mrs. Kelly supports the death penalty, while Mr. Graham supports a moratorium on it. Both candidates favor abortion rights, although Mrs. Kelly opposes so-called partial-birth abortion. She favors increased military spending, while he favors cuts.
Mr. Graham is hoping to benefit from Mrs. Clinton's Senate campaign. He has campaigned alongside the first lady in the district, and the president offered suggestions on strategy and campaign consultants.
The Kelly campaign, meanwhile, hopes to capitalize on antipathy toward the Clintons.
Her campaign has also raised questions about the way Mr. Graham describes himself to voters.
Long a prominent member of exclusive black social circles, Mr. Graham once lectured the intelligentsia. Now he is courting middle-class voters at Rotary Club meetings and train stations.
Before running for office, Mr. Graham proudly discussed driving his Jaguar, wearing expensive suits and dining in the best Manhattan restaurants. His home in Chappaqua has a swimming pool, a tennis court and a guest house.
Now, the Kelly campaign says, he is deceiving voters by offering himself up as a man of the people.
Many articles over the years have portrayed him as coming from an affluent family with a "a real estate developer" father and "a psychologist" mother.
But these days, Mr. Graham tells voters he grew up in a "union labor household" where his mother, a social worker, and his father, a mail carrier and firefighter, could not afford to pay his college tuition.
"As a candidate, Larry Otis Graham claims he grew up in a blue-collar family," said Rob Ostrander, a campaign spokesman for Mrs. Kelly, "but before running for political office, he described himself as 'elite.' It raises a question about who he is and where he comes from."
Mr. Graham dismissed such remarks as "a race to the bottom" strategy meant to skirt more substantive issues. His father only dabbled in real estate, he said, and their inheritance of an old family trucking fortune never amounted to much.
"Proving one of us has more middle-class roots than the other is ridiculous," he said. "She is the daughter of a doctor."

HEADLINE: Q & A/Stanley B. Greenberg;
The Politician's Pollster: What Moves Voters?

BYLINE: By NANCY POLK

 BODY:
TWO presidents, Bill Clinton and Nelson Mandela, and two prime ministers, Tony Blair and Ehud Barak, have turned to the pollster Stanley B. Greenberg for advice.
His polls are not for public consumption. The information gleaned from his polling efforts is shared with his clients, international and national, political and corporate. Dr. Greenberg's interest lies in managing social change and reform. 
 Recently Dr. Greenberg worked with his client Vice President Al Gore in what he called "debate camp" in Tennessee to prepare for each debate. He says the purpose of the polls is "to understand what's going on in the campaign and develop a strategy."
He has on occasion conducted polls together with Fred Steeper, Governor Bush's pollster on international affairs and foreign trade issues. They work together to reassure their clients that the polls will be nonpartisan.
He is interested in the process. "Who's ahead is the least interesting part of a poll. The poll is about understanding the dynamics of the election and then figuring out how to move the voters to a different place than they are now."
Dr. Greenberg believes that the traditional method of polling by telephone is on the way out. Often his staff must make 20 calls to reach one human.
With the advent of fax machines and answering machines, voice mail and screening and the strong aversion people have to being called by strangers, he says, "Vote polling is in trouble." And he explained that his set of questions lasts 25 minutes. He predicts that Internet polling will become commonplace within two to four years.
He polls out of political conviction and carefully selects for whom he will work. "I work for people I believe in. It's part of the kind of political progress I want to see made." Recently Dr. Greenberg met at his home that he shares with his wife, United States Representative Rosa L. DeLauro, in New Haven to discuss his work. Following are excepts from that conversation:
Q. Do poll results influence voters' decisions?
A. I don't believe that and I also don't think that shows enough respect for voters. I think voters take the election very seriously. They know this is an important election. Who gets elected president effects their lives. There is no evidence that they follow the crowd or pundits. If the public followed pundits then Bill Clinton would have been out of office a long time ago.
Throughout the entire time of Monica Lewinsky, the entire impeachment process, time after time, the pundits said "this is the big moment, he's gone," "now he's truly jeopardized his position." They were always wrong. All they had to do was go to a focus group and listen to people who were very thoughtful about it. They had very well developed views of how to judge a president and were balancing some very important things in a very serious way. But they weren't listening to the pundits about how what judgment they should make about the president. They were not going to allow the elite to take away their election. They elected Bill Clinton president. They didn't elect the Republican congress.
Q. Are polls ever inaccurate?
A. Sure they are, though not usually. Usually it's a problem of interpretation rather than the polls being wrong. One problem that you have with polls is the press focuses on the most extreme poll. On any given day you take six, seven polls that are out there. If you take the average that's probably close to where the race is. That's because of sampling theory. There is going to be a distribution around a real value in the middle. But the press wants to write about the most interesting one, the one that is the most different is the one they write about. That's the one that is most likely to be wrong. Not that it was badly done. Polls will have a distribution of samples that will vary. That will always happen. Go to the average, go to the most boring poll, the one that's in the middle of the pack, and probably it's the one that is the closest. So the press will overinterpret the polls, the one that is most extreme.
Q. How do you assess the undecided voting bloc in your polls?
A. Figuring out what is going to happen to the undecided vote is the most difficult, most complex part, of figuring out an election. Usually when you have an incumbent who is very well known, such as Bill Clinton was in 1996, he doesn't get any of the undecided vote. There's a reason why they are holding back. They are not saying what that is. Bill Clinton polled 49 percent. And he got 49 percent. All the undecideds went someplace else.
The difficulty with this election is Al Gore is not quite an incumbent. And you have an election where many more people think the country is moving in the right direction. This is not a "throw the bums out election." People would like to preserve a lot of what's going right and so it's complex to gauge the undecideds. The problem is not the accuracy of polls. The problem is interpreting them.
Q. How do you conduct a poll?
A. I don't believe in doing just polls. I always do focus groups. In a presidential campaign you poll quite regularly. We'll do two or three national polls a week. In addition to that every night we'll have focus groups. We bring a couple of groups of 10 people together in a room. Usually they are people who are like-minded and undecided, people who say they are Bush voters and who say they are open to Gore. People who are the kind of voters we need to reach. Also demographically similar so that they are comfortable. We don't mix post graduates with high school graduates because the post graduates will dominate and there will be a kind of deference to them on issues that they don't deserve. We have demographic homogeneity so people are comfortable. I always separate women from men so women can bond to each other faster. These sessions last two hours maximum.
Q. When you do these groups abroad do you find any differences?
A. In France, when I do these they last about five hours. We serve wine and dinner. It's a very relaxed, full evening. It's an intense intellectual experience. It doesn't matter whether it's a working class group or college educated group. It's a very different environment. The goal is the same, to make people comfortable.
Usually here it's done in a mall because people are comfortable going to a mall, a public place where people get together. In Britain, we do it in people's houses. Americans would not be so comfortable going into people's houses.
Q. What factors do voters consider as they choose between Vice President Al Gore and Governor George W. Bush?
A. They are trying to make an assessment. Is he real? Is he genuine? Does he have a record that says can he can really do this, make a difference? They think, "I don't want to be disappointed. I don't want to believe this is just a bunch of promises. I want to know whether this can be done. That we can afford it. That it will effect my life and the country."
These are underlying fundamentals that have to do with the issues and have to do with the economy.

HEADLINE: Keeping Homeowners in Their Homes

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
TWO weeks after Vehronna Smith bought her five-story, five-apartment brownstone on Dean Street in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, last March, she slumped onto the old, crooked hallway stairs, wept and said to herself, "Oh God, what have I done?"
Ms. Smith, 32, a singer and writer, had lived with her father and brother in the ground-floor apartment for three years, renting for $875 a month, before jumping at a sudden chance to buy the building. 
 That day, two weeks after the closing, she climbed to the top floor, talked with one of her old neighbors/new tenants, and found out that in winter the heat never rose beyond the second floor. "The tenants froze last year," the fledgling landlord said. "I didn't know because our heat was just fine on the first floor. The boiler wasn't large enough to pull for the entire building; it needed replacing."
On the way down, Ms. Smith twisted her ankle on the warped stairs, sat and cried. "I was thinking I had stumbled into the money pit," she said.
And the boiler was just the beginning.
Each year, thousands of new homeowners and small landlords in the city and suburbs find they have tumbled into a money pit, buried beneath bills for some unanticipated major expense or tripped by a sudden drop in income because of difficulties like the loss of a job, an illness or divorce.
To keep those people in their homes, to support the willing but beleaguered landlord and to maintain the quality of housing stock, an array of private and government programs provide assistance -- sometimes independently, often in tandem. The programs offer aid ranging from low-interest loans and debt consolidation to teaching people how to balance their budgets; from a horde of volunteer fixer-uppers descending on needy homes one Saturday morning to teaching a new homeowner how to use a power saw. One organization, in New Britain, Conn., ran what it called a tool lending library, until it discovered that too many tools were too overdue.
"So many people come to us in some sort of trouble, delinquent," said Francine Justa, executive director of Neighborhood Housing Services of New York City, a nonprofit group that operates 11 offices in the five boroughs. "Somebody buys a house for the first time and then they start spending more money on furniture, dishes, supplies, putting themselves further into debt."
The rate of homeownership in the United States hit an all-time high during the second quarter of this year -- 67.1 percent -- fueling and, in part, fueled by a significant expansion of the mortgage market.
There are pitfalls.
"Part of the big push to expand homeownership has been to adopt less stringent underwriting criteria," said George W. McCarthy, a housing economist at the Ford Foundation. "Lenders are allowing people to carry much more debt, relative to their income, than they used to. So a lot of mortgages are now written for people who need to pay at least 40 percent of their gross income to pay their debt" -- leaving them vulnerable to unforeseen expenses.
That trend is one of the factors that have helped spur foreclosure-prevention programs, both for the individual homeowner and, particularly in the city, the struggling small landlord.
Some buyers don't understand even the basics of what they are getting into. "When I first started working in this field," said Ms. Justa of Neighborhood Housing Services, "I got a call from somebody we had just helped into homeownership, and she asked when the man was coming to cut the grass. She had always rented an apartment. I realized we needed to do a little more education."
Jerilyn Perine, New York City's commissioner of Housing Preservation and Development, sees aid to homeowners as part of a larger picture. "It's part of our overall anti-abandonment strategy," she said, "which for us means preserving buildings, particularly multiple dwellings; keeping them in the hands of owners who are capable, struggling a little, but who with some help could do a good job." No small aim of the effort, she said, "is to ensure that conditions for tenants are appropriate."
It took teamwork between Commissioner Perine's department and Ms. Justa's Neighborhood Housing Services to, figuratively at least, lift Ms. Smith off that warped staircase.
Ms. Smith and her family moved into the brownstone on Dean Street in April 1997. Three days later, her mother died "in the middle of the living room," she said, "before we even had a phone."
Over the next three years, the building changed hands three times -- the last, with Ms. Smith buying it for $350,000, on March 24. "I bought it, honestly," she said, "because, with it being the last place that my mom was alive, sometimes you have to listen to that voice even if you don't understand. The voice is saying, 'Do this, it will pay off later.' "
And beyond that inner urging, there was the very concrete revival of the neighborhood. "The area is rising so much," Ms. Smith said. "Every week there are people coming who have literally been priced out of Manhattan."
But first there was that feeble boiler to deal with, and those stairs. "And the windows are cheap and leaky," Ms. Smith continued -- and continued. "The apartment doors are glorified bedroom doors. Floors are crooked, just carpeted over. Kitchens and bathrooms need to be updated. The backyard needs a fence. The back of the house needs new pointing. And those hall stairs are going to be completely replaced, new banisters."
A lot of money was needed. "Conventional lenders don't even want to talk about a renovation to someone who has owned a building for less than three years," Ms. Smith said. "And if you can convince one, you're going to have an interest rate almost double the mortgage; someone mentioned 15 to 18 percent."
Then Ms. Smith saw a cable-television news story about how the housing department offers low-interest loans to owners interested in rehabilitating their properties. "My property was definitely sickly, on life support," she said.
Five days after Ms. Smith made the call -- to (212) 863-5300 -- a financial analyst from the department's Owner Services Program inspected her property, contacted Neighborhood Housing Services and began arranging an $82,500 renovation loan at 8 percent interest over 30 years.
"They gave me a list of approved contractors," Ms. Smith said. "I interviewed a dozen until I found someone I was comfortable with. I even went to see a sample of his work. He handles everything from wood to metal to sheetrock to plumbing to heating and electric." Work is to begin within a month, with the agencies monitoring progress.
"They are directly responsible for me seeing it as a dream house, instead of a nightmare," Ms. Smith said.
FINANCIAL assistance arranged through the housing department can help dissipate anything from a nightmare to an annoyance. "We have little loans, up to $7,500 per unit, at 1 percent interest, under the Code Compliance Loan Program," Commissioner Perine said. "It's there to remove code violations or replace one building system."
There are also "deeper subsidies," she said, under the Participation Loan Program (participation with a bank), for extensive rehabilitation, typically in buildings of 20 units or more.
"An owner comes to us," Ms. Perine said. "We go through a review. The bank does the actual underwriting. We add our money into the bank loan, at 1 percent. The bank has its own market rate. We will sometimes lend up to 50 percent. So the outcome is a below-market loan to complete a very substantial rehabilitation. Generally, we're seeing rehab work at $40,000 to $50,000 per unit."
"And there are three other loan programs in between those extremes," she said. The department also offers free classes for landlords on property management, finances, building systems, and energy, heat and water conservation.
The frequency with which neophyte home buyers and close-to-the-profit-margin landlords slip into financial trouble has been exacerbated -- perhaps ironically in the robust housing economy -- by the ready availability of financing for what the mortgage industry refers to as the nation's traditionally "underserved" population.
"There has been a marked increase in the availability of mortgage financing, both in the conventional market and from subprime sources," said Naomi Bayer, director of the New York office of Fannie Mae, the federally chartered home-financing corporation. Subprime mortgages are offered at higher than conventional interest rates to people with less than stellar credit histories.
"There's been a proliferation of subprime lending over the last five years," Ms. Bayer said. "There's a market for it, and there are investors willing to provide capital."
In fact, according to the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development, 14.9 percent -- or 2.1 million -- of all mortgages originated in the United States in 1999 went to subprime borrowers. "Over 90 percent of subprime loans have been made in the last six years," Ms. Bayer said, "and the subprime market has grown roughly 30 percent each year over the previous year during that time."
Despite the record length of the nation's economic growth, mortgage foreclosure rates have risen steadily in recent years. In 1980, for example, the default rate for conventional mortgages was 0.25 percent; in 1990 it was 0.83 percent and last year it was 1.02 percent.
"That would be around half a million foreclosures a year just for conventional mortgages," Dr. McCarthy at the Ford Foundation said.
When combined with defaults for federally insured mortgages and subprime mortgages, which go into foreclosure at a rate of 6 percent a year, Dr. McCarthy calculated, there were more than 1 million defaults in 1999.
"That's a lot," he said. "Granted we have 70 million homeowners, but still a million is a lot of defaults, especially in a robust economy."
For Yanick Charles, who once found herself teetering near the financial brink, it is little things -- like the window-well cover she installed herself -- that are keeping her and her 9-year-old daughter, Gina, in their three-bedroom brick home in the Clifton section of Staten Island.
Ms. Charles, 47, a single mother, has taken every foreclosure-prevention course offered by Neighborhood Housing Services, including the 10-week home maintenance workshop taught by Carlton Brathwaite. "It's a hands-on program," she said. "We did electrical wiring, a little plumbing, working with sheetrock, installing parquet floors, working with power tools."
"Prevention is better than a cure," she said. "And if what I can do is not enough, I know my limits and call an expert."
Only five years ago, caught in a squeeze, Ms. Charles was way beyond her limits -- "a couple of tens of thousands" in debt after using her credit cards to pay mortgage bills.
AFTER renting the top floor of a two-family house in Jamaica, Queens -- "My baby wants to run, the people downstairs complain and I cannot hold her," she said -- Ms. Charles paid $115,000 for the house on Staten Island, with 20 percent down and a 30-year, fixed-rate mortgage at 6.25 percent.
"I had my parents living with me then," the native of Haiti said. "They were both stroke patients, incapacitated. So, between my parents' pensions and my salary, I managed the household."
By 1995, however, both parents had to go into nursing homes. And then Ms. Charles lost her bookkeeping job. "I became sole proprietor with the same expenses and no income," she said.
And even after she was hired by S.I. Bank and Trust (S.I. for Staten Island), the hole deepened. "Between home expenses and day-care costs for the rest of the afternoon, I reached a point where this paycheck was not covering everything," she said. "My last resort was to use somebody else's money -- the card."
Finally, last December, "before the year 2000 kicks in," she said, "I decided to clean up my act."
Ms. Charles contacted the American Credit Alliance, a nonprofit organization that helps people consolidate their debt. "They negotiated with my creditors to have some of the rates lowered," she said, "and now they collect a set amount from me every month, $638, and dispatch the payments to each creditor. So I don't have them calling me."
"It's the better way to control things than paying 18 to 20 percent -- sometimes 24 percent -- on each of the credit cards," she said.
And over the last two years, Ms. Charles has taken courses in how to shop wisely, how to avoid foreclosure, fire prevention, water-damage prevention, insurance coverage and the myriad facets of home maintenance.
"It gives me confidence," she said, "and I'm optimistic that I can fix a situation, that they are temporary setbacks."
Not everyone can fix a situation themselves. And so, along with about 100 groups across the country, volunteers from the Neighborhood Housing Services branch in New Britain, Conn., participate in Christmas in April.
"We take people from a local business or a church and, with volunteer labor and donations, renovate 20 houses a year, all on one Saturday," said Christine Traczyk, the director of New Britain housing services.
A committee reviews applications from elderly and low-income homeowners. "Every house is different," Ms. Traczyk said. Some require painting, others need a new floor, a window or a door. "We've done two roofs, kitchens, bathrooms," she said. "One year we completely constructed a deck on a home for physically challenged people."
"Twenty-five to 30 volunteers descend on this homeowner at 8 in the morning," Ms. Traczyk said. "And about 5 o'clock, we all gather for a big picnic."
Not even counting the social value of keeping people in their homes, the cost effectiveness derived from the panoply of foreclosure-prevention programs was indicated by a study conducted over the last five years by the Family Housing Fund of Minneapolis.
Between 1991 and last December, said Pam Zagaria, its vice president, the fund and three other groups provided foreclosure counseling and, often, financial assistance to 2,265 households. "Of those, 1,073 had their mortgages reinstated," Ms. Zagaria said.
The program's total cost by the end of 1999 was $3.3 million.
"We divided that by the number of mortgages reinstated," Ms. Zagaria said, "and the average program cost for each reinstated mortgage was $3,075."
"Then," she said, "we calculated the total savings -- to the homeowner in terms of equity, the unreimbursed costs to the lender, to the loan insurer, to the loan servicer, to the city if a house becomes vacant and boarded, and the decline in property values -- and it ranged from $27,000 to $75,000."
There is no way to calculate the savings, emotional as well as financial, reaped by Myla Jones after she received support from the Long Island Housing Partnership.
Ms. Jones, 36, a teacher from Copiague in Suffolk County, is raising her four children herself. Her estranged husband, she said, has barely helped with child support or payments on the three-bedroom ranch.
"Four kids," she said, "and I was trying to pay the mortgage, a car loan, food, you name it; credit cards. By '98, I owed five months, and I'm drawing from savings to make the payments."
To avoid foreclosure, Ms. Jones declared bankruptcy and underwent debt reorganization, requiring her to pay $1,000 a month. "Unfortunately, I couldn't keep up those payments," she said, and eventually owed $18,000. To consolidate that debt, Ms. Jones went to a mortgage broker.
AND then she heard about the Long Island Housing Partnership. "I went in and they helped me," she said. "I learned that the loan from the mortgage company was exorbitant -- 13 percent and a whole lot of points." The monthly payments would have been $1,400 for 30 years. "I couldn't afford the other payments, so how was I going to make that?"
One staff member at the partnership, Carol Woods, "started making calls," Ms. Jones said, "renegotiating with Astoria Federal." The original rate of 9 percent was lowered to 8 percent, and the back payments were incorporated, "so I could start new," Ms. Jones said.
The new payments were $1,050 -- $50 more than on the first loan. "But I can handle it," Ms. Jones said, crediting another partnership worker, Diane Patrizio, with providing one-on-one budget counseling.
"She showed how I could stay on track," Ms. Jones said, "cutting it down to bare necessities. Like cable; I don't have cable. We get free videotapes from the library. I hang clothes on the line."
It was a hard lesson, Ms. Jones said, "a horrible feeling not knowing if you're going to lose your home; I lost a lot of sleep. But they kept in touch, constantly calling, reassuring me.
"Now I know what I'm dealing with."
