HEADLINE: IN BRIEF

BYLINE: Compiled by Warren Strugatch; E-mail: libiz@nytimes.com

 BODY:

Newsday Ends One Edition And Begins New Web Site
 Newsday has ended its weekly Executive Edition and shifted editorial coverage to a new Web site and an enlarged Business & Technology section. The online coverage, at newsday.com/ebiz, will provide frequent updates on local and national business news and emphasize technology, real estate and health care, said Raymond A. Jansen, Newsday's publisher. 
 The expanded Business & Technology section on Mondays will include a column on innovation, industry leaders, a technology-oriented column on workplace issues, and additional Manhattan high-tech news.
Newsday sent the Executive Edition to 10,000 "business and opinion leaders," said Howard Schneider, a managing editor. Its last regular edition appeared on Monday. Newsday will continue to publish quarterly economic reports under the Executive Edition name for the same readership, Mr. Schneider said.
"It didn't make sense to continue publishing a weekly in print when we could publish a minute-by-minute account on the Web," Mr. Schneider said. "By shifting content from the Executive Edition to the Web site, we expand our ability to deliver news in a much more timely way."
 
Morton's Restaurants Post a Record Quarter
 Morton's Restaurant Group (NYSE: MRG) of New Hyde Park reported a record third quarter net income of 20 cents a share on third quarter revenues of $56.3 million, a 23 percent increase over the prior year's third-quarter revenues.
By the end of the year, the company will have 57 Morton's of Chicago steakhouses, most of them in the United States. Its first restaurant on Long Island is scheduled to open in Great Neck on Oct. 30.

HEADLINE: The Pacific Rim, a Continent Away;
Asians, the State's Fastest-Growing Minority, Are Changing the Face of New Jersey

BYLINE: By LYNNE WEIL

DATELINE: EDGEWATER

 BODY:
ON the western bank of the Hudson, right on the river's edge, stands a pagoda-roofed restaurant with postcard view of Manhattan and a serene rock garden in the rear. A few feet away, there is a warren of small, interconnected stores that sell everything from origami paper to kimonos to the latest Godzilla comic books.
Among the many imported items at the nearby grocery story are 17 kinds of tofu and the Korean pickled vegetables known as kimchi. The pharmacy offers barley juice and shark cartilage pills. 
 The unusual collection of businesses -- called the Mitsuwa Marketplace -- is part of a nationwide network of enterprises that cater to an East Asian clientele. To the growing Asian population in New Jersey, it is a merchandise mecca, and for those who were not born here, one of the best places to put homesickness to rest.
Whether they are visitors with visas, immigrants or citizens born in the United States, the state's Asian/ Pacific Islander population has increased by 69.5 percent since 1990, the largest comparative growth of any ethnic group, according to federal Census Bureau estimates.
Put another way, in the last decade New Jersey's total population has increased by 5 percent, to 8.14 million people. And while the white, non-Hispanic population has shrunk by about 1 percent, the group with the second highest rate of growth, the state's Hispanic population, has grown 37.4 percent during the same period.
In five years, the Census Bureau says, New Jersey's current population of 475,000 Asians and Pacific Islanders will have grown to 578,000; the projected population in 2025 is 995,000.
"The ethnic composition of New Jersey is changing in meaningful ways," said James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University. "That is likely to have an effect on how people identify themselves as New Jerseyans, and on the issues that the state faces in the future."
Nor is New Jersey simply following a national trend; it is leading one. With 28.5 percent of its population Asian-born, New Jersey had the second-highest proportion of Asian residents in 1997, the most recent year for which statistics were available. Only California, where 33.5 percent of the population was of Asian origin, outpaced New Jersey.
One recent Sunday, Michael Usami, a product manager for Sony Electronics Inc., was browsing in the Kinokuniya Bookstore at the marketplace here.
Mr. Usami, who moved to Ridgewood from his home near Tokyo two years ago, said: "I come here maybe once a month. It feels good to be here. I think about Japan a lot."
Japanese friends and fishing buddies help him feel at home, Mr. Usami said. On the other hand, he added, his wife, Kaori, has become acquainted with people in their neighborhood, which is racially mixed. And their sons, Shin and Len, seem to "know lots of American kids" and prefer to speak English rather than Japanese.
Peter and Rebecca Jen, who came to New Jersey from Taiwan three years ago to attend college, said they were considering making the move a permanent one. On this day, they drove an hour from their home in Denville to scour the Yaohan Food Market for special sales on the everyday things that they took for granted back in Taipei.
After one such excursion, they took turns holding their 15-month-old son, Jonah, and heaving 60 pounds of sticky rice in cloth bags into the back of their car.
"We normally shop at the local grocery store near our home, and buy the usual things that people get," Rebecca Jen said. "But often there are special items here on sale, so it is always worth the trip."
Whether it is Indians in Jersey City, Japanese in Bergen County or Chinese in Piscataway, Asians have been drawn to New Jersey by relatives who preceded them here as well as by the growing number of job opportunities. But unlike earlier migrations -- made up of people with little money or education -- many of today's Asian immigrants already have an education and have come here to capitalize.
In the 1990 Census, which provided the latest reliable statistics, 71 percent of the state's Asian population said they had attended college.
"Asian immigrants tend to be well-educated professionals," Mr. Hughes said. "In New Jersey, Asians are finding employment especially in the burgeoning high-technology industry, in electronics and computer design."
The Asian-born in this country often are referred to as a model minority because of their relative success. But along with the population and its prosperity, tensions have also begun to rise. Incidents of bias -- including violent crime -- have prompted some to question how well accepted Asians in this country really are. Those concerns were heightened after a nuclear scientist at the national laboratory in Los Alamos, Wen Ho Lee, was accused of stealing nuclear secrets for China.
Like all broad demographic brush strokes, being Asian can mean many things. Mr. Hughes noted that in New Jersey, Asians made up about 90 percent of the people whom the Census Bureau categorize as "Asian and Pacific Islander."
Data from the 2000 Census is not yet available. For now, experts say patterns established in the 1980's are the best indicators for the recent rise in the Asian population.
In the 1990 Census, Indians comprised 1 percent of the 7.7 million people then living in New Jersey, the largest Asian community in the state. In addition, the Immigration and Naturalization Service says that more people have been coming to New Jersey as legal and permanent residents from India than from any other country -- 15,003 from 1996 to 1998, the most recent year for which figures are available.
Residents of South Asian origin are spread throughout the state, but there are regions with comparatively larger concentrations of people from India, Pakistan and Bangladesh. Central Middlesex County is one such area, with an estimated 50,000 people of South Asian origin in and around Woodbridge and Edison. Indeed, a several-mile stretch of Oak Tree Road has come to be widely known as Little India because of the concentration of Indian-owned restaurants, services and shops.
Since 1990, Edison has been home to the annual Navratri, or Nine Nights Festival, which participants say is the largest celebration of Indian religion and culture in the country. The manager of the event, Jayesh Mehta, said that on an average Saturday night in mid-October, as many as 10,000 people were drawn to the festival.
Run by the Iselin-based Indo-American Cultural Society, the Navratri festival features music, dance and foods from throughout the subcontinent. "This is our big opportunity once a year to proudly share some of our cultural gifts with other people," said the president of the society, Pradip (Peter) Kothari.
Not everyone has seen it that way since the Raritan Center in Edison became the site of the festival. Complaints about excessive noise and crowds have led to several legal disputes.
Mr. Kothari dismissed the grumbling as "the irritation some people feel toward any community which is different from them." But, he said, "It could be worse. Things have improved dramatically in that regard in recent years."
For instance, on the night after Mr. Kothari opened his travel agency in Iselin in May 1990, vandals smashed the windows. And he said it happened 10 more times in subsequent years.
As bad as that experience was, it paled next to the wave of beatings and destruction of property visited on Indians in Jersey City in 1987 and 1988. The gang found responsible for much of violence called themselves "dotbusters" -- a crude reference to the bindi cosmetic dot with which religious Hindus mark their foreheads.
In a letter to a local newspaper, the dotbusters wrote that they would "go to any extreme to get Indians to move out of Jersey City."
The group's tactics included "Patel attacks" in which they would select victims from the telephone book by name and harass them in their homes. The most infamous crime took place on Sept. 27, 1987, when a 30-year-old Indian man, Navraze Mody, was beaten to death by a gang of youths after he left a Hoboken cafe.
That incident mobilized many in the state's Indian communities to protest what they viewed as police indifference to their safety, and a lack of prosecutorial rigor.
These days, Asian leaders in the state agree that the most recent issue to galvanize opinion in their communities has been the case of Wen Ho Lee, who was accused of spying, lost his job and was jailed for nine months before his release in September. He pleaded guilty to one felony count of mishandling nuclear secrets, while the other 58 charges against him were dropped.
"A large number of Asians in this state work in science and technology," said Marjorie Li, the president of the Asian American Political Association, based in New Brunswick. "Many had great empathy for Dr. Lee. They felt they might have been faced with the same treatment, and it was really shocking."
Now the state's Asian communities are split over how best to get along in New Jersey: Keep a low profile or to become more visibly active and take more interest in public life.
"Many first-generation Asian immigrants read only the newspapers in their own languages, and keep up only with the news from their old country," said John Bang, a staff assistant on immigration issues and Asian outreach for Senator Frank Lautenberg. "The second generation comes in a little more savvy about U.S. current events. They also show a much greater interest in the political process."
Still, Mr. Bang said the Asian-American community was not a very cohesive political force because it was made up of people of different nationalities.
"But they are starting to come together in regional political groups," Mr. Bang said, "so that they will have more political capital."
Mr. Bang, a second-generation American whose parents are Korean-born, added: "We don't have our own Jesse Jacksons or Al Sharptons. It's contrary to the Asian culture to be aggressive and toot your own horn. But that is what the communities will have to do to gain political recognition."
Michelle Kim, a junior who is majoring in political science at Rutgers, might be ready for the job. A second-generation Asian American, she was student body president at her high school and became active in campus politics at Rutgers in her freshman year.
Now Ms. Kim says she is considering a career in public service when she graduates. "I see the need for somebody to be out there as a voice for the Asian community," she said. "Somebody has got to do it, and not many people are willing to do it, so it might as well be me."
In staking claim to that position, Ms. Kim considers herself unusual among second-generation Asian Americans because she has not been placed under intense pressure at home to earn good grades, but has always been encouraged to take part in social activities at school.
Ms. Kim said: "Maybe it's because my mother went to high school in the United States after moving here in 1970 from Taegu, South Korea. She recognized the importance of my being involved with things that other kids at school were doing. A lot of first-generation Asian parents are concerned only about their children's academic achievement and financial stability in the long term."
Upendra Chivukula, the Indian-born mayor of Franklin Township and one of the few people of Asian origin to hold municipal office in the state, is among those who is trying to raise the Asian profile.
A past president of the local Lions' Club and former head of the Democratic Party for Franklin Township, Mr. Chivukula said Asian transplants to New Jersey did themselves no favor by remaining "in close-knit, ethnically distinct societies, unseen by the rest of the world."
"The challenge they're going to be facing will be getting accepted in the communities where they live, and being integrated into them," Mr. Chivukula said. "They should not appear clannish. There will also be a certain jealousy factor as more people of Asian origin are succeeding here."
If public opinion polls are any indication, however, most New Jersey residents do not resent the immigrants, and are more tolerant of immigration than the country as a whole.
"Keys to Successful Immigration: Implications of the New Jersey Experience," published in 1997, explored various dimensions of immigrant life in the state, including public attitudes toward the foreign-born.
Thomas Espenshade, chairman of Princeton University's sociology department and a faculty associate at the school's Office of Population Research, edited the study.
In a Gallup poll commissioned by the university, slightly more than half of New Jersey adults surveyed welcomed the new immigrants, while 40 percent thought the number ought to be decreased. Those who wanted to see immigration reduced expressed anxiety over the availability of jobs and possible overcrowding, but no specific animosity toward immigrants themselves.
The study contrasted this result with a 1993 CBS News/New York Times poll that found more than 60 percent of respondents nationwide wanted immigration to decrease.
"One of the things that has actually helped in New Jersey's case is that the foreign-born population is better educated than the foreign-born population nationwide," Mr. Espenshade said. "Those who are better educated tend to pass along the values of education and achievement to their children, and that's probably been good for the state."
Asked whether New Jerseyans' attitudes toward immigrants and native-born Asians might change as the Asian population here continued to rise, Mr. Espenshade said: "That would be difficult to predict. But these attitudes tend to remain stable, as long as the economy is good."
For Asians who are newly arrived in New Jersey from overseas, getting acclimated and finding a job are more immediate challenges than the question of prejudice.
"Maybe after living here many years, people begin thinking about their place in mainstream society, or whether they become the object of bias," said Mai Lieu, director of the migration and refugee office of the humanitarian agency Catholic Family and Community Services in Paterson. "But first they think about are how cold the winter here is compared to their country, or how far they need to ride the bus to work."
Ms. Lieu's agency helps newly arrived refugees and immigrants obtain housing, become enrolled in the Social Security and Medicaid programs, and find employment. Initial job placements for many, she said, tend to be in electronics firms staffed by other Asian immigrants.
Ms. Lieu currently is working to help Trang Khanh Huynh, a Vietnamese refuge, resolve some of these very issues. Ms. Huynh, 29, arrived in the United States from Saigon last February with her two younger brothers. Soon afterward, their father was admitted as a refugee in August 1999.
Ms. Huynh is about to complete a six-month beauty school course that will entitle her to become a licensed manicurist.
With Ms. Lieu as her interpreter, Ms. Huynh said: "The first thing I would like to do is to get a job in a salon, so I do not have to depend on anyone else for support. When I have enough money, I hope to start taking English lessons."
Earlier this year, when Catholic Family and Community Services helped Ms. Huynh fill out her census form, she was living with relatives, had no job prospects and was uncertain what the future would bring. How does she envision her life in 10 years, when the next census is to be done?
"I will speak English well and have more American friends," she said. "And I will own a beauty salon."

HEADLINE: New President Seeks Higher Visibility for Pace

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
DAVID ARMAND CAPUTO, a Fulbright scholar and the past president of Hunter College, was installed on Wednesday as the sixth president of Pace University.
Dr. Caputo succeeds Patricia O. Ewers as president of the 92-year-old university, which has more than 13,000 students at five campuses in New York City and Westchester. 
 "I've not taken over a troubled university, although I do want to increase its visibility and move it into a higher tier of major universities," Dr. Caputo said in an interview before his installation.
A 1965 graduate of Miami University in Oxford, Ohio, Dr. Caputo received a Woodrow Wilson National Fellowship and earned two master's degrees and a Ph.D. in political science from Yale University.
He said he wanted to increase the number of full-time faculty at the university -- of Pace's 1,000 faculty members, 59 percent are part-time -- give more honors and opportunities to top students and broaden community input.
In line with the latter goal, Pace is building a $15 million training institute for judges who want a better understanding of changing issues in today's courtroom, like domestic violence. It will be only the second judiciary school in the nation, the first being the National Judicial College of Reno.
"It's a nice blend between academia and the real world," Dr. Caputo said of the judicial institute.
As a hands-on administrator, Dr. Caputo said he enjoys meeting with students and listening to their concerns.
During a recent overnight visit to one of Pace's dormitories, he observed that students today were concerned with how they would fit into the larger economic community when they graduated.
"They're bottom-line oriented," he said. "They're interested in the world at large, and they're competitive."
Pace, which has traditionally attracted students who are the first-generation offspring of immigrants and often the first in their families to attend college, was founded in 1906 by Homer and Charles Pace, two brothers who borrowed $600 to rent a classroom and office space.
Acknowledging the advances since then as well as the anticipated technological changes ahead, Dr. Caputo predicted that "the decade ahead will be one of great transformation."
"Some schools will become virtual universities, some will stay with the traditional approach," he said. "Those are the extremes. To succeed, we'll need to incorporate a variety of methods."
The changes, however, are not being dictated solely by technology, he said. The traditional student, as colleges have known them in the past, have also changed, and those seeking higher education today "want it on their own terms."
"College students work, they have families," Dr. Caputo said, "and we will have to be responsive to that."
As of this fall, Pace reported an enrollment of 13,331 students representing 78 countries. It has 8,132 students at its Manhattan campus, 3,260 in Pleasantville and 1,939 in White Plains.
In the coming decade, Dr. Caputo said, he would address the need to double the university's $100 million endowment.
With a budget of more than $186 million a year, the college is dependent for its operating expenses on the $15,870 annual tuition, which is significantly higher than the tuition at state-supported schools but less than the annual tuition, for example, at New York University, which is $24,336.
"We're about in the middle for private schools," Dr. Caputo said. By comparison, Iona College in New Rochelle charges $15,500, and Fordham's tuition is $20,200.
But for a school that attracts many students from working-class families, Pace cannot depend solely on large gifts from graduates.
"That they give is more important than how much they give," he said.

LENGTH: 2620 words

HEADLINE: A County Consumed by Supermarket Envy

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO

 BODY:
WITH all the variables confronting home buyers in Westchester -- cost, commute, schools, mortgage rates, taxes, termites -- it's no wonder that the local supermarket rarely enters the equation.
But after moving in, many new residents quickly come down with a social ill that seems particularly acute in Westchester: supermarket envy. 
 Retail analysts and supermarket consultants say that for years Westchester has suffered a severe lack of supermarkets and that, for the most part, the stores that are here come up short in terms of size, service and selection, when compared with their counterparts across the country.
"Westchester has one of the 10 highest incomes in the country but some of the worst supermarkets in the entire United States, regardless of income," said Burt P. Flickinger III, managing director of Reach Marketing in Westport, Conn., a marketing and retailing consulting firm. "The Westchester consumer will go to the boroughs of New York and to Fairfield County rather than to experience the pain of supermarket shopping in Westchester."
In interviews with two dozen shoppers, the majority bemoaned their local market's produce section, groused about long checkout lines and universally complained about high prices.
Adjectives like "horrible," "outdated," "cramped" and "dingy" cropped up again and again. Driving another 10 minutes or even a half hour to reach a favorite supermarket or specialty store was commonplace.
Geoff Thompson, a public relations consultant who lives and works in central Westchester, rattled off a handful of supermarket choices within a 10-minute drive of his home: a C-Town in Ossining, a Food Emporium in Briarcliff Manor, a Shoprite in Croton-on-Hudson and an A.&P. in Millwood. "We kind of dance around between these various stores, not being particularly happy with any of them," he said.
The closest one is the smallish A.&P. in Millwood, a hamlet in the town of New Castle. With flourescent lights radiating from a ceiling that shows signs of water damage, it is his least favorite. "We sort of grit our teeth and get what we have to get," he said. "You won't see rats in the aisles. It doesn't feel like Calcutta. It's just that people have higher expectations."
But things are changing. Westchester is poised for a supermarket renaissance.
In just the last year, the Stop & Shop chain, based in Quincy, Mass., has made an aggressive push into the county. It has two new superstores in New Rochelle and another in North White Plains, a store under construction in the Cross County Shopping Center in Yonkers and approvals for stores in Port Chester and White Plains.
Last year also saw the opening of a few alternatives to traditional supermarkets, from the carnivalesque Stew Leonard's in Yonkers to the hugely popular Turco's. Beloved for its produce and fresh fish, Turco's opened a second store in Yorktown Heights after drawing shoppers for years from all over the county to the original in Hartsdale.
At the same time, the few specialty food stores already here, as well as markets eager to break into the county, could realize an opportunity to expand, given the recent bankruptcy protection filing by Grand Union. It is the third Chapter 11 filing in six years for the struggling chain, based in Wayne, N.J., and the company says it is looking for a buyer.
Supermarket consultants say the chain's nine stores in Westchester, ranging in size from 8,000 square feet to 40,000 square feet in affluent communities like Chappaqua and Larchmont, might end up being auctioned off individually to markets that do not require the kind of space a large supermarket chain demands.
"You've got upscale markets like Gourmet Garage and Fairway and Wild Oats, all looking to come into Westchester County, and you've got all these Grand Unions coming available," said Martin A. Deitch of Aries Deitch & Endelson, a leading commercial real estate company in Hartsdale. "The demise of Grand Union is here. And these Grand Unions are going to turn into some absolutely phenomenal retail and specialty stores."
Howard Glickberg, an owner of Fairway, whose two stores -- in Harlem and on the Upper West Side -- are meccas for cost-conscious foodies, said he was eying the Grand Union in Dobbs Ferry, five minutes from his home in Irvington. "I think Westchester would be wonderful," he said.
There are many reasons, it seems, for the county's stunted food-retailing landcape.
Developers cite restrictive zoning, the lack of available land, hilly terrain and the riddle that residents present by demanding a spacious, modern, supermarket convenient to them while shunning any proposed development close to home. Retail consultants like Mr. Flickinger point to the domination of the Grand Union Company and the Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company, which owns Food Emporium, A.&P. and Waldbaum's, among other chains.
They had a "half nelson on the market for far too long," Mr. Flickinger said of the two companies, "and finally the consumers said, 'We quit, we can't take it, we'll drive as far as it takes.' "
Some say the fault lies, too, with consumers, many of them former Manhattanites who, fresh out of college, wheeled their first shopping carts through some of the tiniest, most overpriced supermarkets anywhere.
"I privately speculate that that's one of the reasons we don't have better supermarkets here, because of the low expectations of people coming out of Manhattan," said P. Gilbert Mercurio, executive vice president of the Westchester County Board of Realtors, who emphasized that he was speaking as a county resident (who happens to live in White Plains but drives outside his city's borders to shop for food).
"When I drive to Florida or New Jersey," he said, "they have splendid supermarkets -- supermarkets that far surpass anything you'll see in Westchester in terms of size and choice. Westchester is just not up to par with the rest of the metropolitan region in my opinion."
That seems to be the view of many county residents, though certainly not all. Priscilla Painton, an assistant managing editor at Time magazine and a resident of the Cedar Knolls section of Yonkers, believes she is strategically situated for first-rate food shopping. And her buying patterns illustrate just how fractured and complex food shopping has become.
"Within eight minutes of my home I have Stew Leonard's and for bulk food, Costco, and a very high-end Food Emporium in Bronxville," Ms. Painton said. "If I have a really fancy dinner party, I will drive to Fairway on 125th Street. There's no problem parking, and it has the best cheese, as far as I can tell, on the East Coast. What I like is the complete diversity in price and kind of food."
But Ms. Painton lives in the more densely populated southern half of the county where there are simply more stores. In the northern half, supermarkets are more spread out, and some communities like Armonk, Chappaqua and Millwood feel especially dissatisfied with lackluster food outlets.
A prime exception is Yorktown Heights, in northwest Westchester, which boasts a new Food Emporium, a remodeled A.&P. superstore and a new Turco's. A&P had tried without success to block Turco's from opening. But all three stores appeal to different consumers and the cluster draws shoppers from beyond the area.
Ms. Painton's colleague, Dan Kadlec, who writes the column "Your Money" for Time, calls food shopping around his Chappaqua home "abyssmal" and longs for the "palaces they have" in the Midwest where he grew up.
He and his wife do not enjoy shopping at the Grand Union in Chappaqua. ("I went in there to get a steak one time," he said, "and I think the thickest steak they had was a quarter inch.") Increasingly, they have given their business to the smaller gourmet shops in the hamlet, although Mr. Kadlec said he resents paying a premium.
"Chappaqua is supposed to be this high-end, trendy little suburb, and yet there are real basic things we don't have," he said. "For all the million-dollar houses in town you still don't have a decent grocery store. It cracks me up when I think about it."
Mr. Kadlec surmises that Grand Union has not spruced itself up because people are willing to drive only so far to shop. "Basically, you want to get it over with," he said. "It's not how you want to spend Saturday." Experts on the supermarket industry add that another reason mediocre supermarkets can stay open is that many have cheap long-term leases, allowing them to be profitable even without doing a brisk business.
But some Westchester residents say they do travel considerable distances to shop for food, regularly bypassing a supermarket around the corner with wilted red-leaf lettuce and sullen cashiers.
Cecile Rothschild, a graphic designer in Armonk, is such a shopper. "The supermarkets in Westchester are horrible," she said as she escorted her 5-year-old daughter, Lea, into the local Food Emporium, where, she said, she reluctantly goes a few times a week. Once a month she drives an extra 10 minutes to do extensive shopping at the new Stop & Shop in North White Plains, and she also visits Zabar's in Manhattan monthly for cheese and coffee. Every week or so, she drives 18 to 20 minutes to Greenwich to a Fresh Fields Whole Foods Market, a store prized for its organic produce.
It's the same for Patty Clark, a program manager in the aviation department at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. When she moved to Sleepy Hollow from Manhattan, she asked her neighbors where they shop for food. They suggested a supermarket 15 minutes north in Ossining, since there was no supermarket in Sleepy Hollow. "I remember thinking, 'You have to go all the way to Ossining to get food?' and then I realized, 'Wow, we do have to go all the way to Ossining to get food,' " Ms. Clark said.
But she soon discovered an independently owned store called Scotts Corner Market in Pound Ridge, near the home of a friend but 35 minutes from her own. She was so taken by the fruits and vegetables, whose colors, she said, are "out of a Matisse," that she drives across the county to shop there.
In most parts of the United States, experts on the supermarket industry say, such treks are unheard of. In California or in the Washington area, the average shopper drives no more than three to five minutes to get to a favorite store, but in Westchester shoppers typically drive anywhere from 5 to 25 minutes, Mr. Flickinger said.
Those contrasts have recently made supermarket developers more enthusiastic about building here, despite the obstacles.
"The market got so tight and the demand got so great that the economics started to justify greater investment that really allowed the real estate to work," said Kenneth D. Narva, a managing partner of Street-Works in White Plains, a development and consulting concern specializing in mixed-use retail projects.
Anthony Colavolpe, vice president of real estate for Stop & Shop, recalled the difficult logistics of assembling land for the new store in White Plains. Working with another developer, the supermarket chain is relocating the city's department of public works and will then raze a bowling alley and bank. "All of this to build a supermarket," he said.
Turco's seems ideally positioned to take advantage of the harried Westchester shopper, with its copious takeout selection. The store smokes its own fish, makes 100 types of pastas and 30 different salads and employs a French baker, previously with Eli's Bread in Manhattan. "It's just service and quality and reasonable prices," said Preston Turco, the president, who got his start with produce stores in the Bronx. "You give the people what they want, not what they don't want."
A.&P., of course, has seen the proliferation of alternative grocery outlets, but insists that its two-year-old campaign of self-improvement, called "Project Great Renewal," was not a response to competition but an effort to "proactively improve" both the stores and service, said Richard De Santa, A.&P.'s vice president for corporate affairs. The chain, based in Montvale, N.J., is closing underperforming stores and revamping existing Food Emporiums and A.&P.'s as well as building new ones.
The company, with 415 supermarkets in the East, wants to convert the entire store network over the next few years to one that is dominated by superstores, ranging in size from 45,000 square feet to 65,000 square feet. Indeed, the whole thrust in the industry has been toward larger and larger stores, with bakeries, pharmacies and coffee bars.
A.&P.'s chief executive officer, Christian Haub, began the campaign when he took over the company two years ago. "He said we know we're not getting the job done in terms of customer service, and the other thing that hampers us is having too many smaller, older stores," Mr. De Santa said.
Mr. De Santa said the chain still has a number of small, uninspired supermarkets that have not yet been scrutinized by the company. As leases expire on those stores, he said, the company could well decide to close them.
But such closings can create new problems for a community, as is the case in Briarcliff Manor, where an A.&P. was shuttered more than two years ago and now sits empty in a commercial district.
"Prior to the closing, the Briarcliff Manor A.&P. was overwhelmingly the most hated supermarket in the area," Keith Austin, the village's mayor, said. "I can understand the business proposition of closing marginal stores, but it's hurting us. You have a big empty storefront and the remaining stores are getting killed."
The village's insistence that whatever replaces the A.&P. be modest in scale illustrates the kind of Catch-22 facing both shoppers and the industry. Shoppers seem eager for giant stores able to offer competitive prices and a staggering selection, but they do not want them in their neighborhoods.
"Nowadays everyone wants a 65,000-square-foot big box, but we're not interested in that," Mr. Austin said. "We're trying to preserve a rather small village feel."
The ideal combination, many shoppers say, would be a specialty store down the street and a superstore maybe 10 minutes away, causing traffic snarls in someone else's neighborhood. Indeed, in Armonk two years ago, residents came out to fight proposals for two supermarkets, and Mr. Thompson, the public relations consultant who had represented one of the two developers, remembers hearing people chant "Hay Day, Hay Day."
It was a reference to a small chain of sumptuous food markets, with prices to match, owned by Sutton Place Gourmet in Bethesda, Md., which merged with Balducci's in Manhattan last year. There is a Hay Day in Scarsdale and three in Fairfield County.
In the end, the two supermarket proposals for Armonk, a hamlet in the town of North Castle, were withdrawn. Now, one of the developers, McCann Real Equities Development, has returned with a proposal for a new Food Emporium that does not require a variance, only site-plan approval. It would replace the existing Food Emporium, the one residents seem to love to hate, on a site a mile away. Although it would be small for a new supermarket, at 31,000 square feet, the store would be almost twice the size of the one there now.
Still, there is opposition, especially from residents in a new development of $700,000 houses adjacent to the charming cider mill that would be torn down to accommodate the new supermarket.
"It's one of those great Westchester dilemmas," Mr. Thompson said. "On the one hand you have people clamoring for a better supermarket, but on the other hand they don't want to have anything built. And you know what ends up happening? Nothing."

HEADLINE: IN PERSON;
A Former Sports Star Finds Politics A Rougher Field

BYLINE: By STEVE STRUNSKY

DATELINE: UNION CITY

 BODY:
THE rain is falling on Roosevelt Stadium, and Rudy Garcia is not happy.
Mr. Garcia, who represents the 57,000 residents crammed into this 1.4-square-mile city as their mayor and state assemblyman, is in the stands on a recent gray afternoon, hoping the skies will clear so that the Union Hill High School football team will take the field. 
 The 36-year-old mayor, a former team captain and all-state running back and linebacker during his glory days at Union Hill, also simply wants to see some action out on the turf. For a time, perhaps, it will take his mind off the pressures of running a poor, landlocked city, reviewing state legislation, starting a family, facing down a recall election campaign and having state investigators subpoena documents from the local Democratic organization about his campaign finances.
But the rain does not let up, and the gloomy atmosphere in the deserted stand lingers. Then someone tosses the mayor a football. Instantly, his body language changes. He becomes animated. The paunchy, prematurely graying politician, impeccably dressed in a dark blue suit, smiles the smile that is undefeated in nine primary and general elections.
"This is where I grew up," Mr. Garcia said, with the faintest hint of an accent from his native Cuba, which he left when he was 4.
Traffic whooshes by on Kennedy Boulevard outside the stadium's main entrance. "I lived two blocks away, on 27th Street and Central," he said. "Played Little League baseball, Bugs and Bees, Pop Warner football. At night time we used to come back and there used to be a men's softball league and me and my brothers would be the scorekeepers. We'd get two bucks a game."
Mr. Garcia has come a long way since then. Likewise, his revenue-generating schemes involving the stadium have become much more ambitious. After leaving Cuba with his mother and two brothers, the young Raul Garcia, known as Rudy, eventually led Union Hill to three state championships. He went on to play for Columbia University's perennially powerless Lions while majoring in economics. Next came law school at New York University, after which he became an associate at Lord Day & Lord, Barrett Smith in Manhattan.
By age 28 he was tapped for a State Assembly seat from the 33rd Legislative District by his political mentor, Bruce Walter, a Hudson County power broker who had served as county Democratic chairman and mayor of Union City. When Mr. Walter died in January 1998, Mr. Garcia was chosen to fill his mentor's seat on the Union City Board of Commissioners, whose four other members also elected him mayor. In municipal elections the following May, he led a slate in winning full four-year terms.
"I was, I guess, probably the fastest-rising star, not only in Hudson County politics, but probably in state politics," Mr. Garcia said.
But in a turnaround notable even by the standards of Hudson County's perilous politics, a majority of those same commission members stripped Mr. Garcia of his positions as commissioner of public safety and of recreation -- and most of his real authority -- at the city's reorganization meeting in July, leaving him with little more than his mayor's title. And now even that is in jeopardy, with a drive under way to gather the 6,700 signatures necessary for a recall election. The move is being led by another Union City politician who over two years went from an opponent of Mr. Garcia to an ally and to an opponent again.
That politician, Brian Stack, who represents Union City as a county freeholder, insists that Mr. Garcia has ignored the city's financial realities, granting raises to municipal employees and a tax cut to residents in his first year that have contributed to $12 million budget deficit. Mr. Stack has proposed himself as a candidate for mayor in a separate election that would be on the same ballot as the recall vote. It is a somewhat confusing two-tiered process that in 1995 resulted in a successful recall of Mayor Anthony DeFino of West New York -- and his re-election on the same ballot.
"You know what the problem is with Rudy?" said Mr. Stack, who gives the impression of a scrappy street fighter compared with Mr. Garcia's persona as a smooth operator. "Everything was handed to him."
You might say that Mr. Garcia's political career began at Roosevelt Stadium, and there is a chance that it could end there. Mr. Garcia's initial name recognition grew out of his playing days, and it was while he was still in high school -- after being chosen senior class president and captain of the football and baseball teams -- that he met his political patrons, Mr. Walter and Robert Menendez, who is now the fourth-ranking House Democrat.
At that time, the two longtime allies had recently founded the Alliance Civic Organization with the purpose of breaking from another of Union City's colorful mayors, William Musto -- who was convicted of racketeering charges while in office in 1982. Eventually, the organization would provide Mr. Garcia with his base of support. Two decades later -- in the spring of this year -- Mr. Garcia proposed selling Roosevelt Stadium, a city-owned complex, to the Union City Board of Education for $3.5 million as the main component of his plan to fill the city's current budget gap, which he put at $5 million, well below his opponents' estimate -- the sort of revenue-raising arrangement that is not uncommon in municipal finance.
Mr. Garcia said that the money to buy the stadium would have come not from local school taxes but from supplemental aid the school system receives as one of the state's 30 special needs districts.
The plan appeared to have the support of the commissioners -- until officials in the State Department of Community Affairs, which reviews municipal budgets, balked. City Commissioner Rafael Fraguela called it "voodoo economics."
Moreover, Mr. Fraguela said the effort to use education funds to fill a municipal budget gap -- that should not have been allowed to develop in the first place -- was one reason Mr. Garcia should be recalled. For his part, Mr. Garcia blames Mr. Fraguela, Mr. Stack and his other opponents for scuttling the proposed stadium arrangement and thus creating the need to raise taxes.
"These people can't even spell integrity," Mr. Garcia said, betraying what often sounds like a deep disdain for his less-educated opponents. "They can't even think of a transaction that's going to bring $3.5 million from the state without taking any money from the board of ed, stabilizing taxes. They couldn't even think of it."
Mr. Garcia further alienated himself when he dismissed the law firm of Donald Scarinci in July 1998 as the city's outside council in what the mayor said was an effort to save tax money. Mr. Scarinci -- who accused Mr. Garcia of spending more money on legal fees the following year -- said the real reason he was fired was his longtime friendship with Mr. Menendez, whom Mr. Garcia hopes to unseat in Congress.
Mr. Garcia makes no secret of his hopes to run for Congress. But he said that would only happen once Mr. Menendez chose to leave office. "I've known Bob since I was 15 years old, and I have always been very supportive of him, and he was always very supportive of me. And then, unfortunately, the turning point came when I changed the municipal attorney. It used to be Donald Scarinci, his school buddy," Mr. Garcia said. "And that's what changed our relationship, totally."
But Mr. Menendez claimed that what he saw as Mr. Garcia's mismanagement of the city bothered him most. Moreover, he said that despite his support of Mr. Garcia in the May 1998 election, the new mayor immediately began undercutting him politically. "My relationship with him changed the day after he got elected," Mr. Menendez said.
Mr. Menendez had been Union City's mayor and state senator before being elected to Congress in November 1992, and his ascension created the legislative vacancy that Mr. Garcia stepped into when Bernard Kenny, then an assemblyman from the 33rd District, moved into Mr. Menendez's State Senate seat. It was Mr. Garcia's appointment to the Assembly in January 1993 that led to his first political controversy, when opponents charged he had not lived in the 33rd District for the minimum one year before taking office. But Mr. Garcia still had the support of Mr. Menendez, Mr. Walter, and other patrons, and he emerged from the controversy unscathed.
Mr. Menendez, one of the men responsible for Mr. Garcia's rapid rise, now supports the campaign to recall the mayor. Councilman William Gaughan of Jersey City, whose political and family life overlap with Mr. Garcia's, said the mayor was learning the hard way what it is like to try to stand on his own politically.
Mr. Gaughan, whose daughter Eileen is close friends with Mr. Garcia's wife, Nicole, said Bruce Walter's death was a personal and political blow to his protege.
"I think Rudy was really taken aback, because I don't think he was ready to step in at that point," said Mr. Gaughan, whose council ward, the Heights section of Jersey City, is in Mr. Garcia's legislative district.
Another of the mayor's close friends, Mayor Anthony Russo of Hoboken, insisted Mr. Garcia had been made a scapegoat by Mr. Stack and Mr. Menendez, who alternately viewed the budget deficit as a vehicle for political gain. "I think it's unfair that they should target him," said Mr. Russo, who is no ally of Mr. Menendez.
To add to Mr. Garcia's woes, the State Attorney General's office has subpoenaed financial records from the Union City Democratic Organization, of which Mr. Garcia was chairman before Mr. Sack ousted him in June. The office also seized city billing records for a political consultant, Pat Politano, who was hired to promote its Urban Enterprise Zone and whom critics say acted as the mayor's personal spokesman, a charge the mayor denied.
Whatever he is feeling, Mr. Garcia continues to exude confidence. That much was clear from an interview in the nursery of his infant daughter, Adriana.
"I could walk away from this tomorrow and practice law and make a lot more money -- that's the difference between Stack and I in a nutshell," he said of his rival "Stack's got nowhere to go."

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Hedi Katz, Michael Rorro

 BODY:
Hedi Tamara Katz, a daughter of Betsy Katz Oden of Hurley, N.Y., and Sherman Katz of Williston Park, N.Y., was married on Thursday to Michael Louis Rorro, the son of Dr. Gilda Rorro-Baldassari of Mercerville, N.J., and the late Dr. Louis M. Rorro. Mayor Ann McNamara of Tinton Falls, N.J., officiated outside the Twin Lights Historical Site, a 19th-century lighthouse in Highlands, N.J.
The bride, 34, will continue to use her name professionally. She is a senior director in the residential mortgage-backed securities group in New York for Fitch Inc., a bond rating agency. She graduated from Boston University and received an M.B.A. from Yale University. Her mother, who is retired, was an education evaluator for the New York City Board of Education. Her father is a computer consultant in the Garden City, N.Y., office of the Cendant Corporation, which handles franchising for Century 21, Howard Johnson and other companies. 
 The bridegroom, 33, directs promotional films for nonprofit groups and also directs music videos in Atlantic Heights, N.J. In addition, he works as a freelancer for Miramax Films, writing synopses and comments on screenplays. A graduate of Vassar College, he received a master's degree in liberal studies from Dartmouth College and another in cinema studies from New York University. His mother, who is retired, was an assistant superintendent of human resources for the Trenton public schools. His father was a general practitioner in Mercerville. The bridegroom is the stepson of Giovanni Baldassari.

HEADLINE: BRIEFING: ECONOMY;
SEPTEMBER UNEMPLOYMENT

BYLINE: By Anne Ruderman

 BODY:
The state's unemployment rate dropped to 3.8 percent last month, down from 4.0 percent in August, the state Labor Department reported last week. The September unemployment rate marks the seventh consecutive month that New Jersey has held unemployment at or below 4 percent. The jobless rate has also been at or below the national rate since the beginning of the year and is 0.8 percentage points below a year ago. The state added 14,600 jobs in September. Of the new jobs, the Labor Department reported that 6,0000 were in the public sector and 8,000 were in the private sector. Local government also gained 8,100 jobs, offsetting a decrease in the number of people employed at the state and federal level. Anne Ruderman

SECTION: Section 14; Page 4; Column 2; The City Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1163 words

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
Newcomers Savings and Loan

BYLINE: By SASHA ABRAMSKY; Sasha Abramsky is writing a book on prisons, to be published next year by St. Martin's Press.

 BODY:
WHEN Jemma Legall Romain moved to New York from Trinidad in 1984, she flew on a ticket her mother had bought for her through a saving system known as a susu. Years later, when Ms. Romain had to raise money toward the down payment on her three-family house in Bedford-Stuyvesant, she too saved money in a susu. After she bought the house, she made it pay for itself by renting out two floors.
Though a staple of immigrant communities, susus are little known outside of them. The name is thought to have evolved from the West African Yoruba word "esusu," which means roughly "pooling the funds." In New York, such pooled funds are staples of Trinidadian immigrant communities, and, with variants, of many other immigrant groups. 
 Susus are generally made up of groups of family members or friends, each of whom pledges to put a certain amount of money into a central pot each week. That pot, presided over by a treasurer, whose honesty is vouched for by his or her respected standing among the participants, is then given to one member of the group.
Over the course of a susu's life, each member will receive a payout exactly equal to the total he has put in, which could range from a handful of dollar bills to several thousand dollars; members earn no interest on the money they set aside. After a complete cycle, the members either regroup and start over or go their separate ways.
"It's how our parents, and their parents, used to save their money," said Ms. Romain, 39, who is the office manager at the Central Brooklyn Partnership, a community organization.
As hundreds of thousands of immigrants settled in the city during the 1990's, increasing numbers brought with them informal, bankless savings habits. With immigration showing no sign of slowing -- the New York Department of City Planning estimating that 113,000 immigrants a year settled in the city in the last decade, up from 80,000 annually in the 1970's and 1980's -- this trend is likely to accelerate.
As a new, high-tech century dawns, the susu is one of the key mechanisms helping immigrants in this city of immigrants succeed in their new world. Susu-type organizations are, quite simply, the lifeblood for much of New York's immigrant community. Even some children of immigrant families save this way, chipping in a dollar a week of their lunch money.
There is no legal penalty if a member fails to make regular contributions, which can range from a few dollars to several hundred dollars per week, but the power of community sanction is strong. In the rare case that someone fails to pay, ostracism or, occasionally, violence can result. Those lacking the strength of character to save consistently on their own are propelled by a moral obligation toward other group members.
Madeline Lamour, who works with Ms. Romain at the Central Brooklyn Partnership, directs a self-help group for women from Bedford-Stuyvesant called the Sisters Lending Circle. As part of the program, Ms. Lamour enrolls her clients in a susu run out of the partnership's offices.
"It forces you to save," Ms. Lamour said. "The susu gives us a sense of, 'Yes, I can manage my own money.' It's a form of lending to ourselves, to each other. It makes us responsible for each other's dreams."
In countries in which banks were either not trusted or the preserve of the rich, informal savings networks developed as crucial support systems for poor residents.
"Susus," Ms. Romain said proudly, "sent us to school, helped my mother do renovations on her house back in my country. Susus give you an education, put a roof over your head when the bank denies you cash."
Nobody knows exactly how much money flows through these savings and loan units, but, with tens of thousands of people contributing upward of $100 at a time, a conservative estimate would put the total at millions of dollars a week. And, while this is primarily a New York phenomenon, the national figure might be tens of millions.
The terminology varies. Trinidadians talk about susus, Haitians have mens, Jamaicans save in partners, Guyanans refer to the box, and Dominicans have sams or sociadades. Korean, Portuguese and Jewish immigrants also use community-based savings systems. In some communities, virtually every first-generation immigrant participates, using the money to pay off loans, make down payments on houses or cars, and start small businesses. For many who are low on the economic ladder, susus are the first rung toward the American dream.
NEW YORK being New York, even the city's banks and mortgage lending institutions are taking them seriously, using susu membership as a criteria to help establish a person's credit-worthiness.
"We have accepted this form of nontraditional savings for the last four or five years," said Jackie O'Garrow, senior deputy director at the New York office of the Fannie Mae Foundation, which helps banks channel mortgage loans into underserved areas. "We call it a 'specific variant.' We were hearing from our members that with the growth of the immigrant community this is a very frequent practice."
Many banks have developed formal systems so participation in a susu can help someone seeking a loan.
"We'd ask for a notarized letter from the treasurer stating how long the individual has participated in the susu and how many people are involved," said John Hill, a spokesman for Dime Savings Bank. Dime is among several New York banks that consider membership in a susu when determining the financial viability of an applicant for a mortgage.
Even when banks aren't involved, immigrant savings groups propel many from being poorly paid casual laborers into self-employment.
In October, a Dominican immigrant named Victor Auzon realized a dream he had nurtured since arriving in Washington Heights 12 years earlier: he bought his own Lincoln Town Car. After working for years in low-level jobs in a factory, a sweatshop and a bodega, he went into the livery cab business, but he found himself paying $1,200 a month to rent his taxicab from a dispatch service. Now, thanks in part to money from a susu, he owns his car.
Mr. Auzon, 44, is one of 18 friends, the self-styled "corre caminos," or street runners, all of whom drive taxis in Washington Heights and have spent the last few years aggressively saving to buy their own cars. Every week, each man contributes $250 of the $900 he earns into the sociedad.
This money, combined with low-interest loans provided to immigrant business owners by an organization called Accion New York, lets the cabbies assemble the sizable down payments, more than $10,000, needed to buy their vehicles, which can cost more than $30,000. Today, most of the men are now driving their own cars.
"The sociedad," said Jose-Luis Bido, the group's treasurer, "makes us responsible. It forces us to save because we're committing ourselves to other people. Every Dominican uses sociedades. My mother, my father, my brother, my sister. Everyone I know."

HEADLINE: MIDSTREAM;
Keeping Up With the Croesuses

BYLINE: By JAMES SCHEMBARI; James Schembari is an editor at The Times. His column on the prime earning, spending and striving years appears the fourth Sunday of each month. E-mail may be sent to jimschem@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
I FIRST became concerned two years ago, when my daughter, who was 11 at the time, came home from a house party where the children had a choice of swimming in the pool or at the family's private beach.
Today, my children's best friends sometimes aren't around because they're in Europe or skiing in Vail. My own children have been to Paris twice in the last three years. Everyone's cars are new and nobody does without. When my sons asked for the scooters that are so popular now, I said no, they were too expensive. So a boy who had three offered to give them one. 
 In a nation where many people are enjoying increasing affluence, there is some concern that our children are growing up with a skewed sense of the world -- that while they indeed see Oz, they will insist that it's real even after they wake up. In this surreal economic expansion, how do we show our children that life won't always be this easy, and how do we prepare them for economic reality if they don't believe us?
"They can end up having no sense of the value of money," said Marcee Yager, a financial planner and managing partner of Sterling Wood Financial in San Mateo, Calif. "One thing about human nature in regard to money, the more effort it takes to obtain something, the more value it has to you. With kids who are surrounded by a lot of wealth, they get stuck in a psychological prison because how do they then get anything that is valuable?"
Affluence is a problem that we all should have, but this may be a case of too much of a good thing. It's great that we can provide for our families and that money has given us more freedom to fully enjoy our lives, but are our lifestyles giving our children a goal or an excuse?
Jeffrey H. Bergstrand, associate professor of finance and business economics at the University of Notre Dame, said that children were just reacting rationally to our wealth. That is especially true for teenagers, who may eschew the important experience of a summer job.
"This is a classic backward-bending labor supply curve," Mr. Bergstrand said. "The more you get paid, the more you want to work to grab that income. But as income gets so high, you want to enjoy it. In terms of children with more affluence, there is less of a need to work and make money."
Neale S. Godfrey, the author of financial books for children, including, with Carolina Edwards, "Money Doesn't Grow on Trees: A Parent's Guide to Raising Financially Responsible Children" (Fireside, 1994), said parents were often careless about how they handled money around children.
"They just see us spending," she said. "We're in a store and we want something, so we use our credit card. There is no accountability, because they don't see the bill being paid. The bill just disappears."
SHE says many children expect to live at better socioeconomic levels than their parents did.
"They think they are entitled to it," she said. "They don't understand what it means to have to work for it. If parents don't start teaching them at home and educators don't teach them in school, they will be ill-equipped to handle the $41 trillion that will be transferred to them over the next 50 years."
Alice C. Walsh, 42, of Carmel, N.Y., who raises money for Broadway, Off Broadway and film productions, became concerned four years ago, when her son, James, was about 5. As is typical of children that age, he wanted every toy he saw. "He was writing letters to Santa in April," she said.
So she started giving James an allowance and made him give part of it to charity and save a portion for college. He also was made to save for his toys.
"I'll tell you, when he saw that he could have any of those toys he wanted if he bought them himself, it was a really, really great moment," she said. "He now knows to not just ask us."
Ms. Godfrey suggested something even more radical.
To show children exactly where the money goes, parents should cash their paychecks and place the stack of money in front of their children. They should then put the cash into different stacks, one for each of the household's bills -- utilities, insurance, groceries and so on. There should also be stacks for savings and charitable donations.
"You have to involve them," she said. "You say, 'Here's the bill; here's the money.' "
It sounds unwieldy, but it's worthwhile.
My wife recently asked me why I always tell the children how much things cost. So they will know, I said. I explained that our son, Antonio, 10, recently told me about a toy he wanted, but when he saw the price tag, he dismissed it. "It was way too expensive," he said, a thought that wouldn't have crossed his mind a year ago.
And a thought that will, I hope, haunt him for the rest of his life.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
Debt Debate Ignores The Country's Other Options

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
PAYING off the national debt has been elevated to an obsession. Politics does that. Vice President Al Gore, in the presidential debate last Tuesday, solemnly promised millions of Americans that he would "eliminate the debt in the next decade." So would Gov. George W. Bush. And in their unanimity, they deprive the country of a necessary debate on a crucial question: Is zero national debt healthy for the economy?
There is a strong case to be made that it is not. But rather than conduct a healthy and heated discussion of alternative uses for the growing budget surplus, the candidates close off discussion. In their hands, paying off the $3.5 trillion in public debt becomes almost a moral imperative, beyond politics. But economics often involves political choices. 
 The real issue is this: How can we invest the growing budget surplus for maximum return? Put that way, paying off the debt, or some of it, is one option. So is investing in Head Start, or child care or education or the military or an air transportation system that doesn't waste millions of hours in delays.
"Some debt reduction is a good idea," said Robert M. Solow, the Nobel laureate in economic science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "But the next question is, how much? Here's the next dollar of surplus; what do I want to do with that to earn the best return?"
Think of a homeowner with $50,000 in savings, or surplus, and a $50,000 mortgage that costs $400 a month. Why pay off the mortgage, if he can invest his savings in a security that earns $450 a month? That's enough to cover the mortgage payment and $50 a month in job training to improve his earning power and, in time, his savings or surplus.
Mr. Gore and Mr. Bush, in fact, stump for such alternatives. They would devote big chunks of the projected $4.6 trillion in surpluses over 10 years to spending programs and tax cuts. But in their reverence for paying off the debt, they never ask whether it makes sense, given the high potential return from alternatives.
Prominent on the list are expanding Head Start for preschool children and sending more young people to college on subsidized scholarships. Millions of working parents cannot afford good child care, so federal subsidies here would also pay off handsomely, raising well-being and efficiency in the workplace. There are so many high-yield opportunities, in fact, that maybe consideration should be given to increasing the debt a bit, rather than paying it down.
That politically sensitive option should be on the table in this campaign. After all, the national debt has fallen from more than 50 percent of the gross domestic product in the early 1990's to about 35 percent today, which is like saying that our homeowner's $400-a-month mortgage claims a smaller percentage of his income as he gradually pays it off and his salary rises. He can now borrow more, perhaps to buy an apartment and rent it out at a profit. Debt in America, properly invested, is a tool of enterprise.
ECONOMISTS, of course, know all this, and talk about the options among themselves. Sometimes they review for the public the pros and cons of paying off the national debt, as Mr. Solow did this month in The New York Review of Books.
Like many economists, both liberals and conservatives, he argued that zero national debt is unhealthy. The debt takes the form of risk-free Treasury securities that have an important place in the world. Many investors seek them out in hard or uncertain times, and the Federal Reserve makes use of them to help regulate credit.
Interest rates are the main reason offered for paying down the national debt. In theory, rates will fall as savings are shifted from the public to the private sector, encouraging companies to borrow and invest in more productive modern facilities. That can happen when times are good and confidence is high, as they are now. But in harder, more pessimistic times, investment falls even when rates are low. Given the uncertainties, investing the surplus in education, child care or air transportation may very well produce a higher return than retiring Treasury securities.
Still, there is a case to be made for paying down some debt in good times, to leave more room to borrow when the baby boom generation retires and pension payments soar. Mr. Solow and the economist Paul Samuelson, also an M.I.T. Nobel laureate, even suggest cautiously investing a small portion of the surplus in stocks to help pay those future Social Security benefits.
The options abound and the debate could be exciting, if only the candidates would stop proclaiming their determination to pay off the national debt, and let the debate happen.

SECTION: Section 9; Page 2; Column 3; Style Desk

HEADLINE: COUNTERINTELLIGENCE;
A Legacy of Hints for Stain-Free Living

BYLINE: By Alex Witchel

 BODY:
THE instructions for refrigerator soup should have been the tip-off:
"Just open your refrigerator door, pull out leftovers, any vegetables from the bin, dibs and dabs of rice or squash, meat or chicken cut in bite-sized pieces and put it all in a saucepan and add water and some beef or chicken bouillon. Then season with your favorite spices and simmer for a few minutes. Your family won't even recognize those leftovers!" 
 They won't? Kids in New York know the difference between tuna and toro sushi; does anyone think they couldn't identify last night's meatloaf floating in the soup?
Perhaps only Heloise, that American icon of household wisdom, could get away with directions like these. But "In the Kitchen With Heloise" (Perigee Books) is her ninth book; the first eight sold 5.5 million copies (which goes to show that New York City has never been and never will be an American city). Heloise also writes the syndicated Hints From Heloise column that started in 1959 and is published daily in 500 newspapers in 20 countries.
But be advised: since the original Heloise died in 1977, the Heloise in charge has been her daughter, Ponce Heloise Cruse, 49, who lives in San Antonio with her husband, David Evans, a plumbing contractor. She has grown the franchise past the era of the housewife to encompass the house husband, the working mother and the latchkey child, all of whom write the 2,000 to 3,000 letters, faxes and e-mails to Heloise each week. Heloise Inc. employs 11 people, and its brisk, no-nonsense leader shuns "Ms. Cruse" in favor of just plain Heloise. In fact, that's all her American Express card says. Her license plate says HINTS.
Last week, Heloise came to New York, where we met in the test kitchen of the Good Housekeeping Institute; she writes a monthly column for its magazine. She planned on making a few recipes and on talking about the hints that remain the backbone of her books and columns.
As she barreled into the room with publicists and employees in tow, I must say, I had a heart-sinking moment. I grew up reading Heloise, I still read Heloise in Good Housekeeping (though I live in New York, I like to pretend I live in America) and somehow that resourceful soul who seems to cherish 101 ways to use vinegar more than life itself did not jibe with the hard-boiled Texas babe dressed in red, snapping commands to the troops. This Heloise wore four strands of pearls and a Spiderman watch. Huh? "When I'm giving speeches I can check it and it doesn't look like I am," she said crisply. She seemed to be coated in some sort of nonstick spray -- for humans.
The idea of even broaching the latest in hip New York housekeeping trends seemed absurd. This is not a woman to revere the $999 Miele vacuum cleaners that are rich people's most recent gimme. For all of Heloise's bluster, she is the real thing; the child of Depression-era parents, she wastes nothing, even lamenting the lack of a dish towel in her corner of the test kitchen; using so much paper seems wasteful to her.
While New Yorkers pay lip service to the romance of retro, paying $7 for an order of mashed potatoes in a restaurant, or $95 for a dustpan from Williams-Sonoma, Heloise -- for better or worse -- is retro incarnate. One of her hints for roasting a turkey is to slather it in mayonnaise and cook it under an aluminum foil tent. She swears it comes out moist and golden brown. Then there's her Chocolate Sauerkraut Surprise Cake. Could you imagine the proud Park Avenue owner of an Italian-made squeegee from Restoration Hardware whipping that up -- after Pilates? "The sauerkraut makes it moist, almost like brownies," Heloise insisted. Sure it does. But life has enough surprises, doesn't it?
Still, the instinct to own the fancy vacuum cleaner and the instinct to save money on Windex by combining vinegar and water are actually the same; it's the execution (and the pocketbook) that are different. But that's also why Heloise has thrived. The idea of home as a refuge cuts across all economic lines, and the idea of an uber-mommy who knows everything about stain removal and nothing about you has universal appeal. When I read Heloise, I either think, yes, what a great idea (to increase kitchen counter space, work on a cookie sheet that's been fitted into an open drawer), or I think, no, life is too short (to prevent an electric mixer from spattering, fit a shower cap over the bowl with a hole cut in it for the beaters).
"The point of the books and the columns is that I can't be all things to all people," Heloise said. "There are probably hints in this book I might think are silly, but when I get 50 or 100 letters about it, I have to address it without being condescending."
In the Good Housekeeping kitchen, she examined the ingredients for her recipes and immediately spotted errors. Since her personal staff had already left, she tapped her inner Southern belle instead.
"We're going to punt," she drawled in a suddenly syrupy accent. As she bustled about, trying to find a knife and to tame a persnickety gas burner, her voice rose to a girlish pitch, her fury funneling itself into innocent-sounding questions, flung at the other women in white coats who seemed stunned by this red tornado. When she trilled, "Do you all have a knife?" they came running. "Do you want an apron?" one asked tentatively. "No thanks," she said brusquely, back to business. "I figure I can get the stain out."
Her goal, to prepare four dishes, seemed suddenly preposterous. Even for Heloise, it's hard to cook in someone else's kitchen, so we settled on two: Bootleg Beans a la Heloise, her mom's recipe from the 1950's, which was a can of Campbell's pork and beans doctored with bacon, onion, ketchup and brown sugar; and Salmonettes, from the 1960's, which was a concoction of canned salmon, eggs and baking powder, measured out in iced tea spoons she brought from home, and deep fried.
"I do a chat on women.com on the first Thursday of every month," she said, frying an onion in bacon fat, "and the twenty-somethings from New York all love it. They say their moms worked and didn't have time to teach them, but one admitted, 'If she did, I don't think I listened.' That's really the point."
For Heloise, not listening to her own mother was never an option. Eloise Cruse was the wife of an Air Force lieutenant colonel stationed in Honolulu, when she got the idea to write a household hints column for the local newspaper. A general on base assured her she couldn't; she was, after all, only a housewife.
The housewife went to the Honolulu Advertiser, anyway, and offered the column free on a trial basis (the "H" was added to Eloise only after the column was syndicated, so it would sound better with "hints"); when she offered a pamphlet on laundry and received 100,000 self-addressed envelopes, they knew she had a hit.
"Mother was a piece of work," Heloise said simply. "She would buy theatrical hair spray in sapphire blue or emerald green and spray her hair to match her outfits. On a plane recently, I met a man who was stationed in Virginia when my parents were. L. B. J. was in office then, and he threw a party for Texans in the area at the White House. She had sprayed her hair blue and he said, 'Your mother walked in and everybody's mouth fell open, including the president's.' I said, 'Well, you remember her, don't you?' "
Her parents divorced in 1968; her mother's family had a history of heart disease and she was a heavy smoker. She was 58 when she died. Her tombstone reads "Every Housewife's Friend."
"Her hint to me was: 'You're here for a short time. Make the most of it,' " her daughter said. For her that has meant expanding the column to include hints on home offices, composting and CD storage, keeping up smartly with the times while never forsaking the classic concerns.
But after sampling her recipes, I vote to update Heloise in the kitchen, too. The salmonettes tasted like fishy croutons, and the beans didn't cook long enough for the extra ingredients to do their work.
Still, there are plenty of people who adore Heloise's cooking; after her mother died, some readers mailed her their own collections of Heloise recipes. "They thought I'd like to see them and I should send them back when I was done," she said. "It was touching. They also wrote to say that when their own relatives died, they would find Hints From Heloise tucked into the pages of their Bibles, like messages from the past."
She smiled gently. And for the first time that afternoon, it seemed as if the nonstick spray might finally wear off.
