HEADLINE: BASEBALL: SUBWAY SERIES;
Economic Windfall Is Not Guaranteed

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY JR.

 BODY:
No one doubts that the Subway Series has bathed New York in spiritual riches. It has lifted the morale of baseball fans all over the region and drawn national attention to the Big Apple; it is also a great spectacle, an epic contest between a long-reigning champion and a wild-card challenger.
Local politicians have predicted glowingly that the World Series will also bring material riches to the city. But many economists say the odds that the Series will be an economic boon to New York are as great as the odds that the Chicago Cubs will win a pennant.
Both Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi have said that having the Yankees and the Mets in the Series will inject hundreds of millions of dollars into the local economy and produce millions in taxes to the city.
Hevesi released a report last week estimating that a seven-game Series would add, conservatively, $137.2 million to the city's economy, or between $18 million and $20 million for each game.
The comptroller's economists arrived at this prediction by adding up rough estimates of revenues from sales of tickets, billboards, television and radio ads, and concession stands, then multiplying the sum by 1.5 to account for the second round of spending that is spurred when money is pumped into the local economy.
For his part, Giuliani has boldly predicted that the Series will bring in between $40 million and $50 million in city taxes on everything from hotel rooms and players' salaries to sales of tickets and merchandise.
But independent economists are highly skeptical of both estimates. In fact, some say that a Series pitting a New York team against a team from another city might have been more lucrative, because it would bring in more fans from the rival metropolis.
"There is no basis to think this is going to be a material lift to the New York City economy," said Andrew Zimbalist, a Smith College economist who is an authority on professional sports. "The city would do better if the Mets were playing Seattle. Basically you have fewer people coming in bringing less money."
Hevesi's prediction rests on several questionable assumptions, many economists said. For example, many of the revenues the comptroller has counted as new economic activity would have come into New York's economy anyway, because Major League Baseball is based in Manhattan.
Take the revenues from ticket sales, the largest slice of new revenue in the comptroller's calculations. Hevesi's sports economist, John Tepper Marlin, projects at least $25 million from ticket revenues for each game at Yankee Stadium and $18.4 million for the games at Shea Stadium, counting all of it as new economic activity.
But the World Series is like a traveling show produced by Major League Baseball. Every year the commissioner's office takes a third of the gate receipts for the first four games, no matter where they are played, and a larger percentage of the last three games, if they are played. In the past, about 12.5 percent of ticket revenues went to the participating teams, along with profits from concessions, billboard ads and parking fees, sports economists said.
"The Yankees and the Mets will net about $3 million to $4 million, because they have some expenses," Zimbalist said.
Of the rest of the money from ticket sales, 60 percent from the first four games goes into a pool for all major league players in the playoffs; most of that is divided among players on the winning and losing teams in the World Series. The remainder goes to other major league players.
But there is no assurance that the money paid to players in New York will be spent in New York City or on products made here, economists said. Only a handful of the players on the Yankees and the Mets list their official residence in the state, and even fewer reside permanently in the city.
Similar troubles arise when counting revenues from television advertisements, which the comptroller has estimated at between $2.6 million and $3.5 million for each game.
Baseball officials say the playoff teams do not receive national advertising revenues. The company that does -- Fox Sports, which holds the broadcast rights to the World Series -- is based in Los Angeles. The fees paid to Major League Baseball for the broadcast rights come into the New York economy every year, no matter where the World Series is played.
Dick Netzer, an economist at New York University, said that waves of tourists coming into New York to see the games would provide a true boost to the local economy, but it is unclear how many people have come for the Series.
There are at least 1,400 reporters accredited to cover the games, many of them from other cities. There are also several thousand other people connected with Major League Baseball who get tickets, although baseball officials declined to give a precise number.
About 3,000 tickets are given to other big-league teams for their employees. Another 400 tickets go to baseball writers around the country, while 1,500 tickets go to major league players not in the Series. Corporate sponsors also get large blocks of tickets as well, and some of those tickets may go to people from other cities.
Still, the impact on New York's hotel industry is not very likely to be major, economists said, because October is already the busiest time for tourism in the city. In recent years, more than 90 percent of the city's 66,000 hotel rooms have been occupied in October, city tourism officials said.
Even if one assumes that the nearly 6,000 rooms that are usually empty at this time of year are filled because of the Series, at $300 a night it would mean about $1.8 million in extra revenue, a tiny amount in a regional economy that generates about $1 billion of business a day, economists said. Looked at in that context, even the comptroller's estimate of $20 million a day in new economic activity would be a drop in the bucket.
"This is going to have almost no effect," said Mark S. Rosentraub, an economist at Indiana University who has written extensively on the economics of baseball. "There is going to be a small gain, but you're talking about the nation's largest regional economy."
Giuliani's visions of windfall tax revenues may also be wishful thinking. The city's effective tax rate -- the ratio between its revenues and its gross product -- is about 6 percent most years and never exceeds 8 percent. Even if one accepts the comptroller's questionable estimates of new economic activity, the extra taxes the city could expect would be between $8 million and $11 million, officials at the city's Independent Budget Office said.
Among the flaws in the mayor's optimistic forecast is that income taxes on the ballplayers' additional income are not very likely to net the city much, because the vast majority of Mets and Yankees have legal residences outside New York State. Players who rent in the city pay city income tax based only on the number of days they reside here annually.
One place where there has clearly been an effect is at sporting goods stores, where souvenir clothing, hats, pennants and other knickknacks have been flying off the shelves. Fans have been crowding into Modell's Sporting Goods outlets as if it were the day before Christmas.
Mitch Modell, the chain's president, said sales at his 55 stores last Wednesday, the day after the Yankees won the American League Championship Series, were five times greater than on the comparable day last year.
"There is a fever in New York that is absolutely incredible," Modell said.
That means extra revenues for Modell's and Major League Baseball, which collects a fee on products bearing a team logo. Unfortunately for Giuliani, the city no longer taxes the sale of clothing that costs less than $110.
In the end, economists say, the real boon to New York may not be economic at all, but the less easily definable effect of upbeat news reports and free advertising for the city. The games are being broadcast in 221 markets worldwide and 19 different languages.
"This is simply a great show," said Rosentraub, a lifelong Yankees fan. "Let's just have a good time."

HEADLINE: Portland Journal;
Lingering Harvest, Lingering Doubts

BYLINE: By JOHN W. FOUNTAIN

DATELINE: PORTLAND, N.D.

 BODY:
Bales of hay lie scattered across charcoal-black soil. There is a hint of winter in the wind blowing through rows of golden cornstalks and green grass, an air of peace over this prairie now that the harvest is nearly done.
Yet, the mood here is bittersweet. 
 Over the last five years, nearly 2,000 farmers in North Dakota alone and thousands more across the country have left agriculture. After leaner years and more tumultuous times for farmers here, the Agriculture Department's Farm Service Agency in Fargo says that by all appearances this year's harvest will be better than average.
The production of canola, corn for grain, soybeans and alfalfa hay all reflect gains over last year's harvest. The sugar beet crop is expected to be the third largest on record.
But even with a bountiful harvest, farming is still a tentative prospect for many in the business.
"Right now, it's a precarious situation as people consider their futures," said Scott Stofferahn, the Farm Service Agency's executive director in North Dakota.
"When you talk to farmers out here, they tell you that the majority of their income, darn near all of it, is coming from government payments," Mr. Stofferahn said. "They know without it they can't make their installments on their notes. So this big cloud is hanging over their heads: 'What is the future? Will I be able to survive it?' "
At 66, Albert Hefta is holding on. A farmer for all of his life, he has 2,200 acres on a spread three miles northwest of here. For him, there is something about farming, something that gets in the blood, even when the future is uncertain.
"I like to be out there in the peace and quiet," said Mr. Hefta, a short, hefty man with a tobacco-stained smile and leathery face. "You're your own boss."
His land is anchored by giant bins, a white frame house, a red barn, a fleet of machinery and several head of steer. Mr. Hefta has seen small farmers fall by the wayside. The state lost 16 percent of its farms during the turbulent 80's, and 9 percent more, or 3,000 farms, over the last decade. Mr. Hefta managed to survive, in part, on the revenue from the dairy cows he had for many years. This year, his bins, all 17 of them, are running over.
"We've got a pretty good crop this year," he said, smiling. Still, this year's harvest is not likely to translate into enough profits for his brother, Charles, 59, and him to hire the extra help they could use.
"Can't afford to hire; you'd go broke," Mr. Hefta said.
There are few things still left for the picking here. Corn mostly, burned-brown sunflowers and the last of the sugar beets. But recent rains make work a soggy proposition. Kenard Knudson, who farms about 1,275 acres southwest of Portland, was in the field until about 8 p.m. when the rains came the other night. He still has a few soybeans to harvest.
Mr. Knudson and his wife, Loretta, live on a farm with 60 head of beef cattle. Mr. Knudson, 73, grew up on a farm homesteaded in 1879 by his grandfather, Knut S. Knudson, about four and a half miles west of his own farm. The Knudsons have reared two children on farming. Their son, Kipp, 25, has a degree in economics and financial management, and their daughter, Kari, is a third-year law student at the University of North Dakota. Kipp Knudson is going to run the family farm, a prospect that frightens his mother, given these difficult times for farmers.
"He says he'll make it," Mrs. Knudson said. "I'm scared. He's not." For now, their thoughts are on the harvest.
"It's a time of optimism and hope," Mrs. Knudson, 60, said. "It's what we all look forward to after all the planning in the winter months. It's a cycle."
Mike Workin knows that cycle well. His sons, Daniel, 18, and Scott, 12, used to fall asleep at his feet in his tractor while he tended his wheat and soybeans on 1,100 acres, 700 of which he leased. Farming was nice, said Mr. Workin, 45, a soft-spoken man with a neatly trimmed beard. "It gets in the blood."
But three years ago, he decided to quit.
"I had operating money for the next year," Mr. Workin said. "I just called the bank back and told them I didn't need it. The hardest thing to do was to line up the auction and watch your machinery go down the road." He remembers crying.
He is smiling now, standing on the lot of the Farmers Union Oil gas station in Portland, where he works as an attendant. It's a good job, predictable, with benefits. Mr. Workin and his wife, Judy, a certified nurse assistant, and their four children, including daughters Brittani, 14, and JoAnna, 11, still live on a 250-acre farm about 17 miles southwest of here in Steele County. He leases his land to other farmers. He sold the rest.
"I dreamed I'd hand it down to my son one day," he said of his younger son, his words somewhat slower and choked with emotion. "He would have been the farmer. He just had it in his blood."
Mr. Workin climbs into his red pickup and heads home through the cold and the lingering harvest.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
Ambitious Waterfront Plan for Stamford's South End

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

DATELINE: STAMFORD

 BODY:
THE most ambitious real estate venture undertaken since the redevelopment of this city's downtown 30 years ago, a $200 million mixed-use waterfront complex to be built on 40 acres along the west branch of Stamford Harbor, is being hailed in many quarters of Stamford as a long-sought catalyst for the rebirth of the city's troubled South End peninsula. But the project is so large that some are already questioning certain details.
Called Admiral's Wharf, the 1.2 million square foot proposal includes a 250,000 square foot office building and 516 units of rental apartments and condominiums; a 200-room conference and corporate training center; a ferry service to New York, New Haven and area airports; 50,000 square feet of retail and restaurant space; and parking for 2,300 cars. The project is an expanded version of a similar development called the Strand, proposed 10 years ago by the same developer, Arthur Collins Sr., chairman of Collins Enterprises of Greenwich. 
 Except for two marinas at the southern end, the acreage, which lies across the street from a Pitney Bowes manufacturing complex on Washington Boulevard and Dyke Lane, has been vacant since the 70's, when the owner, United Illuminating, dismantled a coal gasification plant. Left behind was a stew of coal tars, cadmium, arsenic, lead, petroleum and PCB's, according to John DeVillars, executive vice president of Brownfields Stamford, the company that will do the cleanup.
The cost, to be borne by the utility, is estimated by the developer at $10 million to $15 million, and the purchase price of the property to be paid by Mr. Collins and his partners is "slightly under $40 million," he said.
When the real estate market became mired in the recession 10 years ago, financing was not available for Mr. Collins's original project, the Strand -- a $90 million development that was to have contained 85,000 square feet of offices, 200 condominium units, a 20-room waterside hotel, shops and restaurants. Mr. Collins kept his option on the property and two years ago formed a partnership with John H. McClutchy, head of JHM Ventures L.L.C., apartment developers headquartered in Stamford, and with Brownfields Stamford L.L.C., a subsidiary of the Boston-based Brownfields Recovery Corporation. Together, as Strand-BRC Group, they responded to a request by United Illuminating for new proposals and were accepted.
"Real estate market issues were very different in 1990," Mr. Collins said. "Overbuilding had caused some two million square feet of office vacancies. Our market now is very strong, with low office vacancies and a substantial housing shortage."
Mr. McClutchy said: "Arthur and I are putting together the financing and getting the land approvals. We have had discussions with interested bankers and with corporations interested in waterfront locations. The conference center was planned on the advice of Pitney Bowes, who told us there is a desperate need for this type of building." The company has been across from the Admiral's Wharf site since the 20's.
Do H. Chung & Partners of Stamford have been the architects for both the Strand and Admiral's Wharf. Mr. Chung described the new project as Georgian colonial in style with no building exceeding five stories. The commercial buildings and conference center will be built of brick, and the residential structures will be brick and clapboard or shingle. "A tower element, like a lighthouse, might be at the ferry terminal," he said, "and the conference center will be a signature building -- the first one people see coming down Washington Boulevard." The landscaped open space will include a linear park that conforms to the city's plan for a public walk along its entire waterfront.
Stamford's Mayor Dannel P. Malloy, who is committed to opening the South End to a flow of commerce and people, said, "The Collins project addresses the kind of issues in housing and public access to the water that will enable the South End to undergo redevelopment."
The peninsula, extending from Interstate 95 and the Metro-North and Amtrak railroad tracks south to the water, was once a manufacturing engine that drove the city's economy through World War II. Today, it is a patchwork of decaying industrial plants and ethnic residential neighborhoods, where the rate of home ownership has dropped to less than 10 percent.
David Anderson, president of the Stamford Partnership, a 20-year-old economic development agency made up of city officials, business executives and representatives of South End neighborhoods, has been involved in the site since the 80's. "At that time," he said, "we proposed that the industrial zoning be changed on the master plan to Design Waterfront District for mixed use, and we recommended the Collins organization as developers."
IN an agreement between Mr. Collins and the partnership, the developer was to supply a percentage of low-cost housing at the Strand by donating $2 million in cash or construction. He is still committed to the idea, but, he said, "Whether we go to the 70 percent market and 30 percent below-market set by the state or work something out with the city, it's too early to say."
Providing housing that middle income people can afford is a constant priority in the city. "With a median area income of more than $102,000," Mr. Anderson said, both the number of below-market-rate housing units and the income qualifications for them "that the city will accept will require some negotiation." He noted that Stamford's master plan requires developers of such special districts to submit site plans for uses and design for city approval. "That puts the city and the community in the driver's seat for what should and should not happen," he said.
Mr. Anderson criticized the proposed office building for Admiral's Wharf for "taking a bite out of downtown -- in the wrong location for a building that size." He added, "There are downtown sites that could be available for offices," naming an empty parcel behind the Stamford Town Center mall and a property approved for offices that Hines Interests never built.
Concerns that were raised 10 years ago are expected to resurface at public hearings. Many small business and restaurant owners in the central business district who regarded the Strand as a competing second city on the other side of the tracks still do.
And Pitney Bowes has questions about traffic. According to Mary Maarbjerg, executive director of real estate for the company, "any project that affects the infrastructure of the area affects us." She continued, "We have 3,000 employees in several buildings -- 1,800 in the manufacturing plant across from Admiral's Wharf." The number of cars and their comings and goings, she said, "need to be coordinated with our employees' hours and with our incoming and outgoing truck traffic."
The two marinas that will remain on the property will become tenants of Collins Enterprises. The Ponus Yacht Club and Brewer's Yacht Haven Marina currently lease about 14 acres of the tract from United Illuminating. Jack Brewer, owner of Yacht Haven and 16 additional Brewer's marinas between Mamaroneck, N.Y., and South Freeport, Me., said, "We expect to add 50 or 60 slips and install new lifts and floats."
The Strand-BRC Group has applied to the city to bring an eight-acre industrially zoned parcel of the site into conformance with the Design Waterfront District and will embark next month on public hearings, site plan approvals, many months of cleanup and certification by state and federal environmental agencies. Construction is expected to begin in the spring of 2002, and completion could take another four years.
Throughout its 30-year history the Collins organization has focused primarily on developing waterfront properties from Norwalk, Conn., to Norfolk, Va. "Waterfront development is harder to do," Mr. Collins said, "because of the environmental issues, but it's resistant to recessions, moves faster, and the values are higher because there is so much less of it." Between 1978 and 1990 he developed 45 acres of the east branch of Stamford Harbor with 725,000 square feet of offices, 231 condominium units and 570 boat slips in four complexes. Over all, he has developed more than one million square feet of offices and 1,500 residential units.
Richard W. Redniss, whose company, Redniss & Mead, is a land planning consultant for numerous projects in the area, including Collins's, agrees with supporters of the project. "Admiral's Wharf," he said, "marks the beginning of a renaissance in the South End. A hundred and fifty years ago it was an important port, and 75 years ago its industries provided a substantial percentage of the city's jobs. Today, gentrification has a high probability," he said, noting that commuters will be attracted to waterfront housing only one-third of a mile from the railroad station. "We need to work on managing growth with the people who live and work there and the companies that are located there," he said.

HEADLINE: AN EVENING IN STANHOPE;
At the Stanhope House, Echoes of Past and Beat of Present

BYLINE: By JILLIAN HORNBECK AMBROZ

DATELINE: STANHOPE

 BODY:
OLD-TIMERS say there's mojo in these walls," said Maureen Myers, rocking slowly in her chair and smiling at the shrine that surrounds her -- walls painstakingly covered with autographed photos of blues legends. "They feel the spirits here are very friendly, similar to when they started out in Chicago."
As the proprietor of the Stanhope House, she uses the term spirits, literally. "This house is over 200 years old -- a lot of people have died here. Previous owners have died here. And Thelma died in the back room," Ms. Myers says, pointing to what is now a billiards room. "We've got two ghosts here now. I've seen a male ghost here in the entryway, and we've got a female ghost by the console." 
 Dating from 1790 (and four decades before that, if you ask Ms. Myers, who believes that the original deed was issued by the King of England in 1752), the building has sheltered and entertained many souls. It began as a private residence for Lord Stanhope. Over the years it evolved from a stage coach stop to a post office, and some even say a brothel. Babe Ruth gambled here during Prohibition, and Daniel Webster gave a speech from the front porch, says Ms. Myers.
Since the 1970's, it has been a music club, offering its small stage to such blues greats as Muddy Waters, Willie Dixon, Koko Taylor, Buddy Guy and Stevie Ray Vaughn. These days, prominent national acts share the stage with local talent.
"This place has a great sense of history. It's amazing to stand on a stage where Muddy Waters played," said Andy Bernstein, leader singer of the New Brunswick-based VooDudes, a patron since the 70's, and a performer here for the past 10 years. "Over the years there've been different layouts, but it's always been a comfortable place. It's an adventure. For five bucks you don't know what you're going to get."
Red Christmas lights punctuate the darkness where Eva Marie Pucillo swayed to the upbeat, washboard-backed Creole rhythm of the VooDudes on a recent Friday night. "I live right down the street and I've been coming here for 20 years," she said. "There have been so many times when I've had the opportunity to move and I didn't because of this place. I can have two beers and listen to music and ride my bicycle home and feel safe."
One of only two bars in town, the Stanhope House does not serve food, and draws a late crowd. "This is Mayberry," said Ms. Myers. "There's nothing else open in this town." Before 10 p.m., the large, old house with the columned porch on Main Street is as dormant as the rest of the sleepy town. But, in the middle of the night, the old roadhouse erupts with music that shakes the dusty wood floor and ricochets off the pressed tin ceiling.
From Thursday through Sunday, the Stanhope House delivers blues, rock, bluegrass, zydeco, funk and folk music for a cover charge, usually under $10. And the club offers a three-song satisfaction guarantee. Anyone who leaves before hearing a third song can get a refund.
"This is an old roadhouse," said Ms. Myers. "You're supposed to party and have a good time. If you spill your beer on the floor we're not going to run over and clean it up." The mood of the jumping club matches that of the dress code: comfortable and relaxed, but not rowdy.
Beneath the hand-hewn beams of the low ceiling, Mary Myers pulls cold draughts and mixes drinks. "I remember when my parents bought this place seven years ago," she said. "I loved it the moment I saw it. We've made some changes, but not many. You don't want to change a place like the Stanhope House."
Joyce Bickham, a 10-year patron, said: "This place is not pretentious. A lot of people put antiques on the walls, but this place is antique. We like Cajun music, and there are not too many places around here that offer it. And it's a great mix of people. On the dance floor you'll see someone in their 20's jumping around crazily and next to them there'll be an older guy doing a beautiful two-step with his lady friend."
Ms. Bickham's husband, Brett, added: "This is not a townie bar. There's a real eclectic mix of people, from age to socio-economics. You'll see a pickup truck and a Mercedes parked side-by-side. The music quality is always consistently good -- this is the Carnegie Hall for blues and zydeco fans."
Jim Beckerman, keyboard player and co-founder of the VooDudes, appreciates his gigs at this old roadhouse. "It's not corporate -- it's a real juke joint," he said. "There are lots of corporate, fake juke joints that try to look like this. The Stanhope House is the real thing."

HEADLINE: BOOK VALUE;
It Certainly Glitters, but What Is It Worth?

BYLINE: By FRED ANDREWS

 BODY:
PETER L. BERNSTEIN would be a wonderful dinner partner. He has an immense base of knowledge, from which he combs one good story after another. His tales are all rich with interesting characters and charmingly told. Though he has clearly done the scholarly reading, he would never bore you with minutiae. At the end of such an evening, you would understand that his stories all served his theme.
Such it is with Mr. Bernstein's most recent book, "The Power of Gold: The History of an Obsession" (John Wiley & Sons, $27.95). This interesting and pleasurable work tracks the world's passion for gold from ancient Egypt to the present. 
 Mr. Bernstein is a Wall Street consultant with 60 years of experience in finance. He enjoys a reputation for explaining complex financial topics to a broad audience in an engaging way. He has written about the intellectual foundations of the capital markets and about probability theory in managing risk.
This history is about the use and misuse of gold for money or -- in the modern era -- as backing for money, the arrangement known as the gold standard. Nations relied on gold to stabilize the value of paper money by standing ready to buy or sell gold at a set price. For a long time in the United States, that price was $35 an ounce. The gold standard is history now, as ancient as the Vietnam War: in 1971, President Richard M. Nixon "closed the gold window," ending the right of foreign central banks to demand gold for dollars. Gold and the dollar are now worth whatever the financial markets say they are.
Though Mr. Bernstein is discerning and evenhanded in his writing, he shows his colors immediately. He begins with a story told a century ago by John Ruskin: A ship passenger has a big bag of gold coins. Later, when ordered to abandon ship, he straps the gold around his waist, leaps over the side, plunges to the ocean bottom and perishes. So, Ruskin asks, did he have the gold, or did the gold have him?
The pleasure of the book is in its sheer number of unknown places and interesting episodes. Mr. Bernstein introduces us to Offa, king of Mercia, who originated the first widely accepted money in Britain around the year 800. He retained three master moneyers, Eoba, Babba and Udd, to mint silver pennies by the millions, Cornwall being rich in silver. Offa's coin was in circulation for 500 years.
The Chinese invented paper money. Marco Polo marveled at Kublai Khan's currency, "as formal and authoritative as if it were made of pure gold and silver." The Great Khan had ordered every payment, anywhere in his domain, to be made in his currency. "And," Marco Polo observed, "no one dares refuse it, on pain of losing his life." Pretty good backing for a currency. Further, the Khan had ordered that treasure brought into his empire be turned over to him in exchange for paper money.
Real treasure for mere paper -- was that unfair? How different was the Khan's fiat, Mr. Bernstein asks, from President Franklin D. Roosevelt's action in 1933, barring private parties from owning gold and ordering gold turned in for dollars?
There are sugarplums throughout the book. They might be a dazzling piece of prose by John Maynard Keynes, or a description of the logistics of the huge Spanish treasure convoys, or an aside on the relative economic advantages of camel caravans and ships in the gold trade between the Mediterranean and West Africa in the 15th century. Mr. Bernstein explains why, after centuries of coexistence, gold shoved aside silver as the universal standard. (Silver was swamped by a deluge of gold discoveries in the 19th century.)
Mr. Bernstein suggests that a gold standard is a bane in bad times, an irrelevance in good. In hard times, protecting the gold stock requires high interest rates and austerity measures, deepening the downturn. In good times, a strong economy itself supports the currency.
Between the American Civil War and World War I, gold became the near-universal standard, "a symbol of sound practice and a badge of honor and decency," said Joseph Schumpeter, the great economist. The era was known for prosperity and financial stability. But Mr. Bernstein sides with Benjamin Disraeli, who said in 1895, "Our gold standard is not the cause but the consequence of our prosperity."
In a book with much fine narrative, Mr. Bernstein's treatment of gold policy between the world wars is exceptionally lucid. He calls it a horror story with no villains, only disastrous decisions prompted by an eagerness to get back to the comforting, pre-1914 ways. The British set a deadline of 1925 for restoring the gold standard, suspended during World War I. The campaign was led by the governor of the Bank of England, Montagu Norman, an elegant, forbidding man who used his high office to great effect. He more or less browbeat Winston Churchill, then the chancellor of the exchequer, into approving restoration. "I'm lost and reduced to groping," Churchill lamented among the high priests of money.
Churchill grumbled that Norman could be perfectly happy if Britain had a fine credit rating and 1.25 million unemployed. Indeed, the British paid the price in higher interest rates, an economic slowdown, stifled imports and millions more people out of work. An improvement in exports -- the object of the game -- never materialized as trade dried up worldwide. Within six years, Britain dropped the gold standard.
Mr. Bernstein sometimes condenses too much, leaving the reader dizzy. Writing about the great price revolution of the 16th century -- inflation that raged for a hundred years -- Mr. Bernstein notes that some scholars blamed the constant, costly warfare among Europe's kingdoms.
Others, he writes, have focused on population growth that rapidly outpaced food production. (On the other hand, he says, still others have asked how people paid for the food. Mere need doesn't drive up prices.)
The great Adam Smith squarely blamed the huge influx of gold and silver from America, which swelled the money supply without a corresponding increase in things to buy. But Mr. Bernstein says that others exonerated that influx: inflation had taken off before bullion arrived in quantity and continued long after imports subsided.
Rebutting the rebuttal, some objected that the fall in imports was overstated, because the customs figures left out smuggled goods. And finally -- finally! -- some insisted that everyone else had things upside down: the rapid rise in prices had prompted the avid search for gold and silver, not the other way around.
Whew. My kingdom for a one-armed historian.
Otherwise, though, with one illustration after another, "The Power of Gold" amounts to extensive, sophisticated and engrossing variations on the theme of King Midas, who was granted his wish that everything he touched would turn to gold. Midas was shortly in despair when his food, his belongings, even his daughter, were transformed at his touch. Mr. Bernstein believes that throughout history, people have clung to their gold and drowned.
"Gold as an end in itself is meaningless,"' he writes. "Hoarding does not create wealth. Gold and its surrogates make sense only as a means to an end: to beautify, to adorn, to exchange for what we need and really want."
Early in the book, Mr. Bernstein writes about peoples of West Africa who lived great distances from sources of salt. They developed a trade with Europeans, in which they swapped gold for salt, an ounce of gold for an ounce of salt. Mr. Bernstein wonders what the Africans must have thought of the Europeans, who were willing to trade this precious, life-giving commodity -- salt -- for a useless yellow metal.

HEADLINE: COMPRESSED DATA;
Geeks for Gore, but Bosses Choose Bush

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
Two recent polls of the presidential preferences of information technology professionals provide some provocatively conflicting data.
Geeks prefer Al Gore, according to the latest weekly results at www.metricnet.com, an information technology research site created by Howard Rubin, a consultant in Pound Ridge, N.Y. 
 But people more likely to be the geeks' bosses seem to prefer the Bush ticket, according to a survey by CIO magazine. (CIO's name is the abbreviation for chief information officer.)
Metricnet's registered audience consists mostly of information technology managers and high-level programmers, Mr. Rubin said. Among the 14,500 of them voting in the survey in the last week, the Vice President was favored over Gov. George W. Bush by a 50 percent to 38 percent margin. And, in contrast to national polls of the general public which show Mr. Bush inching past Mr. Gore, the margin for Mr. Gore has been widening this month in the Metricnet poll.
But it appears to be a case of same universe, different planet for information technology executives who attended a recent symposium sponsored by CIO magazine. CIO found that 48 percent of the 210 executives at its gathering last week in Phoenix said they intended to vote for the Bush-Cheney ticket compared to just 37 percent for Gore-Lieberman.
The CIO group favors Mr. Bush by a wide margin, but they gave a slight edge -- 41 percent to 38 percent -- to the Gore team as "best suited to lead the new economy," said Karen Fogerty, spokeswoman for CXO Media, the unit of International Data Group that publishes CIO.
Mr. Rubin said that Mr. Gore has led in the Metricnet poll ever since it began in March, although his lead narrowed to a few points in August before widening again. About 217,000 votes have been recorded. However, because each is irrevocable, the trend lines reflect only new votes, and make no provision for people who might have changed their minds.
Education reform has consistently been the top public issue for those in the information technology world, according to Mr. Rubin's polling. The biggest shift in recent weeks on issues directly related to information technology has been a sharp increase in concerns about Internet privacy and security.
 BARNABY J. FEDER

HEADLINE: E-Commerce Report;
PBS and NPR find unexpected success selling on the Web.

BYLINE: By Bob Tedeschi 

 BODY:
LIKE many industries, public broadcasting was not exactly thrilled to add the Web to its to-do list in the mid-90's. At the time, conservative members of Congress were calling for the end to federal subsidies, cable networks like the Learning Channel were threatening to lure away public television viewers, and the competition for private donations stretched the fund-raising abilities of public radio and television stations alike.
Still, because viewers and listeners clamored for Web sites -- if only to learn more about the music they heard or to preview that night's program schedule -- public broadcasters dutifully answered the call, and set out looking for a way to pay for it. E-commerce seemed like a possibility, but it also seemed like a risky experiment for the stations within the Public Broadcasting Service and the National Public Radio network, which had scant retail expertise. 
 Now, though, with the formulas for e-commerce success starting to come more clearly into focus, the experiment looks less risky. Public radio and television stations are starting to build online stores or expand their previously modest online shops. As they do, they are looking not only to generate revenue, but to remain relevant to their audiences in an age when viewers and listeners are awash in media choices.
The public broadcasting entities, like their commercial television counterparts, have a distinct advantage over many types of would-be Internet retailers: recognizable brands. But NPR and PBS and their affiliates also have at least one apparent advantage over commercial broadcasters: an extremely loyal audience that includes millions of people who already pay to support the programming. These people are good prospects for the videos and CD's that are among the main products of public broadcasting's online stores.
PBS would not disclose how much revenue it generates from video sales, but one executive, who spoke on condition of anonymity, put the figure in the tens of millions. And the market for goods related to public radio is apparently ample. Minnesota Public Radio, which produces "A Prairie Home Companion," among other shows, is particularly successful in this regard. Two years ago, it sold Rivertown Trading, which distributed MPR-related goods through catalogs, to Dayton Hudson for $120 million.
Despite the allures, public broadcasters have witnessed enough of the carnage among e-tailers to remain a bit wary -- particularly because direct sales to consumers is still not their main area of expertise. Many have hedged their bets by farming out most of the customer service and order-processing responsibilities to outside companies, which take a percentage of the revenue from each sale.
When PBS opened a shop on the PBS.org Web site three years ago, it was viewed as a way to take orders more efficiently than the 800-number operation that sold PBS videos, said Don Jalbert, who, as vice president of PBS Learning Media, oversees the PBS online store.
But the PBS Web site quickly outgrew the first humble expectations. With the help of the consulting firm KPMG, PBS rolled out a new version of the shop in June, featuring 1,500 videos, books and CD's related to its programs. Both the order-taking and the fulfillment duties are handled by outside companies, Mr. Jalbert said. "We're already profitable," he said, declining to elaborate. "It's tight, but we are profitable."
He also said revenues were growing significantly. "We're 65 percent ahead of where we were last year at this point," Mr. Jalbert said, predicting continued growth as PBS promotes the online store on the air and in its printed video catalogs.
Analysts said PBS's on-air promotion of its Web site had stirred anxiety among some member stations, which also want to drive viewers to the stations' own Web sites and online stores. Steve Behrens, editor of Current magazine, which covers the public broadcasting industry, said the issue came down to whether viewers should identify more with PBS or their local PBS stations. The PBS member stations ultimately benefit from sales to the PBS Web site, because the proceeds can reduce the membership fees that PBS needs to raise from its affiliates. But direct Web sales are a more immediate tonic for the member stations' ledgers.
"It's one of these affiliate-versus-national struggles that goes on all the time," Mr. Behrens said. "Revenue is part of what's driving this. But more important, they want the direct relationship with viewers that PBS is getting."
There are similar rumblings within the National Public Radio family, as NPR prepares to open its first Web store next month. Tom Lix, president of Public Interactive, a for-profit company that builds Web sites for public radio and television stations, said that some of the public radio stations he had created Web sites for were wary of NPR's e-commerce plans, "because they do compete with NPR."
"It's a classic new-media situation, where people are working out the models as they go along," he said. "And I think there probably will be a little tension. But I still think it's do-able, because in the end, people will stay focused on the mission."
NPR executives declined to say how the organization would divide the revenues for its online sales with its affiliates, or how NPR and its stations would handle the on-air promotions for their respective online stores. But Kenneth P. Stern, NPR's executive vice president, said, "We look at this not as how to cut the individual transaction fees, but rather, how can we develop the economics of the NPR system as a whole."
Indeed, some local stations voice few concerns about how the e-commerce revenue comes their way -- as long as it comes. One of these is WHYY, a public radio and television station and production studio in Philadelphia. Robyn Goldman, executive director of WHYY Ventures, the division that sells products related to WHYY's shows, said the company retained the rights to promote its online store on all of the programs it produced. Moreover, she said, "PBS sells some of our videos, and our stuff will also be in NPR's store."
If the goods are sold through another site or company, "we make a lot less money through royalties," Ms. Goldman said, adding, "But still, we've done quite well that way, too."
Tom Fowler, vice president of South Carolina Educational Radio, which operates eight NPR-affiliated stations covering South Carolina and parts of Georgia and North Carolina, said it did not matter which Web store was promoted on the air. "Most listeners don't know NPR from PRI from any of the other acronyms out there," he said, referring to Public Radio Internationl, which produces and distributes radio programs to more than 600 stations.
What is more important, Mr. Fowler said, is that the audience relies on his stations to get the information in the first place. Good information, not Web sales, is what will keep listeners tuning in, Mr. Fowler said.
"With all the things that are coming, with satellite radio and programming on the Internet, people will have choices," Mr. Fowler said. "So however they happen to go online and get something -- whether it's from NPR or our site, it doesn't matter. All that matters is that they hear about it on our air."

HEADLINE: Qualcomm's Shrinking Act Could Pay Off Big;
Company Prospers by Shedding Divisions and Focusing Fiercely on Patents

BYLINE: By SIMON ROMERO 

 BODY:
Irwin Jacobs, the chairman of Qualcomm, had already left China after meeting with Premier Zhu Rongji when word caught up with him at a hotel room in Budapest last week: China's second-largest telecommunications company, China Unicom, had finally confirmed plans to construct a wireless communications network using technology patented by Qualcomm.
The announcement eased the techno-political tensions raised earlier this year after Chinese officials had seemed to assure the United States government that Qualcomm's technology would be adopted by China Unicom -- only to have the Chinese company back out a short time later. 
 More to the business point, though, the news helped drive Qualcomm's stock up 11 percent in one day last week, contributing to a 25 percent rise in the company's stock price since the beginning of last month -- a period when the Nasdaq composite index was declining by 17 percent.
Yet even as the new China deal seemed to vindicate his vision of a world in which nearly every wireless phone might one day use technology patented by Qualcomm, Mr. Jacobs, a former engineering professor, gave a characteristically matter-of-fact reply when asked to comment.
"From a revenue point of view," he wrote in an e-mail message from Budapest, where he was on a business trip, "we would anticipate an interesting impact in 2002 and beyond."
Mr. Jacobs, who turned 67 last week, is seldom showy, despite his bold ambitions for the global wireless market. The rest of the telecommunications industry may be enthralled with bigger-is-better consolidation, but Qualcomm is actually getting smaller, spinning off division after division. If the future belongs to Qualcomm, it will be on the strength of the company's intellectual creativity and a fierce defense of its portfolio of patents -- some 1,000 and growing.
Many of those patents involve a wireless transmission format called Code Division Multiple Access, or CDMA, a "spread spectrum" technology long used by the United States military for secure radio communications.
CDMA competes mainly with two other wireless standards, Time Division Multiple Access, or TDMA, and the global system for mobile communications, or GSM. But last year, in industry standards-setting bodies, it began to look as if many elements of CDMA would be incorporated into the coming generation of wireless networks intended to connect to the Internet and carry massive amounts of voice and data traffic.
Suddenly Qualcomm, with its CDMA patents, was a favorite with investors. The company's share price soared 2,600 percent last year, surpassing all other major issues on the Nasdaq. And although much of those astronomic gains were negated earlier this year as technology stocks went out of fashion and Qualcomm suffered its initial setback in China, the company's shares have resumed their climb in the last three months.
"The pointy-headed professor who took battlefield technology and made it the core of an almost pure intellectual-property company is one of the great telecommunications tales of our time," said Jerry Hausman, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who specializes in telecommunications issues. "If Jacobs succeeds -- and his chances look pretty good -- then his moves will be studied in detail in the years ahead."
Qualcomm owes its existence to an idea Mr. Jacobs had while driving down Interstate 5 in Southern California one day in the mid-1980's, shortly after becoming wealthy by selling his first start-up, Linkabit, a developer of wireless communications technology.
A Massachusetts native, he had left a teaching post at M.I.T. two decades earlier for one at the University of California at San Diego, where he found the region's military industry a fertile field for his interests in business and engineering. So while another person might have been thinking of how to spend his Linkabit wealth that day on the Interstate, Mr. Jacobs was musing about spread spectrum -- a military radio technology with roots reaching back to World War II.
Spread-spectrum radio signals being sent out are scattered over a wide range of frequencies and then collected back onto their original frequency at the receiver. This makes communications hard for an enemy to jam or intercept. For civilian use, the main benefits are signal clarity and the efficient use of increasingly crowded bandwidth, because scattered signals are less likely to interfere with other transmissions -- even ones on the same frequencies.
Seeing the commercial possibilities for spread spectrum, Mr. Jacobs founded Qualcomm in San Diego in 1985. Today, from a corporate campus chiseled into sun-drenched hills on the northern edge of the city, some 6,500 employees are either directly involved in or supporting the research-grounded patent-building process on which the founder has staked the company's future.
In preparing for the patents push, Mr. Jacobs began to streamline Qualcomm in 1998 by bundling its interests in various telecommunications carriers -- including Cricket Communications and a Mexican company, Pegaso -- into a holding company named Leap Wireless International.
The following May, Qualcomm sold its telecommunications equipment business to the big Swedish wireless equipment maker Ericsson. That deal resolved a lengthy patent-infringement dispute, while also effectively taming Ericsson's resistance to the flavor of CDMA technology that Qualcomm is advocating for next-generation wireless networks.
Late last year, Qualcomm announced plans to sell its handset manufacturing business to the Japanese company Kyocera, while securing a five-year commitment from Kyocera to buy most of its CDMA chips and software from Qualcomm.
Next up is Qualcomm's chip manufacturing business. The chip operation, temporarily named Spinco, is being prepared for an initial public offering and the distribution of shares to Qualcomm shareholders.
The selling off of Qualcomm's businesses has been so extensive that one analyst, John Sullivan of Phillips Business Information, questioned whether Mr. Jacobs had taken up the Japanese poetic form of haiku to express his ambitions. In a widely circulated report, Mr. Sullivan imagined the chief executive's musings might look like this:
Many business groups
Mundane thoughts weigh down my soul
Spin off everything
Whatever its literary potential -- or limitations -- Qualcomm's strategy presumes the widespread commercial use of wireless communications. Qualcomm already receives about 4 percent of the wholesale price of each wireless phone that uses CDMA technology, in addition to royalty revenue from the sale of network equipment using its technology.
In its third-quarter results, released in July, the company reported a 40 percent rise in net income, to $218 million, on revenue of $714 million. About half of that amount came from Spinco; the other contributors included OmniTracs, a global positioning system used by the trucking industry, and Eudora, an e-mail software developer.
But royalties contributed $174 million of the revenue total, up 38 percent from a year earlier. For this year as a whole, Qualcomm's royalties should total about $630 million, according to Pete Peterson, a Prudential Securities analyst. And some analysts are projecting annual royalty revenue of $3 billion by 2005.
"The combination of having the best intellectual-property portfolio with the ability to do astute deals is their forte," said Graham Tanaka, who invested in Qualcomm stock about a year and a half ago as president of the Tanaka Growth Fund.
One of the central merits of CDMA technology, according to Mr. Jacobs and some other experts, is that it handles huge amounts of voice and data with great ease. "Whether you're in the heart of Tokyo or an undeveloped corner of Africa, it's clear that CDMA-based systems make the most sense," Mr. Jacobs said in a recent interview at his modest office.
Mr. Jacobs's tendency to go off on intellectual tangents or argue at length about the merits of seemingly obscure statistical minutiae can make him seem better suited for lecturing on engineering topics than running a company that has surpassed Motorola, America's other wireless titan, in market value -- $55.6 billion as of Friday, compared with Motorola's $50.9 billion.
In fact, Mr. Jacobs, whose 3.5 percent stake in Qualcomm is worth almost $2 billion, has demonstrated a fiercely competitive side in negotiations over wireless technology standards.
CDMA systems still lag TDMA and GSM, with only about 15 percent of the global market. But CDMA is growing at a faster rate than its rivals. And the company could yet see its biggest rewards when current networks are replaced with next-generation systems using Qualcomm's technology.
Qualcomm predicts that its patented technology will be used for either CDMA2000 or W-CDMA, the two standards that have emerged as the likeliest to be adopted by carriers building networks over the next five years. But competitors, particularly Texas Instruments, are already preparing either to develop around Qualcomm's patent positions or to favor different technologies.
"We believe there are a lot of patents out there that will apply to the new generations of wireless networks, including many of ours," said Mike McMahan, director of wireless research and development at Texas Instruments, which has supplied many of the chips for mobile handsets using the GSM standard, which is widely used in Europe.
Texas Instruments insists that it is agnostic about standards and willing to work with competing technologies. But it took a step toward confronting Qualcomm's dominance in the CDMA arena in June by acquiring Dot Wireless, a San Diego company with several former high-ranking Qualcomm executives, to try to put itself on equal technological footing with Qualcomm.
The bigger threat to Qualcomm's patents strategy may come from Nokia, the Finnish wireless giant, which is seeking to promote the idea that multiple patent holders, including Nokia, will benefit from coming wireless technologies.
In an all-out effort to show that it is not willing to become a mere assembler of handsets dependent on other companies' technology, Nokia is supporting what it calls an open, global approach to wireless networks, instead of a proprietary one based on Qualcomm's patent portfolio.
"It's unclear what the final applicability of Qualcomm's patents will be," said K. P. Wilska, president of Nokia's United States operations. "Getting patents granted in multiple countries is a long and complicated process."
But Mr. Jacobs contends that specializing in research and patents will give his company the power of concentration.
"By focusing on development, and not manufacturing, we'll keep our technological edge," Mr. Jacobs said. "And we'll be the ones receiving royalties instead of paying them out to our competitors."

HEADLINE: Consolidation Skews Field In Magazine Distribution

BYLINE: By ALEX KUCZYNSKI 

DATELINE: FLORENCE, Ala.

 BODY:
Far from the gleaming steel canyons of Manhattan, where tirelessly urbane editors craft the magazines that entertain and inform the American public, the real heartbeat of the magazine industry beats in a squat office building, in a town on the banks of the Tennessee River, two hours' drive from Memphis.
Manhattan may be the Emerald City of the magazine world, but the industry's Wizard of Oz -- Joel R. Anderson, chairman of the Anderson News Corporation -- keeps his office here on North Court Street, past the Magnolia Church of Christ, the Coon Dog Cemetery, Biscuit Village and the Guns 'n' Such store on the corner. 
 "New York is far, far away," Mr. Anderson said, as he navigated the streets of Florence in his cherry-red Ford pickup. "And I have spent enough time there to know how publishers and magazine folks get a distorted view of the country."
The magazine folks are not too happy with Mr. Anderson, either. In the last five years, Mr. Anderson -- a textbook Southern gentleman, who could have walked off the pages of a Walker Percy novel -- has emerged as one of the key players in the industry as his company, Anderson News, rose to become the nation's largest magazine wholesaler.
Of every 10 magazines on a retail rack in the United States, Anderson delivers 4. If you want your publication at retail stores, you pretty much have to go to Anderson or three other companies, which deliver another 5.
Mr. Anderson is a symbol of a swift consolidation that has left a battlefield littered with defunct wholesalers, both large and small. The consolidation has drawn the attention of the Justice Department's antitrust division and has created mounting, intense consternation among publishers, who say that they are finding it increasingly difficult and expensive to get their publications distributed, and are even attributing magazine closings to wholesalers. Earlier this year, magazine executives cited wholesaler consolidation as part of the reason for the deaths of Details, Mirabella and Life magazines.
The newly concentrated power of the wholesalers is a humbling reminder to publishers that whatever their pretensions, they must fight for shelf space, just like Kleenex, canned hams and Iceberg lettuce in that most brutal arena where 44 percent of all magazines are now sold: supermarkets. There, in fact, magazines that do not sell are given the same shelf life as bananas and milk.
Publishers are trying to adjust to the post-consolidation scenario. They are finding it harder to get their less successful titles onto those retail racks and wholesalers are demanding better deals from them. The Department of Justice investigation has begun to focus in recent months on the large wholesalers, in part to determine if there is any evidence of collusion between the players to keep their costs down, which would violate antitrust laws.
But Mr. Anderson's take on the situation is as different from most of the publishers as the view from his front door is from the view on the 11th floor executive suites of the Conde Nast building in Times Square. And neither side seems to agree on what the solution is.
Mr. Anderson, like other wholesalers, says he is being squeezed by the large retailers to offer more service and better prices. The wholesalers say they are finding that where their gross profit on each copy sold was once around 25 percent, it is now usually less than 20 percent.
And too many magazines are being published for the dwindling retail racks available: there are about 4,700 titles now, as opposed to about 1,300 25 years ago, Mr. Anderson said. He said publishers are printing about 1.2 billion copies a year that go straight to shredders -- without ever seeing the fluorescent light of a retail store. They are known as "premature returns" because the retail outlets, pressed for rack space, will not even let them in the door, wasting the wholesalers resources.
"You could say it is a bit of a mess right now," Mr. Anderson said of the entire distribution system, as he munched on a ham and melted cheese sandwich at The Emerald Coast Cafe in Florence.
John Harrington, the publisher of the New Single Copy, a newsletter about magazine distribution, wrote in a report in July that the industry is "on the verge of collapsing."
"The distribution system is now economically fragile," Mr. Harrington said last week. Mr. Harrington, who once headed the wholesalers' trade group, the Council for Periodical Distributors Association, said of the large wholesalers: "These are the kinds of smart companies that at some point are going to say, 'Do I see a light at the end of the tunnel? Will we make money on this ever?' And if they do not, they will get out. And where will the industry be?"
The major wholesalers all say they are losing money on magazine distribution. But they have the cushion of owning other profitable businesses. (The other major wholesalers are the News Group, which is operated by the Jim Pattison Group of Vancouver, British Columbia, with about 25 percent of the market; the Chas. Levy Circulating Company of Chicago, with about 17 percent; and the Hudson News Company of North Bergen, N.J., with about 10 percent.)
The Anderson Corporation, a privately held company, has been in the periodical distribution business since it was founded in 1917. It also owns Books-A-Million, the third largest bookstore chain in the United States, an entertainment novelty company, and the largest fireworks distribution company in the U.S. (Mr. Anderson has spent so much time in China, where the fireworks are manufactured, that he may be the only resident of Florence who can order "a cold beer, please" in Mandarin.) Anderson is a very closely held family business and keeps its officers in the family, too: Mr. Anderson's nephew, Charlie, is the chief executive of Anderson News Group.
The wholesaler landscape, which scarcely changed from 1917 until the 1990's, underwent a swift transformation in 1995 that mirrored the consolidation among the major retail chains. Safeway announced that it would stop dealing with dozens of small wholesalers to supply its national chain, and preferred to deal with only one. The other big retailers, like Wal-Mart, followed suit, creating, the wholesalers argue, an intensely competitive environment in which companies battled each other to see who could offer the retailers the cheapest deal. Anderson, one of the bigger players, survived. In 1995, when there were about 180 wholesalers, Anderson had 6 percent of the market. Now, with only a handful of players, it has almost 40 percent.
In turn, the wholesalers have gone back to the publishers to help them eat up some of the lost margins. But the publishers fear a squeeze on their own profit. And since the big retailers and the big wholesalers -- the two entities that control the retail flow of the majority of magazines to consumers -- focus on the blockbuster titles, like People, In Style or Good Housekeeping -- many smaller publishers have found themselves squeezed out of some popular spots.
Mr. Anderson said that between pressure from retailers to deliver good deals and pressure from publishers to distribute too many titles too cheaply wholesalers are living in a non-profitable purgatory.
"We went from a profitable to an unprofitable business," Mr. Anderson said. "In order to recover our profitability we had two choices. We were not able to increase our gross margins, so we had to decrease our operating expenses."
This, he said, forced him to stop sending trucks to smaller retailers, like craft stores and out-of-the-way general stores.
That move aggravated smaller publishers who depend on every sale they could get. And in an attempt to bolster their bottom lines, Anderson and the News Group instituted programs that have fired up even more controversy among the small publishers. In 1999, Anderson instituted a two-tiered system to distribute magazines.
Anderson split its list of about 4,700 magazines -- into two parts. The top 1,700 titles, which represent about 97 percent of the company's sales, are handled through the company's network of nearly 50 full-scale distribution centers. The remaining titles, if they chose to stay with Anderson, would be remanded to less efficient facilities and charged additional handling fees.
And last November, the News Group also started a program that separated core and non-core titles. The 1,400 titles that provided it with 94 percent of its sales revenue continue to receive distribution as usual. The other 1,600 titles could still be distributed by News Group but would require additional handling charges.
Small publishers were angered by the plans. "They really started to discriminate against our smaller colleagues," John R. MacArthur Jr., the publisher of Harper's magazine, said.
Norman Jacobs, the president of the Century Publishing Company in Illinois, which publishes 10 small magazines like Cruise Travel, said that he canceled his contracts with Anderson, but recently renegotiated his agreement because there are so few wholesalers available with which to do business. Even after that, he said, it is just a "break-even" situation for his magazines on the Anderson racks.
But Mr. Anderson said his room for profit is exceedingly slim. Most publishers, like Time Inc., Conde Nast or Hearst Magazines have an integrated national distributor arm -- like Time Distribution Services or COMAG, the company shared by Hearst and Conde Nast. Those companies sell magazines to the wholesalers at what is often around a 35 percent discount. They are shipped at the publisher's cost to the wholesaler's distribution depot. The wholesaler pays the national distributor, who in turn pays the publisher. With a successful magazine like People, he said, he will only make 10 cents for every copy he handles -- even when the magazine is sold to the consumer for about $3.20. Even with a successful magazine like People, he still has to bear the cost of handling unsold 2.6 copies for each one sold.
Still, that is profitable. The problems arise when the same discount applies to poorer-selling magazines that eat up his resources and on which he only make 2 cents per copy sold.
"And that just don't work, hoss," he said, poised over a spread sheet in his office, a pencil tucked behind his ear.
A key issue is that large publishers do not agree that they ought to give bigger discounts to wholesalers. Richard Jacobsen, the president of Time Inc.'s retail sales and marketing, said that the solution lies elsewhere.
"Is it as simple as me giving him more margin?" he asked. "No. Is it about me trying to simplify the activities he has to perform better and at a lower cost, and we can do that together? Maybe. But whatever we do on the economic side has to be sustainable. It cannot be something that unravels again in two years."
Some publishers have considered hiring so-called "category managers," who would monitor how many copies of Fortune, for example, sell best in which Wal-Mart, and who would cultivate close relationships with wholesalers.
On his side, Mr. Anderson said he has tried other ways to get publishers to see the error of their ways. He sees all those extra copies that never get sold as a form of overblown institutional egomania.
"The publishers are scared," he said. "They see that guy printing this amount, and they figure, well, just in case, we ought to print as many. But what they do not realize is all that overprinting costs us in shipping and handling. And the magazines are just destroyed anyway."
His solution was to buy a La-Z-Boy recliner, and set it up in front of the Anderson shredder in Birmingham, where literally tons of magazines are shredded every day. "And I called publishers in New York and I said, 'Want to come down and watch as we destroy tens of thousands of tons of your magazines?' "
He paused. "Of course, none of them came," he said. "As I said, New York is far away."

HEADLINE: Beyond Tans and Tinsel;
A New Los Angeles Museum Show Seeks to Smash California Cliches

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 22

 BODY:
A surfboard from the forgettable 1964 movie "Ride the Wild Surf" rests in a corner of one gallery at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. Another gallery displays plaintive visions of Mexicans in California by 1930's muralists like Diego Rivera, Frida Kahlo and David Alfaro Siqueiros. A third shows harrowing photographs documenting the internment of Japanese-Americans during World War II.
Nearby are lavish impressionist-style paintings from the early 20th century of the breaking fog in Santa Barbara and the moonrise over San Diego Bay. Stark and emotional photographs by Dorothea Lange of Depression-era migrant mothers and factory workers are steps from a gallery displaying a 1998 Playboy magazine with "The Babes of Baywatch" on the cover. 
 The culture of California -- from the serious to the silly, from the dynamic and the adventurous to the bigoted and the violent -- is the subject of an enormous landmark exhibition that opened today at the museum. Called "Made in California: Art, Image and Identity, 1900-2000," the show is not only the largest in the museum's history but also perhaps its most provocative.
The exhibition offers what the museum calls a revisionist view of the state and its cultural legacy, a legacy that has traditionally centered on the raw and lavishly beautiful vistas in the north, coupled with the Southern California world of sunny beaches, beautiful bodies and the glamour and tawdriness of Hollywood. Six years in the planning, the show also encompasses the art and the issues of the state's growing Latino and Asian populations as well as the political and social dynamism that gave rise to various movements in Northern California, ranging from the Black Panthers and hippie culture to gay rights. The exhibition also includes some of the more corrosive elements of California history, including photographs of 1,000 Mexican families being forcibly removed from their community in 1959 to make way for a new stadium for the transplanted Brooklyn Dodgers.
"They're very brave to have taken on a more inclusive and expansive interpretation of California, and in that sense the show is remarkable," said Karin Higa, director of the curatorial and exhibitions department at the Japanese American National Museum in Los Angeles, at a private opening attended by artists and other professionals on Thursday night. "It's bound to come under criticism because the more inclusive they are, the more you realize what's missing from standard exhibitions and interpretations of California art and culture."
Ms. Higa said that the Asian-American experience in California, generally ignored in other exhibitions, had been integrated into this one.
Paul J. Karlstrom, a specialist in California who is regional director of the archives of American art at the Smithsonian Institution, said the show was bound to result in omissions and hurt feelings.
"There'll be artists who'll be disappointed," said Mr. Karlstrom, based at the Huntington Library in Pasadena. "That's inevitable." But he added that the museum's goal was all-inclusive.
"Instead of gathering a list of the 100 great hits in California art history, it's trying to seriously examine what distinguishes the art and culture of this state," he said.
Michael Dear, director of the Southern California Studies Center at the University of Southern California, said he walked into a gallery on the 60's in California and burst out laughing. "A lot of people were laughing," he said. "It was a vibrant display of beach culture, of the cars, all these things that comprised the 60's. There's everything there from high art to public art to stuff from the street, if you like."
What makes the show resonant, he said, is that it deals with the political, social and economic fabric of California as well as its art and culture.
"Made in California" includes more than 800 works of art -- paintings, sculpture, photographs, furniture and costumes -- and 400 documents, ranging from anti-Japanese propaganda posters from 1941 to a copy of the first paperback edition of Jack Kerouac's "On the Road" from 1958. Museum officials declined to discuss the cost of the project, which was underwritten by the S. Mark Taper Foundation.
The show is divided into five segments, each covering 20 years. For visitors the dates that the exhibition will be up are a bit confusing. The first four sections, covering 1900 to 1980, opened today. The final section, covering 1980 to 2000, will open on Nov. 12. Although the closing date for most of the show is Feb. 25, the first section, 1900 to 1920, will remain up through March 18.
Stephanie Barron, the museum's vice president for education and public programs and its senior curator of modern and contemporary art, acknowledged that the exhibition would probably stir debate.
"Everyone will come with the expectation of what the show could be and should be," said Ms. Barron, who organized it. "It's inevitable that we'll delight people at times and surprise them and confuse them and irritate them. But that's O.K. That's what an idea show is about."
As she spoke, she walked past a gallery displaying bathing outfits and zoot suits of the 1940's as well as the original Barbie doll. Not far away was David Hockney's classic canvas "The Splash," one of that British-born artist's wittier images (circa 1966) of lawns and swimming pools.
"There are two themes that seem to dominate the century in California," Ms. Barron said. "One is the dialogue with the land, the beautiful rolling hills and majestic landscapes, or urbanism and suburbia or the blight. The other is California's ongoing relationship with Asia and Latin America."
She pointed to the unusual mix of video monitors that show archival films of figures as diverse as Mario Savio, the leader of Berkeley's Free Speech movement, to former Gov. Ronald Reagan to hippies congregating in San Francisco. Visitors can also view scenes from film noir set in Los Angeles. And then there are paintings by artists like Ed Ruscha, Billy Al Bengston, Edward Kienholz and Judy Chicago that seem to embrace -- and perhaps mock -- Southern California culture.
One of her concerns, Ms. Barron said, was whether critics and the artistic community would accept a mix of high and low culture in a show in an established Los Angeles museum. "Everyone was prepared to put up examples of fashion," she said, "but it's a whole different thing to put a surfboard in there."
"It's going to be disturbing for some people," she added. "On the other hand, I'm sure people who will be attracted to the popular-culture aspect of it might have a moment, I hope, to look at fine art."
The idea developed in 1994 when Ms. Barron, together with Ilene Susan Fort, curator of American art, and Sheri Bernstein, the show's exhibition associate, met with other museum officials to create a millennium project that would deal with the culture and image of Southern California. Meetings with historians, writers, architects and artists led the museum to expand the exhibition.
The reason was simple: the San Francisco area dominated the artistic and social worlds of California in the early part of the century, and the social and political ferment there in the 60's and 70's influenced the state's -- as well as the nation's -- culture and politics.
"The idea was to explore the image of California but not just the one that is known," Ms. Fort said. She added: "We wanted to avoid the traditional boosterism promoted by the white culture and the white artists, especially in the early part of the century. We wanted to see other interpretations of California and how they differed from white myths."
The result is that some relatively unknown Asian, Latino and black artists and photographers are represented in the show, and some well-known Californians like Clyfford Still, Alson Skinner Clark, John Alton and Emerson Wolfler are not shown.
"This is a thematic show; it takes risks, and people may not understand why we put in certain works of art but leave out others," Ms. Fort said.
The show handles Hollywood culture as a glamour industry -- with photographs by George Hurrell of Norma Shearer and Joan Crawford, among others -- as well as a source of postwar political tensions, with newsreels of blacklisted writers appearing before Congress.
Developing the show thrust the museum into new territory because the program was not shaped by one or two people, but by more than a dozen curators.
Kevin Starr, a historian and State Librarian of California who served on one of the show's advisory panels, was an early opponent of focusing the show on Southern California.
"To me this exhibit is exhilarating," he said. "It challenges us to ask, 'Is there a California culturally?' " Mr. Starr said that the cliche that California was culturally barren was absurd. "The sheer range and variety of California is extraordinary, and that's what this show addresses too," he said. "It has the sixth largest economy in the world. The state, in many ways, is the distilled essence and conflicts of America itself. This show is trying to reassemble the imaginative visual materials of California into some coherence. And that's a big challenge and a big task."
What gives the show additional significance, he said, is that it tacitly underscores the power of Los Angeles and Southern California over the rest of the state and perhaps even the nation. "It bespeaks the maturity of Los Angeles and the dominance of Los Angeles in the cultural mosaic of California," Mr. Starr said. "This is using a Los Angeles-based show to define the entire culture of the state. This was traditionally done by the Bay area. This is the first time that Los Angeles has, in fact, taken the lead."
