HEADLINE: Time, AOL and Early Illusions

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
As the wedding day moves closer for America Online and Time Warner, it is worth asking whether this couple seems as right for each other as they did when the engagement was announced in January.
As in many engagements, the partners were seeking different things. AOL's motives seemed pragmatic while Time Warner's tended to be romantic. 
 AOL hoped to link up with a respectable blue-chip corporation that could help it settle down and get out of the fast lane. Time Warner, by contrast, hoped that its rich and debonair suitor would provide more excitement and the fashionable trappings of success that would impress Wall Street. While both may yet find what they seeking in this marriage, given the events of the last nine months, AOL's satisfaction seems more likely.
For one thing, the Internet may not be such a lucrative arena after all. America Online, which had made quite a bundle selling big advertising contracts to swashbuckling dot-coms flush with venture capital, is now realizing that many of those clients can be found lining up in front of bankruptcy court -- if they can be found at all.
And the plans for a broadband dream house, bringing America Online's Internet service and Time Warner's cable networks under one roof, may be impaired by surprisingly tough zoning rules imposed by federal antitrust officials.
Then there is the matter of dowry.
The AOL stock that Time Warner shareholders would receive was worth $110.62 for each Time Warner share when the deal was announced -- 70 percent more than the $64.75 at which Time Warner's stock was trading at the time. The AOL stock value to be exchanged has since fallen to $69.86 -- about 8 percent above the predeal price of a Time Warner share and hardly the sort of premium that a company with the pedigree of Time Warner might expect.
In other pairings, such as the Terra Networks acquisition of Lycos, a sharp drop in the buyer's stock has prompted an increase in the number of shares offered. But no provision for such renegotiation was included in the AOL-Time Warner prenuptial agreement. Indeed, merger experts say the contract is so tough that there is almost no way for either party to get out now, even if they wanted to.
Since the deal has received approval by both companies' shareholders and European regulators, what remains is clearance from the Federal Trade Commission and the Federal Communications Commission. The companies expect to receive these by the end of the year.
Gerald M. Levin, Time Warner's chairman and chief executive, insists that he is as committed to the merger as ever, in bull market and bear. And he said he did not regret the lack of a provision in the agreement that would adjust the ratio of 1.5 AOL shares for every Time Warner share to compensate for a drop in AOL's share price.
"Whether AOL's stock is $45 or $95, I stand by the exchange ratio," Mr. Levin said in a brief interview after Time Warner announced its earnings on Wednesday.
Indeed, for Mr. Levin, analysts say, the point of this deal was never simply to get the most money for Time Warner shareholders now. Rather, it was to use the combination with America Online as a catalyst in solving some of his toughest strategic and management problems. Of course, the deal promised a fast way to adapt the company's print and television assets for Internet use, something Time Warner had found frustratingly difficult despite years of trying. And even though Time Warner is more than triple AOL's size by revenue, AOL is still growing so quickly the combined company should be far zippier than Time Warner is alone.
More important in many ways, the far-reaching changes such a deal would presumably cause holds the promise of shaking up and integrating a company that was largely a federation of fiefs -- Time Warner's movie studio, the cable systems, the magazine business and so on.
Executives of both companies tried last week to show investors the potential for selling advertising to their existing clients by noting that of the 100 biggest advertisers on AOL, the top 100 in Time Inc. magazines and the top 100 on Turner cable networks, only four were on more than one list. Of course that may say as much about the lack of coordination at Time Warner as it describes an opportunity for the new company.
"There are a lot of reasons we didn't do it before, but those reasons have evaporated," Mr. Levin said of his company's previous inability to coordinate ad sales. At the merged company, he said, there will be a new operating committee of top division executives charged with finding ways for the divisions to work together better.
As for America Online and its chairman, Stephen M. Case, the deal was in many ways as conservative and defensive as it was bold to Mr. Levin. Mr. Case was worried that the balance of power on the Internet would shift from those that simply aggregated content created by others -- as AOL and Yahoo have done -- to the content creators like Time Warner. And Time Warner's cable systems would guarantee AOL a stake in the market for high-speed Internet connections.
But most important, the deal allowed Mr. Case to capitalize on the remarkable opportunity provided by the then-soaring stock market and use his rich stock to buy a top-tier company with solid assets on terms that might not be available again.
So more than nine months later, how well does the deal meet these various objectives, given the more hostile environment the companies now find themselves in?
The only negative surprise for AOL has been the unexpected regulatory scrutiny, which might impair its ability to profit from high-speed services using Time Warner's cable systems. European regulators have already forced Time Warner to pull back from a proposed combination of its Warner Music unit and the EMI Group of Britain.
The discussions in Washington are heated, but the worst case for AOL and Time Warner is a regulatory regimen that forces it to let competing Internet service providers use the combined company's cable systems on terms that are not quite to its liking. Analysts and executives of the two companies say such a requirement would hardly be serious enough to scuttle the deal or even significantly affect the profitability of the combined company.
Whether Time Warner can achieve a cultural transformation is unknowable and depends largely on how the executives of the two companies get along. So far there have been no unexpected resignations or other visible signs of discord.
The question that investors wrestled with last week, however, was how to evaluate the real potential of AOL's advertising business, given the lower market, especially in with dot-com companies.
Some analysts said the fears were overblown and a combined AOL-Time Warner would have a diversified base of advertisers and would weather a downturn better than smaller competitors.
"In the year after an election and the Olympics, it's no surprise that advertising growth would slow from 18 percent to 8 percent," said Chris Dixon of PaineWebber. "But 8 percent growth is still faster than the economy as a whole, and the big media companies like Time Warner, Disney and Viacom will get more than their fair share."
What is more, the dynamics of America Online's core Internet service business are far better in this environment than those of a purely advertising-based Internet company like Yahoo. To the surprise of many who had written off the AOL service as overpriced and a dinosaur, the company has been able to add subscribers and maintain its $22 monthly fee, even as its telecommunications costs fall 18 percent a year. Advertising has grown to one-third of AOL's revenue but it is still the gravy on top of the subscription fees.
What about the exchange ratio for the companies' stocks? That is essentially a zero-sum game, because it governs what portion of the company is allocated to Time Warner's shareholders and what portion to AOL's.
Whether he was lucky or smart, Mr. Case struck the deal with Time Warner at a time it would give him the most advantage. Indeed, AOL shareholders walk away owning 54 percent of the combined company.
 Consider a back-of-the envelope calculation to see how different the terms might be if the deal had been agreed to on Friday. If Time Warner's stock had performed as the average media-company stock has this year, it would have closed on Friday at $51.15. (In fact, it ended at $69.91.) AOL's shares, assuming they fell as much as the average Internet company, would be at $37.61. (They did close at $46.55.)
The question is if AOL were bidding today, what sort of premium it would have to pay. With its stock down, a 70 percent premium for Time Warner's shares may not be expected. If AOL paid a more typical 40 percent premium, that would be a price of $71.61 for each Time Warner share.
To reach a bid of that level, the company would then need to exchange 1.9 of its shares for each Time Warner share. With that deal, Time Warner shareholders would wind up in control, with 52 percent of the company.
Analysts who cover Time Warner say they do not see this gap as a black mark against Mr. Levin. At the existing exchange ratio, said Tom Wolzien of Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, the deal enhances the per-share cash flow of Time Warner stock.
But Mr. Wolzien has a much cruder way to reassure himself that the deal is not so bad. "Time Warner's stock is up this year," he said, "when almost every other media company is down."

HEADLINE: MEDIA;
Fear of Cutbacks Rattles Papers In Philadelphia

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER 

 BODY:
By almost any business measure, the Knight Ridder newspapers in Philadelphia would be deemed a success. Since 1995, profit margins at The Philadelphia Inquirer and The Philadelphia Daily News have more than doubled, reaching close to 19 percent after years of single-digit doldrums.
Good? Absolutely. Good enough? Not for long. For 2001, the target margin is 21 percent. And now there is talk about 5 percent budget cuts at the papers, if not more. Anxiety is as plentiful as oxygen in The Inquirer's newsroom. 
 The anxiety on North Broad Street is hardly unique in the industry. Publicly traded companies like Gannett, The New York Times, the Tribune Company, McClatchy and A. H. Belo all pay some attention to the Wall Street analysts whose judgments push their stock prices around.
Most big-city papers no longer have strong local rivals left to battle for advertising and circulation, so publishers and owners now see their competition more and more as the financial results posted by other large papers and chains across the country.
At the newspapers of Knight Ridder's rivals, profit margins are rising, analysts say, like skyscrapers in a boom town -- into the low 20's (at The Baltimore Sun), to 30 (at The Chicago Tribune). The Tribune Company, which owns those two newspapers, doesn't even have the highest profit margins. some Gannett newspapers have achieved margins in the mid-30-percent range, analysts say.
For the analysts who follow the newspaper industry, profit margins are the metric that is never ignored. By that measure, single-digit returns that Philadelphia Newspapers Inc., the parent of both papers, achieved in the mid-1990's made it "a laggard" and an "embarrassment," analysts said last week.
Rather than live in anyone's financial shadow, Knight Ridder executives felt they needed, if not parity, at least steady improvement in Philadelphia. But the broadsheet Inquirer and the smaller tabloid Daily News, since summer, have been caught between a local advertising downturn and a 14 percent uptick in newsprint prices, which are expected to rise by $18 million in 2001. Making 19 percent in 2000 will be hard. Making 21 percent in 2001 without budget cuts, probably impossible.
The Inquirer's journalists know the drill -- buyouts, cutbacks, retrenchment, defections by high-profile reporters and editors. They also know things are not as bad as in 1995, when a buyout cut 7 percent of the staff -- more than 200 jobs. This time, the buyout goal is a 3 percent reduction in staff, or about 100 people. Overall the budget cuts at both newspapers are likely to be 5 percent to 7 percent range.
Some of The Inquirer's rank-and-file journalists have a grudging understanding of the financial realities, and many say that the best of The Inquirer's journalism today is as good as it has ever been -- though a few dispute this point. But they still fear for the paper's 25-year tradition of politician-pounding, institution-busting journalism. This muckraking is the yardstick many of its journalists hold it to. How often, some reporters ask, can the place can go through these budget and staff shakedowns and still keep its journalistic ambitions intact?
"The scope of what's going on is not nearly as big as in 1995," said David Zucchino, an heir to the paper's prize-winning tradition (he won a Pulitzer prize in 1989 and was a finalist in 1985 and 1995) who continues to write or edit ambitious projects. On the other hand, some people in the newsroom are concluding that there will be no end to the cutbacks.
"Probably the worst thing about this," Mr. Zucchino said, "is that we hit a 19 percent profit margin, which seems to me fantastic, and it's not good enough."
Mr. Zucchino and other editors and reporters argue that this year's work -- like a wrenching series on the long-term health effects of a toxic waste fire -- shows The Inquirer has not lost a step. Those who disagree tend to remain anonymous.
But the new pressures are a reminder of how long it has been since The Inquirer enjoyed special cachet inside Knight-Ridder, getting a pass on some of the financial requirements imposed on its smaller cousins. The Philadelphia newspapers have traditionally contributed more revenue than any of the company's other 30 newspapers, generating close to 19 percent of the chain's total revenue.
Now, their operating profit margins are approaching those of other papers in the chain, like The San Jose Mercury News.
So of course Wall Street has taken notice. On Tuesday, when Knight Ridder executives talked to analysts about the company's third-quarter earnings, one of the first questions -- after a discussion of the prospects for Knight Ridders's online ventures -- was about profit margins.
Peter P. Appert of Deutsche Bank Alex. Brown, asked, "Are you confident of your ability to sustain newspaper margins" in the coming year?
P. Anthony Ridder, the company's chief executive, responded quickly: "Not only to sustain them. We're working to improve them."
The importance of margins, of course, is nothing new. But, said Michael Beebe, an analyst with Goldman, Sachs, revenue growth was easier to achieve in the industry in the 1970's and 1980's, when newspapers dominated local media markets.
Back when advertisers had fewer options, he said, circulation was reaching a historic peak, and newspaper advertising departments raised their rates at twice the rate of inflation. Newspaper executives, Mr. Beebe said, "did not have to worry a whole lot about their cost structure." Even when competition from catalogues, direct-mail, and inserts grew during those years, one morning newspaper after another -- The Inquirer among them -- found themselves in a monopoly position, as their afternoon competitors died. Then came the market crash of 1987, accelerating the death of major retail businesses and tougher competition from local television news programs. The newsprint price spike of the mid-1990's hit as the industry was finally shaking off its hangover from a wrenching recession.
Then the Internet came along.
Competition for investor favor grew keener. Not only could Wall Street choose between a dozen newspaper companies, investors' other options just kept increasing as initial public offerings multiplied, and old industries like telecommunications developed new dynamism. And from one industry to the next, companies whose stock prices lagged tended to become takeover targets.
"At the end of the day," Mr. Beebe said, "Tony Ridder is trying to manage a very, very delicate balance: between pleasing the public markets, which are fickle and demanding and difficult to please, and doing the right thing for the quality of his news."
"Sometimes you have to trade off economic benefit for journalism," he added. And sometimes, investors and analysts will demand better margins --- or migrate to those, like the Gannett Company, which consistently achieve such profit levels.
In Philadelphia, Bob Hall, the publisher of both The Inquirer (weekday circulation 405,000) and The Daily News (weekday circulation 161,000) has two options -- persuading Mr. Ridder to relax his proposed profit-margin goals, or finding a way to meet them. But he is working in a region whose economy has grown slowly in recent years, and has, like other markets, lost some major retail advertisers to bankruptcy. This year, after two or three years of strong performance in the high-margin help-wanted ads, The Inquirer's recruitment advertising began to dwindle.
That, combined with the decline in dot-com advertising, helped push down the newspapers' advertising revenues about $17 million below the goal of more than $560 million. Mr. Hall is putting into place a plan to offer advertisers options like fine-grained, targeted placements across his nine-county market or the ability to reach every home in the market, if they choose -- an approach called total market coverage. But his older, dependable revenue dwindled before he could tap this new source.
The advertising initiative was one of a variety of ways the newspapers have been rethinking their strategy. The Inquirer has focused on hyperlocal coverage.
In Southern New Jersey and Chester County the existing, zoned local news sections have been refined, pumped up with more high school sports and opinion pages, and heavily marketed as a "paper within a paper."
The effort has yielded circulation gains. How about the journalism? Robert J. Rosenthal, the editor, said: "There are fine stories in there. It's not schlock."
The downside is heavy production costs, which raise the marginal cost of every new subscription gained. That has made some of The Inquirer's business executives wary of expanding the initiative to other regions, like Montgomery County. The final decision belongs to Mr. Hall. He will not tip his hand but he speaks of the "paper within a paper" initiative in bullish terms.
That may come as a relief to some newsroom editors, who are frustrated with the new hesitation by some of their counterparts on the business side. They were once skeptical of the initiative, and some senior reporters did not enjoy reliving their youths at suburban zoning meetings. But with the project paying off in circulation gains, more editors supported it. So now they find it disconcerting to see its further expansion called into question.
Lots of things are being called into question, and not just for economic reasons. In January, well before the revenue leached away, Mr. Rosenthal launched a group of high-ranking editors on a project to examine how the paper could use its journalists better. "These were not budget-driven meetings," Mr. Rosenthal said. "We talked a lot about the reader and his time demands."
As a result, the entire Sunday newspaper is being rethought, Mr. Rosenthal said, with an eye to consolidating a number of entertainment and other features, along with the television listings, into the Sunday magazine. The magazine, recently a persistent money-loser, would expand to 70 to 80 pages, "with some of our best Sunday content," Mr. Rosenthal said.
As those options were being discussed, the budget troubles hit. After the revenue shortfall and the challenge of meeting the 2001 goal became clear, Mr. Hall this month announced a buyout proposal.
Several Inquirer editors said the fiscal stringency provides a useful spur in the effort to set priorities. But they could not resist asking why it is being imposed after Knight Ridder has reported 11 straight quarters of double-digit earnings growth. And some journalists are nervous about the future.
Craig McCoy, a reporter, said, "There's been a lineage, a tradition, of real quality journalism." What will happen, he wondered, if the news executives, like Mr. Rosenthal, who come out of that tradition, become defeated by the push for financial improvement. My biggest worry," he said, is that this demand for return would lead someday to a management team here" that would massively cut back on the editorial product."
But Mr. Rosenthal, the editor, said that such worries, while understandable, were unfounded. Whatever the financial load is he added, "I'm going to do my damndest to make sure we can carry it" while keeping The Inquirer's brand of journalism intact.

HEADLINE: Mitchell Sviridoff, 81, Dies; Renewal Chief

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
Mitchell Sviridoff, a national leader in urban social policy and philanthropy who played an important role over three decades in developing strategies for lifting people out of poverty and reviving decaying neighborhoods, died early Saturday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 81.
The cause of death was kidney failure, his family said. 
 Mr. Sviridoff, known as Mike, had several careers. He was an assembly plant worker, a labor organizer and the architect and administrator of antipoverty programs, both in his native New Haven and later in New York. He was a Ford Foundation official and a professor of urban policy at the New School.
His most important contribution was in the field of community development.
An early and enthusiastic proponent of grass-roots organizations as the engine for rebuilding poor neighborhoods in places like Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, Mr. Sviridoff persuaded foundations, government agencies and corporations to recognize such groups and provide them with millions of dollars.
He was the first president of the Local Initiatives Support Corporation, an organization that pools technical and financial resources to help so-called community development corporations create jobs and build housing for low-income residents.
Unlike many champions of the poor, Mr. Sviridoff was a pragmatist without a political agenda, a trait that enhanced his effectiveness in corporate boardrooms.
"He always wanted to figure out the most practical and sensible way of getting something done," said Carl Weisbrod, the president of the Alliance for Downtown New York, a business group, and a regular in the weekly poker games that Mr. Sviridoff used to hold in his apartment.
Mr. Sviridoff was born in New Haven on Nov. 4, 1918. After graduating from Hillhouse High School, he went to a vocational school. At 19, he took a job at an aircraft parts plant in Stratford, Conn. That led to a succession of posts in the labor movement, and he eventually became president of the state A.F.L.-C.I.O. Despite his lack of a college education, he was appointed president of the New Haven Board of Education.
In the early 1960's, Mr. Sviridoff worked for a State Department program that administered aid to Latin America. But what people were calling the crisis of the cities had captured the public spotlight, and Richard C. Lee, the mayor of New Haven, summoned Mr. Sviridoff home.
Two years before President Lyndon B. Johnson declared the war on poverty, Mr. Sviridoff became the executive director of Community Progress Inc., an antipoverty program in New Haven that was set up with a Ford Foundation grant. In its first 30 months, the program found employment for 1,500 people and became a national model.
Rather than trying to supplant community groups, Mr. Sviridoff tried to help them achieve their goals. He and his staff were so adept at writing grant proposals to federal agencies that people in New York began referring to New Haven's "magic at getting money." In 1965, the program received one-third as much federal antipoverty money as New York, a city 50 times its size.
By then, New York had a mayor, John V. Lindsay, who wanted his antipoverty efforts to win similar notice. Mr. Sviridoff was recruited to study a hodgepodge of programs dealing with welfare, employment training, youth programs and the poor and consolidate them in the Human Resources Administration. In 1966, Mr. Sviridoff became the agency's first administrator.
It did not take him long to discover that New York was not New Haven, and that its problems were too big to be solved by the neat organizational charts and other strategies that had worked so well in Connecticut. His staff rebelled. Nearly 200 frustrated employees protested in a memo to Mr. Lindsay that the agency was so chaotic and the working conditions so intolerable that the human resources agency should be disbanded.
Only nine months after assuming his new duties with the city, the Ford Foundation offered Mr. Sviridoff a position as a vice president for national affairs, and, much to the chagrin of the mayor, he accepted it.
In later years, some people said Mr. Sviridoff had repaid the city when Stanley Brezenoff, who had been Mr. Sviridoff's assistant at the Ford Foundation and was one of many New Yorkers in public service who regarded him as their mentor, became the city's human resources administrator.
"I think that ought to settle the score once and for all," Mr. Sviridoff said when his protege's appointment was announced in 1979. "I think that the city is getting the better part of the bargain."
By that time, Mr. Sviridoff had become disenchanted with the unwieldy structure he had helped design, saying that such efforts were doomed because of turf battles, bureaucratic inertia and other obstacles.
At the Ford Foundation, Mr. Sviridoff helped nurture a wide variety of programs to address the problems of the cities, some of which were later spun off, including the Vera Institute for Criminal Justice; the Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation, a social policy research organization; and the Police Foundation.
"He was extraordinarily supportive of innovative work,"said Herbert Sturz, the founding director of the Vera Institute.
One innovation was the Local Initiatives Support Corporation. When a Ford trustee asked Mr. Sviridoff what he would do with $25 million to spend on declining cities, he answered by recalling a suggestion by Franklin A. Thomas, then a Ford trustee (and later its president). Mr. Thomas, who had run the Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation, had proposed identifying 100 communities with promising self-help groups and getting money to them.
In a year, the program was up and running. In 1980, Mr. Sviridoff resigned from Ford to work full time for the local initiatives group.
"And the results speak for themselves," Mr. Sviridoff wrote recently. "Community development, something that in the 1970's and early 80's was really just a movement, is something we now quite properly call an industry."
During the last two decades, corporation officials say, they have raised $3 billion, money that has been used to produce more than 100,000 units of housing, more than 10 million square feet of commercial and industrial space, and projects like a Pathmark store in East Harlem, the neighborhood's first full-size supermarket in three decades.
In 1985, Mr. Sviridoff resigned from the Local Initiatives Support Corporation to teach at the New School for Social Research, where he was director of the Kaplan Center for New York City Affairs at the Milano Graduate School. He was also founder of the school's Community Development Research Center.
He had a steady stream of guests at the vacation home on Martha's Vineyard that he shared with his wife, Doris, whom he married in 1940. Until his recent illness, he swam and played tennis almost daily and often cooked for his friends.
The couple had two daughters, Karen Segal of Los Angeles, and Michele of New York, one grandchild and one great-grandchild.
At a 1985 party to celebrate his years of public service, Mr. Sviridoff recited lines from a poem by William Butler Yeats:
 God guard me from those thoughts
men think in the mind alone.
He that sings a lasting song
thinks in a marrow bone.
He said the lines expressed his own approach to helping people.
"That is the way I function," he told an interviewer after the party. "I do things that do not seem logical at the beginning and sometimes fail. But when they succeed, they tend to be lasting songs."

HEADLINE: Chinese Official Beats Albright to North Korea

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Oct. 22

 BODY:
China's defense minister flew to North Korea today for "friendly talks," just hours before Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright was due to arrive in the North Korean capital.
Minister Chi Haotian was accompanied by senior military officials and will spend five days in North Korea, according to the New China News Agency. 
 The visit had been long planned -- its official purpose is to commemorate the 50th anniversary of China's entry into the Korean War, which falls on Wednesday. But the sudden departure this weekend was unexpected, perhaps related to Dr. Albright's impending arrival.
The visit is "intended to improve the existing friendship and cooperation between the two countries," the agency said.
In recent months, China's leaders have served as quiet mentors to Kim Jong Il, the formerly reclusive North Korean leader, as he has sought to expand his foreign ties and perhaps loosen his country's rigid planned economy.
Outwardly, the Chinese have been extremely supportive of his efforts to establish diplomatic ties with Western nations, including the United States. "China welcomes any progress in the relations between the Democratic People's Republic of China and the U.S.," Zhu Bangzao, a foreign ministry spokesman, said last week.
But some Chinese military analysts have worried about the possibility that better relations between North and South Korea -- perhaps eventual reunification -- could give American troops stationed in South Korea free access to the Chinese border.
Since the collapse of the former Soviet Union, China has been the only major power to maintain friendly ties with Pyongyang. And despite a long history of "socialist brotherhood," the Chinese leaders in recent years have clearly grown weary of supporting a government that could not support itself.
Foreign health experts say that more than 1.5 million people have died as a result of food shortages in North Korea over the past six years. Many of the country's factories are at a standstill because it has little gas or electricity.
China is a major donor of coal and corn to North Korea. And, in the past few years, more than 100,000 North Koreans have sneaked over the common border into China in search of work, food and money, putting a strain on the local Chinese economy.

LENGTH: 1371 words

HEADLINE: Buffalo, Often Butt of Jokes, Is Serious Senate Battleground

BYLINE: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD 

DATELINE: BUFFALO, Oct. 22

 BODY:
The Queen City is finally being treated like one, at least until Nov. 7.
The jokes -- about snow in June, the struggling Buffalo Bills, dat accent -- have been put in a lockbox. New York's candidates for the United States Senate have lavished attention and resources on this city and its suburbs, mindful of recent statewide campaigns that have established Buffalo and surrounding Erie County as an electoral touchstone. 
 Political analysts say that it would be very difficult for a Democrat to win statewide office without winning Erie, to compensate for the bedrock support Republicans can count on in the rest of upstate. So both candidates are trying to capitalize on the shifting, unpredictable political dynamics here, a classic bellwether "swing" area that, were it not for New York City, would be the dominant region of the state.
Although Democrats hold a 132,000-person margin over Republicans in voter registration, the county is filled with a sizable number of what were once called Reagan Democrats, working-class Catholics of Polish, Irish and Italian ancestry without a firm allegiance to either party.
Ed Kolenko is a registered Democrat who twice voted for Gov. George E. Pataki and is now leaning toward Hillary Rodham Clinton. "I trust what Hillary's saying more than Lazio," he said.
Peter Marini, a Democrat who has voted for Mr. Pataki, President Clinton, former Senator Bob Dole and last year, for Charles E. Schumer, a Democrat, for senator, said he now leaned to Representative Rick A. Lazio. "I'm tired of the Clintons," he said. "Hillary is smart and I may go with her, but there is something about Lazio and new blood that I like."
With a laugh, he added, "And Lazio is Italian like me."
He was only half joking. Ethnic politics do play a big role here.
That is why Mr. Schumer two years ago brought his own Brooklyn sausage to a light-hearted taste test at the renowned Polish festival in Cheektowaga, a working-class Buffalo suburb that gets nearly as much attention from candidates as Buffalo.
In an interview on Friday, Mr. Schumer, who won Erie County and the election in 1998, called his appearance at the festival a "breakthrough" event in that "it really made a splash."
"It said to voters: 'He gets it. He understands what is going on here.' You know if you do well in Erie you may not win upstate, but you certainly come close," Mr. Schumer said.
Mrs. Clinton, following that strategy, brought a Democratic Irish stalwart, Senator Edward M. Kennedy, to a rally here the other night. "The Kennedys are gods up here in the Irish community," said Gerald M. Goldhaber, a professor at the State University at Buffalo who has conducted polling for Democratic and Republican candidates and is the president of Goldhaber Research Associates.
And Mr. Lazio is suddenly invoking his Italian heritage -- telling stories about his grandmother Rose's journey here decades ago -- at stop after stop, not just here but also in other Italian enclaves. (His schedule today included "Rigatoni With Rick" events in Rochester and Rome, N.Y.)
Recently, he posed for pictures with Bishop Henry J. Mansell of the Diocese of Buffalo, and with his bus blaring the Italian folk hit "Lazy Mary," dined at a "Rigatoni With Rick" event here the other week that his campaign claims drew more Democrats than Republicans.
He attended Mass this morning in nearby Sloan at St. Andrew Roman Catholic Church, which has a predominantly Polish congregation, and met with the editorial board of the Am-Pol Eagle, a newspaper geared toward Polish-American readers.
Both camps say that by Election Day they will have visited Erie County more than two dozen times since May, when they received their parties' nominations.
Both campaigns have saturated the airwaves here with commercials -- a recent Lazio ad included people wearing Buffalo Bills caps -- and say their internal polling shows they are running strongly here.
An independent poll of 400 likely voters in Erie and Niagara Counties, conducted by Goldhaber Research Associates, suggested that Mrs. Clinton was leading 50 to 36 percent, with 13 percent undecided. The poll, conducted Oct. 17 to 19 and released on Friday, had a margin of sampling error of 4.9 percentage points.
Some high-profile victories in recent years have cheered Republicans and, Mr. Goldhaber said, buttressed the theory that "people here don't vote party line, they vote economic issues."
In 1994, Mr. Pataki won Erie County by nearly 40,000 votes over Mario M. Cuomo, the first Republican gubernatorial victory since Nelson A. Rockefeller's. Mr. Pataki also won in 1998.
Republicans in the last decade have taken control of three prominent countywide offices -- county executive, comptroller and sheriff -- although Democrats have maintained a majority in the 17-seat County Legislature since 1982.
The victory of Joel A. Giambra as county executive last year in particular bears closer inspection.
Mr. Giambra, the former Buffalo comptroller, who had been a Democrat until the year before, when he switched parties, ousted a three-term Democrat, Dennis T. Gorski, by 54 to 43 percent.
He did so largely by a calculated appeal to ethnic Democrats, particularly Italians, who had flocked to unions and to the Democratic Party when Buffalo was a manufacturing powerhouse, but who lost their party allegiance as the steel and other industries went bust.
Mr. Giambra's television advertising stressed his concern over the economy, with spots depicting emotional farewells to young people forced to move out of the area for jobs. He deplored what he calls "the runway of tears" at the Buffalo airport, in keeping with his campaign slogan, "keep our kids."
"The Reagan Democrats were concerned about pocketbook issues," said the Erie County Republican chairman, Robert E. Davis, "and we were able to address pocketbook issues that Democrats recognized."
Mrs. Clinton, like Mr. Schumer, has seized on the economy as an issue here, unveiling a plan in February aimed at bringing relief to the area, and knocking Mr. Lazio at every turn for his more optimistic outlook on things. Her campaign has used a Buffalo News editorial to buttress commercials that said Mr. Lazio was "orbiting another planet" for his views on the economy, though Mr. Lazio has said his views have been misconstrued to suggest that he did not believe economic aid was needed.
"The issues piece is vital, here and the issue is the economy," said Mrs. Clinton's campaign manager, Bill de Blasio. "It's astounding he hasn't changed his tune."
Mr. Davis, who helps to coordinate Mr. Lazio's campaigning in Erie County, said: "The issue has been so spun by the Clinton folks that we need to be a little bit more aggressive on these things. Lazio has had to spend more time defining what his plan is. Frankly, it's similar to 1994. It's not brain surgery here. Cut taxes and create jobs. We have direct mail pieces that address that. We need to build on that."
Asked if Mr. Lazio had enough time left to persuade people of his concern for the economy, Mr. Davis replied, "We don't have a choice, do we?"
Such sentiments arose the other night at a bar Mr. Lazio visited to watch the first game of the World Series. Rising property taxes have irritated many people to the point that they are itching for someone -- if not the mayor, then perhaps the United States senator -- to do something.
"Property taxes have to be lower so small businesses can come in here," said David W. Gacioch, 34, an independent who owns a property management company and is supporting Mr. Lazio.
Others had chosen their candidate based on other issues, though the fluid nature of their party affiliation was evident.
John Maney, 60, who worked as a police officer and correction officer in New York City before retiring, said he considered himself an "independent" registered Democrat. He had intended to vote for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, whose place Mr. Lazio took when the mayor dropped out for cancer treatment. Now, Mr. Maney favors Mrs. Clinton.
"I would've preferred Giuliani," he said. "I liked what he did in New York City. No one really knows Lazio, he's from the wrong end of the state for me now."
